div.p:
A Treatie of the RICKETS: Being a Diea common to CHILDREN. Wherin (among many other things) is hewed,
1. The Eence
2. The Caues
3. The Signs
4. The Remedies of the Diea.
Publihed in Latin by Francis Glion, George Bate, And, Ahauerus Regemorter; Doctors in Phyick, and Fellows of the Colledg of Phyitians at London.
Tranlated into Englih by Phil. Armin.
LONDON: Printed by Peter Cole, at the ign of the Printing-Pres in Cornhil, near the Royal Exchange. 1651.

div.head: The Preface to the Reader.
div.p:
BEfore the pace of five years, we have mutually communicated by written Papers omthing concerning this Affect in privat meetings (which om of us Phyitians ue omtimes to have for Exercie-ake in the works of Art) When the things had opened a way in ome ort to the deeper enquiry and earch after the condition and cure of this Diea; We thought it might prove a very uccesful undertaking to recal thoe Papers once again to a Review; and (thoe things being called out which might be bet accommodated to this ue) to prepare a perfect Tractate of this Diea. That Care by common uffrage was entruted to Dr Glion, Dr Bate, and Dr Regemorter, who purpoed at firt to divide this buines among themelvs according to the parts of the future Tractate, and to aign to each one his proper task. But when Dr Glion in the judgment of the ret had accuratly interweaved his part (which comprehended the finding out of the Eence of this Diea) and in that had propounded many things different from the common Opinion of Phyitians (though perhaps the les different from the truth) we altered our Reolution, and committed the firt Stuff of the whol Work to be woven
by him alone, let at length the parts hould arie deformed, mihapen and heterogeneous to themelvs. He accepted the offer, but with this condition, that whilt he was employed in beautifying and adorning this part, the other two hould often hold conultation with him, and confer unto the Wouf their Covenanants of free commerce by their own obervations concerning this Affect, and that thoe things which hould be delineated and haped by his labor and tudy, hould preently undergo the examination and judgment of the ret, as if they had been fahioned by their hands. And o at the length we have brought this Work (uch as it is) to perfection, and have offered it to the publick view, being by no means moved therunto by an itch of writing (which is the Epidemical ill cutom of this age) but by this Conideration only, That becau we are not born for our elvs, we might make thee (uch as they are) common, which in om meaure may advance the health of Infancy and tender age (in which for the preent a great part of Mankind, but for the future all Mankind is comprehended) and likewie propagate an Encrea unto Learning: with this hope alo, That by this Example we may invite the Wits of other mot learned men to make inquiition into the Eences of Dieaes and their Caues, and to examin thee our Labors that poterity may enjoy them yet more perfect. But the obcure Eence of this Diea, and this our daring to tread in unbeaten paths (were we ilent) might obtain a pardon, and modetly chalenge a candid interpretation for all defects, lapes, and errors in thee our Endeavors. Finally, expect no flahes of Rhetorick and Courtly-Language;
Nobis non licet ee tam dicertis,
Muas qui colimus everiores.

And indeed the condition of the matter forbids all uch Painting; in uch a manner,
Ornari res ipa negat, contenta doceri.
Farewel (kind Reader) and perue them as we dedicate them, that is, with an ingenious and candid mind.

div.p: Cum multis aliis—

div.head: CHAP. I. The Antiquity and firt Origine of this Dieae, the Name of it, and the Derivation of the Name.
div.p:
THAT ome new Dieaes altogether unknown to the Ancients, have, for ome Ages lately pat invaded divers parts of Europe, is a known & undoubted truth (whether we attribute it to the viciitude of things, or impute it to the Sins and Impieties of men, and their corrupt manners) as the French-pox, the Scurvy, the A mot loathome and horrible Dieae in the Hair, unbeard of in former times, bred by modern luxury and exces: It eizeth pecially upon Women; and by reaon of a vicous venimous humour, glues together (as it were) the hair of the head with a prodigious ugly folding & entanglement: omtimes taking the form of a great Snake, ometimes of many little erpents: full of natines, vermine, and noyome mel: And that which is mot to be admired, and never eye aw before, pricked with a needle, they yeeld bloody drops. And at the firt preading of this dreadful Dieae in Poland, all that cut off this horrible and nakie hair, lot their eyes, or the humor falling down upon other part of the body, tortured them extreamly It began firt, not many years ago, in Poland: It is now entered into many parts of Germany H Saxo Profeor of Phyick in Padua. Plica, and the like; in which number this very affect we are now about to handle may be jutly Regitred. For if we examin al the dieaes of Infants & children decribed either by the Ancients or Modern Writers in their Books of the Dieaes of Infants, we hall meet with none which with a ufficient
exactnes doth delineate the condition and Idea of this evil. For although it may eem to hold a correpondence, or to have ome affinity with a chronical Feaver, a Conumption, the extenuation or leannee of Infants, and the A Dieae in the head, coming fro¯ Rhewm.Hydrocephalos; yet to peak truth it is an affect evidently different from them in the Species. For you may oberve many to be vehemently afflicted with this Malady without any Feaverihditemper, or any caue of uch upition: in like maner although a Conumption doth freque¯tly upervene upon this Dieae before the diolution of the Patient, yet is it eldome een to accompany the firt invaion thereof, as for the meagernes or leannes, although ome parts are perpetually oberved in
this affect to be made lean, yet this doth not happen in all alike, as in a right and true leannes, but you may perceave the parts about the head and face to be in a thriving condition as to outward appearance, and well complexioned, even to the lat day of life. Finally, The Hydrocephalus is very frequently complicated with this affect, yet we have diected ome whoe Brain hath been ufficiently firme, and not over-moitned with this uperfluous humour. Some have conjectured that this Dieae is an imp or fruit of the French-pox or Scurvy, decending from the viciated Bodies of the Parents upon the Children: For we deny not but the Parents, being infected with the Scurvy or the venerous Pox, may propagate and bring forth an Iue, not only affected with that Pox & Scurvy, but likewie infected with this evil, and this even hath alo faln under Obervation: yet for the mot part this Dieae in the propriety of its Eence, hath neither affinity nor familiarity with thoe affects, and beides it requireth a different progres of cure; we have ometimes likewie oberved a trumatical and welling Malady to be complicated with this; but we have alo many times beheld this to be well ditinguihed from that, and that from this.

But why do we dwel o long upon this inquiition? eing that he, who wil accurately contemplate the igns of this affect, as in their due places they hal be propounded, may mot eaily perwade himelf, That this is abolutly a new Dieae, and never decribed by any of the Ancient or Modern Writers in their practical Books which are extant at this day, of the Dieaes of Infants.

But this Dieae became firt known (as neer as
we could gather from the Relation of others after a edulous enquiry) about thirty years ince in the Counties of Doret and Someret, lying in the wetern part of England; ince which time the obervation of it hath been derived unto other places, as London, Oxford, Cambridge, and almot all the Southern and Wetern parts of the Kingdom: in the Nothern Counties this affect is very rarely een, and carcely yet made known among the Vulgar ort of people.
The mot receaved and ordinary Name of this Dieae is, The RICKETS: But who baptiz'd it, and upon what occaion, or for what reaon, or whether by chance or advice it was o named, is very uncertain
However it obtained that Name, yet in o great a variety of places through which it hath ranged, it hath not to this day been known by any other Denomination.

But it is an accident well worth our admiration, That this Dieae being new, and not long ago nameles, at leat not known by this Name, neither preading o much in remote as in adjacent places, yet no man hitherto could be found out, who knew, or could hew, either the firt Author of the Name, or the Patient to whom the appellation of the Dieae was firt accommodated, or the peculier place where it was don, or the maner how it cam to be dipered among the common people: for the inhabitants having gotten a Name for the Dieae, receave it with acquiecence as a thing done with diligence and deliberation, and are not at all further olicitous either about the Name, or the Author of the Name.

But becaue they which are expert in the Greek & Latin tongues, may peradventure expect a Name from us, wherof ome kind of Reaon maybe given, we have made fit together divers Names to this Dieae, yet we conceave it omewhat unneceary to make a particular rehearal of them in this place: Nevertheles it may perhaps be proper and profitable to commemorate the Rules which we propounded to our elves in the deignation of the Name: The Firt therefore was, That the Name hould comprehend ome notable condition of the Dieae. The Second was, That it hould be ufficiently ditinct from the Names of other Dieaes and Symptoms. The Third was, That it hould be ufficiently familiar, eaie of pronounciation, acco¯modated to the Memory, of no undecent length, and not tudiouly, and laboriouly compounded.

Whilet we bend our employments to the atifaction of thee Rules, One of us by chance fell upon a Name which was complacenceous to himelf, and afterwards pleaing to the ret; now this was < in non-Latin alphabet > . or indeed < in non-Latin alphabet > (for that termination is not altogether abhorrent from the common Gender) the Spinal Dieae, alo < in non-Latin alphabet > , the dieae of the Spine of the Back: For the Spine of the Back, is the firt and principal among the parts affected in this evil. Then no other Malady or Symptom did by the prerogative of time vindicate this appellation from it; beides the Name is familiar and eaie. And finally, The Englih Name Rickets, receaved with o great a conent of the people, doth by this Name eem to be excued, yea, jutified from Barbarim. For without any
wracking or convulion of the word, the name Rickets may be readily deduced from the Greek word Rachitis, or Rachites; provided, That we will but allow that conideration of change, which in vulgar pronounciation uually happeneth to words tranplanted from one Language to another.

Object. You will ay, That they which impoed firt the Englih name Rickets, were peradventure altogether unskilful in, and ignorant of the Greek tongue, or that they never thought of the Greek word Rachites, at leat undertood not that the Spine of the Back was the principal among thoe parts which were firt affected in this Dieae?

Anwer. We Anwer, It concerns not us whether they were ignorant of, or thought not upon the Greek word, or whether they did not undertand the principal part that was firt affected; yet are the things freely aerted. For we knew many at that time when the Dieae did firt pring up, and the Name was impoed, indeed learned men and skilful in the Greek tongue, to have their Reidence in thoe places, to whom it was not perhaps any difficulty to oberve that conpicuous debility of the Spine in this affect, and thereupon they might aign this Name unto it; although tis very poible, yea probable, That the common people by the error of pronounciation might omewhat pervert the Name o given, and expree it, as to this day they retain it by the word Rickets. But whether it were, or were not o, we are not at al olicitous. If the matter were o, the impoed Name will (as is manifet) be altogether congruous, and perhaps alo at the lat will mot fitly correpond with it. For uppoe you
hould fall upon ome Name, received not o much by choice as chance, yet o fit, that a more comodious Name could carce be devied by councel and deliberation, nor one more cononant to Reaon; in uch a Cae, What would you do? Would you extirpate and banih the receaved word, to introduce one that was new and nothing better? This practice would uurp upon the priviledge of Converation, and be injurous to the cutome of Speaking: Words contract a value by their ue, and ought not to be denizen'd with rahnes, or innovated by timerity: Or would you not rather confirm the Name receaved, yet as a new one, and from that time to be deduced from a new Origine: for this would be at the leat like a choen Science inoculated upon a new tock, which by reaon of the affinity with the Root, would without any difficulty receave trength and nourihment: Or if this pleae you not, uppoe if you pleae, That we now newly devied the Englih name of this Dieae, and deduce it from the Greek word Rachites: the Englih word reulting from hence would be the Rachites: and how little is the difference between that and the ordinary word Rickets? Certainly o little, That the vulgar pronounciation is not wont to be greatly olicitous about o mal a difference: But we trifle too much in taying o long upon thee trifles. Let the Greek Name therfore of the Dieae be nóos Rachitis, or Rachites (if the word may be allowed to be of the common Gender) or tes Rácheos; in Latin Morbus Spinali • , vel Spine Dori: and by coyning a Latin Subtantive out of the greek Adjective Rachitis—idis let the ordinary Englih name Rickets be retained, or in tead of it, to gratifie more curious ears, you may
ubtitute the Rachites. And thus much, if not too much, of the Name.

div.head: CHAP. II. Anotomical Obervations collected from the Diection and Inpection of Bodies ubdued and killed by this Dieae.
div.p:
BEfore we attempt an enquiry into the Nature and Caues of this Dieae, we hold it convenient to premie ome few certain and undoubted things, as being obvious to the Senes, which both demontrate the real exitence of this Dieae, and may alo be cat for a foundation, whereon to build the Supertructure of our judgment & opinion concerning this new Dieae. For we would not have any man to imagine that we here treat of ome Fictitious & Imaginary Evil, much les to expect that our Opinion hould be credulouly embraced without examination. But this we rather aim at, That the matter of our Dicoure to all poibility may be known and preconceived in the very entrance, that we may confirm thoe things which we hall propoe, by thoe things that are obvious to the Senes, as occaion hall require; and that the Reader being intructed in thee, may become a competent judge of our Reaons, and with the more facility be able to interpoe his judgment concerning each of them. We attet therfore
that many of us have been preent at everal Diections of Bodies which have been eparated by this Dieae, and that we will in this Chapter briefly and faithfully declare thoe things which we have hitherto Oberved by long experience and frequent Diections, namely, Thoe things which we have een with our eyes, and have handled with our hands.

In the mean time Two things are here to be premonihed: The former is, That the Reader carry in his memory, That the dead Bodies which we opened were mot vehemently afflicted with this dieae whilet they were animated, for they are uppoed for the mot part to have yeelded to the very magnitude of the Dieae, and therefore he mut not expect that magnitude of the Affect or Symptoms which we here decribe, in other Bodies yet living or newly beieged. For every Dieae is moved to a Conitence, and then alo Nature being oppreed and unable to maintain the conflict groweth wore and wore. The latter is that the Reader take notice, That almot all Dieaes in procee of time, do unite unto themelves other affects of a different kind, and therefore that chronical Dieaes are for the mot part complicated before death: Let him not therfore imagine that every preternatural thing that is found in dead Bodies, though detroyed by this affect, mut of neceity belong to this evil; for perhaps it may rather have reference to ome other Diea • e upervenient upon this before death, then to this very Malady: And the truth is, Anatomits through inadvertency, and want of due regard to this Caution, have fouly ered in their Obervations, whilet they acribe thoe things which concern another
Dieae, to another wherewith it was complicated before the diolution. The bet prevention therefore or rectification of this error is, Not to make a rah judgment from the inpection of one or two bodies, but firt by a reiterated and edulous experiment, to be able to ditinguih what things perpetually occur, what for the mot part, what frequently, and what but eldome, in the diected bodies that have perihed of the ame Dieae: for you mut know, That whatoever is not perpetually conpicuous in the opened Bodies diolved by the ame Dieae, cannot appertain to the intimate and chief Eence of it: for neither the Dieae it elf can have an exitence being eparated from its Eence, nor the Eence being eparated from the Dieae. But enough of thee things; let us now proceed to the Obervations themelves.

p.hi: Thee our Anatomical Obervations are ditinguihed into thoe which do extrinecally occur, the Body being not yet opened, and thoe which preent themelves only upon the Diection of the Body.

list.label: I. Thee of the former kind are they which are outwardly viible upon the firt appearance of the naked dead Body.

list.item:
1 An irregularity, or diproportion of the parts; namely, The Head bigger then ordinary, and the Face fat and in good contitution in repect of the other parts. And this indeed hath appeared in al thoe whom hitherto we have beheld to perih by this affect,
one only excepted, who together with this Dieae had uppurated Lungs, and was pined and disfugured with the Phyick. Yet he alo throughout the whole progree of the Dieae, was full faced, and had his head omewhat big; but for about fourteen dayes before he Deceaed, on a udden all the flehy parts about his head conumed away, and his face was like the picture of Hippocrates, not without the jut wonder of all thoe who beheld o udden a change.

2 The external members, and the mucles of the whole Body were lender and extenuated, as if they had been wated with an Atrophy, or a Conumption. This (for o much as we know) is perpetually oberved in thoe that die of this Dieae.
3 The whole Skin, both the true, and alo the flehy and fattih Membrane, appeareth lank and hanging, and looe like a Glove, o that you would think it would contain a far greater quantity of fleh.

4 About the joynts, epecially in the wrets and ankles certain wellings are conpicuous, which if they be opened, not in the flehy or membranous parts, but in the very ends of the bones, you may perceave them to be rooted in their appendances; and if you will file away thoe prominencies of the bones, you will eaily perceive them to be of the ame imilary ubtance with the other parts of the bones.

5 The articles or joynts, and the habits of all the external parts are les firm and rigid, and more flexible then at another time they are oberved to be in dead bodies; and in particular the Neck after death is carce tiffe with cold, at leat much les then in other Carkaes.

6 The Bret is outwardly lean, and very narrow, epecially under the arms, and eemeth on the ides to be as it were compreed, the That part of the bret where the ribs meet.Stern alo is omwhat pointed, like the Keel of a Ship, or the breat of a Hen.
7 The top of the ribs to which the tern is conjoyned with gritles, are knotty, like unto the joynts of the Wret and Ankles, as we have already aid.

8 The Abdomen indeed outwardly in repect of the parts continent is lean, but inwardly in repect of the parts contained it is omwhat ticking out, and eemeth to be weld, and extended. And thee have been our Obervations before the opening of the bellies.

list.label: II. The Abdomen being opened, we have Noted thee things:

list.item: 1 The Liver, in all that we have diected, hath exceeded in bignee, but was well coloured, and not much hardned, nor contaminated by any other remarkable vice. We deire om bodies hould here be excepted, in which other Dieaes before death were complicated with this, as in a Dropie & an extream Conumption we remember to have hapned.

2 The Spleen (namely o far as hitherto it hath been lawful for us to oberve) for the mot part is not to be contemned, whether you conider the magnitude, the colour, or the ubtance of it; notwithtanding we do not deny but it may otherwie happen in regard of a complication with other Dieaes.
3 We have ometimes epied a wheyih water to have glided into the cavity of the Abdomen, but indeed not often, nor in any great plenty.
4 The Stomach and Guts are omewhat more infected with flatulent humors, then ound bodies uually are, which partly may be the caue of that extenion of the hypochondriacal parts above mentioned.

5 The Meentery is ometimes faultlee, and ometimes affected with glandulous excrecences bigger then ordinary, if not with welling bunches: But concerning the weet-breadwe declare nothing for a certainty; only we upect that obtructions, if not a chirrhus, may ometimes invade that part. But thus we delegate, to the enquiry of others.

6 The Kidneys, Ureters, and Bladder, unlee there be a concomitancy of ome other Dieae, are laudably ound. We oberve in general of all the Bowels contained in this Belly, that although the parts containing them, as we have noted above, are very much extenuated and emaciated, yet are they as large and as full, if not larger and fuller, then thoe een in ound bodies, as hath been aid of the Liver.

list.label: III. The Sterne being with-drawn, thee things have preented themelves in the breat.

list.item:
1 A certain adherence or growing to of the Lungs with the A thin and mooth skin which cloatheth the ribs in the inner ide.Pleura which hath been more or lee dicernable in all the Bodies which hitherto
we have cut up. Yet we uppoe that this affect may happen without any uch nourihment, although in the advancement of the Dieae for the mot part it cometh before the Patient die.

2 The topings or tuffings of the lungs are no les frequent, epecially in thoe coadhering parts. Hard humours alo engendered by a thick, vicous, and blackih bloud, ometimes in one, ometimes in many of the trings of the Lungs, yet are not thee alwayes conpicuous, many times alo Impothums and Ulcers.

3 One amongt us doth attet, That he once aw glandulous knobs and bunches, o numerous, That they eemed to equallize, if not exceed the magnitude of the Lungs themelves They were cituated on both ides between the Lungs and the Mediatinum (that is the Membrane that divides the middle belly) and were extended from the Canelbone to the Diaphragma.
4 In the cavity of the Breat we have ometimes een a collection of wheyih waters, & indeed more frequently then in the cavity of the Abdomen, but not in all.

5 One amongt us hath likewie een this affect complicated with a great Impotume, and with the Ptyick: the Stern being removed, all the Lungs on the left ide were infected with an Impotume, and on every ide growing to the Pleura, and the humour being lightly cruhed, a copious, thick and tinking Matter of a yellowih colour, flowed out thorow the harp artery into the very mouth: The outward Membrane of the Lungs whereby they firmly adhered to the Pleura, appeared thicker then ordinary, and by the mediation of it, the trings on
that ide did o grow together, that you could carce ditinguih them • or uch: the ame Membrane alo, involved both the Lungs and alo the Impotume it elf which being opened the magnitude of the Impothume was dicernable, which by the etimation of thoe that were preent, contained at the leat two pound of water.
6 The kernel in the Canel-bone in Childhood is alwayes oberved to be great, and perhaps greater yet in thoe who have died of this Dieae.

list.label: IV. The Skull being awed thorow in a circular Figure, and the little cover being removed, we have oberved thee things:

list.item: 1 The Dura Mater hath been more firme, and adhered to the Skul in more places then is uual in men of ripe years: perhaps the ame may be oberved in other Children not affected with this evil, although, as we uppoe, not in o great a manner: for certain it is, That in new born Infants there are many and traight connexions between the Pericranian and the Dura Mater which are afterwards broken off and are carce dicernable.

2 In ome Bodies that we have diected, between the Dura and the Pia mater, and in the very ventricles of the Brain, we have found wheyih and waterih humours; from whence it is manifet, That this affect is complicated with the Hydrocephalus.
3 We have found the Brain in others that we have opened, to be firm and inculpable, and not overflowed with any waterih congetions.

item.p:
4 Latly, We have oberved in ome Bodies lately
opened, That the Carotides have exceeded their jut proportion, and o alo have the jugulary Veins; but the Arteries and the Veins which are delated to the outward parts, were of an unuual lendernee.

But whether or no this be perpetual in this affect we cannot yet witnee by an occular tetimony; yet we conjecture, That it happeneth o perpetually, but it came not ooner into our minds to examine it, ince the beginning of our Anatomical enquiries into this ubject.

div.p: Thee things being premied, our next Diquiition hall be to find out the Eence of the Dieae.

div.head: CHAP. III. Certain Suppoitions are propoed for the eaier finding out of the Eence of the Dieae. Firt of the Eence of Health. Secondly of the Eence of a Dieae. Thirdly of a threefold Diviion of Health and Dieaes. The Explication of the third Diviion, and the e of the ame. The Decription of a natural Contitution, and the exaltation of it. The Fourth Suppoition of the Combination of three Contitutions in the ame parts.
div.p: THat we may proceed the more ditinctly and clearly in the finding out of the Eene of this Dieae, we judged it very advantagious to premie thee ubequent Suppoitions:

I That the Eence of Health doth conit in ome Contitution of the Body according to Nature. But eing this is twofold in the kind, one Eential and neceary, repecting the tò ee imply, which during life continueth immoveable and immutable under various affections, and is indiviible: The other Accidental, having reference to the tò bene ee, which in repect of the whole Animal, is both moveable and mutable
and hath a great latitude, and can be preent or abent without the diolution of the whole. Health conits not in the former, but in the latter Contitution.

II. That the Eence of a Dieae in like manner coniteth not in the Eential Contitution: For o the diolution of the whole would by and by follow: But in the Accidental Contitution, namely uch an one, as in repect of the whole can be preent or abent without its diolution. We have aid (and not without reaon) that this Contitution wherein Health and Sicknee are founded, is moveable and accidental in repect of the whole; for even this alo in repect of ome part may be eential: as for example, a finger being cut off, a Dieae arieth in the defective number of the parts, which in repect of the whole, is founded upon an accidental Contitution; for that finger may be preent or abent without the diolution of the whole; but in repect of the lot member it is founded upon an Eential Contitution, for this Dieae being uppoed, the Eence of that finger periheth.

III. That the Contitution wherein the Eence both of Health and Sicknes coniteth, admits a threefold manner of diviion or ditinction in the method of Dicipline. The firt is omewhat thick, and is reolved into parts altogether Concrete, namely, It proceedeth Kata topous, according to the diviion of the parts from head to heel. The econd is purely abtracted, and earcheth out all the Elements of the moveable Contitution, from whence cometh the diviion of Dieaes into imilar, organical, and common; and then again thoe various ubdiviions into ditempers, faults of figure, uperficies, cavities and paages,
of magnitude, number, ite and continuity. The third is as it were a middle manner, and although it hath been hitherto neglected, yet we dare avouch, That it may have its ue, and that no contemptible one, in the handling of Dieaes, and the finding out of the caues of the Dieae; and it is divided into a Contitution Natural, Vital, and Animal.

The firt is proper to, and inherent in every part, abolutely competible to it, and without any dependance upon the other parts according to the Eence of it imply: This remaineth a while after death, till it be reolved by Putrefaction, Ambution, imple Exiccation, Mummification, Petrification, and the like violent Caues. This Contitution in repect of its imple Eence, doth not depend upon thoe Members which miniter an Influx, but it dependeth upon them both in repect of its Conervation, and likewie of its Operation. For the vital influx ceaing after death (which is as it were the alt and condiment of it) quickly periheth, and as long as the creature liveth, this is variouly affected by the influxes, and thereupon the actions are either promoved or interupted.

The Second is the Vital Contitution, which is produced by that continual influx from the heart thorow the arteries into the parts of the whole Body. This alo it admitteth degrees, and is often ubject to variations more or lee, and ometimes alo eemeth to uffer a kind of eclips, as in a wouning, a yncope, &c. yet it perevereth from the beginning to the lat period of life (at leat in its fountain, and in ome other parts.

The Third is the Animal Contitution, which is derived
from the Brain thorow the Nerves into the Organs of Sene and Motion. This is many times totally wanting in many parts, the life notwithtanding remaining; yea it might for a long time together be defective in everal parts, or all the parts, did not repiration, which is abolute neceary unto life, depend upon it. Thee Contitutions therefore keep uch a connexion between themelves, that the econd doth eternally and continually preuppoe the exitence of the former, and the third of the econd; but there is not back again o abolute a dependance between them, becaue (as we have even now aid) the former can for ome time ubit without the econd, and the econd commonly altogether without the third: And thee three Contitutions may in mot bodies be manifetly perceived, yet we affirm not that they may be found in all. The Natural indeed and the Vital are wanting to no part: but the Animal is defective in the Bones (though the teeth will admit ome doubt) gritles, perhaps ligaments, and ome ubtances as of the Liver, Spleen, &c. we aert therefore this threefold Contitution to be in all thoe parts, to whom the Natural, Vital, and Animal Faculty is communicated. For although thee Faculties as to the firt act may be aid to depend upon the Soul (which relation hath indeed no relation to the Medicinal art) yet in repect of the econd act they are necearily rooted in ome material Contitution of the parts to which they belong. For whereas ome ay that the Vital Faculty is derived from the Heart, and the Animal from the Brain unto the other parts, that mut not o be undertood, as if the Faculties themelves in a wandring manner were tranient from part to part (for the paing of
an accident from ubject to ubject cannot be conceived by any undertanding) but that the Vital Faculty is derived with, and in the vital Spirit from the Heart unto the parts, or at leat is excited by ome motion of the Heart and Arteries in the parts themelves, and in like manner the Animal Faculty doth decend in and with the Animal Spirit by the Nerves, or is produced in the parts by ome motion of the Nerves in the Brain. Which way oever it comes to pae, we mut needs confee that ome alteration is imprinted in the part it elf receiving it either from the aid Spirits, or from their motions. Which alteration as it is here granted to be the root of the Faculty, either Vital, or Animal in the repective parts, o is it a moveable Contitution, becaue it can be variouly changed, remitted, and intended without the diolution of the whole; and it is the Contitution wherein either Health or Sicknee may conit, eeing that whenoever alteration is deficient unto the parts wherein it ought to be, or any other wayes adminitred then is requiite, the action will thereupon be unavoidably depraved; but if it be rightly performed, then ound and perfect health is aid to be preent from the part of that Contitution. Conidering therefore that there are two kind of Alterations beides the natural and inherent Contitution, one from the influx of the Heart, another from the influx of the Brain in mot parts; and eeing the aid alterations, as they themelves are more perfect or more imperfect, do render the Faculties in the repective parts (at leat as to the econd act) more perfect or imperfect, and that the actions are thereupon depraved or ound, it is neceary that this threefold Contitution reide in mot of the parts,
and that the aid kind of alterations be medical contitutions whereon Health and Sicknee may be grounded.

That this Diviion or Ditinction is not frivolous or altogether unprofitable, appeareth from hence, becaue the practical Phyitians in their Methods do rightly admonih, that in obcure Dieaes the Faculties mut be accurately oberved, when their actions are een to be depraved, which diligence may erve as it were for a Manuduction to guide us to the Origine of the affect; now if it be a conideration of o jut importance to note the interupted Faculties in Dieaes, certainly it will be an exercie of no lee moment to take cognizance of the Contitutions themelves, upon which thoe Faculties have an immediate and trict dependance.

Now leat any man hould conceive that there is almot a coincidence between this third Diviion and the econd, he may oberve, if he will diligently weigh the matter, That every member of this diviion doth in ome manner include al the members of the next precedent, namely that the natural Contitution doth comprehend primarily indeed the imilar Contitution, but that econdarily and in order to the whole creature, it containeth in a ort the conformation and continuity; in like manner that the Vital and Animal Contitution do in their way o clearly participate of all the Members of the aid Diviion, that to offer proofs of it were an unneceary undertaking: Only we deire the Reader to take notice (which alo we even now intimated) That the natural Contitution primarily and principally hath repect unto the temperament, the common qualities, the plenty of the Spirits, and the peculiar
dipoition of them (which by ome are refered to the form and the whole ubtance) but that it hath repect unto the manner of the Organe and the continuity as it were econdarily, and in order to the whole creature, and that it can carce be otherwie hurt or vitiated by them. Yet we mut not deny but that the natural Contitution is ometimes vitiated as it is meerly Organical, for thus it falleth out in the obtructions of the natural paages; as for example, when a tone is impacted or grown to hardnee in the paage of the Meter or the yard, and in the like caes: but this happeneth unto it epecially in as much as the paage is ordained for the ue and conervation of the whole; but for the mot part the Organical vices in the natural Contitution are of lee note and conideration then the imilar.
Thee things may uffice to be poken in a general way of this triple Contitution. We will now in particular peak a few things of them in few words.

The Natural Contitution which is proper unto and inherent in every part, may be known by this dicription, That it is the manner of the natural Being, etled in the parts, competible to them, in as much as they are aptly contituted by their temperament, and common quallities, by their ufficient portion and convenient dipoition of ingenerated Spirits, and by their jut conformation and continuity, to a perfect performance of natural actions, together with the concurrence of the Vital (and perhaps the Animal) influx. Therefore when there is in any part a jut temperament, convenient common qualities, an exquiite proportion, and harmonious dipoition
of inherent Spirits. Finally, when there is a laudable conformation and unity, and yet notwithtanding all this, the natural action is depraved, we may well conclude that it is not vitiated by the natural Contitution, but by reaon of the concurrent caue, namely the vital or natural influx, or of both together; for the natural actions in creatures in regard of the union and wedlock of life, are exalted to a more eminent condition then otherwi they would attain unto by the natural Contitution alone. And from hence it comes to pae, That although the natural Contitution in lain Creatures remaineth after death undepraved for a while, yet the attractive and retentive Faculty, the concoction of the aliment, and the expulion of the exctement do altogether ceae: And in Dieaes alo many times the natural Contitution is at firt untoucht, yet the natural action is vitiated meerly by the defect of the due concurrence of the vital influx: after the ame manner omttimes the natural and vital Contitution being ound and healthful, yet ome natural action is depraved by reaon of the defect of ome animal influx and concurence: but this for the mot part happeneth only in the Nervous, Fibrous, and Membranous parts, epecially where they make a hollownee, but eldom or not at all in the ubtance of the parts: As in the Paly the excrements are many times unduly retained, by reaon only of the atonihment and ineniblnee of the guts, the other contitutions being ound. Therefore in thee caes, when ome natural action is hurt, we mut not preently conclude that the natural Contitution is firt vitiated, but we mut with dilligence enquire out that Contitution which is firt vitiated, for that
is to be looked upon as the root and firt eence of the evil; in like manner if ome vital action be depraved, we mut not preently infer that the vital Contitution is primarily vitiated; becaue ometimes the firt Origin is more rightly deduced from the natural, or perhaps the animal Contitution: as for example, Through the intenivenee of cold, a finger is mortified by inflamation: in this cae it is true that the influx of the vital bloud is plainly intercepted; yet the beginning of that interception mut be ought out in the natural Contitution of that very part o benumned: So alo in a Convulion the circulation of the bloud is perhaps omething diturbed and interupted; but the firt depravation mut be acribed to the animal, not to the vital Contitution. On the contrary, in a Feaver the Head is invaded, but the ource of the evil will peradventure be found out in the vital Contitution: o perhaps the Fleh is wated, and al the natural Spirits are decayed; yet the root of the evil wil be found out in the vital, not in the natural Contitution: So that any Contitution of the three before named may be in everal Dieaes, ometimes the firt, ometimes the econd, and ometimes the third caue of vitiated actions.

Not only many other parts of the body (yea imply al the enible) which exhibit not an influx, neither are ubervient as delatory parts, do naturally admit this threefold Contitution, but beides alo even the Heart it elf, and all the arteries, and the Brain and al the nerves, o that the Brain (excepting the fault in its natural Contitution) may be cherihed and helped by the vital Spirit which is tranmitted thorow the veins and the arteries, being wel
affected, or vitiated and hurt if that be ill affected: And after the ame manner alo may the Heart by the animal Spirit which hath an influx thorow the recurent nerve of the ixth pair, the arteries alo by the animal influx thorow the nerves by a way perhaps not yet found out: And Finally, The Nerves alo by the vital Spirit deduced thorow the Arteries.

div.head: CHAP. IV. That the Eence of this Dieae conits not in the Animal or Vital, but in the Natural Contitution; not as Organical, but as Similar: Three Limitations are Propounded.
div.p: THee things being Preuppoed, We hal proceed to enquir in what Contitution of the parts the firt Root or Eence of this affect is lodged. Be the firt Concluion therefore this,

The Firt Root of this Affect is not in the Animal Contitution, or in that which dependeth upon the Influx of the Brain into the parts. Indeed we confee that al the nerves which without the Skul proceed from the pinal marrow, are found to be looe and weak in this affect; yet this doth not here eem to arie from a defect of the influx of the Brain, which we thus prove, Firt the loonee and weaknee
of the nerves, which cometh primarily from the Brain, is almot alwayes conociated with omnolency and drowinee; but this Symptom happeneth but rarely, and by accident only in this affect. Secondly, As we remember, we never knew the Paly, or the Apoplexy to upervene or follow upon this Dieae; but it ought necearily o to do, and that very often (at leat in the confirmation of the Dieae) if this loonee and weaknes of the nerves hould take beginning from a defect of the influx of the Brain. Thirdly, We have oberved the Brain to be ufficiently firm and inculpable in many diected after death. Fourthly, For the mot part thoe that are afflicted with this evil are ingenious in repect of their age, which doth evidently attet the vigour and vivacity of the Brain.

The Second Concluion. The firt root of this affect is not in the Vital Contitution, or in that which dependeth upon the Influx of the Heart into the parts. An unequal ditribution of bloud indeed almot (if not altogether) perpetual may be oberved in this affect: neverthelee the chief reaon of this inequality mut be acribed, not to the inequaity of the influx of the Heart or Arteries, but to the unequal reception and unaptnee in the parts themelves to receive it; for the Heart and the Arteries do for their part indicriminately or equally ditribute the bloud with the Spirits every way into the parts. But if it o fal out that an Artery of ome part be interupted in his function by reaon of the benumnednee and tupefaction of that part, or the parts adjacent, there is a neceity that the bloud mut be minutely tranmitted thither, and o unequally in repect of the other parts which expeditely and aptly receave the bloud.
Therefore in this cae this inequality of ditribution doth properly and primarily depend upon a preexitent fault without the artery pertaining to the natural Contitution of the parts.

Object. But ome may Object, Although perhaps the aforeaid inequality hath no dependance upon the Heart, yet it may o happen that a weak Pule may uffice to ditribute the bloud thorow the leer Circulations in the inner parts, which nevertheles may not be altogether o ufficient to undergo that duty thorow the greater Circulations in the outward parts which are more remote from the Heart, the fountain of bloud.

Anw. We Anwer, That this Objection was formerly of o great importance with one of us, that he uppoed uch an inequality of the vital influx did belong to the prime Eence of this Dieae, and did therefore endeavour to deduce the reaon of the firt Symptoms from it. But after econd thoughts, the matter being more neerly and deeply examined, he was of Opinion, That this inequality of the vital influx had no relation to the primary, but to the econdary Eence of the Dieae. But we return to the olution of the Argument. And Firt we grant indeed that in this affect there is an unequal ditribution of the bloud; and that in the internal parts and in the head it is more liberal, in the external more paring. Secondly we grant that the Circulation of the bloud may be kept in the inward parts, even although no Pule apear in the outward parts; but this happeneth only in a vehement either weaknee or oppreion of the vital Spirits, as in a wouning, and a trong hyterical paroxim, or fit of the
Mother, in which affect ome that have been accounted for dead have been een to revive again. Thirdly we grant that a more liberal Circulation of the bloud may be in the internal then the external parts, yea and in ome one external part more then in another, as it happeneth in the inflamation of ome external member.

Thee things being granted, we affirm, that in the firt Cae the inequality of the ditribution of the bloud doth not principally depend upon the weaknee of the Pulifical vertue for as much as concerns the heart; and the reaon hereof is plain. For the heart, as we have already aid, doth emit the bloud indicriminatly or equally, and with one continuation from it elf into the Aorta or chief artery, even at uch time when as the Pule is mot weak. This artery doth exonerate or disburthen it elf again with al poible expedition, and from hence proceedeth the inequality of the diffuion of the bloud, as the bloud is more eaily impelled from on rivelet then from another. This inequality notwithtanding mut not properly and primarily be attributed to the heart, but to the recipient parts, and to the particular tranmitting arteries. For any primary affect of the heart is necearily univeral, and communicated to al the parts of the body: wherefore although we grant this enequality of the Circulation of the bloud to be in the econdary Eence of this Dieae, yet we exclude it from the primary.

Moreover in the Second Cae propounded, we ay that there is a great diparity between the caes of extream neceity, and ordinary caes. Neither indeed do we know whether in the aid caes the circulation
in the inward parts, howoever it be granted, be of any moment. And for o much as concerneth the preent buinee, we deny any uch debility of the heart in this affect, that the Pule hould be defective in the outward parts; yea we have not oberved that any one afflicted with this Dieae hath been prone to fal into an extacy, or a wouning; which would readily happen if the origin of the Dieae were rooted in the debility of the heart it elf. Beides when we have een uch as were ick in their tender age, to endure without any los of trength ometimes a liberal eduction or flowing forth of the bloud from the opened veins of their ears, yea and een it ometimes reiterated with good uccee. Finally, When alo they have very wel endured purgations, with repect had to their age, it doth not appear to us how the firt root of the evil can be acribed to the weaknes of the vital contitution.

In the Third Cae it is evidently manifet that the firt caue of this unequal circulation of the bloud is ome dipoition of an outward part, as in an inflamed member, laboring under ome private Dieae, there happeneth a more ful and impetuous Pule by reaon of the accidental heat of the artery, infued by the immoderation of heat which is in that outward part.

Therefore eing that the Eence of this affect cannot be primarily rooted in the animal nor the vital Contitution of the parts (as we have now hewed) it followeth (which hal be the Third Concluion) That the primary Eence, or firt root of this affect, coniteth in the proper or inherent contitution of the parts. But becaue the natural Contitution (as we have
aid above) coniteth partly in the common qualities and the temperament, and partly in a jut plenty and dipoition of the inherent Spirits, and again partly in the organical contruction and continuity; our next enquiry mut be to find out in which of the prementioned contitutions it lodgeth, and whether it be rooted in one alone, or in many, or in altogether. Be the Fourth Concluion therefore this:

This affect is not radicated in the Organical Contitution of the parts. For although in progree of time the Organs themelves are divers wayes affected in repect of their conformation, quantity, and ite, as it is ufficiently manifet from the encreaed bulk of the head, liver, &c. from the tumours of the bones unto the wrets, the ankls and the extremities of the ribs; from various obtructions and the extenuation of the outward parts; eing neverthelee that al thee things depend upon a higher origin and howoever alo we may necearily admit thee things in a Dieae confirmed, and now variouly compounded; yet in the original Eence, we preume, for the ubequent reaons they are to be rejected.

Firt, Becaue the depravations aforeaid in the Organical parts do not appear preently in the beginning of the Dieae, but encreae afterwards by little and little: And although perhaps ome of thee may be aid from the beginning to have taken root in the body, notwithtanding they cannot as yet be immediatly dicerned by the ene, neither do they manifetly hurt any actions, and for that reaon they cannot appertain to the firt Eence of the Dieae.

Secondly, Becaue the Organical vices aforeaid are not the Caues but the Effects rather of the chief Symptoms which from the beginning exhibit themelves in this
affect. For the augmented figure of the head, liver, &c. the tanding out of the bones, and the leannee of the external parts, are more rightly refered to the inequality of the nourihment, then on the contrary the inequality of the nourihment hould be acribed to them: For when one part doth exceively encreae, and another is defrauded of a due & decent augmentation, there is a neceity that a diproportionate and an unequal nourihment mut not only be preent in the parts, but alo have had a preexitence in the body, whereby one part is nourihed, and another neglected beneath a mediocrity. But eeing this unequal nourihment is a depraved action, and o a Symptom preuppoing ome preexitent Dieae, and yet withal (as we have aid) doth precede, as a caue, the organical vices aforeaid, it is manifet that thoe organical vices are not the firt root of this Dieae. As for the obtructions which indeed are for the mot part conjoyned with this affect, yet neverthelee there is a great deal of reaon to exclude them from the firt Eence of this Dieae, becaue they neither pecificate the Dieae, neither can any reaon of the Symptoms be rendered from them, neither do they perpetually beiege ome certain and determinate noble part. Some man perhaps, who hath repect to the exceive magnitude of the liver, may object that in this affect that is perpetually obtructed, and thereupon the anguification being vitiated the other things are prepoteriouly derived; but if this welling of the Liver did alwayes proceed from the obtruction of it, then a palenee of complexion, a cachexia or indigetion, and by the advantage of time, the Dropie it elf hould necearily and perpetually accompany
this affect: Moreover, The Liver hould alwayes be een to be vitiated in the colour, and at the diection hard tumors and knots hould be oberved in the ubtance of it, epecially in an inveterate affect, and that which killed the Patient; but eing thee things do not frequently (much lee perpetually) occur in dead bodies, the augmented bulk of it mut rather be refered to the irregular nutrition: Moreover, we deny it not but that we have oberved by Anatomy in thoe who have perihed of this Dieae, obtructions, various tumours, and knotty excrecencies in the Lungs, but we attet withal, That we have een ome Infants, yea Boys lightly affected with this evil, in whom there was no upicion of vitiated Lungs, for there was no cough, no impediment of repiration, which necearily is an individual companion of the obtruction of the Lungs.
Thirdly, Becaue a ufficient reaon of all the Symptoms proper to this Dieae, may more cleerly and eaily be derived from other fountains, as we hal ee anon.

And thus we have ufficiently proved, That this affect in repect of the firt Eence of it, conits not in the Organical Contitution of the natural parts. The ame arguments wil more effectually convince (more might be produced, but we judge accumulations unneceary) That this evil is not radicated in the continuity of the natural parts, o that there needs no more words to prove it.

The Fifth Concluion. This Dieae is primarily rooted in the imilary Contitution of the natural parts: And therefore in repect of the radical Eence therof, it is a imilary Dieae. And becaue a imilary
Dieae, as uch, is not perpetually Simple, but omtimes variouly compounded (namely a Ditemper is either Simple, or Compound, and this becomes uch, not only by the firt qualities among themelves, but perhaps by hidden qualities conjoyned together; or, which is more agreeable to our Conceptions, epecially in the preent buines, by a kind of ure proportion and medification of the inherent Spirits) We judg this to be a Compound Dieae, and we aert the prime and radical Eence thereof to conit in a cold and moit Ditemper, with a Defect and tupefaction of the inherent Spirits, concurring in the inherent contitution of the parts primarily affected. But before we proceed to an higher Explication of this Opinion, we wil premie ome Limitations of it.

The Firt hal be this: That in this Dieae, ome parts of the Body are Primarily, and others Secondarily affected: And truly, to us the External parts eem ooner to be affected than the Brain and Bowels, as we hall declare more at large when we come to peak of the parts affected.

The Second is this: That in thoe parts alone which are Primarily affected, do labor under a notable cold Ditemper with penury and tupefaction of pirits: For the Brain perhaps and the Bowels may be moderatly hot, and ufficiently abound with Spirits, by reaon of the copious vital influx; and moiture may exceed in them by reaon of the affuion of our overplentiful aliment: but the other External parts are alwaies affected with a cold and moit Ditemper, and a benumednes of the natural Spirit, &c. Wherupon we aert, that in this Dieae they are primarily affected, and that they alone are the eat of the firt Eence of this Dieae.

Be this the Third: All the External parts, and thoe firt affected, do not equally labor under a cold and moit Ditemper, and with benumednes of Spirits, &c. For the Ligaments, Tendons, and Nerves, are in their own nature more cold, and les moit; the Mucles, or flehy parts are rather more moit, and les cold: the skinny parts uually retain a mediocrity, yet al the aid parts recede more or les from the natural towards a cold and moit temper. And in like manner, although ome of the aid parts do require a greater plenty and activity of Spirits than others, yet al of them a jut proportion, being oberved to the plenty and activity repectively due to each of them, are defective and detitute of that jut proportion.

div.head: CHAP. V. The prepoed Opinion is examined by Parts. Firt, That this Dieae is a cold Ditemper. An Objection, and the Anwer thereunto; That it is moit: That it coniteth in the penury or paucity of the Spirits. An Objection, with the Anwer. Finally, That this Dieae coniteth in the tupefaction of the Spirits.
div.p: NOw let us more neerly examin the Opinion propoed, and aert it by parts.

Firt, That the parts firt affected do labor under a cold ditemper may be proved. Firt, from the unequal and diminihed nutrition of the aid parts; for as the inborn heat when it is augmented to a jut proportion doth very much conduce to further the concoction of the Aliment; o if it be too remis, it eaily retardeth and leeneth the ame.

Secondly, The ame ditemper is proved from the lownes and unaptnes to motion; and alo from the averation to exercie, and deire to ret. For as the activity and agility of the Body is attributed to the Heat, o the tardity and lothfulnes of it is in great part acribed to Cold, Namely, uppoing (as before) that this lothfulnes hath no dependance
upon the fault of the animal influx.
Thirdly, It is further confirmed, becaue this Dieae many times followeth other accute Dieaes, whereby they end not eldom (after the Wat or Conumption of the Natural heat) in a cold ditemper.
Beides, It alo receiveth Chronical Dieaes which extenuate the Body, and uch as in any manner are prone to leave a cold ditemper behind them as Pertinacious Obtructions, the Scurvy, Cachexy &c.

Moreover, Becaue it ucceedeth the importune uppreion of Scabbednes, and Impetiginous effects, as we have often oberved, when the Scabs have newly broken out again, and the Itch is revived, uch Boyes have been eaily retored to health, becaue by that means the Natural heat is reaugmented in the outward Members.

Latly, Becaue many times it happeneth after a continual ue of cold, thick, and vicous aliment, after urfeting and idlenes, and the like evident caues, either diminihing or overwhelming the Natural heat.

Fourthly, It is yet more plainly evinced, becaue thoe helps which excite, augment, and cherih the heat in the outward parts, as various agitations, rubbings, and anointing of the Body, do contribute a large hare to the advancement of this Cure. Thee things being all cat together into a heap, it is ufficiently conpicuous that a cold ditemper of the Natural contitution of the parts firt affected is contained in the primary eence of this Dieae.

Object. But here we meet with a pecious Objection, That a little Feaver, epecially a low one, or uch
as is erratical and wandering, is frequently conjoyned with this affect, which at the ame time eemeth abolutely inconitent with a cool ditemper. For all Feavers by all men are accounted to be a hot ditemper which is diametrically oppoite to the aid eence.

We Anwer (that we may not here interpoe any thing concerning the eence of a Feaver) we freely grant, for o much as concerns the preent Quetion, that a Feaver is a hot ditemper; but this doth not chiefly conit in the Natural contitution of the parts, but in the vital contitution, namely in the influent heat preternaturally affected. For a Feaver is not ome private Dieae, but univeral, and is diffued from the Heart through the Arteries in and with the vital Spirit, be it either overheated, or otherwie viciated. For this preternatural heat hath only a repect to that inherent as a caue potent and able variouly to alter it, yet indeed by degrees and little and little. For firt the influent heat is manifetly an actual heat, but the heat of the natural contitution is only potential: wherefore we affirm that a cold ditemper in repect of a natural and potential heat may conit with a hot ditemper in repect of an actual and influent heat. For indeed an actual heat is not o directly avere to a cold ditemper which is o called by reaon of a defect of the potential heat, but it may (the caue perevering) conit for a good while with it. As for example, there is an actual heat in Simple Water, Barly Water, divere Juleps and the like being made hot, although at the ame time they are potentially cold. So that to be actually hot, and potentially hot differ not in the Degree, but in the Species, neither are they o directly contrary to one another, that one
mut preently expel the other out of a ubject.

Moreover, Secondly, The influent hot ditemper doth not o much correct the inherent cold ditemper, as by accident it augmenteth it, namely by a wat and diipation of the Natural Spirits, wherein chiefly the natural and potential heat reides: Jut after the ame manner as the actual heat introduced by the fire diminiheth the potential heat of the Wine. Whereupon any kind of Feaver upervening upon this Dieae, uually brings more damage than advantage to the ick.

Secondly, We affirm, a moit ditemper to be lodged together in the parts firt affected; this is manifet from the laxity and oftnes of the aid parts: and this ign likewie doth more trongly confirm the ame thing, becaue the aid parts are extenuated, o that unles there were a redundancy of moiture in them, a certain rigidity and roughnes would aault the touch; again, a cold ditemper doth very rarely continue long without a moit: and latly, things helpful and hurtful attet this truth, for drying things are helpful, and moitning things are hurtful.
Thirdly, we affirm, That in the parts firt affected there is a penury of natural pirits. This is proved by the very ame arguments which we produced to evince it to be a cold ditemper.

For firt the unequal and imminute nutrition of the parts firt affected doth not only argue a coldnes of temper, but withal, a want of natural pirits, for otherwie this defect of nutrition might be eaily corrected. For the caue of that coldnes wherewith the defect of the pirit is conjoyned, or ome peccaut humor is not impacted, is eaily cahired,
and ooner then is wont in this dieae, as may b • een in the parts grown extream cold in the winte eaon; for example ake, in the handling of now; the parts o extreamly cooled provided that they be rightly handled, wil return to their pritine temperame¯t in few hours: but wher there is a ditemper with the matter of it, as a cae conjoynd, or where ther is a defect of the inherent pirits, uch a ditemper indeed is not o oon nor o eaily removed. But in the preent affect we cannot affirm that a conjoyned or impacted matter of any note is (at the leat alwie) caued in the parts firt affected, becaue they are oberved to be more withered, feeble, and extreamly extenuated, and eeing this affect is very different from Cachexia and the Virgins dieae; in the which for the mot part, it is not the want of Spirits, but the conjoyned matter that cheriheth the cold ditemper: wherefore we may rightly infer that the pertinacity of this evil doth chiefly depend upon the defect of the natural Spirits. Secondly, The ame is proved after the ame manner by the econd argument before alleadged for the cold ditemper, namly from loth and avernes to excercie. For activity hath not only a dependance upon the temper, but chiefly upon the fulnes of the Spirits: as may be een in trong and heathful men, who in winter time, and hardet frot, are more prompt and inclinable to violent exercies, then in ummer, when the inherent Spirits are wont to be omwhat diolved. Thirdly, Feavers, and long extenuating dieaes, as they often introduce a cold ditemper, o they evidently diminih and diipate the inherent Spirits. To thee we ad that argument which is deduced from the contitution of the Parents the Parents that are more trong and luty (experience
witneeth it) and accutomed to labour, eldom bring forth children obnoxious to this dieae: on the contrary, uch as are weak, ickly, idle, tender, delicate, very prone to immoderate, premature, or decriped Venery, uch as are troubled with a Gonorrhea, &c. for the mot part beget children ubject to this affect: Namely, becaue the Seminary principles are furnihed only with a deficiency of Spirits. We hould now proceed to the fourth aertion, but mut firt remove a remora that cometh in the way.

Object. For ome may object. That the natural cold ditemper is ubordinated to the want of Spirits, and not contraditinguihed to it, as is here uppoed. For the paucity of the Spirits eemeth to be the very caue of the cold ditemper, and the natural heat be it more intene or more remis, eemeth repectively to follow the proportion of the natural Spirits, as being radicated in them as their firt ubject.

We anwer. Firt, That the inherent heat is indeed firt grounded and ubjected in the inherent Spirits. Moreover as the inward heat is divided into two par s, namely, the natural, and the acquired heat; o the inward Spirit mut be alo conceived to be twofold, the primigenial or eminal derived from the Parents in the eed, and the acquired Spirit contracted from a perfect aimilation of the aliment, the former Spirit is the bais of the engrafted natural heat, the latter of the inward acquired heat; we mean, not that thee heats and Spirits are in themelves ditinct in the pecies but only in their origin and degree of perfection, which is ufficient to invet them with a various appellation. For in nutrition the aimilation of the aliment proceedeth even to a pecifical identity, and not an individual, although ometimes, alo it attaineth not the degree of original
perfection. For which caue it eemed ufficient to us to have named the implanted heat, and the implanted Spirit, without any higher ditinction; and therefore we grant that the implanted heat is firt ubjected and rooted in the Spirits, and that it is nothing ele then a certain modification of the aid Spirits, whereby they being irradiated by the vital heat do delight to indeavor to diffue themelves and to enlarge their dominions, by attracting, retaining, aimilating the aliments like unto themelves by evering the excrements, and latly, by dipoing the things acquired in due places: we ay, likewie that this endeavor (wherin we place the eence of heat) by reaon that it is diffuive doth omwhat diipate and wat the implanted Spirits, which becaue of this effect are vulgarly called by the name of radical moiture continually devoured and conumed by the heat. Thus far we grant the argument: But in the econd place we affirm that the implanted heat doth differ fro¯ the hot implanted temperament; for the implanted heat is only a part of the hot implanted temperament, for not only a Spirit, but ulphur alo, and alt, or perhaps choler, contribute their heat to the contitution of the whole hot implanted temperament, wherof the implanted heat is only a part. Wherefore it is faly uggeted in the propounded argument, that a plenty of Spirits is the ole caue of a hot ditemper, and a paucity of a cold ditemper: for a pound of the fleh of an infant containeth more implanted Spirits then a pound of a yongmans fleh: yet it is mot evident that the temperament of a yong man is far more hot then that of an infant: a hot temperament cannot therefore depend upon the ole plenty of the Spirits, nor a cold temperament upon a want of
Spirits. Moreover in many maladies a hot ditemper is conitent with a paucity of Spirits; as in a Hectick of the third degree; in like manner of a cold ditemper with a competent plenty of Spirits, as in the Green icknes.

We ay thirdly, That a plenty or paucity of Spirits is not perpetually a ufficient caue to determine the temperament either hot or cold; as on the contrary, neither doth a hot, nor a cold temperament certainly and necearily demontrate a plenty or paucity of Spirits, as is manifet from the intance given. So that the temperament is no ure ign of the quantity of the Spirits, nor the quantity of the Spirits a ure ign of the temperament; and therfore purpoeth not without jut caue, thee things come to be conidered and examined as contraditinct, if we wil procure a certain and inconfued knowledge of them.

Fourthly we anwer, That although it were granted, that the implanted heat is ubjected in the implanted Spirits, yet notwithtanding that heat is not intended nor remitted according to the ole plenty, or paucity of Spirits: for the Spirits howoever ufficiently copious, yet if they be too much fixed, torpid, and as it were frozen; they exhibit not any implanted heat worthy of conideration. As for example, the white of an egge welleth with copious Spirits, yet are they o benummed, and the inward heat is thereupon o mall, that it obtaineth not the formation of a chicken, unles it be firt excited by incubation, or ome uch other heat; therefore we may lawfully conclude, that a conideration from the want of Spirits is ufficiently ditinct from the conideration of a cold implanted temperament, although the objected argument doth eem to ininuate

the contrary. Moreover from this fourth article of our anwer, there reulteth a fourth aertion of the eence propounded, Namely,

That beide the ditemper and want of Spirits a certain benumdnes of them, mut be added as a ditinct part alo of the eence of the dieae. This benumdnes of the engraffed Spirits appeareth chiefly by the defective nutrition, and averation from exercie, which proceed not primarily (as we have proved above) from any defect of the influx of the brain. It is alo manifet from hence, becaue all thoe things which drive out that tupefaction of the Spirits, although they do not altogether drive it away, yet they conduce very much to the cure of this dieae; as exercies of any kind augmented by degrees, frictions, anoyntings, &c. and things inwardly taken, of a heating, cutting, purging, and gently opening quality. But that this benumdnes is ufficiently ditinct from the want of Spirits (beides that which we have aid in the 3. article of our Anwer is ufficiently manifet from hence, becaue an exceive excitation, contrary to a benummednes is often conjoyned with a penury of Spirits: as it commonly falleth out in a Hectick feaver, in diolving fluxes, and the like dieaes, in which howoever there be a want of Spirits, yet no benummednes is conociated; but on the contrary that vehement excitation, & propenity to motion, mut be retrained.

On the contrary, copious Spirits may conit with a benummednes, as in wheat or meal. For although it may eem to have but little Spirit, becaue the Spirits of it do yet lurk in their fixation, and benummednes; yet indeed the Spirits do abound in it, and may be ummoned out by a imple fermentation, and excited to a manifetation of their activity:
As trong Beer made thereof doth plainly declare. In like manner juice newly preed out of immature grapes, is very mild and pleaant, containing in the mean time plenty of Spirits, which afterwards the due fermentation being finihed, reveal themelves in generous wine.
Let us conclude therefore that the benummednes of the Spirits in this affect deerveth a particular and ditinct conideration.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Part firt affected in this Dieae.
div.p: WE have already propounded the firt Eence of this Dieae, it remaineth now that we enquire after the firt Subject in which that Eence is radicated.
The heart and the brain do here eem rightly to be excluded, for the reaons before alleadged, the repetition whereof for brevity ake we hal omit.
The liver and the Lungs are not as yet exempted from all upition of this fault, we wil therfore examine thee bowels apart, and firt we demand,

p.hi: Whether the Liver be the ubject of the firt eence of this Dieae?

div.p:
The principal Argument is for the Affirmative, becaue this Dieae may eem to proceed from a vicious anguification, the Shop and Work-houe whereof (at leat in probability) the Liver is uppoed to be, but that a viciated anguification is the
firt origine of this dieae eems to be made manifet by many igns. Firt, becaue this dieae for the mot part followeth after many other great dieaes, either acute or chronical, which in great meaure have beforehand weakned the anguifical vertue of the Liver. Secondly, Becaue this dieae doth not only depend upon outward, but inward caues, namely the vicious humors. And eing the vicious humors are generated in and with the mas of blood in the liver, the firt eence of this affect eemeth to be referred hither. Thirdly, The Liver is perpetually oberved to be bigger than ordinary in this affect; which manifetly witneeth the Liver to be affected. Fourthly, thoe internal Medicines which have a faculty to putrifie the blood are requiite to the cure of this dieae and being exhibited are found to be very profitable. 5. The miian of blood from the veins of the ears (which is not the meanet help to vanquih this affect) doth more than ufficiently argue ome fault to be in the blood, which eemeth to be acribed to the contitution of the Liver, in as much as it doth anguificate. Thee Arguments have o far prevailed upon ome very famous Phyitians, that thereupon they have attributed the firt eence of this dieae to the Liver alone.

But we conceive that thee things may be ufficiently anwered, if we hall firt grant what can be further or what hath already been rightly aid concerning this matter, and then diolve thoe things which are inferred by bad and invalid conequence.

Firt, Therefore we grant that the mas of blood is viciated in this affect, and that from thence is conveied a continual •••• editati ••
<> the dieae.
We grant alo for the preent that the Liver is the Officin of anguification: but we deny that every vicioity of the blood doth depend upon the viciated anguification contitution of the Liver. For firt, the blood may be corrupted by unwholom aliment, the Liver in the mean time remaining ound, in like manner if the firt concoction in the ventricle by any caue whatoever be rendred imperfect; yet it cannot be fully corrected by the econd concoction in the Liver be that bowel never o ound. Beides, although the generation of vicious blood hould be olely acribed to the Liver, yet the other parts hould necearily concur to the conervation of that which is generated, as the Kidneyes, the Spleen, the Pancreas, the Womb &c. yea, and it eemeth undeniable, that all the parts which the blood waheth in his circulation, do variouly alter it, whilt according to the capacity of the ubject they imprint their qualities in it: for they are natural agents, and act by neceity and continually without any upention of their actions or intervenient paues, unles they be etrained by ome predominant power: therfore if thee be il affected, they give a greater or a les tincture of pollution, to the blood which paes through them, as may be een in a contagion gotten by an external contact communicated to the inward parts. Moreover, ometimes a great pollution from the other dieaed parts is ininuated into the blood, the liver in the interim being afe, as hath been ometimes oberved in opened bodies, that have perihed by a Dropie, in whom the Liver was found to be ufficiently ound and whol. Moreover, We grant that the faults of the Blood do frequently derive their beginning from the depravednes of their anguifical contitution of the
Liver, and that that depraved contitution is an affect of the Liver. But we deny this to be the ame Dieae whereof we now treat, becaue it differs from it in the whol Species. For that ame depraved contitution of the Liver is alike common to men of full age, to Boys, and Children; but this dieae is olely apropriated to boys and infants. Again, We grant that a vicious contitution of the Liver may by generating a corrupt blood be a common caue, and foment the augmentation of this affect: but we deny that to be the dieae it elf, whereof we now peak, or any part of the firt eence thereof. For it is one thing to produce a common caue of a dieae, and another thing to be of the firt eence of a dieae. We deny alo that to be the continent caue of this dieae, or to be a ufficient caue of it elf alone, or to be alwaies a caue. For the vicious contitution of the Liver, of what kind oever you will uppoe it, doth not produce this affect in thoe that are come to ripenes of yeers, nor perhaps always in yong boys: and this our anwer in general to the argument: we proceed now in a like method to the confirmation of it.

Firt, Therefore we grant that this affect doth often follow other dieaes be they either acute or chronical, but not o much becaue they had hurt the anguiffical contitution of the Liver, as becaue they had left the outward parts cold and benummed the ingrafted Spirits exhauted. Although we may eaily admit the viciated liver to be able to foment the evil by reaon of the depraved anguification.

Secondly, We grant that this affect doth not only depend upon outward caues, but alo upon inward, namely the faults of the blood it elf; but
that all thee faults have their beginning from the Liver, that we flatly deny for the Reaons before alleadged.

Thirdly, We grant that the mole or ubtance of the Liver is augmented in this affect, but we deny that to be the firt eence of the Dieae, for the reaons above reheared, where we reject the organical vices from the primary eence of this evil. Yet we admit this and the like dieaes in a econdary eence of this affect, as we hal ee hereafter.

Fourthly, We grant that internal Medicines can both alter and purify the blood, but in the preent Affect they conduce to the cure, in this regard, principally, becaue they facilitate the ditribution of the blood to the outward members, attenuating the thicker and cutting the vicous parts thereof, and becaue they alo do impregnate the blood, with a copious and benign Spirit, whereupon it happens, that the implanted Spirits of the parts before languihing, are cherihed, augmented, and excited. In the mean time we acknowledge that general benefit which accrew to the whole body, by the purging of the blood, by iedge, vomit, urine, or any other ways of evacuation. Only this is it which we affirm, that the more pecifical part of the cure is wrought by way of alteration with the medicines aforeaid, as we have intimated already.

Fifthly, and latly, We grant that the opening the veins in the ears doth omewhat attenuate the blood, and conduce to the renovation of it, as alo to the ditribution of it to the external parts, and the withdrawing of it from the internal parts oppreed with too much plenty, and in that repect very much to advance the cure yet we deny that it can from thence be rightly inferred that the firt Eence of the dieae is radicated in the
Liver. And thus we uppoe we have atisfied the reaons brought for the confirmation of this opinion. We wil now produce ome arguments that eem to perwade the contrary.

The firt is this, The firt Eence of a dieae doth Specificate the Dieae. But the vitiated anguifical contitution (however it be conceived) doth not pecificate this Dieae. For eing that this Dieae doth appertain to infants only and children; it behoveth them who adhere to the contrary opinion to deign ome certain way of the depraved anguifical Contitution of the Liver, which may be proper to the tender age alone, but no depravation of the anguifical Contitution of the Liver can be imagined, which is not alo common to thoe of ripe years. If therefore the firt Eence of this Dieae hould conit in that, this Dieae would at leat ometimes be oberved in thoe of ripe years, which notwithtanding hath never been hitherto oberved.

Secondly, The ubject of the firt eence of a Dieae is o long affected with that Eence, as the Diea continueth. For neither can the Diea Exit without its Eence, neither can that Eence wander from one part to another: If therefore the Liver be the ubject of the firt Eence of this Diea, then hould it be affected thorowout the whole progres of the Diea; which nevertheles doth not eem credible, eeing that the Livers of thoe who have died of this Diea, and have been diected, have excepting the augmented bulk thereof, been een inculpable in repect of the other conditions.

Thirdly, If the Liver be the ubject of the firt Eence of this Diea, necearily it is, that upon the dayly increae of the Dieae that hould be more grievouly and evidently afflicted, and before death certainly it hould be marked by ome manifet igns. For eeing
that every Dieae is contrary to the nature of that part it beiegeth, and doth dayly more and more damnify and empair it: And although the beginnings of Dieaes are many times obcure, yet in proces of time (epecially if they continue till the lat day of life) they imprint mot evident marks in the parts primarily affected; o that it can carce be avoyded, but that upon the opening of the body they will be apparent to the firt ight: although alo when an enquiry is appointed into ome Chronical Diea, by diection of the body that perihed by it, the finding of it out be grown difficult by reaon of ome other intervenient Dieaes, or otherwie complicated: Yet the part firt affected is ever oberved to be grievouly and manifetly hurt. Seing therefore in thoe whom this Diea hath detroyed, the Liver is oftentimes ound, excepting the augmented bulk, or at leat not coniderably hurt, it will be to infer, that that bowel is not the ubject of the firt Eence of this Diea.
