Fourthly, If the liver were the ubject of the firt eence of this dieae, it hould labor under a cold and moit ditemper, and alo under a penury and benummednes of pirits, as is ufficiently manifet from what hath already been poken. But in this preent affect the liver doth not always labor under a cold ditemper, nor with a penury and tupefaction of pirits. For in this affect the vital blood being paringly ditributed to the outward members, it mut needs be uperabundantly poured upon the bowels, epecially the brain and the liver; and eeing this blood, which is circulated thorow the bowels o neer the heart, is made very hot and ful of pirit: as even now iuing out of the fountain of the vital pirits, it is impoible that it hould permit a cold
ditemper, or any defect of pirits to be in thoe parts, which it watereth with o copious an afflux.
Fifthly, In this affect we often behold the face to be wel coloured, & the cheeks ruddy, which can carce happen in a cold ditemper of the liver if it be of any continuance.

Sixthly, From a bad habit of breeding blood in the liver; a ufficient reaon cannot be rendred of the ymptoms proper to this affect, a Cacotrophy indeed, or a vitious nourihment, and an Atrophy, or a defective nourihment: nay many times and peradventure not unjutly be acribed to the fault of the liver: but an Alogotrophy, or a diproportional nourihment cannot immediately be referred to that bowel, For the liver maketh the blood equally and without difference, for al the parts; neither is it liberal to our part in the dipenation of it, and reerved to another. Moreover the debility of all the mucles, the dilike of exercie, the affectation of ret, eemeth to have no correpondence with the Liver, wherefore neither do we acknowledge the Liver to be the firt eat of this dieae.

Seventhly, This dieae in trong children is cured ometimes, only by exercie, play, tirring, and rubbing of the body; by which means the heat is ummoned to the outward parts, new pirits are raied up, the tupefaction of them is chaed away, and the aliment is with a more plentiful benignity drawn to the outward members, which benefits without doubt are more properly accommodated to the outward parts then to the Liver.
And this quetion being thus olved, we proceed to the other; namely,

p.hi: Whether the Lungs be the ubject of the firt Eence of this dieae?

div.p:
The ymptoms which eem to perwade the affirmative, are the frequent narrownes of the breat, the difficulty
of breathing, an atma, a cough, the inflamation of the Lungs, the hard wellings of the Lungs, the impotume in the Lungs and the Ptiick. Firt, The narrownes of the breat doth not preently arie from the very beginning of the diea, & therfore cannot be atteted to be of the firt Eence of this Diea, in like manner the difficulty of breathing & the atma do not perpetually accompany this affect, and therefore an indication of the part firt affected cannot be borrowed from them. Thirdly, the cough is ometimes preent, ometimes abent, and is often times variouly intended and remitted, til the eence of the dieae periteth in the ame tate; which alo happeneth from very many of the aforeaid ymptoms. Fourthly, An inflammation of the Lungs doth not frequently molet the patient, and when it invadeth him, it is an acute and not a chronicle dieae; as this, whereof we now peak, o that we cannot lawfully conclude any certainty of the firt affected part from a ymptom o unuual and o Fugitive. Fifthly, Hard wellings of the Lungs, little wellings, impotumes; yea, and bunches may precede, aociate, and follow after this affect, but thee dieaes are altogether of a different kind from that we now peak of; yea, and are common as well to men of ripe years as to children, and infants: moreover the Ptyick doth not uually uperveen unles after a long continuance of this affect, as being far from the firt Eence of this Diea; and that it may manifetly appear to be very remote from the firt eteem of it, o that can confer little or nothing to the finding out of the part affected. Moreover, thoe ineparable and vulgar ymptoms of this Diea, as the impotency of the external parts to motion, and the inequality of nutrition, can by no reaon be deduced from the affected Lungs: and therefore we cannot admit this
Bowel for the firt eat of this Diea. And thus at length we decend to point out the parts firt affected.

The pecial marrow iuing out of the skull doth eem to deerve the firt place: The econd, all the Nerves produced by it; the third all the membranous and fibrous parts unto which thoe Nerves are carried along. And in thee parts we affirm the firt eence of of this diea to be rooted, neither do we think it needful to joyn other parts with thee. For the oftnes, loones, and Atony of the whol Spine without the Skul, of all the Nerves ariing from thence, of all the Fibers of the Univeral Body, and by that means an inability to motion, a lothfulnes and affectation of ret, which bewray themelves from the very beginning of this affect, do abundantly evince thee parts to be affected with coldnes, defect and benummednes of Spirits, and from hence it comes to pas that they are extenuated and afflicted with an incompetency of nourihment. For they do omewhat communicate their benummednes to the tops of the Arteries, whereupon the Flux of blood that is detributed unto them, uffers diminution; and becaue they are cold and labor under a defect of Spirits, they imperfectly concoct the affued blood, o that there is a neceity that they mut be unduly nourihed and les than the other parts, and by conequence be extenuated. Therefore we jutly and deervedly acribe the firt eence of this Diea to thoe parts alone.

Yet it may be here doubted whether the bones may not alo be numbred among the parts firt affected, eing that certain tumors of the bones may be oberved preently after the firt invaion of the Diea in divers places, but epecially in the appendancies of the Bones to the Wrets and tops of the Ribs, where they are conjoyned
with the grizles of the Stern?

We anwer, That indeed it cannot be denied, but that the aid tumors of the bones, both in repect of the encreaed greatnes, and alo by reaon of the viciated figure are really and truly Dieaes, and therefore we grant that the bones mut be referred to the primary or econdary eence of the Diea: but that they do not pertain to the primary eence of the Dieae is manifet from hence, Becaue the aid tumors of the bones depend upon the firt eence of this Diea, and uppoe the preexitence of it. For they pring from the unequal nourihment of the parts which is a Symptom of the firt eence of this Diea. But here the inequality of the nourihment can depend upon the firt eence of this Diea, hall more fully be declared in its due place; namely, where the reaon of the econdary eence is to be rendred. We will only here hew that thoe wellings of the bones are rightly deduced from the improportionate nourihment, to wit when in repect of the ret it is too much augmented in the welling parts. That is proved by this argument, Becaue the protuberant part of the bones are altogether of the ame Species with the other parts of the bones; whereupon it is neceary, that they come out by the ame way of generation, by which the ret are augmented and encrea. Therefore eeing that the other bones are augmented by nutrition, that is, by the introumed aliment, and the aimilation of it, certainly we mut judg that thee bones alo acquire their augmentation by the like reaon (although without reaon, meaure and proportion) You will ay, That tumors are uually generated not of an alimentory or good, but a corrupt and vicious juyce. True it is indeed that this is for the mot part true, but as true it is that it is only for the mot part true. For
ome tumors well from a legitimate and alimentary juyce, as caruncles or little pieces of fleh, knobbed wellings, and perhaps ome hard bunches, but even thee wellings do alo differ much from the preent tanding out of the bones. For thoe tumors which we ue to call excrecences, have omewhat in them without the habit of the part and in the whol kind beide nature: but thee tumors do not grow without the habit of the part, neither do they include or contain any other preternatural thing beide the ole magnitude diproportionately encreaed, and by that means the viciated figure of the parts. For otherwie thee wellings hould not be of the ame Species with the ret of the Bone, to which they are continued, but that is repugnant to the experience of the ences.

If therefore it be granted that ome tumors (even among thoe which are altogether preternatural and conit without the habit of their body) are generated of alimentary juyces, certainly much les hard is it to be undertood that thee wellings of the bones are generated and formed of the legitimate matter of the bones, by the inherent nutritive faculty. And this is clearly confirmed by this, becaue the bones according to their imilary nature are by no means legitimately produced by an illegitimate matter, that is, an indipoed and diagreable matter to the other imilary bones. Ex quolibet ligno non fit Mercurius, Every natural agent dipoeth the matter before it can introduce the form. It is neceary alo that the matter o dipoed be legitimate. Now the matter of the welling bones is manifetly dipoed; for otherwie it could not actually receive the pecifical form of a bone. Moreover that thee tumors of the bones are generated by the nutritive faculty is likewie evident, becau in all our body there is
not any other oifical vertue beides that nutritive Faculty inherent in the bones themelves, becaue alo thee tumors are generated and augmented by the introumed aliment, and aimilated by the bones themelvs: although perhaps in repect of the whole Bone this reception of the aliment may be unequal, and a ufficient caue of error in the nutritive faculty, whereby one part of thoe Bones may be too paringly nourihed, and another part too plentifully even to a tumor.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the Secondary Eence of this Diea.
div.p:
THe firt and Radical Eence of this Diea, and alo the parts firt affected being explained, now in the next place the Secondary Eence; namely that which immediatly followeth this Diea, offereth it elf to our examination. And here we mut refreh the memory by an intimation of that threefold Contitution already aerted, the Natural, the Vital, the Animal, and thorow thee particular Contitutions, hall our examination proceed. And firt we will conider the Natural Contitution. This as we have taught above coniteth in the Temperament, common qualites, the plenty and dipoition of the Natural Spirits, in the Organization, and continuity: now we have already proved, that the firt Eence of this affect is radicated in the Temperament, and in the plenty and dipoition of the Natural Spirits: but the other
parts of this Contitution, to wit, the common qualities, the Organization, and the continuity do yet remain to be examined.

By Common Qualities we undertand in a manner the ame which ome others have called the Modos Materiae, and others, Qualitates Secundas. Now we cal them Common, becaue they are not retrained to any one Element or Form; but in ome ort may expiate and range thorow all the Bodies, and for the mot part affect them more or les. Of this ort are denity, rarity, conitence, fluidnes, tenacity, friability, laxity, tenion, (or rather tenity, that the habit may be ditinguihed from the action) witherednes, welling, and tifnes, oftnes, hardnes, moothnes, roughnes. But it is not our meaning, exactly to reckon up all and each of the Common Qualities, nor to proecute thoe already reheared, further then the preent occaion hall require.

The Tone or Harmony of the Parts doth eem to reult from ome Common Qualities mutually embraced among themelves. For the Tone of the Parts properly coniteth in a du tenor and mediocrity between certain oppoite Common Qualities, as between thicknes and thinnes, &c. But if there be a reces or departure from the jut mediocrity to either of the extreams, then there is a neceity that the Tone mut be vitiated. Two things therefore do here eem to be enquired after concerning the Tone of the Parts; the firt, whether in this Diea the Tone of the Parts be in any degree vitiated. The next, Whether thoe faults of the Tone do belong to the econdary Eence of the Diea.
As concerning the firt, It wil be unneceary to run thorow the particular Parts of the Tone everally, it will be ufficient to examine thoe that eem guilty of the upected crime.

Firt, Therefore we meet with an evident loones of the Tone in this affect: But this loones differeth both from the infirm coherence, and likewie from the Paralytical reolution of the Parts: for the infirm coherence or weakned tifnes of the part is eaily made an occaion of the loones, becaue in uch caes the Part can carce be tretched forth; but a part may at the ame time be both looe, and likewie ufficiently tiff, as may be een in the trings of Intruments, which if you wind down the pins, they become looe, although in the mean time they forgo not the tenacity of their ubtance. And in diected bodies we have frequently oberved the looe parts themelves to be ufficiently tiff; yea, and that ometimes in this affect. Wherefore this loones is a ditinct quality from the vitiated tifnes of a Part. Neither doth it les differ from that reolution of the Parts which happeneth in the Paralytical Members. For the dead Paly firt coniteth in the depraved Animal Contitution: But this loones is rooted in the Natural Contitution. For here is no Paly preent either in repect of motion, or in repect of the ence of the Parts: Neither is the Brayn in this Diea primarily affected, as we have already demontrated. Moreover that there is uch an exceeding loones of the Parts firt affected, in this Diea is a thing o conpicuous, that we judg it a uperfluous employment to offer proof thereof. For it is obvious to the very enes, and therefore we have lited it among the igns of the Diea. For whether it be a Part of the Eence or not a Part, if it be manifetly ubjected to the Senes, it acquireth the propriety of a ign in repect of the other Parts of the Eence, which are removed from the Senes.

Secondly, In this Diea there is not only a loones but likewie a witherednes, and feeblenes. Now this
quality comprehendeth omwhat more then the meer and imple loones; for it denoteth withal a certain emptines of the parts, wherby they ink down of themelves. Now uch an emptines, and uch a falling down of the Parts firt affected in this Diea are o obvious to the Senes, that there is no need of further proof.

Thirdly, A a oftnes alo may be named in the Tone of the Parts firt affected in this Diea. For ometimes it o falleth out that there is no coincidence between the oftnes and the aforeaid qualities; but that it includeth or excludeth ome other thing, as in a uppurated Tumor there is oftnes, but without any laxity of the Tone, any emptines or ubidence. For in this preent uppoed cae the oftnes chiefly dependeth upon the manner of Termination, and the tenacity of the Part being vitiated. But in this affect there is for the mot part a coincidence with the laxity and flaccidity before mentioned: So that it is needles to ditinguih it more accurately then by the name only.

Fourthly, There happeneth alo another fault in the Tone of the Parts firt affected in this Diea, and this is an extream inward lipperines. Some perhaps may wonder what the meaning of thee words may be, Internal lubricity. We confes indeed that for want of words we have been contrayned to joyn this appellation. For when in nature uch a quality as hath a true exitence hath by the overight of Philoophers, and alo the neglect of Grammarians wanted a name, we have taken o much liberty to our elvs, as in repect of the great vicinity which it hath with the uperficial lubricity of the body to give it the ame Name, with the ditinctive Epethite of Internal. In natural bodies therfore we acknowledg a twofold lubricity; one External and Superficial which indeed coniteth in the moothnes and equality of the
Parts of the Superficies, by reaon whereof the Subject of it doth eaily lide by other bodies which it lighteth upon without much attrition and reitance, Now contrary to this lubricity, is the Superficial roughnes: but thee two qualities have no reference to this place, becaue they are Organical, neither do they any way belong to the Tone of the Parts. That other lubricity whereof we began to make mention, conits in that internal, profound and imilary moothnes, and equality of the body. By reaon wherof, the whole ubtance of its Subject doth eaily lide by the other introubient bodies without much attrition and reitance. And to this lubricity alo there is an Internal roughnes. Now that there is uch an internal imilary lipperines, and uch a roughnes alo oppoite unto it may be hewed almot by innumerable intances. For almot all mucilaginous ubtances are lippery, and that not only in repect of the outward Superficies, but alo inwardly, and in repect of the univeral Subtance, and every particle thereof; o that, according to the definition of a imilary body, every particle, by reaon of this quality is made like unto the whol, and therfore this quality is internal, and imilary, and diffued through the whol internal ubtance of the Subject. In like manner uch an internal roughnes may be oberved in unripe fruits, extentended thorow their whole ubtance and Internal fleh. But when they have attained to a jut ripenes then uually, in the room of that roughnes there ucceedeth uch a lipperines as we have now decribed. And here it mut be oberved, that if thee bodies internally lippery be bemeared or daubed upon the Superficies of bodies otherwie rough, they bequeath a certain degree of lubricity to them, for the time they adhere in like manner being inwardly taken as the lippery
juyces, and mucilages of Althea, &c. They do communicate a certain lubricity to the Internal paages of the Body; yea, and not only to the paages that relate to the inward cavities, but alo more or les to the very Similary ubtance of the parts of the Body, which alo the blood waheth being impregnated with that lippery juyce.

But this internal lubricity is manifold: oyly or fat, watrih, piritous, altih, and perhaps earthy. The oyly is chiefly conpicuous in the fat of Creatures, epecially uch as are yong, and in many expreed Oyls, epecially the moiter and colder, and alo the temperate; as may be oberved in the Oyls of Poppy Seeds, Pippin Seeds, the four greater Cold Seeds, Time Seed, and the Oyl of weet Almonds, and the like. A watrih lubricity is in ome meaure found in imple water it elf, although by reaon of the fluidnes it is les enible; alo this lubricity may mot evidently be taken notice of in the mucilages, &c. The Spiritous perhaps doth never happen alone, but it is mot frequently mixt with the waterih, as in the perm of almot all Creatures, and ripe fruits. The Saltih likewie is rarely imple, although there is a man that contendeth it is to be found in alt of Tartar. But the compound altih lubricity is frequently obvious, as in Soap and Salt of Tartar diolved with waterih and oyly ubtances. The Earthy (even mixt) is carce worthy of obervation, unles it be in repect that it concurreth to the thickning of fluid bodies, as in white clayih Mud, and Fullers Earth diolved. But in this place we have regard chiefly to that lubricity which is waterih, as being that alone which can be guilty of the crime in this affect we now handle,

And thee things may uffice in general of the internal
or imilary lubricity. The next enquiring mut be whether the firt affected parts of this Diea be affected beyond a due proportion with an internel or imilary lubricity. And at firt indeed it eemeth very probable that there is uch an extream lubricity in the aid parts, becau moiture doth uperabound in them, which ever favoreth the aid lubricity, be it conjoyned either with heat or cold. Every one knoweth that the Sperm of Creatures by how much it is moiter than the creatures produced by it, by o much alo it is the more lippery: in like manner that the yong fleh of Creatures is more lippery than that of old. Seeing therefore that humidity and lubricity of this kind are o inwardly converted: Seing alo that in the parts firt affected there is manifetly an extream humidity, certainly it may eaily be granted that a lubricity likewie doth too much abound in the aid parts. And to the production of this the benummednes of thoe parts have no mall hare. For the Spirits when they are in their exaltation contract a kind of acrimony and harpnes, as may be een by comparing Mut with old Wine, or with Spirit of Wine or with Aqua vitae. For the Spirits of Mut may truly be aid to be benummed or tupified, if they be compared with the Spirits of old Wine; and by how much more they are tupified, o much more lubricity they likewie contain, and alo o much the les of harpnes and acrimony. From whence it is manifet that that benummednes and dulnes in the Spirits lodging in the firt affected parts doth favor that extrem lubricity; for that dulnes of the Spirits in the aid parts is almot of the ame degree with the dulnes of the Spirits in Mut. And becau the Spirits are defective in the parts firt affected, it is evident that this lubricity is an over-watrih lubricity. Moreover, laxity, flaccidity,
and oftnes do alo eem to conpire. For unripe fruit as they are hard, o till they wax ripe they grow ofter and ofter, and withal acquire an internal lubricity; in like manner the parts are looned by relaxant baths, and together they become more lippery; alo lippery things taken inwardly, as the mucilage of Althea, &c. Do not only looen the Parts, but they alo make the paages lippery, for which cae in the pains of the tone they are drank with good juyces. Again, this lubricity of the firt affected parts, eemeth to be much confirmed by this, becaue in the diected Bodies a manifet lubricity is obervable by the touch; and if they be queezed a mucilaginous kind of blood, inwardly bemearing them, is cruhed out with the fingers. We ay nothing of the skin, which for the mot part is lippery in this affect, and is eldom felt to be rough to the touch: but it is worthy to be noted, that extream lippery Medicines either outwardly applyed, or inwardly taken, do uually more hurt then good in this Diea. And thus we abolve the former quetion, of the manner whereby the Tone of the Parts is vitiated in this Affect. The other now preents it elf to our conideration.

p.hi: Whether the Tone vitiated after that manner as hath been aid, be a Part of the Eence of this Diea?

div.p: We uppoe here that whatoever is found to be vitiated in the Body, is either a morbifical caue, or a Symptom, or the Diea it elf; and therfore this Diea either imple or compound, or any part of a compound, and that either primary or econdary.

We ay firt, That the vitiated Tone above propounded is not properly a caue of the Diea. And this carce need any proof. For the aid Tone is a preternatural Contitution, rooted in the Parts themelves, and by that reaon it is mot evidently ditinguihed from a
morbifical caue properly o called. For although, one Diea may be the caue of another, nevertheles even then it is not properly called a morbifical caue, but a primary Diea, and that other which it produceth, a a econdary affect. But every where there is a growing together of them both into one total Diea, the former wil be the primary Part of the Eence, and the latter the econdary part of the Eence.

Secondly, We affirm, that the decribed Tone of the Parts is not a meer Symptom, for it is not under the things ecured and retained, neither can it be comprehended under any depraved action, or any changed quality, not vitiating the action. But that the vitiated Tone is not comprehended under the things ecured and retained, nor under any depraved action, may by the ame labor be proved by this Reaon, becaue thoe kind of Symptoms are not indeed Contitutions of the body; but the aid vitiated Tone without controvery is a preternatural changed contitution, as we have already mot playnly demontrated. Secondly, That the aid Tone vitiated after that manner, is not contained under any changed quality, not depraving the action, is o clear and evident, that it needs no proof. For laxity and flaccidity hurteth the motion of the Parts, and an extream lubricity is an impediment to the du quickning of the vital Spirits, as hal hereafter be made manifet.

It may be Objected, That ome bare changed qualities which are comprehended under the Genus of Symptoms, may alo vitiate an action: as the colour changed in the skin yeeldeth an unpleaant propect to the beholder, o that it begetteth deformity and defect of du comlines?

We anwer, That the changed colour of the Skin in as much as it vitiateth the beauty therof (which is the proper action of the Skin) doth in rigor (in a large
acception) fall under the Notion of a Diea. But eing this action of the Skin is only Objecture and Ad extra, and eing that altered color doth hurt no Internal action of that individual: Phyitians, who in the definition of a Diea, have repect only to the Internal actions of that individual, do uually exclude it from the Clais of Dieaes. Or if the vitiated color of a part do chance in ome place to deprave an internal action (which is known only to happen in the Tunicle of the Eye, called Corura) the bet Phyitians do ever reckon it for a Diea, although perhaps econdarily. But that we may return into the way from whence we have a little erred: eing that the vitiated Tone may hurt, as we have aid, the internal actions, it doth not properly belong to that kind of Symptom, which is wont to be called by the name of a changed quality.

Thirdly we ay, That this vitiated Tone, eing it is neither a Morbifical cau, nor a Symptom, and yet is omthing preternatural, mut needs be the Diea it elf. Moreover, the ame is clearly proved by the very definition of a Diea. For this vitiated Tone is a preternatural Contitution, primarily or immediatly hurting the internal action; therfore it is a Diea. For to what the definition is competible, to that alo the thing defined is competible. That it is a preternatural Contitution is manifet by this, becaue it is inherent in the olid parts of the body: that it likewie depraveth the Internal actions, is manifet from hence, becaue an extream laxity, lubricity, and flaccidity of the parts being granted, preently the agility is weakned, no other caue approaching, and a certain luggihnes deadeth the irritation of the vital Spirits. In agility, the matter is plain, eing that firm and tretched bodies, other things being anwerable are more active, and o on the contrary:
that the ame thing alo happeneth in the dulnes of the irritation hal be hewed in its place, for the preent we labor to prove no other thing then that the vitiated Tone in this affect is a Diea.

We ay fourthly, That this vitiated Tone in this Diea is not any imple affect, having an exitence apart by it elf, but that it is o conjoyned and compounded in thoe ame parts with the primary Eence, that the whole Eence of the Diea (wherof we dipute) may be aid to conit of many Dieaes united together (in themelvs indeed imple, if they be conidered aunder) and therfore that the vitiated Tone is only a part of the whol Diea. And this needeth no other proof, then becaue the firt Eence propoed above, and the aid vitiated Tone are both found in thoe ame parts. For that is properly called a compound Diea, which is produced by many imple Dieaes conjoyned in the ame Part.
Fifthly, We affirm that the vitiated Tone is not only a part of the whole Eence, but uch a part as hath ome dependance upon the primary Eence, and therfore that it is a econdary part of the Eence.
Before we proceed to the proof of this Propoition two grants or conceions are to be premied.

We grant firt, That the aid Tone may be even immediatly vitiated in other caues perhaps, and likewie by other caues, although that happen not in this preent Diea. For the inherent Tone of the Parts may be primarily looned in the Animal Contitution, and that uddenly, as may be oberved in the dead Paly. For the natural tenity (and not the Animal only) of the Paralytical member is looned, and indeed uddenly without any conpicuous intervention of any part of the aforeaid primary Eence. After the ame manner in a Lipothymy
or defection of the mind, loones and languihing uddenly attatcheth al the parts. Now we cannot in either of thee two caues refer the caue of the loones to the cold and moit ditemper of the natural Contitution, eeing that cannot be o uddenly and o enibly changed. Which let them conider (that we may give warning of it by the way) who wil have thee common qualities to be always econd and dependent upon the firt alone: yea, on the other ide let them in that caue oberve how a cold and moit ditemper doth afterwards by degree, follow that loones uddenly introduced. Again, as for the flaccidity of the parts that may be immediatly produced by large evacuations, as a flux of the belly, weatings, and the like immoderate vents, the temperament being not yet coniderably changed, although we deny not but this may eaily and doth uually follow. Moreover an internal lubricity may be manifetly eparated from coldnes, though very difficultly from moiture.

Secondly, We grant that in the preent Diea, the vitiated Tone doth not in any manner depend upon the firt admitted Eence, nor that in every repect is ubordinate unto it. For firt the qualities of the Tone here vitiated, do alo ow omwhat to common caues, namely to themelves, and alo to thoe that are common, to the firt granted Eence. For extream moitening things by one and the ame operation are apt to produce both too much moiture, and alo loones. In like manner from violent evacuations, a want of Spirits, and withal a witherednes doth arie. Alo from things too too lippery, either outwardly adminitred, or inwardly tataken, or both, an internal lubricity is augmented, together with a moit ditemper. For there is o great a connexion of the whole Eence, hitherto propounded
with the common caues, that there is carce any thing which doth augment the firt eence of the Diea, but at the ame time more or les it hath an influence upon the vitiated Tone.

Thee things bring granted, We ay notwithtanding that in the preent affect there is a very great dependance of the vitiated Tone upon the firt Eence of this Diea; for which repect alone we have here referred the vitiated Tone to the econdary Eence. If any lit to contend, That the aid Tone in another repect may relate more clearly to the Secondary Eence, becaue he may imagine that the primary Eence of every Diea is necearily imilary and perpetually grounded upon the firt qualities alone; or becaue he may conceive that the qualities wherein the Tone coniteth are perpetually econdary, and that they follow the firt only (as the hadow doth the Sun) that man may take notice that we purpoely decline uch quetions, leat we hould traggle into an unwarrantable digreion.

It remaineth therefore only that we prove the Dependance of the vitiated Tone upon the firt Eence of this Diea to be very great, and that we hal do by parts. We wil begin at the laxity. We grant indeed that a laxity may be omtimes uddenly produced, and in that caue a moyt ditemper may often follow upon it, Namely, when the laxity primarily dependeth upon the fault either of the Animal or Vital Contitution; but in this Diea, eing that neither the Animal nor the Vital Contitution are primarily affected, there is a neceity that it mut flow from other caues. Moreover, uch is the condition of laxity and tenity, that they are obnoxious to udden alterations. For the trings of a Lute may almot in a moment be tretched and looned again; the ame thing likewie from ome caues befalleth the Fibers
of the Parts, But in this affect the laxity tealeth on by degrees and lowly; therfore neceary it is that it mut begin, be ruled and moderated by ome cau leiurely and lowly augmented. Although therfore we granted even now, that the laxity doth own omwhat to the common caues of the Diea; yet the augmentation therof is chiefly retrained and moderated by the primary Eence of this Diea. For moitning Medicines although they looen withal, yet they carce looen more than they moiten, becau for the mot part they looen by moitning. Seing therfore that the common caues of this Diea do flow into the Tone, chiefly by the Mediation of the firt Eence of this Diea: And eing that neither the Animal nor the Vital Contitution can here upply the vertue of a cau, we may Lawfully infer that the laxity of the Tone doth chiefly depend upon the firt Eence of the Diea. This is further confirmed, there is of it elf a certain prones and tendency of the Body to be through wet, o that the fibers of the parts mut needs be looned by it: Moreover, the defect of the Spirits and the tupefaction of them doth cau a remiion of the Tone by diminihing the vigor of the part. Therfore we may conclude that the Diea, laxity principally dependeth upon the primary Eence of the Diea. As for the flaccidity becaue it comprehendeth the laxity, it pringeth from the ame caues as that doth; but in as much as it includeth alo a ubidence and a certain emptines, it evidently dependeth upon the defect and benummednes of the inherent Spirits; the plenty and vigor whereof being augmented the lank and flagging member is eaily rendred turgid and welled. In the interim we deny not but that that ubidence doth withal depend upon the extenuation and atrophy of the parts.
Latly, How the lipperines doth proceed from thee caues is ufficiently manifeted by what hath been aid above.

That we may at the length put a period to this matter, it may be oberved for the higher confirmation of thoe things already poken that there is uch a trict dependance between the Tone and the firt granted Eence, that throughout the whol cure of the Diea they are intended & remitted together almot in equal pace. For at firtthe Children that are afflictedwith this affect; do only go lowly & leiurely whilt the Tone of the parts is yet but a little looned; but in the progres they carce and with much ado trut to their feet, then they play only itting or as thay are carried about. Afterwards they can carce it upright; and at the lat when the Diea hath attained the highet exaltation, the feeble neck cannot without much difficulty upport the burden of the head; all which things as they attet the primary Eence of the Diea to be gradually augmented, o alo they make it manifet that the vices of the Tone are intended by an equal pace. And o all thee things being rightly weighed, we refer the viciated Tone to the econdary, not the primary Eence of this affect, and by conequence we conclude, indeed the thing that was in quetion, that that depraved Tone is a econdary part of the Eence of this Diea.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. The Secondary Eence of this Dieae in the Vital contitution.
div.p: WE have already propounded that part of the Secondary Eence of this Diea which is radicated in the natural contitution, in as much as it comprehendeth the common qualities; it remaineth now that we examin the organical vices, and the faults of continuity, if any uch be found out. But eing that no proper faults of continuity do accur in this affect, and eing that the organical vices do depend partly upon the Eence above given, and partly upon the vital contitution being viciated, it eems neceary in the next place to earch into thee faults of the vital contitution.
The vital contitution is aptly ditinguihed into the original, or that which maketh an influx, and the participative or that which is produced by that influx.

The ubject of the original vital contitution are the Spirits themelvs excited in the blood of the Arteries. You will ay, The heart rather eemeth to be the ubject of this contitution. But it is not o, for the heart it elf through the coronary Arteries receiveth the vital Spirits brought down with the Arterious blood from its left Ventricle. But it is aburd to uppoe the wals of the Heart to be the firt ubject of the vital heat, and in the mean time for thoe to receiv that heat from the Arteries. We mut ay therfore that the olid ubtance
of the heart is indeed the firt & principal ubject of his natural and inherent contitution; but eing that receiveth the Vital Spirits (as hath been aid) it cannot be accounted the firt ubject of the Vital Contitution, which is imprinted in it by thoe Spirits, and continueth no longer than the ubtance of the Heart is hedded and beprinkled with the Vital Spirits. For neither can life ubit in any place without the Vital Spirit. Wherfore the ubtance of the Heart doth o far participat of the Vital contitution, as it is wah'd and bedew'd with the Vital Spirits, and by Conequence tha • Contitution in the ubtance of the heart is not original or influent, but participative or produced by that influx. This is alo confirmed in that, becau the vital heat of the blood in the hollow Parts, or Ventricls of the Heart (which heat is at leat a part of the Vital Contitution) is for greater and more inteniv than that which is within the wals of the Heart, as any man may oberv by the opening of the Bodyes of living Creatures, the Ventricle of the heart being wounded, and the Finger preently thrut in. For he hall feel a far more augmented heat in the blood, than in the very ubtance of the Ventricle, however it be handled. Moreover the vital Contitution is a thing tranient and coniteth (as the Phyloophers Phra is) in motu & fieri; therfore it is rooted. In the movable and decaying Spirits (uch as the Vitals which are contained in the Arterious Blood) for om Member being cut off, the Life vaniheth almot in a moment, and by Conequence the vital contitution: but the natural (as we have already ininuated) continueth (though not in uch an exaltation as when the Vital remaineth) for a while after death. And indeed the Life and the Vital contitution is uddenly taken away in the cae aforeaid not by any
poitive contrary Caue, But by a meer privation of the Conervant and Continent CAUSE. This is mot evidently confirmed, becaue the Vital contitution is uddenly intended, remitted and altered in al the parts in repect of the model or meaure of the Vital Contitution, excited in the Ventricles of the Heart, o in a Lipothymy, the heart fainting, the life of the parts preently vaniheth, at lat languiheth; but aoon as the Ventricles of the heart are refrehed with Spirits by ome proper cordial applications, traight way we behold the vital Contitution to be uddenly in ome meaure repaired in all the Parts. In the uppreion of the breath udden death followeth the torrent of the vital Blood from the right to the left Ventricle being intercepted. In the opening of a Vein or in any other immoderate profuion of Blood there happeneth a wouning by the ole defect of the Vital Spirits. Therefore eing the Vital contitution is tranient and fugitive in any of the olid parts, and eing it dependeth upon the proportion of the vital pirits flowing into them from the Ventricle of the heart, we may rightly infer that in the olid parts, it is not original but participative. But in the Vital Spirits themelves, by whoe function the Vital contitution is diffued and tranmitted into all the Parts, it mut necearily be original: For there is no other original ubject of it to be found in the Body.

Yet we grant that the olid ubtance of the heart by his Natural Contitution (epecially being watred by the Vital) is the aitant cau of the excitation of the Vital Spirits in the blood included their Ventricles, although it cannot be the firt ubject of that ame Vital Contitution, as we have even now abundantly proved. And thee things for the preent may uffice in general
concerning each vital contitution, the original and the participative, and to prov that that mut properly be acribed to the Vital Spirits, this to the olid Parts as the immediate Subjects of the inherence. Three kind of vices belonging to this Contitution do til await our examination: The two former wherof relate to the Original: And the third pertaineth to the participative Contitution. The firt vice concerneth the Generation of the Vital Spirits. The econd hath reference to the ditribution of them: And the third appertaineth to the participation of the Vital Contitution. Of thee we hal make enquiry in their order.

div.head: CHAP. IX. The vitiated Generation of the Vital Spirits in this Affect, and whether that fault be a Part of that Secondary Eence?
div.p: THe Vital Spirits are firt excited or generated within the Ventricles of the Heart; namely, in the very mas of the Blood, and properly they dicriminate the Blood in the Arteries, from that in the veyns, after that they are generated they are cherihed and conerved within the cavities of the Arteries, until they are ditributed into the habit of the Parts. Yea, they are not only cherihed in the Arteries, but in them alo rightly dipoed, perhaps om new ones are excited, though with les efficacy then in the heart.

We ay firt, That in the very Subtance of the heart
there doth not occur any fault repugnant to the Generation of the Vital Spirits, which properly can be a part, even of the econdary Eence of this Diea. For the heart it elf, for his doth rightly perform his function in this Diea: and if any imperfection happen in the Generation of the Vital Spirits, it cannot be properly acribed to the heart, but to the ineptitude of the matter, to receive the form of the Vital Spirits. As the ingeted aliment if it be extreamly crude, it may frutrate the perfection of a laudable concoction, the Stomach being otherwie ound and faultles: So the unapt and unprofitable blood exported to the ventricles of the Heart, may render the action therof imperfect, in repect of the operation and effect, how ound oever it may be in it elf: In which cae the acription of the fault is uually and truly attributed to the indipoed matter, and not to the Heart. You wil reply, a Feaver is omtimes complicated with this affect, and at uch time the heart doth unaptly Generate the Vital Spirits, But that Feaver is a Diea of a different kind, and by no means either the whol or any Part of the Eence of this affect.

Secondly, We affirm that the leer Arteries inerted into the firt affected Parts, are in ome degree really cooled and benummed by them, through their adjacency and contact, and for that cau they do unaptly conerv the Vital Spirits contained in them, wherupon the Vital Contitution of them is rendred omwhat imperfect, before they can be effued into the Parts themelvs. And this fault of the little Arteries eemeth by very good right to be acribed to the Generation of the vital Spirits. For although it be not the function of the Arteries to propogate the Vital Spirits according to the firt ignification of the word; yet for this very reaon,
that they are obliged to conerv them when they are propagated, namly by uch a conervation as in a manner includeth a certain continuate Generation of them, their faults are rightly to be referred to the Generation of the Vital Spirits. For the Vital Contitution is a certain tranient action (as we have hewed before) which, while it lateth, is in a continual flux and motion, and which like a flame, when the continual fomentation and reparation of it is upended and uppreed, uddenly extinguihed. Therfore are the Arteries as a continuate Heart to all the parts of the body, unto which they tranmit and powr out their contained Spirits; and what faults oever of the Spirits happen before the effuion of them into the habit of the Parts, eing that they necearily belong to the Original Vital Contitution, and cannot otherwie be acribed to the ditribution of the Spirits, they mut be referred to the very Generation of them; namely, a continuate Generation in the Arteries, wherby they are continually preerved from a udden extinction.

Moreover, This fault of the Vital Spirits is the depravation of the Vital and Original Contitution, and eing that it is omwhat preternatural, firt hurting the action, from whence the participative contitution, floweth in like manner depraved, and eing that it meerly dependeth upon the primary Eence aforeaid and is complicated in the ame parts, it will be a part of the econdary Eence of this Diea.

Thirdly, We ay that the matter of the Vital Spirits, to wit the Blood of the Veins impregnated with his Natural pirits returning in his circulation from the firt affected parts towards the Heart, is omwhat diabled by them to admit the form of the Vital Spirit. For it is neceary that the Blood, whilt it paeth
through the parts affected with a cold ditemper, want and benummednes of inherent Spirits, mut alo thereupon affected with ome kind of frigidity, benummednes, and perhaps with a thicknes and vicous quality beyond the uual degree of Nature. For as the blood doth give a tincture of his qualities to the parts thorow which it glideth; So on the contrary, the parts themelves bequeath alo as much as they can of their qualities to the flowing blood. But here likewie we mut grant withal that this indipoition in the parts firt affected (epecially when it is light and mal) in the return to the inward parts, is very much corrected by their heat, before it arieth at the Ventricles of the heart, nay that it is omtimes ubdued or if any uch contracted fault remain, it is commonly totally abolihed by the length of the journy before the return of the Blood to the left Ventricle of the heart, whilt it floweth down by the right, and the ubtance of the Lungs, the ame thing alo may be thus confirmed, becau if that indipoition hould continue till the return of the blood to the left Ventricle of the Heart, the whol mas of blood in the Arteries would become crude and imperfect; and eing that this blood thus abounding with imperfect Vital Spirits hould be tranmitted from the Aorta to al the Parts, it would more or les affect them al; which very rarely is oberved in this Diea. For the head, & many bowels, however om of them are found to be greater then ordinary yet they eem to be watered with a perfect Vital Spirit. But although, as we have aid, the light indipoition of the Blood may be corrected, before its return to the right ventricle, yet when the contracted fault is great and more coniderable, it cannot be altogether overcome, wherupon the Lungs in this Diea are commonly afflicted with the mot grievous Evil.
For, when the les Spiritous, and therefore the les paable Blood, is continually tranmitted thorow the Lungs, cold and thick, or vicous, in proces of time it mut needs more or les infect and obtruct the weaker parts of the Lungs; from whence proceed difficulty of drawing breath, a tubborn cough, hard tumors, inflammations, impotumes, and the Ptyick. Feavers alo both Erratick and Hectick, may from hence dirive their Origen. But eing that fault may be uddenly introduced from the firt affected parts, it is credible (although we have aid the Lungs are often infected by it) that it is for the mot part overcome, before the Blood can com to the left Ventricle. And this may be the reaon why the Head and the adjacent parts do look o well and flourihing, namely, becau neither the Natural nor the Vital Contitution is hurt in them, eing that the perfect Vital Spirits generated in the left Ventricle, and ditributed from thence, do excite that freh color in the face; when on the contrary the Lungs do oftentimes labor under the faults aforeaid, the viciounes of the Blood not being corrected before it enter the right Ventricle and the Arterious vein.

Moreover, This imperfect production of Vital Spirits in the right Ventricle of the Heart, by reaon of the crudenes of the affluent Blood, flowing in the Veins, totally appertaineth to the econdary Eence of this Diea, and mut be accounted a part of it: for the Vital Contitution is vitiated, wherupon the actions in the Lungs are depraved, and it dependeth wholy and in every repect upon the primary granted Eence, neither in the mean time, doth it reide in the olid Subtance of the Heart, that it hould therfore deerv the name of a a new diea.

Here we note by the way, That Phyitians in the cure
of this affect do ever intermingle uch things with their remedies as have repect to the benefit of the Lungs; and not without reaon, eing that it is apparent by what hath been aid, to how much danger that Bowel is continually ubject. And this may uffice concerning the faults in the Generation of the Vital Spirits: Now follow the faults of the ditribution of thoe Spirits.

div.head: CHAP. X. The vitiated Ditribution of the Vital Spirits in this Affect, and whether it be a Part of the Secondary Eence therof?
div.p: THis vitiated ditribution eemeth to conit in three things: Namly, in the Dimunition, Slownes, and the Inequality of it. The defective, and alo the low ditribution of the Blood and Spirits, may be een in ome one Part, and perhaps in all thoe that are firt affected: But the inequality cannot be oberved in any one, eing that it reulteth from a collation of a various wiftnes and lownes, greatnes and malnes of the torrent of the Blood in repect of the other parts. The defect and lownes of the ditribution: eing that they depend almot upon the ame caues in the preent affect, they may be handled together, and eing thoe differences are more imple then the inequality, the handling of them eemeth deervedly and jutly to be premied.

But firt we mut grant that the paages and circulation
of the Blood, thorow the firt affected parts is not very difficult in this affect. For although a cold ditemper, a want and benummednes of Spirits, do eem very difficultly to admit a tranition of the Blood thorow the parts affected, with thee qualities; yet indeed other conjoyned qualities; as moyture, loones, laxity, flaccidity, oftnes, and internal lubricity, can at the leat contribute as much power to facilitate the paage of it, as the qualities aforeaid can oppoe to the interruption of it. Yea, if you valu them by a jut etimation, perhaps they can do more, but we wil not in this place aert it, only we flatly deny the difficulty of the circulation to be greater. For, if we may compare hard bodies with oft, low bodies with traight, moit with dry, lippery with rough, we hal eaily perceiv that the circulation of the blood is much more quick and expedite in thoe, then in thee. And this is manifet in young Creatures in whom thoe qualities abound, in uch as are new born, although the Heart be very tender, the Arteries les firm, the pulificative vertu, yet feeble and weak, yet the paing too and fro of the blood are readily and eaily exercied; which in thoe that are older is not accomplihed without a tronger pule, and an indeavor or a kind of labor of the Heart and Arteries. Again, according to the opinion of Galen and Hippocrates, the Bodies of children are mot paible; namly, by reaon of their humidity, laxity, and oftnes. Beides, if we oberv the formation of the chicken in the eg, the matter wil be yet more plain. Within few days after the incubation the Heart of the chicken is enibly and evidently een to beat, and to begin the circulation of the Blood: but if at the ame time we conider the frailty of the Heart it elf, and how weak a coherence there is between the parts of it, til in the interim it finiheth the circulation of the blood according
to the manner of it, uch as it is we mut necearily grant that in that hapeles lump, moiture, and internal lubricity do expediate and facilitate that motion. Some perhaps may object that in thee cited caes the liberty and readines of the circulation of the blood, depends not o much upon the moiture, oftnes and lipperines, as upon the plenty of the inherent Natural Spirits. For in the Cachexia, Green icknes, and the dropy, the fleh is very oft, moit; and perhaps lippery, when in the mean time the tranition of the Blood is very difficult. We anwer, thoe Bodies that wax tender and oft by a paucity of inherent Spirits, are les indipoed, and more apt to admit the circulation of the Blood then the other parts. But it is not imply tru that uch bodies which mot abound with Spirits do perpetually obtain the mot expedite and unretrained circulation of the Blood: for the Blood is more eaily circulated in Fih, then in Creatures of the Land, as is manifet by the tender and frail Contitution of their Heart, and Arteries; yet they enjoy a les quantity of Inherent Spirits. But becaue they live perpetually in the waters, therfore is their fleh more moit and lippery. Whence it mot evidently appeareth how effectual the inward lubricity and moiture are to facilitate the paage of the Blood. As for thoe that are invaded with the Green icknes or afflicted with a Cachexia, we grant indeed that the circulation of the Blood is difficult in them, yet not only through a defect of inherent Spirits, but by reaon of tubborn obtructions lodging in the whol body. Wherefore it mut be granted, notwithtanding the cold ditemper, the penury, and tupefaction of the Spirits, which procure a difficulty to the circulation, that uch a Mediocrity is impoed upon it, by the moiture, oftnes, and internal lipperines, that the paage of the
Blood may be reduced to a jut, if not an extream facility. But if the moiture, oftnes, and inward lipperines be o coniderable to effectuate an eaie circulation of the Blood, Truly, the ditribution of it through the parts firt affected eemeth to be expected more wift and not more low. We anwer that the facility of the tranition of the Blood is oppoed to the lownes of the motion, or to the malnes of the paage. For a wift motion may be low, and in a mal Channel. But the facility is here oppoed to difficulty, triving, and labor, which in this cae, if the circulation were difficult, hould happen to the Artery in the paage of the Blood. But that the Arteries do undergo ome labor in expediting the circulation of the Blood into the firt affected parts, hall anon be demontrated; we only affirm in this place that the facility, of the paage of the Blood doth not ufficiently argue either the wiftnes of the motion, nor the widnes of the paage. For, two caues do chiefly conpire to haten the coure of the Blood through the habit of the parts. One is the aptitude of the part recipient, or that through which the blood ought to flow; and this caue is meerly paive and lothful: the other is the impulion of the Heart and Artery, and alo of the Arterious Blood contending to tretch and dilate it elf. This caue is active and full of vivacity. For upon the ceation of this impulion, the ditribution of the Blood will preently after totally ceae, however the paage may be otherwie uppoed to be mot eaie, manifet therfore it is that this impulion is the principal & active caue of the wiftnes and lownes, and alo of the quantity of the ditribution of the Blood. Wherfore thoe caues which do any way advance or hinder this impulion, do now come to undergo a more accurate examination.
For by thee we hall know whether the detribution of the Blood in the parts firt affected, be really more paring or low than is meet.

Thee caues do chiefly concur to excite that impulion. Firt, the plenty and activity of the Vital pirits contained in the Blood. Secondly, the perfect oundnes of the Heart. Thirdly, The firmitude, heat, and jut magnitude of the Arteries. Fourthly, An irritation both of the Heart and Arteries, whether extrinecally or intrinecally caued. Thee we will run over in their order, that it may appear in what condition they are in this preent Diea. Firt, As for the plenty and activity of the Vital Spirits, we have already hewed that in this affect the imperfect Vital Spirits are frequently excited in the right Ventricle of the Heart. Seing therefore that the Blood tainted with thee imperfect Spirits, mut be driven into the Lungs, there is a neceity the detribution mut there become more paring and low by reaon of the defect of the Spirits. Again, eeing that the vital blood, as we have alo hewed above, is omwhat cooled in the Arteries, which are terminated in the firt affected parts, it is neceary likewie that the paage of it through the aid parts mut be diminihed and more dull.
Secondly, The vertue of the Heart, unles peradventure by accident through the complication of ome other Diea, is eldom een to be viciated in this affect.

Thirdly, For o much as concerneth the Arteries, we cannot accue their condition of any notable defect in reference to their trength. But there is a manifet fault both in their heat and magnitude. Firt, in their heat, the Arteries inerted into the firt affected parts, mut necearily by their cold ditemper be omwhat affected with the like ditemper. For eing that a ditemper
of the parts firt affected is active and permanent, it is unavoidable but they mut more or les introduce a like quality into the parts o neerly bordering to one another, For natural agents are buily indutrious to aimilate all Bodies placcd within the Sphear of their activity, but epecially uch as are circumambient and neerly adjacent. But if any man doubt whether that coldnes of the Arteries can retard and leen the current of the Blood through the firt affected parts, let him conider that frigidity is of it elf an enemy to any kind of motion. For it is the quality of cold by its own Nature to arret Violences, and impetuous oppoitions, to condenate, to induce loth, to uperinduce Somnolency, tupefaction, and immobility, and when it attaineth a more intenive degree, to congeal and mortifie the parts. Therfore it mut needs cat a Remora to the torrent or the Blood waving through the parts affected with that quality. Beides, In the opening of a Vein we have often oberved upon the cooling of the member that the Blood hath flowed more lowly and paringly, and if the member be warmed again, or the pule be excited by rubbing or any other motion or means, that then the Blood floweth again with a more plentiful and liberal current. Moreover, the application of cold things is enibly effectual to top Blood preternaturally burting out of any part, as on the contrary, hot things do provoke the ebullition of it.

It may be objected, That the Pule is many times actuated and intended by the cold outwardly oppoed; as by the handling and playing with now, we ee that not only the Pule but the heat alo is augmented in the hands of thoe that port themelves with it.

We anwer, Cold things of themelves do alwaies move the paage of the Blood through the habit of the
parts; but that by accident they may intend the circulation of the Blood, if at length they provoke the pules of the Arteries (as in the aid cae of the now it happneth) to beat tronger marches. But this never comes to pas in this preent affect. For (as we have already hewed) the circulation of the Blood in this Diea, however it may uffer Immunitior or Retardation, yet it continueth ufficiently eay and expedite, neither doth any irritation of the pul arie from thence, as anon we hal perceiv more plainly. For eing it is manifet by what hath been aid, that the Arteries reaching to the firt affected parts, become more cold then ordinary, or is meet, we may eaily beleev that they become likewie more lender; o in any cooled member we ee the Veins and the Arteries become more lender then they were wont to be; and it cannot be denyed, but that actual cold doth traighten the Veels. But it is more then probable that a Potential coldnes (uch as perhaps that may be aid to be which is of an inward ditemper) doth likewie make the Veins and Arteries more lender. So we ee cold Complexions, and alo cold and moit, to have les Veins and Arteries then the hot. Corpulent bodies, women, children, have narrower Veels, then lean, men, or youths. Beides, the very heat it elf is an expanive quality, that it may enlarge the Veels, and cold a contractive quality, that it may retrain and traiten the Veels. Finally, one of us oberved that upon the diection of the Bodies perihing by this affect: He hath omtimes found the Veins, and the Arteries, tending towards the firt affected parts to be of an undue lendernes: but that thoe Arteries called Carotides, and the Iugulary Veins were diproportinatly amplified; and in is credible that this might have been perpetually oberved, had they that opened the bodies minded it with a
attentive contemplation. But this we peremptorily affirm not, but leave it to future inquiry: in the interim eing that it ufficiently appeareth by what hath been aid that the circulation of the Blood, in the firt affected parts is diminihed, it is likewie agreable to reaon, that the Veels alo of thoe parts are traitned. And eing that the left Ventricle of the Heart, doth pour o great a quantity into the Aorta as may uffice al the parts, and eing that o many parts primarily affected do paringly ip, that blood it is very probable that it is ditributed with an unuual liberality thorow the other parts, and namly thorow the Head and Liver, and therefore the Veels of thee parts are omwhat dilated and amplified. Concerning the lened circulation of the Blood in this affect: We ad this experiment only, a ligature being wound about the arm or thighs of a yong boy grievouly tormented with this Diea, the Veins did not o eaily wel beyond the ligature, neither did the habit of the part ful of Blood appear in that place o well'd and colored as it uually doth in thoe that are ound. From whence apparent it is, that the tranition of the Blood thorow thoe parts is more dul and les plentiful, then it ought to be as a river topped by a dam or wal doth ooner or later overflow the Banks, according to the various wiftnes and magnitude of the Torrent: So likewie it happneth here, the retiring of the Blood thorow the Vein, to the inward parts, is intercepted by the force of the ligature, which if it were violent, would in a hort time fil the Veins, and the habit of the parts beyond the ligature; as we ee it to happen otherwie in ound Perons; but becaue in this Diea it filleth them lowly, and very dully, we mut conclude that the circulation of the Blood in thoe parts is extreamly leened and low, and that the Arteries inerted into thoe parts are more
cold and lender then they ought to be, as we have mot abundantly proved, that the Arteries of the firt affected parts are vitiated by a defect of jut magnitude.

Fourthly, As for the irritation of the Heart and Arteries (which perhaps is the principle cau of many differences in the pules) it is manifetly found to be weak and ineffectual in the Arteries of the firt affected parts. We purpoe not at this time to dicoure of the nature, caues, differences and effects of irritation in the pules; only we oberv in general that it may be either natural or violent; and that each of them may be univeral or particular, and withal may arie either from within or from without. And latly, that it may be exceive or defective: In the handling of the preent Diea it wil uffice to touch upon the particular Irritation of the Arteries, and afterwards to accommodate our Dieaes to the preent buines. 1. Therfore, we affirm that the Arteries impel the Blood into the ubtance or habit of the parts, by a certain labor and contention; and that the parts which receiv that Blood do make om reitance and oppoition: that by reaon of this conflict the Arteries are Irritated to make tronger reitances or pules; and that that Skirmihing is of o great moment to fortify the pule and render it more vigorous, that when it is weak, the Pul can carce be trong: but where the contention is omwhat more increaed, yet o, that it doth not overcome the oppoition of the Arteries, the pule becomes more trong and lively, provided that no impediment from om other cau doth intervene. This we might illutrate by divers intances, but we wil exemplify it only in a few: in the winter the pules are more ful, hard, trong and contant, then in the ummer; but it is certain that at that time the outward parts of the body being bound up with cold, are more firm and les
paable, and therfore that they do more trongly then at other times reit the Blood, contending to pas thorow the ubtance of them in his circulation; wherupon the Arteries, when no other intervening matter hindreth, mut needs move more vigorouly, and drive the Blood more forcibly, if they perform their office in perfecting the circulation of the Blood. Hereupon thoe Arteries are irritated, unles they be totally uppret, or by ome other means charmed, and by degrees yeeld tronger trokes; and withal the Spiritous Blood being pent in & triving for more room they do wax a little more hot, and are omwhat enlarged, and omtimes having a little triumphed over the ubdued oppoition, they drive forward the blood into the parts, with a more wift & copious torrent then before. This is further confirmed by the heat augmented by handling now, for although at the firt the Hands wax preently cold, yet in a hort time after they grow hot, & withal they are died & colored with Blood, as the intenivenes of the heat doth jutify. For upon the firt contrectation or touch of the now the parts are bound up, and trongly reit the circulation of the Blood, the Arteries alo in thoe parts are at the ame time contracted But, unles the cold prevail to a total uppreion of the Spirits contained in thoe Arteries, and to a tupifying of the Arteries themelvs, or at leat a benummednes, thoe Arteries are by degrees irritated, and the interrupted Blood more forcibly contends for wider room, and o at length by this counteroppoition, the Arteries wax hot and are dilated, and the pul being increaed, they extrude the Blood more plentifully into the part before overcooled. On the contrary, in the ummer, when les reitance is oppoed againt the paage of the Blood, the pule becomes more feeble, more languid, and more oft. From whence it appears
that the defect of a du irritation, proceeding from the weak reitance of the parts which receav the Blood from the Arteries doth diminih the vigor of the pules.

Secondly, The ame is yet more evidently een when the Pule is augmented by the motion of the Body; for in any violent motion almot all the Mucles are tretched, by reaon wherof they omwhat more reit the paage of the Blood; hereupon the Arteries are provoked to contention, their heat is encreaed, and therefore more nimble, trong and full Pules are emitted.
Thirdly, As the inflamation of a part doth enibly irritate the Arteries thereof, o it exciteth a more vehement Pule and baueth a more liberal Flux of the Blood. The ame may be aid of pain.

Fourthly, Hither alo mut be referred the bruiing of any part. For a bruied part doth difficultly receive the Blood flowing to it: hereupon the Arteries provoked, they beat more trongly, and well the bruied part reiting them into a tumor. This might be demontred by many more examples, but we conceive thee to be very ufficient and atisfactory.

Moreover, It mut be noted that the parts caued by the reception of the Blood in the Arteries, may be very great, and yet not ufficient effectually to irritate the Arteries; in which cae it rather remitteth and diturbeth them, encreaeth, or facilitateth the force of the torrent of the Blood. For that oppoition of it elf interrupteth the channel of the Blood thorow the ubtance of the parts; but becau it doth withal irritate the Arteries to emit more lively trokes, it quickneth the torrent of it by accident. Wherfore we are here compelled into another involuntary digreion, by ditinguihing
between the reitance of the part that irritate, and that which doth not, or doth very little irritate the intances already alledged will uffice for the former, and to explain the latter we will ad a few.

Firt, Therefore there is a reitance that totally uppreeth the torrent of the Blood. Such a one is caued by a trong ligature, which doth altogether intercept the pule in thoe parts beyond it, neither yet doth it irritate the Arteries on this ide of it, becaue it overcometh all the force of the Artery beyond the Ligature and doth wholly break off the action thereof. The ame is een in the parts mortified with cold, or by other caues corrupted with an inflamation; and perhaps in ome hard wellings, contractures and ome confirmed wounds.

Secondly, There is a reitance preing down the Arteries even by the compreion of the Arteries, and this happeneth in a ligature indifferently bound. Alo in the compreion of an Artery by ome tumor in the adjacent parts as in a raw welling; alo in a compreion from any outward caue, many things which belong to the lying down on the right ide epecially, and the left are referred hither; o in tumors on the right ide, the lying on the left ide is many times endured with the leat patience by the compreion of the ound parts by thoe that are welled &c. and this compreion however it reiteth the circulation of the Blood, yet it doth not eem much to irritate the Arteries, becaue it doth no les intercept the very pulificative force, then it diminiheth the action thereof. Although perhaps it may omtimes irritate in the Lungs by reaon of their vehement heat, jut as it ueth to do in aching and inflamed parts.

Thirdly, There is a reitance in part repreing the
circulation of the Blood, but without compreion of the Arteries, nor yet totally uppreing them, nor very much irritating the Artery. Such an one occurreth in obtructions caued by cold, low, thick, and moit humors, which although they may omwhat retard the free paage of the Blood, yet they provoke the Artery very little, becaue at the ame time they uperinduce a certain benummednes in them, at leat a cold ditemper, as alo in the Blood which they contain. The ame almot may be aid of paralytical members, but that in thee a benummednes is more evidently introduced in their Arteries, and the channel of the Blood is les retarded in them,

Moreover, We affirm econdly that the parts firt affected in this Diea do not ufficiently irritate the Arteries, by which the Blood is ditributed through them. For although in thee parts, both by reaon of their olidity, and alo in repect of their coldnes, we grant ome kind of reitance, yet it is extream feeble and low, and very little provoking. Firt, becaue in thoe paris a moit is conjoyned with the cold ditemper, which of it elf tempereth and qualifieth all manner of provocations. Secondly, Becau there is a penury of inherent Spirits, which otherwie, where they abound, are wont to cherih the vigor of the Arteries, and the blood contained in them. Thirdly, Becaue thoe parts are loo, weak, and oft, and therfore more prone to receive with facility that which the Arteries end in, than to exaperate them by reitance. And that the Arteries do not conveigh the Blood by any vigorous and coniderable force into thee parts, is manifet by this ign, becau after the influx of the Spirits, and the Blood they till continue loo, oft and feeble, when on the contrary trong Pules are wont to render
the parts otherwie weak, ful, woln, and tiff, on a udden. Fifthly, becau the firt affected parts have in them a imilary lubricity. For as the uperficiary or external lubricity uffereth any thing to pas by, without attritition: o alo the Internal or imilary lubricity facilitates the circulation of the Blood, o that the paage is accomplihed with very mal oppoition. We conclude therfore that the proirritation of the Arteries is in this Diea deficient; and therfore that the Arteries are very dully and ineffectually excited to trengthen the pul.

Having at the length weighed al things which we propounded concerning the caues which actuate and advance the Blood in his circulation, it ufficiently appeareth, that the circulation of the Blood in this affect is eay and expedit enough, but that it is leened and paeth dully thorow the parts firt affected, both by reaon of the luggihnes of the Arterious Blood contained in the Artery of the aid parts, and alo becau of the defective heat, and lendernes of thoe Arteries; and finally, in regard of their ineffectual irritation. And let thee things uffice concerning the two former faults belonging to the ditribution of the Blood in this affect, namly, the diminution and lownes therof. It remaineth in the next place to examine the inequality of that ditribution.

div.head: CHAP. XI. The Inequality of the Ditribution of the Blood in this Affect.
div.p: THis inequality is to be etimated by a comparion of the greatnes & wiftnes of the current of the Blood, made in divers parts. For if the circulation of the Blood according to a Geometrical proportion be either equally mal and low, or equally great and wift, that mut be judged equal by the cope of the preent enquiries: on the contrary, if in ome parts it be little and low, and in others great and wift, that mut be reputed unequal and diproportionate. And this is the State of the preent diquiition.

It is manifet by what hath been aid, That the tribution of the Blood thorow the parts firt affected, is extreamly paring and low: It remaineth therfore only that we conider whether it be tranmitted thorow the other parts with a quicker and more plentifull motion.

We have already affirmed that the root of this evil is not fixed in the Heart it elf, and that this Bowel of it elf is not primarily il affected in repect of the left Ventricle therof. It is credible therefore, that the Heart (unles perhaps om other Diea be conjoyned or upervene) doth rightly execute his function, and expel a ufficient quantity of Blood, for our turn by every troke into the Aorta. Seing therfore (as hath been already
proved) that the Blood is niggardly dipened from the Aorta into the firt affected parts, a uperfluous portion of it mut needs be ditributed into other parts not o affected: for otherwie the Aorta hould not ufficiently dicharge it elf, nor disburthen the Blood received from the Heart, but it would be obtructed and oppreed with the plenty therof; and this repletion upon every light occaion would fly back, even to the left Ventricle of the Heart, and there kindle a Feaver. And we grant indeed, for this very cau, among others, that in this Diea a Feaver is eaily and frequently produced. But eing that the Feaver is another Diea conjoyned, and eparable and different from this, and eing that this Diea very often happneth without a Feaver; it mut needs be granted, that by how much more paringly the Blood is ditributed to the firt affected parts, by o much the more plentifully conv •• ed to the other parts, at leat in the abence of the Feaver. For eing that quantity of Blood, as we aid even now, is extruded into the Aorta, as may uffice the whole Body, and eing al of it mut be ditributed into everal parts, it mot plainly follows, that the les is tranmitted into one part, the more is dipened into another. And thus it may be perceived that the inequality of the ditribution of the Blood is inferred from the ole diminution thereof, in the firt affected parts above aerted, (at leat probably) namly, from the mal and low current of the Blood thorow the parts firt affected, there may be rightly collected à more quick and plentiful tream of it, into the inward parts not o affected. Now let us ee whether the other appearances relating hither are correpondent to this Dicour.

Firt, It eemeth manifet by what hath been alleadged, that the Head, the Brain, the Liver, and the other Bowels, are not afflicted with that cold ditemper, nor
that tupefaction and penury of inherent Spirits, wherwith the parts primarily affected are oppret. For the bowels and the aid parts do not receive their Nerves from the Spinal Marrow, without the Skul, but they are involved in the ame condition with the other parts. Moreover, thoe parts, as far as we can judg by the touch are (at leat outwardly) moderatly hot, and as far as we can gues by the ight they retain their native and florihing color, beides they are more ful and flehly, then the firt affected parts.

Moreover, Children afflicted with this Diea have an indifferently good appetite, they do not il concoct the introumed aliment, and about the Head they retain their enes very acute: they ee, they hear, they tat, they mel as ubtily as others, and as for their wit, they many times urpas thoe of equal years with them; unles an impediment from ome other cau. All which things put together do abundantly witnes, that a cold ditemper, nor a benummednes or penury of Inherent Spirits, hath none, or at leat a very mal predominancy in thoe parts. Thee things being granted, we mut likewie needs grant that a more liberal ditribution of the Blood is dipened to the aid parts. For as for the heat, we have already hewed that that doth both amplify and tir up the Arteries to end forth a tronger pulation; and we have alo noted above that the plenty of the Spirits, doth not only cherih the pulificative force of the Arteries, and conerv the vigor of the Blood contained in them, but that it doth omwhat enliven and excitate both of them, and that by o much the more effectually, by how much the les the inherent Spirits are affected with a tupefaction.

Secondly, unles thoe parts were watered with a more liberal circulation of the Blood, they would becom more
oft, loo, and feeble, then they are, even as the parts firt affected are oberved to be. For upon the defect or languihing of the Pul in any part, the part preently becoms loo and weak, as it happneth to al the Parts in a Lipothymy. On the contrary, when the Pul beats trongly, the Part wherunto it belongeth, is een to be omwhat rigid and welled. For a ful Pul doth preently fil up thoe parts, which were before unk down by emptines; as the Lypothymy being driven away, and the Pul being retored, the Parts of the Body, which were before loo and languid, are not only wel colored, but ful of vivacity and turgid: eing therfore that thoe Parts are not affected with that oftnes, loones, and weaknes, we mut conclude that they are actuated with a full Pul.

Thirdly, The very augmented magnitude of the parts, in comparion of the parts primarily affected in this Diea doth witnes, that they are more liberally fed with their aliment, namly, the Blood, (which is reputed the common and lat aliment of the Parts) for otherwie carce any ufficient reaon can be imagined, why, when the firt affected Parts are o extenuated, thee hould be (epecially the Brain and Liver) in o good a condition, o ful and o plump. The ame thing is confirmed by the lively color of the ame parts. For if the Pul languih in any part, omwhat of the freh and amiable color preently retireth from that Part.

Fourthly, The Arteries called Carotides, and the Jugulary Veyn, which belong to the Brayn, and the parts about the Head, are oberved to be very broad in this affect; but the Veels tending to the firt affected parts to be unduly lender; from whence we may clearly infer, That the dipenation of the Blood to thoe Parts is unequal. And here we intreat and beeech thoe who have
an opportunity to open uch Bodies as this affect hath detroyed, that they would accurately contemplate whether the welling Arteries inerted into the welling parts of the Bones do more liberally, and more commodiouly tranmit the Blood into thoe, than into the other les nourihed parts of the Bones, and whether the Arteries of thoe parts are more broad than of thee. Although indeed we confes that this enquiry is mot difficult, both becaue of the lendernes of thoe Arteries, and in regard of the obcurity of their inertion, and alo in repect of the hardnes of the Bones.
