Fifthly, Hither alo belong things hurtful and helpful for children afflicted with this Diea are manifetly benefitted by rubbings, motion, and various agitation of the Body, by exercies, trengthning Oyntments, and the like means which raie the heat in the Members on the right-ide, and the other parts primarily affected, and irritate the Pules and augment them after any ort, whereby the ditribution of the Blood may be more neerly reduced to ome equality; with the contrary things they are damnified. In like manner uch Medicines which promove the dipenation of the Blood to the firt affected parts (as thoe which are moderately hot, benign and familiar to Nature, and o attenuant, incident, and deobtruent that at the ame time they do not in the leat degree wat but cherih and augment the Spirits) help very much towards the cure of this Diea; the contraries do either produce or foment it being produced. All thee things being conidered we mut conclude that the detribution of the Blood in this affect is irregular and unequal. And thus at length we have finihed the diquification of the faults in the detribution of the Vital Blood; we now proceed to the
examination of the faults, if any uch there be, of the Vital participative Contitution in this Dieae.

div.head: CHAP. XII. The faults of the Vital participative Contitution in this Affect.
div.p: WE have already aid that the Origine of the Vital Contitution is grounded in the Arterious Blood, and epecially in the piritous part thereof: but becaue the olid parts alo do omwhat truly participate the nature of Life we jutly acribe unto them the Vital participative Contitution.
Now this Contitution coniteth in Three Things.
Firt, In a certain union of the Arterious Blood with the ubtance of the olid parts through which it paeth.
Secondly, In the Vital heat excited in thoe parts.
Thirdly, In the enlivening and exaltation of the Natural Contitution, and of all the Natural faculties of thoe parts.

Firt, As for that union of the Arterious Blood, it mut be jutly reputed, the firt part of the participative Life. For the olid parts are therfore aid to participate of the Nature of Life, or the Vital Contitution, becaue the Vital Spirits are contained in them. For
Life cannot conit without a Vital Spirit. Therfore when the Vital Spirit is ditributed in and with the Arterious Blood to the olid parts through the Arteries, and thee parts do uck in that Blood into their ubtance, it comes to pas, that the aid parts are counited with the Vital Spirits, and o they participate of the Nature of Life.

Moreover, Seeing this union is not permanent but tranient and coniteth in motion, it eemeth to conit in the confluence and mutual embracement of the inherent natural and influent Vital Spirit: but the conditions which are requiite to make this a natural concoure, are,
Firt, That it be in all repects, moderate, and not impetuous.
Secondly, That it be in all repects trong, and not feeble and tupified.
Thirdly, That it be friendly and peaceable, not hotile and Turbulent, that it be gentle not tumultuous; that it be neither too lippery and mooth, nor too rough.

Fourthly, That it end not in any kind of diipation of the Spirits, but rather in the appeaing and apt dipoition of them for their return into the Veins. More uch conditions might perhaps be added; but becaue they very little belong to this Diea, we hall here uperceed any further examination of them. We only note that the mutual concoure and union of the Vital and natural Contitution by their Spirits, doth not occur in this affect, with that activity, vigor and complacency, as it uually doth in ound Bodies. And this carce needeth any proof, eeing that it is manifet by what hath been aid above, that not only the natural contitution of the firt affected Parts doth labor under a
cold and a moit ditemper, a defect and benummednes of Spirits, but that the Vital Blood it elf is alo omwhat damped and tupified in the tops or ends of the Arteries, before it can be conveighed into the firt affected parts, o that that union mut needs be performed without either a ufficient vivacity, or pleaure. For when the vigorous Vital Spirits do meet together with the Natural Spirits no les vigorous, they are united with a kind of curteous trife and delightful contention. Whether, that we may illutrate this matter by an example, the natural Spirits as a Bride do here allure and in a manner repel the Vital Spirits who as it were act the part of a Bridegroom: But the Vital Spirits provoked with their heat, and driven on by the vigor of the Pules do more confidently invade the Natural Spirits and penetrate into their confines and regions, whilt the Natural Spirits in the mean time (however as it were with modet reitances repuling the aault) receive them at length not without a certain pleaure. For the very corporal pleaure is etablihed upon, and encreaed by a kind of amorous trife, and the principal part of Life it elf coniteth in uch a contention about the Reciprocal union of the Spirits; for to that end the Vital Spirits are both generated and detributed, that at length they may pas through the olid Natural Contitution of the Parts, and may profoundly imbue them with their vital power and vertue; but eing this peneration cannot be effected without endeavor and reitance, it mut needs be, that the vigor of that contention & reitance, be either more or les according to their copiounes, vivacity, and heat of thoe Spirits that maintain the conflict. Therefore becaue in this affect, both the Natural and the Vital Spirits are more cold, fewer, and les active; their
concour and union mut needs be dull and undelightful. Moreover it mut be noted in this affect (which alo we have hewed above) that the permeation of the Blood thorow the firt affected parts is to eay and lippery, wherupon even for this reaon, that concour and union of the Spirits in thoe parts is rendred more lothful, and les pleaant. Beides, hot exhalations although for the mot part they are paringly raied in this affect, yet being raied, by reaon of the oftnes, loones, and internal lubricity of the firt affected parts, parts, they evaporate ooner then is meet, wherupon they leave thoe parts cold and feeble.

Secondly, As for the Vital heat communicated to the olid parts (which is the econd part of the Vital participative Contitution) that partly depends upon the aforeaid union, or the Incorporation of the Arterious Blood, with the olid parts; but partly it coniteth in a certain expanive motion or endeavor (like to that expanive endeavor of the Arterious Blood) excited in the very olid parts. The firt is very perpicuous, for the Arterious Blood through the impregnation of the Vital heat, when it is receaved into the olid parts, mut needs with their ubtance communicate their heat alo unto them. The econd is likewie proved without difficulty, For if the Vital heat radicated in the Arterious Blood coniteth in a certain motion or endeavor of that Blood uniformly diffued and withal at the ame time omwhat retrained, it mut unavoydably excite the ame motion in the olid parts thorow which it paeth, eing that natural caues do always act to the extremity of their power, and as much as is poible by way of aimilation. If any man doubt whether the Eence of the Vital heat conit in uch an uniform diffuive motion, moderately retrained and intrinically advancing: let him know that
the Eence of heat doth in general conit in motion or a rerefactive endeavor omwhat interrupted, as Sr. Thomas Bacon doth mot clearly demontrate in his Novum Organum. But this I ay, the Vital heat, eing that it containeth in it elf the tru nature of heat, it wil be alo necearily uch a rarefactive endeavor omwhat retrained. But that this heat may be retrained to the Vital; more conditions mut be added, which nevertheles we cannot in this place either reckon up, or accuratly earch into, leat we hould run into an unreaonable digreion: In the interim that we may have the matter, and the manner of enquiring, whether or no in this affect the Vital heat be moderated according to nature, it eemed good unto us, to propound thee ubequent conditions.

Firt, That the Vital heat may be called Natural, or according to Nature, it is requiit that the Origin therof be Internal; Namly, in the Arterious Blood, and that it be derived to the olid parts, as hath been aid, by the implantation and union therof; for that any thing may be called, Natural, it mut needs flow from an Internal Principle, although it be likewie tru that what things oever do moderatly cherih, augment, and excite that Internal Principle, may in that repect deerve this appellation.
Secondly, It is required, that that heat be moderate, not unequally, remis, or intenive, but communicated to the parts, in an even degree.

Thirdly, It is required, that it be in ome meaure uniform, and like it elf in thoe parts, that rejoyce in the ame imilary contitution, provided, that they be equiditant from the fountain of heat, and after the ame manner affected by ome other concurrent and adjacent caues. But in the parts further ditant from the fountain
of heat; yet otherwie, as hath been aid, after the ame manner affected, that it may be uniformly diminihed: And in like manner in the colder parts in repect of the inherent contitution, that it may be alo proportionably more remis. Latly, In the parts diverly affected by other caues, o that one may be much more intenively hot then another: it is requiite, that between the hotter and the colder part there be found a heat gradually, and as it were uniformly more remis (if you proceed gently from the hotter towards the colder part.) And even a certain uniformity may be oberved in this deformity or diparity of heat, o long as it continueth within the bounds of Nature. For the parts immediatly and intermutually touching one another, are in a preternatural capacity, or condition: If one of them be extreamly hot in comparion of the other. For eing that this Vital heat coniteth in a rarefactive endeavor omwhat retrained, if it be very unequal and diproportionate in the Parts bordering upon one another, it will happen, that that part which endeavoreth with vehemence, doth withal endeavor to eparate it elf, from that which ueth no uch vehemence, and o that it wil becom a preternatural endeavor, cauing pain: for pain coniteth in the olution of continuity, not yet made, but to be made.

Fourthly, That this heat may not actuate or ait the action of any other hurtful conjoyned quality whatoever. For although in this cae the conjoyned hurtful quality is chiefly peccant, and meriteth the greater part of blame, yet cannot the heat be altogether excued. For an acrimonious and malignant heat, denoteth other qualities to be conjoyned beides the bare heat, yet the Vital heat it elf, in as much as it exaperateth and provoketh the activity of thoe conjoyned qualities to a more
potent depravation and annoyance, it mut be judged partly culpable of their vitious actions.

Fifthly, On the part of the reitance moderation is alo required, both in repect of the appeaing of the irritated Vital Spirit, and alo in regard of the paage of the Arterious Blood, and finally in repect of the tranpiration of the unappeaed exhalations.

Sixthly, A certain proportion mut be oberved between the expanive endeavor of the Vital heat, and the reitance that retrains it, an exces therefore in either of them in it elf is not a fault, but if one be diproportionate to another, in that regard it mut be reputed faulty.

Seventhly, A certain harmony and order is obervable both in the endeavor, and in the reitance. For they do not always proceed in one form and continuation, but as it were fighting, they are omtimes intended, omtimes remitted. And indeed they are chiefly increaed in the Diatole of the Arteries, wher the blood not being contained in his Marrow Veels, trugleth for more room, and o tretcheth the Arteries, til a competent portion of it falleth down, into the habit of the parts, and is there digeted; for then the place doth not compel the Blood into uch traights, but after a hort time it deiteth from that impetuoity, and among the caues of the pulation this motion of the Blood is not the leat coniderable. Now that we may apply thee things to the preent buines, amongt all the conditions now propoed, the econd alone eemeth manifetly to be deired in this affect. For the Vital heat is not here moderate, but defective and more remis than the jut and Natural Degree. For eeing that the firt affected parts are beieged with a cold and moit ditemper,
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
and with a penury and benummednes of Spirits, they mut necearily (as we have already demontrated) omewhat rebate the heat of the Arterious Blood before it is tranmitted into the ubtance of them; wherupon thoe parts participate a more remis degree of Vital heat, than is due unto them. And this hall uffice concerning the communication of the Vital hear to the Parts.

Thirdly, As for the lat part of the participative Life, which indeed dependeth upon the two former, and which is the firt in the intention, though the lat in the execution of Nature; we ay, that it is in ome ort the end both of the Original Vital Contitution, and alo of the ditribution thereof, and finally of the aforeaid union and heat communicated to the parts. For the Vital Spirits are not excited in the Arterious Blood for their own akes alone, neither are they ditributed into the parts, and united to them, only for their own advantage; but chiefly, that they may enliven and dignifie the inherent contitution of the olid Parts, and o actuate and promote their faculties. For as the heat of it elf is only potentially viible, unles it be irradiated with light, o thoe inherent faculties of attracting, retaining, concocting, ecreving, and forming, are dead as it were and meerly potential, when they are deprived of the vivification and erogation of the Vital afflux, This is mot clearly conpicuous in a lipothymy; for upon the defect of the Vital influx, all thoe faculties uddenly fail, decay, languih. But eing all the faculties are etablihed upon ome contitution, which is both the caue and ubject of them, it might be demanded in which Contitution of the parts it is grounded? We anwer, in repect of the potential Nature they are radicated in the Natural Contitution
which we have before decribed; but that in reference to the Actuated and Elivened Eence that they depend likewie upon the Vital influx. And we declare in general that the participative Vital Contitution, which we have already aerted to conit in Three things, conjoyned with the Natural Contitution, is the total and adequate, both caue and ubject of all thoe faculties. But it would be a tedious degreion, and inconitent with our purpoe, to make enquiry how thoe Contitutions can produce this or that faculty determinate in its Species. For the preent we will only run over thoe faults of the faculties aforeaid which occur in this affect.

Firt, The fahioning vertue here erreth by an unequal purging out of the Vital Blood in divers parts, as we have dicoured above. Hereupon the Head and the Liver grow to an unmeaurable bignes; the firt affected parts are extenuated, the ends of the Bones tick out, and omtimes the Bones themelves, which are otherwie traight, wax crooked.

Secondly, The Concoctive faculty is weak in this Diea and in the firt affected part by reaon of the inherent cold ditemper, the penury and benummednes of the Spirits, the brittle and lippery union of the Vital pirits with the Natural Contitution, and by reaon of the feeble imprinted Vital heat.

Thirdly, The Attractive, Retentive, and Expulive Faculties, eem not to recede much from their Natural Condition; yet the Attractive is omwhat more low than ought to be; the Retentive, by reaon of the internal lubricity is omwhat weaker, and the Expulive is more vehement for the ame Caue.

And thus at length we have dipatched the faithful examination of the faults of the Vital Contitution in
this affect. The Animal Contitution hould now undergo the next diquiition, but that om faults of the Natural Contitution; namly the Organical faults therof, which have ome dependance upon ome of the recited faults of the Vital Contitution, do challenge this place, as mot proper to themelvs.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. The Organical Faults of the Natural Contitution in this Affect.
div.p: SEing that the Organical faults in this Diea belong to the Inherent Contitution of the parts, tho indeed by the Law of jut Method hould be immediatly after the imilary vices of the ame Contitution; but as we have noted above, the Reaon and Cau of them mut be derived from the faults of the Vital Contitution lately mentioned, and therfore we are contrained to premie the examination of thee, and to reerv the conideration of the other for another place.
The Organical faults in this affect are fitly reduced to thee Heads.
Firt, To the extenuation and leannes of certain parts namly, the parts firt affected.
Secondly, To the unreaonably augmented magnitude of ome parts, as the Brain, the whol Head, and the Liver.

Thirdly, To the tumors or lanching out of certain
Bones, as of the Bones to the Wrets, to the Ankles, and the ends of the ribs.
Fourthly, To the bowing of certain Bones, as it frequently happneth to the Bones of the Cubit, and the Shin Bone, omtimes to the Bone of the Thigh and Sholder.
Fifthly, To the poynted figure and narrownes of the breat.

And thee faults are reckoned beneath among the Symptoms and igns of the Diea, not becaue they are indeed meer Symptoms, but becau they are obvious to the Senes, and o do fitly upply the place of igns, both in repect of the parts of the Eence of the Diea more deeply retired, and alo in repect of the hidden caues therof. For whatoever is perceived by the en, and beides it elf repreenteth omwhat el to the undertanding that is obcure, hath the formality of a ign. For indeed thee faults are parts of the econdary Eence of the Diea, eing that they are the vitious Contitutions of the Organs depraving the action, and have a dependance upon the other parts of the Eence of the Diea.

The common cau almot of al thee recited affects eems to be an uneven or diproportionate nourihment or Alogotrophy of the parts. Now this dependeth chiefly upon two caues in this affect. The firt is, the unequal inherent Contitution of the parts irregularly nourihed. The diparity between the inherent Contitutions of the firt affected parts, and the Head and Bowels, cannot be o wel collected by what hath been already aid, but that it may deerve a further inculcation. The lat ca u, which is indeed of equal moment, is the very unequal ditribution of the Arterious Blood into the parts unevenly nourihed. That the Blood is unequally ditributed in this affect we have already hewed, here we
only infer that that mut needs produce an unequal nutrition of the parts. Al Creatures the more liberally they feed the more fat and flehly they are unles om oother impediment doth intervene; but if the du quantity of aliment be ubtracted, they grow lean, and are daily more and more extenuated. Why hould we not uppoe that the ame thing happeneth in the Parts of Creatures? the Blood, or at leat omwhat contained in the Blood, is acknowledged for the lat aliment of al the parts, wher therfore that is liberally dipened to one part, and paringly to another, certainly, it is no wonder if one part be exceively augmented, and another extreamly extenuated. But thee things may uffice in general. In particular,

Firt, We aert, that the firt affected parts in this Diea do dayly wax lean and fal away. Proof of this aertion cannot be reaonably expected, eing that dayly experience yeeldeth an occular demontration of it. But why thoe parts are o extenuated, that may require om reaons, and we offer thee.

The firt is deduced from the primary eence of the Diea; namly, from a cold ditemper, a penury, and inactivity of the inherent Spirits in the parts aforeaid, For by this means the attractive, retentive, and concoctive faculty, do execute their functions in thoe parts, unduly and ineffectually.

The econd is brought from the loones, oftnes, and internal lipperines of the ame parts; for hereupon the expulive faculty is too much irritated, the breathing is too eay and diipative, the circulation of the Blood is to lippery, the retentive faculty through the weaknes of it, parteth with the aliment too oon, and with too much facility: and this very thing almot happneth here in thee parts, which befalleth the Guts in a Lyentery.
Howoever it be, the expenes exceed the incoms, and by conequent thoe parts are extenuated.
The third Reaon arieth from the unequal ditribution, and indeed defective in the firt affected parts, of which we have already uperabundantly dicoured.

Secondly, We affirm, that in this affect the greatnes of the Head, and epecially of the Liver, as alo of the Brain is unreaonably increaed. Somtimes the Paly in the Head is conjoyned, which nevertheles we uppoe to be of a different Species, and no part of this Diea: although we grant, that this affect may omtimes give occaion to the upervening Hydrocephalus. Moreover, we have omtimes een, the Conumption being uperinduced upon this affect, and long continuing alo, the Face, and the parts about the Head to be omwhat extenuate before death. But this was produced by the Conumption, not by this Diea we now treat of. But that we may give a reaon of that greatnes unmeaurably increaed in the Parts aforeaid. We note,

Firt, That the parts belonging to the Head and almot all the Bowels, do receive the Nerves from that part of the Spinal Marrow, which is included within the Skul, and therfore that thee parts are not necearily ubject to that unhappy condition of the firt affected parts. Wherfore no reaon doth compel us to affirm, that thee augmented parts are either affected with a cold ditemper, or a penury and dulnes of Spirtts, or that the attractive, retentive, or concoctive faculties are therupon vitiated, and by conequence that thoe parts are totally exempted from the firt caue of that extenuation which befaleth the parts firt affected.

Secondly, we oberve that neither loones, nor flaccidity, nor oftnes, nor internal lipperines are predominant in thoe immeaurably augmented parts, and
that thee qualities (as it happneth to the firt affected parts) do not yeeld a more irritated expulion then is requiite, o that the exportation hould be feared to exceed the importation, which we have hewed to befal the extenuated parts.

Thirdly, We oberve that the Blood in his circulation, by how much the more paringly it is ditributed to the firt affected parts, the more liberally it doth water and nourih thee parts. This we have already proved, and it is needles to inert more arguments to that purpoe. Thee things therfore being oberved, the Reaon is playn, why the parts aforeaid are unmeaurably and irregularly augmented. For if the attractive retentitive and concoctive faculties be not weakned in them, according to our firt annotation, and the expulive be not immoderately irritated according to the econd, and in the interim if ufficient aliment be dipened to them according to the third, the bulk of them mut needs increa beyond proportion.

Thirdly, We affirm that the protuberancies or wellings of the Bones in the Wrets, Ankles, and the ends of the Ribs do vitiate the Organ in a twofold repect namly, in repect of the greatnes, and alo of the figure. The parts vitiated in both repects are obvious to the Eys, and therfore we hal uperede al further proof.

p.hi: But why are the Bones tretched out after that manner in thoe places?

div.p: Truly it is very hard to render a Reaon therof, neither perhaps dare we engage our elves by promie to give atisfaction in all repects herein to the curious. Therfore intead of an anwer we dedicate to the Reader thee ubequent obervations as not altogether unprofitable.

Firt, The Bones in many do agree with the ubtance
of the Bowels. For firt they conit of a certain imilary matter evered from the preterfluent Blood, not needing any laborious aimilation, and eem to admit a mot eaie nutrition till they arrive at the exaltation and highet pitch of their encreae; Moreover, they eem to be nourihed until by age they are brought to an extream drines, and they eem not to be obnoxious to any coniderable extenuation; o the ubtances of the Bowels are imilary being joyned together by the eparation almot of the Blood alone, and they likewie eaily encrea, and are difficultly and rarely extenuated. Secondly, The Bones are nourihed almot after the ame manner, as the Parenchymata or ubtances of the Bowels: Through the Arteries they receive the blood, through the Veins they amandate and conveigh away the uperfluous portion of it, and intead of Veels of the third kind whereby the excrements are expelled, they are furnihed with Cels and Cavities. Some perhaps may doubt of the Arteries of the Bones, becaue o hard and rigid a part may eem unapt to admit any pulation of the Arteries within it, we grant indeed that the Bones in regard of their hardnes and tifnes are les apt for the pulation of the Arteries, and therfore we acknowledg that they admit not within them any notable ramification or branching of Arteries; but if any man will from thence infer that no Arteries are admitted into them, truly herein he mut expect our abolute denyal, for they are living Parts, they are nourihed, they grow, and they exercie the Attractive, Retentive, Concoctive, and Expulive faculties. Again, they receive the Blood, which they cannot do but by the conduit Pipes of the Arteries, and this is manifet by the bloodines of them, when the Bones of Living Creatures are either broken or any other way divided.
In yong Creatures the pongy ubtance of the Bones, and the very Marrow is enibly perfued with Blood, and the greatet part of their Cavities is filled more with Blood than Marrow. In elder and greater Creatures you may oberve both Veins and Arteries through the Membranes enwrapping the Marrow; all which things do ufficiently prove that the Blood is ditributed into the very Bones. But wie Nature (who in the conformation of all the parts doth mot equiitely and aptly proportion all things) foreeeing here that the Veins and Arteries could not conveniently be extended by a longer carnification through the ubtance of the Bones by reaon of their hardnes, he cateth that vat number of them, ome being as mal as hairs, into almot inconpicuous little holes in the Bones. But if you oundly boyl the Bones of greater Creatures thee Orifices of the inertion of the Veels may very eaily be perceived in the outward uperficies if you remove the Skin enwrapping the Bones. But let this uffice concerning the Veins and Arteries of the Bones, eing that this matter is omwhat incoherent with our cope. As for the Veels of the third kind, eing that the excrements of the Bones were not about to prove altogether improfitable, nor could commodiouly be expelled out of the Body, Nature, intead of a Veel of the third kind hath made certain Recepticles (namely Cavities and Cels) into which he would exno • rate and cat aide the excrements, namely that fat part which is altogether improfitable to furnih the Bones with nourihment. There are ome who uppoe the Marrow to be the principal nourihment of the Bones, but very inconiderately, eing that the Marrow, as we have aid, is altogether unapt for the generation and nourihment of the Bones, for the bones are not only mot
hard and olid and naturally of a white colour, but they conit of a certain earthy and clammy ubtance, which conditions differ very much from Marrow. Again, Marrow cannot by any art be ublimated to the firmnes of a Bone. Moreover, Marrow melteth, and is diolved with a moderate heat of the fire; but the Bones endure the mot ardent flames of fire without any melting. Beides, Boil the Bones as long as you pleae, they reolve into a gelly, not into the ubtance of, or like Marrow. Again, Bones may be worn to pouder, o cannot Marrow. Certain therfore it is, that the marrow is not the Aliment of the Bones but a kind of excrement, or rather ecrement of them, profitable indeed, and therfore to be preerved in thoe receptacles. For the Bones being otherwie dry, cold, and rough, would be unapt for motion, were they not moitned and made lippery by the exundations and exhalations of the Marrow, and cherihed by their gentle heat. All thee things are confirmed by this ingle experiment. In yong Creatures the greatnes of the Bones being conidered, there is les Marrow in the Bones, and more Blood, than in greater Creatures. In the Embrion, there are carce oberved any igns or appearances of Marrow detinct from the Blood. But after the birth the medullary ubtance is daily augmented, and it is viibly perceived to be les and les intermingled with the Blood; again in the maturity of years the Bones are filled almot with pure and incere Marrow, without any coniderable commixture of Blood; but in the approaches of old age it is credible that the Bones are les and les watered with the circulation of the Blood; and perhaps the Marrow it elf upon the upenion and ceation of the nourihment is rather augmented than diminihed; in which repect the propounded experiment
mut be peradventure limitted. Thirdly, the Bones (the Teeth perhaps excepted) cannot want their nervs, at leat very little, neither are they uppoed to be otherwie enible, then by reaon of the Periotium, or the Fibers therof fatned into the Orifices of the Bones. In like manner the ubtances of the Bowels eem to obtain that dul ene, which they poes, rather by the Membranes and veels, then from their own ubtance.

From hence we collect, that the Bones in this affect are not much otherwie affected, than the ubtance of the Bowels in repect of nourihment. We have already hewed that the Bones are not to be reckoned among the firt affected parts, as likewie neither the Parenchymata: only we here further affirm that all the Bones univerally conidered, are not perhaps les paringly nourihed in this Diea, than they uually are in ound Bodies, for if they be nourihed by way of coaugmentation, or joyning together, as the Parenchymata are, and with uch facility alo, if they poes Arteries and Veins delated unto them, and Cells, and Cavities to receive the Blood, if they be not in the number and condition of the firt affected parts, and if they receive not Nerves from the pinal Marrow; it is very credible that they do duly receive, laudably retain, and perfectly concoct their Aliment. Moreover, If you will conult experience, Children afflicted with this Diea, a regard being had to their age, and the magnitude of their parts, weigh heavier than others for the mot part, as we have omtimes oberved, which very thing eemeth partly to be acribed to the greatnes of the Bones. Although in this cae we wih more frequent, certain, and accurate obervations, which others who are befriended with opportunity may oblige the world withal: in the mean time we uppoe in general
that the Bones are not illiberally nourihed in this Diea.
Some may reply, That what hath hitherto been poken doth concern the nourihment of the Bones in general, but that they yield not a reaon of the protuberances in them.

We deny it not, but eing that thee faults of the Bones depend upon their unequal nourihment, as we have already proved, we uppoed it would not be unprofitable to purpoe ome reaon of their nourihment in general: now we draw neerer to the aforeaid wellings of the Bones. And we oberve, Secondly, That thoe tumors of the Bones are not of a different kind in repect of the other parts of the ame Bone, but that they are parts altogether imilary and of the like kind with the ret, and that they are not faulty in repect of the imilary Contitution, but in repect only of their greatnes and figure.
From hence it followeth thirdly, that thee wellings are not produced by any illegetimate matter of the Bones, or by any other vertue than the ame by which and from which the other are generated.

Fourthly, That the aid wellings are produced by an unequal nourihment of the Bones, as by a more liberal nourihment of the welling parts, and a paring nourihment of the other parts of the ame Bone. And thee Three lat obervations we have already abundantly proved where we treated of the affected parts.

Fifthly, We oberve the Epiphyes of the Bones in the Wrets and Ankles, and perhaps in ome other places, to be more oft and pongy than in the other parts of the ame Bones. And peradventure they receive into themelves greater Arteries and Veins, although indeed we are not yet fully aured of this. The
tops of the Ribs are alo much more oft and pongy than the other parts of them. From whence we infer that thoe more oft and pongy parts of the Bones may more eaily and freely admit the circulation of the Blood, and therefore be more plentifully nourihed than the ret of the parts of them. You will ay, That oftnes and pongines of thoe parts is oberved to be as well in healthful Children as in thoe affected with this Diea. We grant it, but yet it mut needs be, that thoe parts which are of a more compacted ubtance, and with difficulty admit the circulation of the Blood, mut be affected and obtructed upon lighter caues, then thoe parts that are more open, and more eaily receive it. But the Blood in this affect is tranmitted to the external parts omwhat more cold, vicous, and thick, then it ought to be; therfore thoe parts which are unapt to admit the circulation of it, thoe are more apt to be omwhat obtructed, and les liberally nourihed.
But, Why alo are not thoe oft and pongy parts more liberally nourihed in ound Bodies, eing that they (as hath been aid) do more plentifully receive the Blood?

We anwer, Becaue, as in health thoe parts do in a larger meaure receive the Blood thorow the Arteries, o they remit the ame more plentifully thorow the veins which certainly doth preerve them from that exceive augmentation unto which otherwie they would grow. But in this affect the ame parts by reaon of the coldnes thicknes, and vicoity of the Blood, do perhaps more paringly and more lowly remit it, then it is poured in to them; and therfore from that abundance and exces of the Blood, thoe parts do omwhat increae; whilt the other parts of the Bones by reaon of the narrownes of the cavity of the Artery, are not perhaps ufficiently nourihed with Blood, wherby to obtain an equal
nutrition and increa. And from hence (at leat probably) we deduce the inequallity of the nutrition of the Bones in this affect. But the condition of the Blood wherby in this Diea it is apt to obtruct an parts thorow which it floweth, eems to have a peculiar repect to the quality of the Bones. For in the Bowels, the Lungs excepted, the Blood doth eldom Generate obtructions, as alo ne ither in the firt affected Parts: However it be the Bony ubtance, either becaue it is incapable of the internal lipperines, or becaue the nutritive juice in the mas of Blood is peculiarly apt to congeal in the parts o vehemently fixed: or latly, becaue it hath in its own nature ome affinity with the Bones: we ay, the Bony ubtance is eaily infeted with obtructions in this Diea, and therupon it happneth to be unequally nourihed.

The Faults of breeding Teeth are likewie to be referred hither, eing that they alo eem to depend upon this unequal nutrition of the Bones. For if the Teeth hould be equally nourihed, they would be of a uniform ubtance, and would not fal out by pieces, as it here frequently happneth. For the imilary parts, when they are equally nourihed, acquire not uch an interrupted and unequal conitence, as to be eaily broken in pieces. Wherfore eing the Teeth are parts naturally delighting in a imilary ubtance, were they equally nourihed, they hould enjoy an equal and uniform conitance, and would either continue firm in their gums, or would fal out whol: And there can carce any other reaon be given, why they hould be broken and fal out more on one ide, or in one part then another. We grant indeed that their aptnes to break, may hitherto conduce very much: but we conceive that even that aptnes to break, doth in great part depend upon the unequal nutrition aforeaid. For otherwie
the Teeth do uually obtain a very firm, olid, & coherent ubtance; and the truth is, they eem to conit epecially in this vicous affect of a very matter. For the Blood for the mot part is oberved to be more vicous and thick then ordinary, o that this aptnes to break off the Teeth, cannot be o eaily acribed to a defect of vicoity in the matter, as it may much more probably to the inequallity of the nutrition. We conclude therfore that the tanding out of the Bones, and likewie the faults of the Teeth, do proceed from the unequal nutrition of thee parts, ariing from a peculiar obtructive dipoition of the Blood, having reference epecially to the Bones. Now we proceed to the crookednes of the Bones in this affect.

Fourthly, In this affect the Bones are frequently omwhat crooked, epecially the Shin Bones, and the leer Bones of the Legs; alo the Bones of the Cubit, the leer of the two long Bones of the Cubits, and the bigger Shank-Bone, omtimes the Bones of the Sholder and Thigh: om Joynts alo becom crooked, omtimes inward, omtimes outwards: the whole Spine is likewie many times bended, omtimes it is wreathed like the letter S; namly, partly forwards, partly backwards, and omtimes partly to the right Hand, partly to the left.

Some acribe this crookednes of the Bones, to the bending faculty of them; for ay they, in the tender age of Children, the Bones themelves are not o tiff tubborn, and inflexible, as in their riper years; and therfore upon the invaion of this Diea, they are rendred in ome degree eaily flexible. Therfore they rebuke the Nures, which too oon commit the children to their Feet, uppoing, that the Bones are made crooked by the utained burthen of their Bodies. Others alo tax the Nures of imprudence in wadling them.

But we cannot yeeld our ful aent in all repects to thee Reaons. And firt we flatly deny, that the Bones of Children afflicted with this Diea are more flexible, or les tiff and friable then the Bones of others. For we have already proved, that the Bones in this affect do not differ in repect of their imilary ubtance from the Bones of ound perons. Beides, no man hitherto worthy of credit hath atteted that he hath een the Bones flexible in this Diea. Moreover, if we hould grant that in this tendernes of years the Bones might perhaps be omwhat bended, yet they would not continu o bent like lead or wax, but being left to their liberty they would return again to the proper poition and figure of the parts. For they conit not of any ductile matter, and therfore by being thus bent, they would either be broken or ele doubtles they would endeavor to reobtain their former ituation. As for the ignorance or negligence of Nures, although we do not altogether excue it, yet cannot we jutly impute this crookednes of the Bones to their carelenes. We ee the Children of Poor People are ordered and handled with les care, and ooner committed to their feet then the Children of the rich, yet the Children of Poor People are more rarely afflicted with this infirmity, then the Children of the rich. Beides, we have known Nures ue all manner of diligence as wadling them, and every other way laboring to prevent this incurvation, yet al their pains, otherwie praiworthy, hath in this repect been ucceles. Therfore we mut indeavor to find out ome other caue of this crookednes.

We compare the Bones therfore, in which this crookednes ueth to happen, to a Pillar, and not unaptly, eing, that when they are erected, they reemble a Pillar; and from thence we deduce a demontration that illutrates
and makes the matter very plain. Let the Pillar therfore conit of three tones A B C placed over one another. We uppoe it uch an one as is perpendicularly erected on every ide, and of the ame height: If therfore you hal faten in a wedge on the right ide between

G the tones A B through the line F D, the Head of the Pillar; Namely, the tone A will of neceity be bended towards D and wil make an Angle in D, and the height of the Pillar on the right ide, wil be higher than on the left. In like manner if you drive in another wedg thorow G E into the tones BC the pillar wil be yet more bowed, and the angle wil be made in E. Now therfore the Pillar tands bent to the left hand after this manner.

G ABCFGDE. but if you build the Pillar of more tones, & betwixt every two, as hath been aid, a wedg be interpoed on one ide, it will not reemble the figure of a Pillar, but the proportion of a Bow, as by this following may be perceived.

Now that we may accommodate thee things to the preent buines, if the Bones aforeaid be more plentifully nourihed on one ide, and therfore do grow out more on that then the oppoite ide, there is a neceity, that that mut grow crooked: For here the overplentiful nutrition of that ide, hath the ame power after the ame manner to bow the Bones, as the interpoed wedg hath to bow the Pillar, ave that the wedg is fatned only in ome places of the ide of the Pillar, and the overplentiful nutrition of the ide of the Bone, is commonly equally made, according to the whol length therof. For the aliment received into the Bone, in what part it more liberally admitteth it, that part it obtructeth: and like the wedg thrut into the Pillar it extendeth it into an augmented length, wherupon the Bones mut needs be bowed towards that ide which is not lengthened in an equal degree with the other. Moreover, if the production of one ide of the Pillar happen only in one or two places therof and not in many, as in the third figure, then
o much the neerer the inflexion of it approacheth to the figure of a part of a Circle, or a Bow. But if the aid ide according to the total longitude therof hould be equally lengthened beyond the oppoite ide, doubtles it would be bended towards the oppoite ide, & would exactly reemble a piece of a Circle or Bow without any Angles, jut after the ame manner, arieth the bending of the Bones in this affect: namly, from the greater lengthning of the ide mot nourihed; for eing that that lengthning happneth by the received aliment, according to all the parts of that ide, an Angular figure cannot be expected, or one compounded of many traight ones angularly connexed, but a crooked one like a Bow, wherin the convex part is contituted by the ide, plentifully nourihed, & the concave or hollow part by the ide, which is paringly nourihed. But when it happneth that ome part of the convex ide of a crooked Bone is diproportionatly nourihed, in repect of the oppoite ide, without all doubt the convex Bone wil tick out more on that part then in the ret: and o from the inequallity of the nutrition, we have given a reaon of the crookednes of the Bones in this affect. We wil ad for a higher confirmation of this matter. An obervation raied from the cure of this crookednes of the Bones. The Quacks of our Country are wont to rub dayly the hollow, not the convex ides of the Bones, and that rubbing, ay they, doth very much conduce to the cure, but this doth rather hinder it. But it is certain that rubbing doth powerfully ummon the nutritive juice out of the Bloody mas into the part o rubbed, therfore if at any time you rub that hollow part which is inufficiently nourihed, it is no wonder if it do good, eing that thereby the aliment is more plentifully allured, and the heat of the part is alo excited and augmented; neither on the other ide is the
Gibbous part of the Bone, being hurt by rubbing to be wondred at, becaue by that means the aliment is attracted to that part which was before uperabundantly nourihed: beides, the Oyntments, which may cherih the inherent heat, and trengthen the nutritive faculties, after the rubbing, do mot good, when they are applyed to the hollow part of the Bone; but the convex part a trait ligature which may retrayn the riing up of the Bones is uually fitted with deired ucces: chiefly indeed for this reaon, becaue the capillary Arteries which convey the Blood, or nutritive juyce, to that ide of the Bone, are bound up by uch a ligature, and therupon the nutriment is leened. And thee things hal uffice concerning the crookednes of the Bones in this affect.

Moreover, To this Article we opportunely ad the inflexion of om of the Joints, as of the Knees, and Ankles, which happneth very frequently in this Diea. omtimes being made inwardly, omtimes outwardly, And this bending alo eemeth to be not unfitly referred to the inequallity of nutrition. For if it happen by unequal nutrition, that one ide of the Shank-Bone be o lengthned more then the other: uppoe outwardly, that it doth omwhat lift up the outward part of the Epiphyis of the Shank-Bone above the inward part, the joynt in the Knee mut needs tand outwardly bent; and on the contrary, if the inward part be lifted up, and the outward depreed, the ame Joynt mut needs tand inwardly
bent: as may be eaily perceived by the following Figures.

In the Joynt of the Knee, A B, that part of the appendance of the Shank-bone B, in the two firt Figures, is higher than the other part of the ame appendance; whereupon the Bone of the Thigh (is inwardly bowed, and o likewie is the Shin-bone D; but the Joynt A B is thrut omwhat outwardly. But in the two lat Figures all the contrary things may be oberved. The Joynt A B is inwardly, becaue that part of the Shinbone A, is higher than the other part of it B. Whereupon it mut needs lift up the inner and lower top of the Thigh-bone, o that the Thigh-bone will be bent outwardly, and the Joynt inwardly.

The ame thing likewie may happen in the Anklebones, and the turning Joynts of the Back, if the Bones fatned to the Joynt be higher on one ide than on the other. But in the Ankles, becaue there, beides the Shin-bone, the leer Bone of the Leg is alo fatned through the Joynt, it may o fall out, that the leer Bone below may tand out further than the Shin-bone, and o bend outwardly the Joynt of the Ankle; and on the contraty, if it happen that the Shin-bone be longer than the leer bone, the Joynt mut needs be inwardly bent. Although we confes that uch an inequality of length between the Shin-bone and the leer Bone in the Leg doth not o often happen.

Moreover, We uppoe that the preternatural bending of the Spine doth rarely happen from the unequal altitude of the ides of the turning Joynts of the Bones, but more often from another caue which we will now proecute. We have already aid that the Spine is omwhat weak in this affect, and that Children afflicted with this Diea are unapt not only to motion, but alo to tand upon their feet, yea, and to raie their backs by reaon of the weaknes of the Spine. Therefore
whenoever their Bodies are raied, they eek omewhat to ret upon, and they uffer their Spine to be bowed ometimes forwards, ometimes backwards, ometimes to the right hand, and ometimes to the left; whereby the burden of their Body may be reted upon omthing that tands neer them. Hereupon it many times happens, that the Ligaments of the turning Joynts of the Spine in that part which is mot commonly bending out are looned and lengthned, and on the oppoite ide they are contracted; o that intract of time the Spine cannot be erected according to the traight and natural Figure. And truly in this cae we cannot excue the Nures indiligence or negligence, becaue they do not oberve with a ufficient attentivenes, to which part the Children which they uckle are mot prone to bend their Bodies, that by that means they may endeavor to bend them to the oppoite part: In like manner alo when Nures without due regard and care do too oon commit weak Children to the ue of their feet, it may happen, that, when the regular motion of the Mucles is too weak to bear the Body, Children may uffer either their Knee or Ankle to be bowed to one ide; whereupon the Ligaments of the Joynt are extended either on the inner or the outward ide, and by conequence the Ligaments on the contrary ide are contracted, whereupon the joynt mut needs be bended either inwàrdly or outwardly, therfore although we have denied above that the crookednes of the Bones dependeth hereupon, yet we grant that the bending of the Joynts may happen in weak Children by the negligence of the Nures. We grant moreover that the Bones which would otherwie have been traight, may be crooked by an unskilful wadling; yet that this caue doth happen exceeding rarely in this affect we are omewhat
confident, as we have hewed already more at large. Now we proceed to the pointednes and narrownes of the breat in this affect.

We oberve that this pointednes and narrownes of the Breat doth not appear preently at the beginning of this affect, but that it ucceedeth upon the confirmation of the Diea, and is by degrees intended, till by the pereverence of the Diea it becomes evident and conpicuous, when the Breat forwards reembleth the Breat of a Hen, or the Keel of a Ship. This viciated Figure of the Breat which otherwie hould be broad according to Nature, and not traightned on the ides, and even not pointed forwards, we reduce to four caues. The three former whereof we confes do contribute little efficacy to this matter, but the fourth alone doth almot al the work. Yet becaue the three former do contribute omthing, we will likewie recite them here in order. Be this the firt, In this affect the Bone of the Stern by reaon of the augmented Bulk of the Liver is omwhat elevated or thrut forward, wherupon there happeneth ome part of the aid viciated Figure; and moreover from the ame elevation of the Bone of the Stern there happeneth a certain contraction of the Ribs towards the Spine, and this caueth the other part
of the viciated Figure. This contraction of the Ribs we thus demontrate. Let the circle be A B
A
B
C
D C D, this mut be uppoed to be made of a flexible matter, but not equally extenible, as for example, of the Bone of a Whale. Therfore when the ides A C are both tretched from one another, o that line of ditance is produced into length between A C, then the ides of that circle D B are necearily contracted almot in equal degree, and by the ame means the line of lateral ditance from D to B is abreviated; for the Circle becomes an Oval Figure, as any man hall find who wil take the pains to reduce it to experiment. For the Figure will be changed into this form which the Figure following doth expres;
A
B
C
D In which the line of ditance between A and C is repreented longwie, and withal the line D B appears to be abreviated, and the Circle becomes Oval; neither is there need of more words to prove this matter.

Now it mut be known that the oppoite couples of the Ribs do expres a
certain rude kind of circular Figure, epecially the uppermot which chiefly fahion the Breat, by the mediation of the Spine on the hinder part, and the Stern on the fore part. Nor hould it trouble any man, becaue they will not make an exact and perfect Circle, eing that our demontration is as effectual in a circular Figure how imperfect oever, as in the mot exquiite and perfect; provided that there be a coherence among all the parts, that they be not ditorted, that they be flexible, but not eaily extenible; which conditions are ufficiently conpicuous in the Figure of the Ribs even now propoed to view. Therefore if in this affect the Bone of the Stern be omwhat elevated forwards, that it may yield room to the augmented Bulk of the Liver, the Ribs towards the Spine mut needs be drawn in neerer to one another, whereupon the Breat mut unavoidably be laterally traightned, the latitude of it, being leened.

Some may ay, If the riing of the Bone of the Stern did conduce any thing to the pointed Figure of the Breat, it would chiefly effect that about the inferior Ribs, eing that this elevation of the Stern doth begin at the lower part; but it is manifetly known to fall out otherwie; for the narrownes of the Breat happeneth chiefly about the Armpits, and afterwards beneath the Channel Bones; but the lower Ribs eem to be enlarged about the ides rather than traightned.

We anwer, That the Five lower Ribs are not articulated with the Stern, neither do they make a perfect Circle; and therefore in no wie do they relate to the propounded demontration; but the tretching of them dependeth upon another cau, namely, the fulnes of the Hypocondriacal parts. Let it likewie be noted that we aign not this for the chief cau of the
viciated Figure, yea, we uppoe that it conferreth very little towards it. And o we proceed to the econd cau of this viciated Figure, which we alo conceive to be a very light one.

In this affect the Hypochondriacal parts is almot perpetually oberved to be full and tretched, namely both in repect of the greatnes of the Liver, and alo becau all the other Bowels almot which are contained in the bottom of the Belly are ufficiently large; eing that as hath been aid, the firt eence of this Diea is not rooted in them. And latly, Becau the Guts and the Ventricle are uually more or les ditended with wind. But now from that fulnes and extenion of the Hypochondriacal parts we may jutly collect that in this affect the Ribs are drawn downwards a little more than is expedient. For the greatet extenion is here oberved in the oblick Mucles that are extended beneath the Hypochondriacal parts; Now the Mucle obliquely dicending hath toothed heads fatned to the ixth, eventh, eighth & ninth Ribs, and the part of the broad tend on alo oblickly acending is adjoyned to the grizles of the ninth, tenth, and eleventh Ribs. Wherfore eing that the aid Mucles are almot pertually too much extended in this affect, they mut needs in ome manner draw the aid Ribs downwards, and eing all the Ribs are firmly fatned together by the intercotal Mucles, it happened that in this affect al the Ribs are omwhat drawn downwards.
But now that thee Ribs o drawn down do omwhat traighten the Breat may be perceived by this following Figure.

Let A B be the Back-Bone. CD E the Rib. F the Bone of the Stern. We uppoe that every one may ee here in the Skeleton, that the Ribs are not conjoyned with the Spine, according to the traight Angle, but that the Angle beneath the Rib is omwhat les then the traight Angle: So that if the Rib be drawn a little upwards, the Articulation of it approacheth neerer to a traight line. We uppoe alo, that the circulation of the Rib, whether with the Spine or with the Stern abideth firm, and doth not draw upwards (leat any man hould er) ave only the middle parts of the Rib between the aid Articulations. We ay, therfore on the contrary by how much the more downwards the Rib is drawn, o much the more acute is the Angle with the Spine, which it then maketh: Wherfore that part of the Rib furthet ditant from the Back-Bone A BC; (namly, D in each of the Figures) as being thrown downwards, it contitutes a more acute Angle with the Spine, o is it alo les ditant from the Spine then it was before, and rendreth the broadnes of the Breat more narrow. For the ides of the Breat were then indeed mot broad, when the Ribs are mot erected upon the Spine, according to a traight line. For that part of the Rib D wil be then furthet ditant from the Back-Bone A B, as you may oon perceive if you compare the firt and econd figure with the third. For in the third Figure, the Rib is expret erect in a traight line, with the Back-Bone, and then that part of the Rib D is enibly further ditant from the Back-Bone A B, then it is in the firt or econd figure, as he that wil examin them, hal quickly apprehend: but in the econd Figure, the Rib with the Spine is uppoed to make a more acute Angle, and in proportion that part of it D (as you may perceive) is les ditant from the Spine than the ame part D in the ame Figure, whoe
Angle is uppoed to be les acute; and yet that is much les ditant from the Spine, then in the third Figure, whoe Articulation is erected to a traight Angle. We infer therfore, that the Ribs, when they are drawn upwards, do amplify the Breat idewie, but when they are drawn downwards, then they traighten the Breat on the ides.

This is further confirmed in that, becaue at uch time when the Breat is dilated; namly, when the breathing is rightly performed, the Ribs are drawn a little upwards by the trength and force of the Intercotal Mucles; and when the expiration is performed; namly, when the Breat is contracted, the ame Ribs are drawn back again downwards by the help of the oblique Mucles of the Abdomen. Any man may oberve this in himelf or in any other man epecially in great inpirations and expirations. For in a vehement inpiration he hal plainly perceive at the ame time to be lifted upwards, and withal to enlarge the breadth of the Breat; but in a vehement expiration he hal feel the Ribs as it were bowed downwards, and at the ame time contracted inwards. Neither of thee things could happen, unles the poition of the Ribs were uch, as that thoe beneath in repect of the Spine, hould make an acute Angle, and being more depreed, hould make it o much the more acute, and by conequence the Breat, hould be then mot traightned; and on the contrary being lifted upwards, they hould appracch neere to a traight Angle, with the Spine, and o extend the ides of the Breat. We conclude therfore that the Ribs in this affect ar drawn omwhat downwaads, and that the Breat is contracted on the ides, by reaon of the plenitude and tenity of Hypochondrical parts; although we grant as we have intimated above, that this caue is not o coniderable, that
we hould attribute any great part of this Diea unto it.

Be this therfore the third, The Cau of this vitiated Figure of the Breat, Is a lateral growing of the Lungs in the Pleura, in this Diea epecially, being confirmed it is mot frequently oberved to happen. Doubtles uch an adnacency doth retrain and interrupt the motion of the Ribs outwardly, wherby the Breat is laterally dilated. For if the Rib, under which this adnacency lieth, hould endeavor forcibly to remove it elf, from the center of the Breat, there would be danger of pulling the Lungs that grow to it, or the Pleura it elf from the ribs with intollerable pain. For although the Lungs upon the ingres of the ayr admit an eay extenion, according to al the parts therof, yet when they fal down, or are tuffed with thick humors (which mot frequently happneth in this cae) they carce admit any notable ditention, without diolving the unity either of om Veel, Membrane, or the ubtance of the Bowels themelvs. Moreover, whilt we conider that in ound bodies the Lungs are very rarely laterally divided from the Pleura; and but in thoe parts only of the chet, which were to be expoed to motion at a coniderable ditance; namely, the Back, the Stern, the Mediatinum (that is the Membranes that divide the middle of the Belly) and perhaps the middle parts of the Diaphragma, &c. We conceive that wie nature did this deliberatly and with deign; namly, leat their connexions hould either offend the dilitations of the Breat, or render the Lungs themelvs obnoxious to thoe kind of calamities. However it be, it is carce conceivable, but that preternatural growing together of the Lungs, with the Pleura more or les mut hinder and retard the free preading of the Ribs towards the ides, and therfore it conduceth a little at leat to occaion the narrownes of the Breat.

Be this the fourth, The cau of the vitiated Figure aforeaid, is an unequal nutrition of certain parts of the Ribs in repect of others. And this caue we affirm to be much more effectual then the ret, to procure this Symptom. Which that we may demontrate, we aert firt, that the even uppermot Ribs do chiefly, if not olely, contitute this Figure of the Breat for the five lowermot, as they are not immediatly conjoyned with the Stern; So neither can they in any manner point, or elevate the Stern. Ad alo, that eing (as we have already hewed) they do not cloe in perfect Circles, their Figure is eaily movable, that it may more or les yeeld to the fulnes of the Hypochondriacal parts. But the even upper Ribs are Articulated by their Grizles, with the Bones of the Stern: from whence it may perhaps com to pas, that they do omwhat lift up foreright tho bones of the Stern, which they do touch, when the five lower Ribs being deprived of the contact of the Stern, cannot effect it. Secondly, We aert, that all the Ribs, and not only the five lowermot, but alo the even uppermot do admit an equal nutrition in this affect, and that they are more nourihed in one part then in another, & therfore that they are more extended in length by that, then by the other, which is more paringly nourihed: and indeed that they grow more on that ide in which they are conjoyned with the Gritles of the Stern, and that they are les and more lowly lengthened on the other part, namly, the Head or top, wherby they are fatned to the Regions of the Back. The Reaon is, becau the forepart of any Rib is more oft and pongy, then the hinder part of it, as any man may make tryal in any Creature. Seing therfore (as it is clear by what hath been aid) that the ofter parts of the Bones do in this affect more eaily receive their aliment and augmentation, then the harder
and more olid, it followeth that the foremot parts of the Ribs which are mot oft, are more lengthened than the undermot. Thirdly, We aert, that in a Body of a Circular or Anulary Figure, if one part of the Ring be more lengthened than another, the other parts mut needs give place to this increa, or ele that part o unequally lengthened, wil either outwardly hang out, or be inwardly knotted, either upwards or downwards, and be bent either one, or many of thee ways. This we thus demontrate. Let the Circle or Ring be A
A
B
E
C
F
D B. Let the former parts of it be uppoed to be lengthened from A to B. But the other parts of it; namly, C D E to remain in their poition, and not at al to yeeld to the aid lengthning. Thee things being uppoed, the lengthened portion of the circle, namely, A B mut needs be either lifted up outwards, or depreed inwards, either bent upwards or downwards or variouly: For otherwie the ditance between the limits of the tring F would not uffice to contain that portion of the Circle now lengthened, the figure of the Bow being changed. For thoe limits did only uffice before; therfore the Bow being lengthened, and not the tring, or the tops and limits of the tring, it cannot be, that the Bow hould be to the tring as before. It mut be changed therfore, the bending being made either outwards or inwards, or upwards or downwards, or many of thee ways, as may be perceived by the Figures following. The firt Figure repreents a
Bow outwardly prominent The econd, Inwardly, and the third variouly bent and intorted. And indeed the firt doth very fitly et out the Figure of the Breat vitiated in this affect. For we have noted above, that the ribs articulated

D with the Stern & Spine do make a kind of imperfect Ring, and that they are in this affect ooner nourihed, and lengthned in the foremot, then in the hindermot part, therefore in repect of the caue this Symptom fully and fitly agreeth with that Figure firt decribed. Beides, we have uppoed that the parts of the Circle do remain firm: that alo in this affect may be accommodated to the lateral and hindermot parts of the ribs For eing thee grow much les then the formot, certainly, they may wel be uppoed to be table, unles, perhaps om may ay, that either the ides and hinder parts of the Ribs, by dilating themelvs, or their Joynts, with which they are fatned with the turning Joynts of the Back, by uffering the Ribs to be bended backwards, do yeeld
omwhat to that exceeding augmentation. But neither of thee can be rightly aid. For firt, the latter and hinder parts of any Rib as they are more hard and olid, o are they likewie more tiff and trong then the formot; now it is aburd to imagine that the weaker parts of the ame Rib can bend the tronger, or that the les flexible parts will yeeld to thoe parts which are eaily flexible. Wherfore the lateral and hinder parts of the ribs cannot be o bent, as that they hould yeeld to the formot lengthened parts therof. As for the Joynts of the Ribs, doubtlee that Joynt, wherwith the Rib is conjoyned with the turning Joynt of the Breat, can by no means uffer the Rib to be bent o much backward, as that it hould yeeld to the lengthning therof; and that not only becaue it is double; namly, in the hollownes of the turning Joynt, and in the tranveral proces therof: and therfore very unapt to permit a backward motion. But chiefly, becaue it is even ten times tronger than the formot Joynt, wherwith the ame rib is fatened to the Bone of the Stern. Now a Joynt ten times tronger, and withal double, and in uch a manner formed double that it is altogether unapt to endure any retrograde motion, cannot by any means be imagined to yeeld backwards, leat the Joynt ten times weaker hould be bent omwhat forwards. We mut conclude therfore, that the lateral and hinder parts of the Ribs do not yeeld to that unequal production of them, which happneth forwards, and by conequence, that in this repect they are to be accounted firm; and therfore that unequal lengthning, mut needs change the figure of them, on the forepart; and that by bending them there either upwards or downwards, or inwards or outwards, or divere ways.

This bending of the Ribs here cannot be made either upwards or downwards, becaue the Ribs in regard of
their latitude are unapt to be bowed either way. Ad alo becaue that they are firmly retrained by the Intercotal Mucles in their poition; o that without offers of violence to thee Mucles, they can carce be bent, either upwards or downwards.

That that elongation cannot, or indeed very carcely can bow the Rib inwards may thus be proved; becaue, the greatnes of the Liver is repugnant to uch a motion. For we have proved before, that the greatnes of that Bowel doth omwhat lift up the Bone of the Stern outwardly or forwardly. Then the very figure of a Circular Rib doth evidently contradict the inward making of any plication, or bending. Latly, becaue that elongation doth not many ways bend the Ribs, it may from thence alo be inferred, that uch a bending would infer a compound Figure, and hould necearily contain om of the imple figures before rejected.

Wherfore we conclude, that that unequal length of the Ribs on the forepart, mut needs change their outward Figure, elevating the Bone of the Stern, and then pointing forwards the Figures of the Breat (otherwie almot even.) The following Scheams do lively expres the manner of it.

Let A be the Bone of the Stern, B the turning Joynts of the Back. C and D the two oppoite Ribs, which as we have aid do make a kind of Ring. Therfore if the forepart of the Ribs; namly, between C and A and between D and A be lengthned, and yet the parts between C B and D B are no way anwerable to this elongation, the figure of the Ring mut needs be outwardly changed. Therfore eing that the Rib is, (as we have already hewed) unapt to be bent either upwards or downwards, or inwards, it mut needs be outwardly bowed, as it is expret in the econd Figure, wher the tern A by reaon of the elongation of the part of the Rib CA and D A is repreented, as if it were outwardly pointed, which is the very vitiated Figure of the Breat in this Diea.

Beide the caues of the narrownes of the Breat hitherto commemorated, we can here ad the mal increae of the Ribs between C and B and alo between B and D. For the Jut Latitude of the breat doth chiefly depend upon a du augmentation of thoe parts of the Ribs. For if thoe parts of the Ribs do grow to a jut length, they mut necearily dilate the Breat unto the Ribs almot in a jut proportion, that little of the narrownes only being taken away, which the former caues alone were able to introduce. For by how much the more thoe parts of the Ribs are lengthened, by o much the more alo the Lateral part of the Rib D and the part C wil be ditant from the Back-Bone B, and wil make the Breat o much the broader. On the contrary when upon the increa of the other parts of the Body, thoe parts of the Ribs are but little, or not at al augmented, they mut of neceity be laterally les ditant from the center of the Breat then is meet, and therfore the Breat mut
be traightned towards the ides. For the ides of the rib C and D are o much the les ditant from the Back-Bone, and the center of the Breat, as the parts of the Ribs between C B and D B are les lengthned. And let thee things uffice to have been poken concerning the narrownes and acumination of the Breat in this affect: With which we put at lat an end to this diquiition of the Organical vices occurring in this Diea.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. The Secondary Eence of this Diea in the Animal Contitution.
div.p: HAving put an end to the examination of the Natural and Vital Contitution, vitiated in this affect, it now remaineth that we make enquiry into the Animal Contitution. And we have already affirmed, that no primary fault doth here occur, and that it is a part of the primary Eence of this Diea. But whether there lurk in it any econdary vice, that we hal now examin.

But eing that neither the Ancients nor the Modern Writers, who have written of the Animal Faculty, have made any mention of the Animal Contitution, nor indeed o much as once attempted a decription of it: It may very jutly be expected from us, who acknowledg uch a Contitution. And eing om wie men do dient from that decription, which may be deduced from
the opinion of Antiquity, and the common opinion concerning the Animal faculty, and otherwie expounding the matter do ubtitute a omwhat different decription, we thought good to offer both to the Readers conideration.

According to the former and vulgarly received opinion and decription of the Animal faculty, the animal contitution is that affection of the Body which coniteth in the generation and due motion of the Animal Spirits. Now by the due motion of the Animal Spirits they undertand the excurion of them from the Brain thorow the Nerves like lightning, and again their recoure back to the Brain, whereby they declare unto it what is perceived by the Organs of the outward Senes.

Others (as we have aid) do otherwie explicate this matter. They grant indeed that the Animal contitution doth include the generation and detribution of the Animal Spirits but they ay that that wift motion of the Flux and Reflux of the Animal Spirits like lightning, is inconceivable in the Nerves, and if it be not unprofitable, yet certainly it is very little neceary to etablih the animal faculty. But intead of this they ubtitute in time of waking a certain contractive motion, of a moving endeavor of the very ubtance of the Brain, of the Spinal Marrow, of the Nerves ariing from thence, and of the parts into which they are detributed. And this motion or endeavor produceth (ay they) a certain Tenity in the aforeaid parts, by whoe force all the alterations imprinted in thoe parts by any objects, are communicated to the Brain. For as in a Harp when the trings are tretched to a jut pitch, if they be tricken in the mot gentle manner at either end, that motion in a moment, at
leat a Phyical one, runneth to the other end; o they likewie affirm that any Nerve being moved which is duly tretched without the Skull, that motion is extended to the Brain it elf by reaon of the continuity and Tenity of the aid parts, and there fixeth a certain impreion conformable to the cau thereof. But in time of leep they uppoe the Brain, the Spinal marrow, and ome of the Nerves to be omwhat looned. And indeed they ay perpetually and imply that the foremot connexions of the Spinal Marrow with the Brain remain loo continually during leep; but they grant that the hindermot connexions with the Cerebethi are omwhat extended, as in Night-walkers, and o by that means they do in ome ort dicern outward objects, but they judg not of them by common ene, but as it were reflected from the memory to the Fantaie. Neither do they uppoe it neceary that all the inferior parts of the Spinal Marrow, and therfore the Nerves from thence proceeding hould be perpetually looned during leep: eeing that mot Birds leep tanding upon their feet; eing that repiration in time of leep doth preuppoe the Tenity of ome Nerves; and latly, eing where leep firt teals in, the uppermot Nerves are wholly looned before the neathermot. As for Dreams they conceive that they proceed from a various and chanceable agitation and commixture of divers impreions treaured up in the memory, which are now again frehly perceived by reaon of a retained Tenity in om parts of the Brain. But when in deep and profound leeps no dreams are repreented, then they ay that the whol Brain is looned.

Now whether the former opinion or this latter be mot agreeable to truth, for the preent we do not much care; Neither do we here undertake to determine this
Controverie, eing that the Animal faculty doth exercie his function both waies, from the ame caues, and that the econdary vice doth happen by this affect in the Animal Contitution almot after the ame manner. For firt, as for the generation of the Animal Spirits, whether the former or the latter opinion be true, it wil be all one; becau we find no fault in the Brain (unles perhaps ome other Diea be conjoyned) wherin each opinion uppoeth the Animal Spirits to be generated. For we have hewed above that the Head ought not to be numbred among the firt affected Parts, and that the internal and proper actions therof are not viciated in this Diea. Then econdly, As for the detribution of the Animal Spirits, whether it be perfected backwards and forwards by that rapid and udden motion like lightning, or by a motion only made forwards and that too gentle and low, commonly the ame fault occurreth in this Diea.

For firt, Seing that that uppoed rapid motion of the Animal Spirits is caued by their paage into the firt affected Parts, namely, through the Spinal Martow without the Skul, through the Nerves from thence proceeding, and through the parts into which thoe Nervs are detributed; and eing that all thee parts in this affect do labor with a cold ditemper, with a paucity and dulnes of inherent Spirits, the due wiftnes of that motion mut needs be omwhat retarded. For a cold ditemper, as alo a benummednes and penury of Spirits are repugnant to any motion, excepting a contrictive; ome may ay that the opinion propounded in the firt place doth uppoe a wonderful activity and ubtilty of the Animal Spirits, wherby they can eaily overcome this repugnance. But, however it may be, eing that the parts react through which the Spirits have their paage,
and labor to communicate their coldnes and dulnes to them, they mut needs in ome degree retard that activity of the Spirits, leen their ubtilty, and omwhat intercept that expedite tranition. Wherfore this opinion being uppoed as true, the Animal Contitution will be viciated in this affect, in regard of the retundation of that motion of the Spirits. And that econdarily, eing that this motion is not interrupted by the primary fault of the Animal Spirits, but by the fault of the firt affected Parts, as hath been aid in like manner in the Opinion lat propoed, wherin the motion of the Spirits is uppoed to be peaceable and gentle, they mut needs whilt they are omwhat lowly tranmitted through the firt affected parts, contract ome vicioity from the depraved inherent Contitution of thoe parts, for the ame Reaons which we alleaged in the Quetion immediatly preceding. It will be therfore according to this Opinion alo, a Secondary vice in the detribution of the Animal Spirits,

Again, As for the Tenity of the very ubtance of the Brain, of the Spinal Marrow of the Nerves and the Nervous parts in time of waking, which is uppoed in the latter Opinion before propounded, there mut needs be ome defect of a due Tenity in the Spinal Marrow without the Skull, in the Nerves ariing from thence, and in the parts unto which they are detributed. For firt, A cold and moit ditemper is repugnant and adver to that due Tenitiy, o alo is that dulnes and penury of inherent Spirits; wherwith the Parts are without controverie rendred lothful, and les apt to perform the Animal Actions; the contrary wherof happeneth, when the aforeaid parts obtain their due Tenity. Secondly, It is manifet by what hath been aid, that the Tone of thee parts is omwhat viciated in this
affect, by reaon of their exceeding loones, lipperines, oftnes, weaknes and internal lubricity, which qualities do mot evidently enfeeble the jut Tenity of the aid Parts. Although therfore that the Brain in this affect do for his part yield a due and jut influx, yet it is carce poible, nay it is altogether impoible, that it hould communicate that Tenity in a ufficient degree to to the Spinal Marrow without the Skull, to the Nerves from thence proceeding &c. becaue of the ditemper, benummednes and penury of the inherent Spirirs. Thirdly, The Symptoms in this Diea that relate to the Animal faculty do mot clearly confirm the ame thing. For Children afflicted with this Diea do from the very beginning therof (if they be compared with others of the ame age) move and exercie themelves very weakly, and are les delighted in manly ports: but upon the progres of the affect, they are aver from any vehement motion, as they tand upon their feet, they reel, wave, and tagger, eeking after omwhat to upport them, and can carce go upright; neither take they pleaure in any play unles itting or lying along, or when they are carried in their Nures Arms: Finally the weak Spine is carce trong enough to bear the burden of the Head, the Body being o extreamly extenuated and pined away. All which things do abundantly demontrate that the Tenity of the parts ubervient to motion is les rigid in this affect than is jutly requiite in time of waking. If therfore that due Tenity in time of waking be a part of the Animal Contitution, which we here uppoe, that being viciated mut without all doubt necearily contitute a Diea in the Animal Contitution; and eing that this fault hath no primary dependance upon the Brain it elf, but upon the inherent Contitution of the firt affected parts, it
ought in all Reaon to be reputed a Secondary fault in repect of the Animal Contitution.

Yet here we meet with a cruple. Som may demand, Why the en as well as the faculty of motion is not vitiated in this affect? The reaon is plain, a far greater tenity, trength and vigor of the Nervs is required to exercie the motive then the enitive faculty. For almot the gentlet motion of the Nervs is ufficient for ene; but not for motion. So you may oberve in the motion of any Joynt, that the Mucles which move it are very hard and tiff, but that hardnes being remitted, yet the enation is eaily performed. Nor doth that any way hinder, becaue that omtimes in the Paly the ene is omwhat tupified, and the motion remaineth: for the Paly is an affect very different from this; for in that the primary fault reides in the very Animal Contitution, therfore it may o fal out, that both the ene and the motion may be equally affected. Beides, when perhaps one Nerve doth want the du influx of the Brain, and another which is extended to the mucles of that part doth enjoy it, it may be, that for this caue alo the ene may be abolihed, and yet the motion may continu; although this cae is not o frequent, and that the motion is more uually taken away, the ene remaining. But we have aid enough concerning this matter. And thus at length we have produced thoe things which we have meditated of the integral Eence, both primary and econdary of this Diea; and that with as much perpicuity as a matter o difficult and unearcht into, would bear: In the next place we hal addres our elvs to the examination of the caues of this Diea.
