div.head: CHAP. XV. The Caues of the Rachites. And firt thoe things which concern the Parents.
div.p: WE have largely explained above both the Primary and Secondary Eence of this Dieae. And indeed we have ufficiently demontrated in the ame place, the dependance of the econdary upon the Primary Eence. It may not therfore be here expected, that we hould again purpoely and in particular dicus the caues of the econdary Eence, which we have handled before. It may uffice that we have found out the caues of the econdary Eence. Yet if any caue do occur which at once hath an influx as wel into the primary or econdary Eence of the Diea, we hal not refue to take notice of it, by the way as we proceed.

But omitting al diligent earch into the everal kinds of caues, we purpoe to contract this our dicour chiefly to two heads. The former containeth the Infirmities and the dieaed dipoitions of the Parents, which perhaps have o great an influence upon the Children, that they uppeditate, at leat a prones to this affect, and infer an aptitude to fal into it, if they have not actually fallen into it from their very birth. The latter comprehendeth the acceary caues of this Diea; namly, thoe which happen to children after their birth.

Concerning the caues of the firt kind we meet with a Quetion at the firt entrance: How and whether this Diea may be aid to be hereditary? That we may the more uccesfully proceed in the determination of
this quetion, an hereditary Diea mut be ditinguihed into that properly, and that improperly o called. And indeed an hereditary Diea properly o called, is ever uppoed to be preexitent in both or one of the Parents, and from thence to be derived to the Progeny. But an hereditary Diea improperly o called, is not uppoed to be preexitent in the ame kind, either in both or one of the Parents; yet the ame fault mut always necearily precede (perhaps altogether of a different kind) at leat in one of them, by vertu wherof a certain dipoednes is imprinted in the children, wherby they are made obnoxious to fal into this improperly hereditary Diea.

Moreover, An hereditary Diea properly o called, is twofold; either in the conformation, as when a lame Peron begets a lame; a deaf Father, a deaf Son, or a blind a blind; or in the imilary Contitution: as when a Gowty Father begets a Gowty Child. It is to be noted, that in the firt kind, ther is an hereditary fault inherent in the firt affected parts of the Conformation. But in the latter, there is no neceity that a Diea of the ame kind with the Diea of the Parents, hould be actually inherent in the Embryon, from the firt formation. But uch a dipoition imprinted by one or both of the Parents is ufficient, which as the life is lengthened may be actuated into the ame, by the concour of other intervening caues. Again, an hereditary Diea improperly o called, may be likewie twofold; namely, either in the Conformation, or in the imilary Contitution. In the formation, as when neither of the Parents is blind, pore-blind, lame, &c. yet have begotten a Son blind, pore-blind, or lame, by the very fault of the formation. For in thee caes, that very fault which is enible and conpicuous in the Iu, flowed from om fault in the Parents, although perhaps of a different
kind, and o it may be called, though improperly an hereditary Diea. In like manner in the imilary Contitution of the Iu, there may reide an hereditary Diea improperly o called, as when a Melancholy, edentary, or an intemperate Parent, begetteth a Child ubject to the gowt, or the Cachexia, although perhaps the Parent was never troubled either with the one or the other.

Thee things being thus premied, we approach neerer to the reolving of the Quetion. And firt, we affirm that this Diea is not comprehended under the former pecies of an hereditary Diea, properly o called. For that coniteth in the formation: but this Diea according to its primary Eence, is a imilary Diea, as we have before demontrated, and very rarely bewrayeth it elf from the very Birth, much les from the very conception and formation. And for the ame Reaons, we alo affirm this Diea belongeth not to the former kind of herditary Dieaes improperly o called. Which after a like manner conit in the formation of the parts, and are begun preently after the firt formation.

Secondly, We ay, that o it may com to pas, that this Diea may fall under the econd pecies ptopounded, of an hereditary Dieae properly o called; namely, that which coniteth in the imilary Contitution. Yet we cannot affirm this as certain and undubitable, becau the Children which we have hitherto known to be afflicted with this Diea, have not lived to uch maturity of years as to beget Children: and therefore we cannot otherwie uppoe, then by probable conjecture, whether or no their progeny hould be infected with this affect, as it were by right of inheritance.

Thirdly, We ay, that in many Children this Diea doth directly fal under the econd pecies of an hereditary
Diea improperly o called. For according to the primary Eence of it is a imilary Diea, and although it hath not yet been o long and ufficiently dicovered unto us, that we can determin the effects of it, how they wil operate in the Progeny, yet frequently in the preent progeny we have oberved certain Rudiments of this affect to have been derived to many from one or both of the Parents. So that although neither of the Parents were in their infancy or child-hood afflicted with this Diea, yet om prones and dipoednes to this Diea hath preently appeared in their little Infants, epecially in thoe whoe Parents before coition were predipoed by om vitioity of body, or error of life, to tranmit this pollution to their Iu; but thoe defilements of the Parents which dipoe them to propagate Children obnoxious to this affect, we hal by and by reckon up, in their order; from whence alo a higher confirmation of this aertion may be deduced.

Fourthly, We ay, although the affects of the Parents do frequently imprint a certain propenion in the Iue, to fal into this Diea, o that this Diea may be therefore reputed in the econd acception of an hereditary diea, improperly o called; yet it very rarely happneth that this Diea doth actually break out before the birth of the child. One amongt us atteteth, that once, and only but once, he aw a Child new born invaded with this Diea. And in this Child the Back-bone, and the neck were o weak, that they could not utain the weight and greatnes of the Head, within three months after it was born, the Child dyed. Wherby it is apparent that he was grievouly affected. It eemeth conpicuous by what hath been aid, that Infants, however they may frequently borrow from their Parents a dipoednes to this affect, are mot rarely and eldom troubled with it
before they are born, but if at any time they are o prematurely afflicted, that then the affect is mot vehement and grievous. Now a reaon of the event of both thee may be demanded. To the former therefore we ay, that this Diea doth partly conit in a cold ditemper of the firt affected parts, and indeed an unequal one, as namly, being very cold in the aid parts, repect being had to the temper of the Head, and the Bowels: and that hereupon that unequal coldnes of thoe parts, is of great moment in this Diea, and that alo in repect of the very inequallity. For this contributeth much to that unequal and deficient ditribution of the Vital Blood to the parts firt affected. Seing therfore at uch time when the Embryon is carried in the womb, this inequallity of the temperament of the firt affected parts may be much corrected and averted by an equal heat, wherby the womb may on every ide embrace, and cherih the body of the Embryon, it followeth that the getation doth very much drive away this Diea, at leat retard the invaion of it. For the body of the Womb being all about equally warmed with an even heat, and equally embracing and cherihing al the parts of the Embryon, doth not eaily permit one part to wax colder then the ret, and by that means to be cherihed with a defective and paring afflux of the Vital Blood. Wherfore eing that that very inequallity of heat and comfort, are Eential parts of this Diea, and without which this Diea cannot conit, it is no wonder that the womb trongly reiting thee parts of the Diea, and the invaion therof, doth for the mot part protract it, at leat during the impregnation.

As for the latter part of the quetion propounded, namly, Why Infants, who before their birth were infeted with this Diea, are more grievouly and dangerouly afflicted? We ay, according to that Aphorim of Hippocrates,
that a Diea which holdeth the leat congruity with the condition of the Dieaed, is more dangerous then the contrary; as a Feaver threatneth more danger to an old man, than to a yong, and in the winter, then the ummer. For a Diea that hath om correpondence & conformity with the condition of the Dieaed, requireth a lighter cau for its introduction: but that which is contrary therunto argueth the magnitude of the cau, which notwithtanding reitance, and oppoition, will produce his effects. In the preent Diea therfore if the equal and impartial heat of the womb cannot retrain the propenity of the Embryon to this affect, but it wil fal into it, om vehement caue mut needs be imprinted by the Parents, and the eminal Principals extreamly weakned. Therfore there is little hope when the Embryon laboring with this Diea is born, neither wil a prudent Phyitian attempt the cure without om Prognotick of imminent danger. Moreover, intead of a Corallary, we ubtitute another Rule, having om affinity with the former, although perhaps it be not yet certain and approved; namly, that Children by how much the ooner after their birth they are invaded with this Diea, o much the more difficulty (caeteris paribus) are they delivered from it. And let thee things uffice concerning the Quetion propounded.

We wil now apply our elvs to the diviion and reckoning up of thoe caues which on the Parents parts may produce this Diea. Som of thee faults in the Parents relate to the Generation of the eed, wherof the Embry on coniteth, others have reference to the Embryon now conceived, and yet born about in the Womb. The faults of the Generation of the eed proceed either from the man or the woman, or from the whole Body, or from thoe parts onely which are dedicated
by nature to Generation. The faults of the Parents depending upon the whole Body have the tronget influence into the Child, becaue it tranmitteth uch matter to the Generation of the Seed, as is unapt for thoe parts dedicated to that office. We purpoe not here to particularize the everal faults of the matter of the Seed, but to intance in thoe alone, which conpire to entitle the Progeny to this Diea. Thee we reduce to four Claes.

The firt Clais containeth a cold and moit ditemper of the matter, wherof the Seed is Generated. This chiefly reulteth from a cold and moit ditemper of the Parents, unto which we alo refer a predominancy of il juice, epecially that which is Phlegmatick and waterih alo a Cachexia, and Dropy, and perhaps the Green-Sicknes, which om cal the white Feaver, not ufficiently ubdued before conception; al which affects manifetly help to contitute a waterih matter, both cold and moit in the Genital Parts, which is not only in general les apt for the Generation of the Seed, but it particularly inclineth to a condition of this Diea; a part of whoe primary Eence coniteth in that very cold and moit ditemper, as we have already proved. Moreover, we may perhaps hither reduce the Scurvy, the French Pox, & the Jaundice, in which affects the Blood alo is polluted with filthy excrementitious humors, and corrupt exulcerations, which cannot eaily be changed into laudable and fruitful Seed.

The econd Clais containeth containeth the penury of Natural Spirits, wherby the good Seed hould be Generated. For a Spirituous Seed cannot flow from uch a kind of matter. The caues which uppeditate that impure matter to the Parts of Generation are the dried and extenuated Bodies of the Parents, wated either by
long abtinence, or by om vehement evacuation, as by vomits, lasks, Lienteries, Dyenteries, Hepatical Flures of long continuance; by an exceive Hemorrhage from any part, by violent weatings, or any Chronical Dieaes, which wateth the trength and is not repaired before Coition epecially, a Conumption, a Hectick Feaver, an indigetion from any kind of Cau. Latly, from a defective and imperfect Concoction of the lat aliment, or the fault of any part. For in uch caes the matter which is eparated to the parts ubervient to Generation, is detitute of a competent plenty of Natural Spirits, wherupon the Parts preparing and concocting the Seed cannot perfectly correct this defect, and ejaculate uch Seed as is ufficiently abounding with Spirits. Seing therfore that a coniderable part of this Diea coniteth in the paucity of Natural Spirits, it cannot otherwie be, but that the iue propagated by uch a crude and almot Spiritles Seed, hould be tainted with a certain Natural Propenion to this affect, even in their firt rudiments, which afterwards upon the concurrence or other caues, is eaily deduced into Act.

The third Clais containeth the benummednes or tupour of the matter tranmitted to the Generative Parts, wherof the Seed is produced. For not only the olid parts, but alo the whol Mas of Blood, and the humors therin contained are obnoxious to that ame tupour. And from hence it is that Phyitians being to render the caues of Dieaes, do ue to ay, that the humors and alo the Blood are too fluid and moveable and unduly vehement; omtimes on the contrary that they are unapt for motion, les fluxible, and unactive beneath a Mediocrity, & in repect of this thing alo a certain Mene is mot wholom: but more things relating hither may be een above. We will here only proecute thoe faults
of the Parents from whence this defect of vigor and activity in the matter of the Seed doth arie. Thee therfore are firt the fot, loo, and effeminate Contitution of either or both the Parents, indipoed to trong and Maculine exercies. Secondly, an overmoit and full diet and epicurion, obnoxious to frequent crudities. Thirdly, A delicate kind of life abandoned to ea and voluptuounes, lothful, and rarely accutomed to labor, danger, and care. Hither you may alo refer a total defect of manly Exercie immoderate leep, epecially oon after mate, and any kind of leepings whatoever, a edentary, peculative life, intent upon oft and queint Arts and Sciences, as Poetry, Muick, and the like, to thee may be further added a dayly frequenting of Comedies and other Plays, an aiduous reading of Fables, and Romances, and intead of manly and laudable Recreations, a loo expence of time in Carding and Dicing. Hither alo belong the neverfailing fruits of a lating peace and plenty, uch as ecurity, indiligence and the like. All thee enumerated faults do manifetly contribute a hare to introduce a lazines and Effeminatenes in the parts. Seing therfore that the Blood, together with the humors contained in it, doth in its circulation wah all thoe tupified parts, it cannot otherwie be, but that as it glideth along it mut participate ome uch alteration; and eing that ome portion of the tranient Blood affected with this tupefaction, is tranmitted to the Generative Parts, with the very matter wherof the Seed is Generated, it is eaie to infer that that Child which pringeth from uch principals mut inwardly contract at leat ome propenion conformable to the luggihnes, and tupour of its Native matter, and that that propenion, after-Birth when the preervation is taken away by the equal cherihings
of the Womb, is by divers caues without difficulty deduced into act, wherfore eing that uch a dulnes is a part of the Primary Eence of this Diea, it followeth that in uch vitiated principals there lurketh a propenity to this affect, derived from one or both of the Parents.

The Fourth Clais containeth the vicious Dipoitions (if any uch occur) of the Parents, who in their Childhood were infected with this Diea. For thee would tranmit into the Children a continuation of an hereditary Diea properly o called. But becaue, as we have aid, it is not yet manifet whether the Parent afflicted with this Diea in their infancy hall beget children therewith affected; beides, becau the faults of the Parents may be conveniently referred to any one of thee Claes aforeaid, or to many, or indeed to all of them, it will be fruitles to init longer upon them. Therfore having reckoned up the faults of the Parents which depend upon the whol Body, in the next place we proceed to their faults which peculiarly reide in the Genital Parts.

Thee faults are omtimes a cold ditemper, omtimes a moit, when by reaon of too much humidity they are looned or weakned, wherupon they ejaculate either an unfruitful deed or uch as is propene to this Diea, omtimes thoe parts are infeted with a virulent, vicious or waterih Gonorrhea, and they excern a Seed not ufficiently elaborated; the ame mut be aid of the white and red Fluxes of Women. Again, ome things outwardly applied to thoe parts have reference hither; as Ointments of Hemlock and other Narcotical things, epecially if they be often anointed with them, in like manner Oyntments that are incorporated with white or red Lead, Chalk of Lead, Litharge, Sugar of Saturn
and the like, dayly and for a long time adhibited to thoe parts. For uch as thee blunt the activity of the inherent Spirits in thoe Parts, and introduce a certain dulnes in them, which being communicated to the Seed prepared in them dipoeth the progeny to this affect.

At length we have finihed our intended enumeration, if not of all, yet at leat of all the mot principal caues which happen before Conception about the Generation of the prolificative Seed, and have any concurrence to produce this Diea, or to dipoe to the production therof. Now follow the faults and errors of the Mother in the time he beareth the Embryon in her Womb, which alo mut be reputed among the caues of this Diea before the Birth.

Firt, There hapneth a cold and moit ditemper of the Womb it elf, which (as were we ilent is eaily manifet to every one) may mot readily be communicated to the Embryon by the perpetual contact of the Womb.

In the Second place, All thoe things offer themelves which uppeditate to the Embryon crude and impure Juyces converted by excrementions and corrupt humors intead of laudable aliment. Hitherto principally belongeth the unwholom and prepoterous diet of Women with Child, epecially inclining to moiture, coldnes and the heaping together of crudities. The ame things alo happen by the imperfection and defect of the firt or econd Concoction, epecially when they are not excerned by vomit or ome other evacuation of the Crudities from thence proceeding, but are at length tranmitted with the Mothers Blood for the aliment of the Embryon. Beides, if a moit and cold Diea, as a cold and moit ditemper with the matter, an ill digetion,
a Cachexia or Dropy, &c. do invade a woman with Child after Conception, it may thereupon eaily happen, that the impure aliment alo, which nouriheth and cheriheth the Seeds of this Diea, be dipened to the Embryon.

In the third place are to be reckoned al thoe things that defraud the Embryon of du aliment, as any exceive evacuation, epecially a lahing flux of Blood in any part; alo a rah opening of a Vein, or Phlebotomy that exceeds in quantity. The uckling of another child may alo divert the afflux of ufficient aliment from the Womb towards the Breats. Hitherto likewie belongeth inordinate fating, or any indigetion in the Mother, any inappetency after meat, or defect of concoction. Moreover, an acute Feaver hapning to a woman with Child, beides other inconveniences, may alo defraud the Child of du aliment; o alo an Hectick Feaver. All thee things do not only infer to the Embryon, a dejection of Vital Spirits, and a defective nourihment, but alo they caue a want of natural Spirits. For the Naturall Spirits are wated and diipated without due nourihment, and are alo detitute and diappointed of neceary reparation. Seing therfore that a part of the Eence of this Diea coniteth in the defect of Natural Spirits, om dipoition to this affect mut need be bequeathed to the off-pring from the caues aforeaid.

4ly. & latly, exceive leepines of women with child, lothfulnes, ea, any vehement labor and exercie after Conception, do alo contribute their hare. For although violent motions and actions of any kind are forbidden to women in uch caues; yet moderate labors, watchings and exercies which offer no violence to the womb, or provoke to abortivenes, do not only conduce to the health of the Mother, but in om degree they drive away
that dulnes from the Embryon, and augment the heat, vigor and activity of it. And thus we put an end to the firt Chapter of the caues of this Diea before the Birth. Thoe which happen after the birth hall be the ubject of our next examination.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. The Caues of this Diea incident to Children after their birth.
div.p:
WE have noted in the precedent Chapter, that Infants from their firt Origin are eldom afflicted with this Diea, but by reaon of the Caues there reheared, that they are frequently affected with a natural dipoednes, and propenion to the ame. We hal now proecute thoe caues which are apt to actuate that Natural dipoition after the birth, or newly and fully to produce this Diea. For it mut be known that the ame caues which may actuat that predipoednes to this Diea, may produce this Diea a new, if they be ufficiently intenive in their degree. And therfore we confes that thoe children which are prone to this Diea from their Nativity are eaily affected; but that other which are free from al Natural corruption fall not into the ame but upon more potent caues; and yet thoe caues are the ame for their kind and differ only in the degree. We therfore thought it needles to peak of thee things ditinctly and apart: it
may uffice that we have poken of them indecriminately and together.

At the very entrance a Quetion there is which importunes a Reolution; namely, Whether Contagion may be numbred among the caues of this Diea, and therfore whether this Diea in a proper and right undertanding be a contagious Diea, indeed he that conidereth this Diea unknown to the Ancients, how it firt invaded the Wetern Parts of England, and in few years hath been ince dipered all England over, will at the firt thought eaily judg it to be contagious, and to have been pread o far and wide by the infection of it. But the matter will eem to be otherwie to him that will conider it more intentively, For although this Diea may in ome manner endeavor to imprint an affection like unto it elf in other Bodies, yet it carce advanceth o far that it can totally produce a Diea of the ame kind. For perhaps it may in one ome light inclination in another Body, yea, omtimes perhaps it may accelerate or haten the invaion of an affect in a Body highly predipoed unto it, yet it cannot therfore deerve the Name of a Diea properly contagious. For all Dieaes conpire to change and aimilate thoe Bodies which are neeret to themelves, yet that is not ufficient to denominate Dieaes contagious. For to contitute a contagious Diea properly o called it is further required that out of it elf it propagate a certain Seminal fermentation of it elf, which ecretly ininuating it elf into other Bodies, may by degrees introduce into thoe Bodies a Diea of the ame Species. But this Diea containeth no uch fermentation in its eence, neither is it ecretly propagated by a precedent emiion of Seed from it elf which may imprint a Diea of the ame Species in the adjacent Bodies.
For we have already often aid, That the firt eence of this Diea coniteth in a cold and moit ditemper, and in a dulnes and paucity of inherent Spirits, which affections if they endeavor to aimilate any Bodies that are neer them, they attempt and undertake it by open violence, and not by nares and fraudulence or a preimmiion of ecret little fires. In like manner if you reflect upon the Secondary Eence therof, neither the viciated Tone, nor the depraved Vital nor Animal Function, nor the Organical faults are found apt and fit in this affect to ininuate themelves into other Bodies, and to propagate their own Species. Finally, if we will conult experience, the matter will quickly be vindicated from all doubt. For we frequently oberve Children either of the ame age, or very neer to the ame age, be brought up in the ame Houe, wherof one or other of them is perhaps afflicted with this Diea, whilt a third or many amongt them do ecape it. Yea, We have known Children not only educated under one common Roof, and delighting in the continual and mutual ociety of one another, but dayly meeting at one Board and lying together in one Bed; wherof one who hath been ill affected with this Diea hath not infected any of his companions either by feeding or lying together. Which could carce poibly happen in a Diea properly contagious. Wherfore Contagion being excluded from the Catalogue of this Diea, we will addres our elves to the finding out of uch as are more true and unquetionable. We divide the caues which produce this Diea after Birth into two Claes. The firt containeth the errors which procure it in the ue of the ix nonnatural things. The latter comprehendeth the precedent Dieaes of divers kinds, which are wont very often to leave behind
them ome Inclination to this affect.

As for the former Clais concerning the abue of the ix non-Natural things, o far as they relate to this Diea, eing that children are eldom dicompoed with any vehement paions of the mind, and can thereupon very difficultly fal into this Diea. Again, in regard that the ue of Venery appertaineth not unto them; we wil reduce and limit thee caes to the five ubequent heads. To the Air, alo to what things oever extrinecally occur, or are applyed to the body, to meat and drink, and uch things as are inwardly received, to motion and ret, to the kind and manner of life, to actions and exercie, to leep and watching; latly, thoe things which are preternaturally retained in, or evered from the body. Thee everal things we hal examine in the propounded order with al convenient brevity.

div.head: Of the Air and uch things, as happen outwardly.
div.p:
A cold and moit Air doth powerfully contribute to this Diea. For eing that it doth more eaily teal into the external and firt affected parts in this Diea, then into the hidden and fenced bowels, it directly helpeth to imprint in thoe parts that unequal; namely, that cold and moit ditemper. The contitution of this kind of Air, is chiefly predominant about the beginning of the Spring, at which time the Nures ought to be cautious and circumpect. How they too confidently expoe their children, which are ubject to this affect, to the injuries of the Air; as alo when the Air is cloudy, thick, rainy, and ful of vaporous exhalations. Hereupon places neer the Sea, great Marihes that are obnoxious to much rain and howers, and fed with a great number of Springs, are wont to be (caeteris paribus) very fruitful of this affect.
In like manner houes neer the banks of great Rivers and Ponds or Meers are for this purpoe condemned. Moreover, frequent bathing and wahings with weet water, although they be applied actually hot, yet in regard that they are potentially cold and moit, they are alo jutly culpable; for they do in om ort communicate their ditemper unto the parts whereunto they are adhibited, and more or les cau a oftnes and loones in thoe parts, and make the circulation of the Blood too lippery.

Hither we may alo refer cold and moit liniments, as alo uch as are looe and lippery, being too often continued in that tender age, epecially about the Spine or the Origin of the Nervs: latly, oft linnen cloaths, if they be not wel dried, they cherih the roots of this Diea. For this cau amongt others, it hapneth that the Children of poor people are the les obnoxious to this Diea, becaue namely, for the mot part they are enwrapped in coure cloaths, and woolly integuments, each of which doth rub and tickle the parts thereby exciting and augmenting the inward heat, and irritating a more copious afflux of the Vital Blood unto the habit of the Body, and are therefore very effectual to banih this Diea. But the oftned fine linnen doth neither irritate the heat into the external parts, nor laudably cherih it. For if they chance to be for om hort pace of time removed from the touch of the parts, they preently looe their warmth, and at the next touch they conveigh a ene of coldnes into the parts. Wherefore uch linnen cloaths being in the number of thoe things which are dedicated only to extrinecal application, and eing that they are hurtful by their ole coldnes & oftnes, we have referred them to this firt Claes of caues, & the firt part therof
which containeth cold and moit things outwardly occurrent.

In the econd place the Air being infected with any particular infection, as noxious Metalline exhalations, which for the mot part ight againt the inherent Spirits of the parts, by a kind of venemous malignity, and do either extinguih them, or drive away and diipate them; withal they diolve the Bone of the parts, and the pulificative force, epecially in the parts external, where they firt happen, they at leat diminih, if they do not weaken it, and affect it with a languidnes. Thee things are principally caued by exhalations from Lead, Antimony, Quick-ilver, and the like. Moreover, ointments made of the ame, are almot alike perillous, if the firt affected parts be frequently and uneaonably anointed therewith; although perhaps thee things do alo belong to the fouth title of this Clais. Finally, we have oberved om Children who have been anointed with Mercurial Unctions for the Scabs, to have fallen afterwards into this Diea.

In the third place an Air vehemently hot and ubtle, extreamly attenuant and diolvent, may likewie be numbred among the caues of this Diea, becaue it allureth forth, diipateth and conumeth the inherent Spirits. In like manner hot liniments and epecially dicuive withal, Chymical oils ditilled and not ufficiently corrected by the commixture of things temperate; for thee in uch a tender contitution of the parts do eaily melt and reolve the Spirits into a volatile and Airy thinnes, and by conequence infer a penury of Inherent Spirits. Hither alo belong harp, altih, hot and dicuive Baths, epecially, if they be uneaonably and unmeaurably ued, for thee no les then the former do wat and conume the Spirits.

Fourthly and latly, An Air filled with Narotical vapors or exhalations, and baths, fomentations and Liniments made of Soporiferous and Narotical ingredients, as Hemlock, Henbane, Opium, Nighthade, and the like, and externally applied, are very fitly reducible, alo to this Clais. For they eaily introduce a benummednes into the firt affected Parts, into which they firt conveigh their force. Which benummednes is not only it elf a part of the firt Eence of this Diea, but it alo eaily dulleth and diminiheth the Vital influx in thoe parts, and conequently is alo a cau of that part of the Secondary Eence of this Diea, which coniteth in the Vital Contitution, which thing we have already explained more at large. And thus much of things outwardly occurring.

div.head: Secondly, Of Meat and Drink, and things inwardly taken.
div.p:
To this Title there belong firt aliments of any kind which are too moit and cold, for thee things manifetly cherih the ditemper, wherin a part of the Eence of this coniteth. Hither therfore we refer mot kind of Fih, and crude Meats which are not well prepared by Coition; alo all thoe things whatoever they be which cau a defect of concoction in the Ventricle. Therfore the feeding upon new Meat, before the former Aliment is concocted, is very hurtful for Children dipoed to this affect; and in this repect, a plentiful Diet is altogether to be abandoned, and a thin pare Diet ought to be oberved, for too liberal feeding doth overwhelm and choak the heat, and therfore mut needs accumulate many crude and raw humors. And perhaps this one may be reputed among the epecial caues,
why this Diea doth more frequently invade the Cradles of the rich; then afflict poor mens Children. In like manner cold & moit Medicines taken inwardly, and alo uch as are laxative, and endued with an internal lipperines, do manifetly relate hither. For thee things do not only infer a like ditemper, but they produce a Relaxation in the Tone of the parts, and affect them with an internal lipperines, and in a word they render the current of the Blood through the firt affected parts over lippery and eaie.

Secondly, Nourihments that are too thick, vicous and obtructive belong hither, epecially becau they interrupt the equal ditribution of the Blood. Hither we refer fleh hardned with moke, and eaoned with much Salt; in like manner Salt Fih, and Cheee almot of any kind plentifully fed on. Bread newly taken out of the Oven, and not yet cold; alo almot all weet things condited with Sugar, unles they are withal tempered with Wine, or cutting, or attenuant. Obtructive Medicines likewie of any kind belong hither, unto which we may further ad uch as are Partotical, and whatoever being drank induce a benummednes into the parts.

Thirdly, Nourihments that are of an extream hot and biting quality, harp, & corroive, as old & trong Wines, epecially being drank upon an empty Stomach, Meats alo that are eaoned with much Pepper and aromatical Sawces, mut be connumerated among the reputed caues of this affect, For thee things in uch a tender conitence of the Parts, do eaily feed upon and devour the inherent Spirits. The ame thing is alo affective by Medicines that are immoderately hot and dicuive, yea, thee are far more powerful to hurt, becau they more quickly and forcibly poil the inherent Spirits, than the prementioned Nourihments.

div.head: Thirdly, Of Motion, Ret, Exercies, and Actions.
div.p: Motion and Exercies, if they exceed a mean, they diolve the Body of a little Child into a profue Sweat, and withal they omwhat diipate the inherent Spirits of the Parts, and therfore for that reaon they may conpire the introducing of this Diea although we conceive it falleth out exceeding rarely, that Boys are infeted with this Diea, wherof we dicour. But a defect of Motion and want of Exercie doth mot frequently, yea and mot effectually concur to the production of this affect. For the Spinal Marrow, and the Nerves from thence ariing, and the other firt affected parts, erve chiefly for Motion and Exercies. A tupidity therfore and luggihnes of thoe parts, is a cau that neither their inherent heat is ufficiently cherihed, nor that heat extenuated, nor the cold ditemper tealing in banihed, nor the excrementitious, and uperfluous moitures expelled by a due tranpiration, but it permitteth them to be affected with a certain oftnes, loones, and internal lubricity, wherupon the Arteries alo detributed unto them are faintly irritated, yield a dull and lothful Pule, neither do they render the parts omwhat turgid or welled, but leave them lank and ubiding. By which means the circulation of the Blood becomes low and lened, and more lippery than is meet, the production alo of the vital heat mut thereupon be necearily be feeble and weak, all which coniderations do ufficiently evince that this is an efficacious cau of this Diea.

div.head: Fourthly, Of Sleeping and Watching.
div.p: We grant that Children hould leep oftner and longer then Men; yet if it be exceive even in Child-hood the matter is the ame as in defect of exercie and motion. For leep is a certain ret and privation of watchings or of the exercie of the enes. But watchings conit in the very exercie of the enes, according to Aritotle in his Book de Som. & Vigill. Wherefore the evils that we have decribed to arie from the defect of motion and exercies, the ame alo mut needs happen from immoderate leep. On the contrary, in that tender age, inordinate watchings are no les noxious. For they do not only retard the concoction of the aliment, but they likewie taint the Blood with a kind of acrimony, and conequently diipate the Principals of the Natural Contitution of the firt affected parts, and without difficulty introduce a defect of inherent Spirits.

div.head: Fiftly. Of things preternaturally cat out and retained.
div.p:
All the internal caues of Dieaes might be perhaps not incommodiouly reduced to this title. For any thing whatoever contained in the Body, and preternaturally altered, as they are preternatural, they indicate their ablation, and may o far forth be reputed among things to be cat out, which are nevertheles preternaturally retained. But we more rightly grant, that all internal caues may be ditinguihed into two kinds: one wherof containeth thoe things which are preternaturally retained and cat out: the other, uch things as are contained in the Body being preternaturally altered. For thee latter are not only taken away by cating out, but alo by
Alteration, they may be reduced to an agreeable proportion of Nature. However it be, there is a great affinity between the Humors vitiated by Alteration, and the excrementitious Humors which are retained. For there are o many and uch various ways of cating out in the Body, that carce any humor can be imaginably produced by Alteration, which doth not properly relate to the ecretive and excretive faculty of ome Bowel, or ome other partt and is detinated to be evered and evacuated from it; and therefore though the errors of the firt concoction are carce corrected in the econd or third, by Alteration, yet they may be mended by local motion, or excretion, made from ome part of the Body, the unprofitable parts being eparated and rejected. In like manner the mas of blood being any ways preternaturally altered, or infected with ome Humor, the peccant matter which cannot be otherwie ubdued by Alteration, is quickly exterminated perhaps by excreion made from ome part or Bowel (unles withal the ecretive or expulive faculty thereof be hindred) therefore it mut needs be of great moment for a Phyitian to know what Humors are particularly predominant in any Diea, and by what determinate ways they may be mot properly pied out according to the intent and purpoe of Nature.

For there are as many ubordinate pecies of things pied out, as there are ditinct ubtances of the Bowels and other parts detinated to that office in the Body. For it is credible that the Liver doth cat out one thing, the Kidnies another, the Sweet-Bread another, the Spleen another, the Stomach and Guts another, the Lungs another, the Brain another, the Stones, the Matrix, the Kidnies, the Kernel under the Canel Bone, the glandulous parts of the Larynxes, the Throat and Jaws another,
the carf Skin and the Skin another. For it eemeth carce admittable, that Nature hould build and prepare for her elf Organs of different kinds, and yet hould make ue of divers of them for the performance of one and the ame action. Therfore when the excretion of any of the aid parts hapneth to be retrained, a certain peculiar filth will flow out from thence into the mas of Blood, and o there wil be o many differences of things preternaturally retained, as there are kinds of parts inervient to particular cating out: and in like manner there wil be as many kinds of vitious excretion, either by exces, defect or depravation, as there are divers wais thorow which the excretion may be made.

If any man demand, Whether the everal kinds of things excerned be ufficiently dicovered and undertood by us: We anwer, that an exact knowledg is deired of that particular humor which is to be cat out thorow the new Veel of the Sweet-Bread, then in the next place, what is cat out by the Kidnies, the Kernel under the Canel Bone, and the glandulous parts of the Larynx: yea, perhaps it is yet care ufficiently known, what is rejected by the Spleen. For this caue therefore amongt others, it eemed good unto us to uperede in this place any high and accurate diquiition of things ecerned and retained, either in relation to the parts and ways whereunto they belong, or in order to the preent affect, and rather to init on that fourfold diviion of Humors made by Galen; namely, into Choler, Phlegm, Blood, Melancholy, adding only undue tranpiration and weating. For although we may doubt, whether this diviion can deduce the humors to the ubordinate Species, (as we have noted above) more then four parts ditinct in the pecies are evidently dedicated to the cating out of the humors; yet eing that this diviion
of the Humors is not only approved by al Claical Phiitians, but that it is likewie profitable in it elf, and at leat reduceth the Humors to certain Heads or Kinds, (however perhaps every kind may comprehend under it everal pecies) we are reolved for the preent to init upon it, and o much the rather, becaue under a general notion it very fitly conjoyneth and containeth both things altered and preternaturally contained within, and alo things to be pied out which are not yet excerned, and in that repect it will ea our burden and contract our work. For whilt we make our proceedings in this manner, it will be needles to intitute any other peculiar Chapter of the Caues of this Diea, namely of this altered which are preternaturally contained, eing that they are comprehended, as we have aid, under this Title.

We reduce therfore the internal Caues of this Diea (whether they be excrementitious humors retained, or viciated by alteration) either to Choller, or to Melancholly, or to Elegm and a Waterih humor, or an undue Tranpiration and weating, for the Blood properly o called is in this affect carce oberved to be faulty.

p.hi: You may object, That Practical Phyitians do in this Diea commonly precribe the opening of a Vein in the hollow of the Ear, oberving that Evacuation to be very profitable, which Reaon could hardly admit, unles the Blood were in ome degree peccant?

div.p:
We anwer, That this Remedy is available, not in repect of the univeral plenitude of the Blood, but by reaon of a peculiar plenitude of the Head it elf. For we have already hewed how that the Blood is uneqally dipened to the parts of the Body and indeed illiberally to the firt affected parts, but to the Head uperabundantly.
Therfore although there be not an univeral redundancy of the Blood in this Diea, yet in repect of the particular Plenitude of the Head it elf, uch a particular emptines, is perhaps profitably intituted thoe outward and mal Veins of the Ears being cut. You may reply that we by this Anwer do indeed decline the univeral Plethora, but that we grant a particular one of the Head, which ought no les to be eteemed a cau of icknes, We anwer, That we have at large explained this fault of the Blood, when we dicoured of the unequal ditribution of it, unto which place it properly belongeth, eing that it is a cau of the Secondary, not of the Primary Eence of this Diea; and therfore a vain and uperfluous repetition therof ought not in this place to be expected, We will now therfore proceed to our purpoed diquiition of the Humors, and likewie the Tranpiration aforeaid.

Firt Choller (whether by this word you undertand that excrementitious humor in the little Bladder, and the Chollerick pore, or a hot, dry, harp, and bitter part of the Mas of Blood, or that unavory humor that tateth like tinking Oyl, begotten and flowing in the Stomach by ome corrupt aliment, epecially, that which is fat, addut, or alt; or certain harp and corroive Excrecences produced in the Body by corrupt Blood) if it abound and luxuriate in the Body, very probably be a cau of this affect.

For although it may rather eem to impugn that cold and moit ditemper, which is a part of the firt Eence of this Diea; yet in regard that it is apt in ome ort to hinder the nourihment of the Parts, either by a vehement irritation of the expulive faculty, or by attenuation of the aliment, and to extenuate and wat the very inherent contitution of the Parts, and by conequence
to conume and diipate the Natural Spirits, it may not unjutly be numbred among the caues of this Diea. For every one knows that Perons of a Chollerick Contitution are lean, and of an extenuated habit becau of the Reaons aforeaid. Secondly, A Melancholly humor (whether you undertand the Earthy Portion of the Blood, or that altih or tartar like matter excreted in and with the Urin, and when the Urin groweth cold, incorporating into little Sands; or that owr humor powred into the Ventricle perhaps by the Spleen (though not through that hort Veiny Veel, as the Ancients beleeved) or thoe terrene Parts of the aumed Aliment, which are evacuated by iege with the other Excrements) undertand either or any of them, if this humor aboundeth and be not purged out after a due manner, may be blamed as a cau of this Diea. For firt, that humor which is the more Earthy part of the Blood, if it exceed a jut proportion in the Mas of Blood, it rendreth it unapt to nourih the Parts, epecially thoe that are firt affected; for the firt affected parts are of a more noble texture than the ubtances of the Bowels, or the bony parts; and therfore we have already noted how the Parenchymata of the Bowels and the Bones do eaily admit nutrition, and by a way like unto digetion; but thoe former parts do require a far more exquiite ecretion & elaborated aimilation. And this is the Reaon that the flehy parts of the Bowels are rightly imputed among the impure and groer aliments, namely, Becau they are nourihed with a cour Blood, and not accurately elaborated before the Union. Secondly, Any great accumulation of Saltih, and Tartar like matter is an Enemy to Nutrition, and is rather diipative and devouring than favoring augmentation. Thirdly, The owr Humor of the Ventricle is
totally ravenous, and as it were hungertarved, and perhaps where it aboundeth it eaily communicateth to the Blood uch another Depredatory quality; Fourthly and latly, The Terrene Dregs of the Belly may if they be inordinately retained, taint and infect the Chylus, and render it unapt for the nourihment of the part. Finally we grant, that every propounded kind of Melancholly uperfluouly coagumented or preternaturally retained, doth not primarily, properly, and directly concur to the production of this evil; but nevertheles we are of opinion that indirectly, and after rhe manner propounded it may contribute omthing to the generation of it,

Thirdly, Flegm (whether it be taken for the moiter and colder part of the Mas of Blood, or for the wheyih part therof, or for the low humor of the Stomach and Guts, or for the Spettle, or for the Snot of the Notrils or Jaws, or for that peculiar humor, which perhaps the new Veel of the Sweet-Bread doth ue to evacuate) however you take it, if it be retained or abound in the Body, it hath a direct reference to this Diea, and properly deerveth to be called the cau therof. For this humor is cold, mot, low, thick, benummed, little piritous, lot, and affected with an internal lipperines; all which things do exactly comply with the primary and econdary Eence of this Diea as they have been propounded. Wherfore upon a uperfluous accumulation of this humor, eing that there ucceedeth a conpiracy to the production of this affect, it ought jutly to be eteemed a proper cau and a Primary Agent.
Beides thee humors undue Tranpiration, as alo immoderate or defective weating may be omtimes numbred among the caues of this affect.

For exceive Sweating, as alo immoderate Tranpiration, doth diipate the Spirits, and withal diolveth the parts, epecially the external which in this Diea are the firt affected, and the inherent Spirits being conumed it eaily leaveth a cold ditemper behind it. For to a jut excitation and conervation of the heat of the parts there is required a certain due and regular trife of the exhalations between breathing, which if it prove deficient, the actual heat alo (becau it partly coniteth in this trife) becomes very feeble and languid, and the parts are eaily expoed to a cold ditemper. But we have already poken of this matter at large. On the contrary, Sweat preternaturally retrained, as alo a very mal or lened Tranpiration, doth eaily kindle a Feaverih heat, and therfore it likewie injureth the Spirits and diolveth the parts, and rendreth them afterwards eaily obnoxious to a cold ditemper.

Finally, That we may comprehend all in a word, Any humor excerned above Reaon or Meaure doth eaily introduce a colliquation of the parts and a diipation of the inherent Spirits, and conequently dipoeth the Body to this affect. And let this uffice to have been poken of non-Natural things, and the caues of this Diea thence ariing.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Precedent Dieaes which may be the Caue of this Dieae.
div.p: THee Dieaes, in repect of their proper Eence, ought only to be called by the name of Dieaes, but in repect of this Diea they may rightly pas under the notion of caues of Dieaes, becau they leave it behind them as one of their Effects. Yet although many of them (as they relate to the Parents and o imprint a Natural pollution in the Off-pring) are rehered above, nevertheles, by right they here deerve their conideration, yet in a different repect and order. Thee Dieaes we reduce to three Kinds or general Heads.
Firt, To Dieaes that have ome affinity with this affect.
Secondly, To Dieaes that extenuate the Body.
Thirdly, To Dieaes inducing a tupor and dulnes in the firt affected parts.

div.head: Of the Firt Kind.
Of the econd kind.
div.p:
Mot Dieaes making lean, or any ways extenuating the Body, although perhaps they no way participate of of the Eence of this Diea (like the Dieaes of the firt kind) yet they do dipoe the Body to the invaion of this affect, and may alo leave it after them. For all great quotidian Dieaes, in proces of time do extenuate the Body, wat the inherent Spirits, and diolve the Tone of the parts; and this attrition and attenuation of the parts doth chiefly refer to the firt affected parts in this Diea. For as we have already aerted, the ubtance of the Bowels are not o eaily ubjected to diolution or diipation. But in the diected Carcaes of thoe who have dyed of Chronical Affects, the Bowels
are oberved to be no les; yea, many times much bigger when the external parts (which in this Diea are firt affected) are for the mot part made lean with the vehemency of the affect. And therefore eing that extenuating Dieaes, do chiefly communicate their force into the firt affected parts, it eaily falleth out that in Children they help to introduce this Diea. For the inherent Spirits of the firt affected parts being very much wated, a cold ditemper mut needs follow, which by reaon of the crudity is (as we have aid above) received by a moit one and a benummednes; becaue the heat, activity, and vigor of the parts do chiefly depend upon the plenty of Spirits. And thus we have exhibited the manner wherby this Diea doth follow and as it were tread in the footteps of other foregoing affects of this kind, which we now further ubditinguih into three Claes.

The firt comprehendeth Dieaes extenuating and conuming the habit of the body, by ways inenible; hither are referred almot al Feavers, epecially the Hectick and Conuming, an Ulcer of Lungs with a putrid Feaver. Alo any continual Feaver that is violent, as a burning, malignant, petilential Feaver, a Pleuriie, and an inflamation of the Lungs, alo the mal Pox, and the Meazels when they grievouly afflict the Patient. In like manner intermitting Chronical Feavers. Latly, al Chronical Feavers that torment with vehemence do the ame. The econd Clais containeth Dieaes conuming by manifet paages, and evacuating the olid ubtance of the parts. Hither you may refer immoderate vomiting, a Lyentery, Dyentery, Lask, the Hepatical Flux, the Diabetes, any profue Hemorrhage or Bloody Iue, any exceive weating, any great Ulcer in any part, eating deep, and dayly cating out much matter.
For al thee Affects do evidently extenuate the habit of the body, and caue the introduction of this affect.

The third containeth the Dieaes which are aid to extenuate the ubtance of the parts not directly, but by conequence: as al Dieaes interrupitng concoction or the ditribution of the Blood. For thee prohibit the reparation of the parts continually fed upon by the Vital heat. Hereupon everal Dieaes of the Ventricle, Guts, Meentery, Sweet-Bread, Spleen, Liver; Yea, Dieaes in the Mouth, Jaws or Throat, which hinder only the aumption or wallowing of the Meat, may in this repect be numbred among the caues of this Diea. As a ditemper, a tumor, a naueating, a feeble appetite of the ventricle, a ditemper, a tumor an obtruction & Skirrhus of the Meentery, & Sweet-bread, or the Liver, Spleen, and the like effects of any of the aid parts, which by any means frutrate the due concoction and ditribution of the nourihment, and thereupon extenuate the parts by defect of nutrition.

div.head: Of the third kind.
div.p:
Dieaes that induce an atonihment to the firt affected parts, do alo by a peculiar propriety conpire the production of this Affect. For the Natural heat of thoe parts is omwhat dulled by them, and is rendred les effectual: whereupon a cold ditemper tealeth in by degrees, which is alo (as hath been aid) eaily waited on with a moit ditemper, a oftnes, and internal lipperines. Moreover, the Pul of the Arteries reaching to thoe parts is ecretly, and by little and little weakned, the ditribution of the Blood, and the Vital Heat is diminihed, the parts themelvs are paringly nourihed, and at length there comes a defect of Natural Spirits. So that from this Root alo, for ome time perevering
the Eence of this Diea may at lat bud forth. The Apoplexy, Paly, Lethargy, and the like effects do chiefly belong hither. Yet Children do exceeding rarely fall into this affect from thee leepy Caues, and o rarely, that we have not yet oberved this Diea to own its beginning to uch affects. If any demand a Reaon of this rarity; we ay, that the Bodies of Children by reaon of their permeability and thinnes, are eldom ubjected to thoe affects; but if at any time they are invaded by them the Diea doth not firt aault the Natural or Vital, but the Animal Contitution, and conequently procureth for the mot part a deprivation of the Animal Faculty, before it interrupteth either the Natural or the Vital. But the benummednes wherof we now peak, belongeth to the Natural Contitution, into which it cannot be preently transferred. Moreover, they are eaily and peedily driven out, by reaon of the facility of tranpiration in the Bodies of Children, if peradventure thoe affects do gently invade them: but if they rage and tyrrannize, they eaily and peedily dipatch and kil, as being in their own Nature mot terrible and grievous Dieaes; and the ooner, becaue of the weaknes of their Contitutions over whom they prevail. But which way oever they happen, they carce continue o long, as with ufficient efficacy to imprint this benummednes in the Natural Contitution of the parts. Yet we grant that thee affects may, if perhaps, they perit longer with life, affect the Natural Contitution with that benummednes o that this Diea may follow thereupon, although we can neither jutify, nor aert it upon the credit of a ingle obervation.

But the Dieaes which do mot frequently introduce an atonihment in the Natural Contitution of the firt affected parts, are thoe very ame, which hinder
Children any way from ordinary actions and due exercies, epecially from the ue of their feet, as the luxation fracture, or om wound of a foot, or thigh, or the leg, or the Back-bone: alo tumors and pains, or the like affects, whether they afflict the parts aforeaid or others, provided that they hinder the Children, o that they cannot walk, or play tanding upon their legs, or ue any Maculine Exercies. For hereupon by degrees the rigor and heat of the external parts waxeth dul, which in this evil are the parts firt affected, and from thence the other parts of the Eence of this affect, follow by an uninterrupted and linked ucceion, as whooever wil may ee above.

We have now run over the Caues of this Affect, and hould in the next place proceed to the differences therof, but that two difficulties do here interpoe themelvs, which properly reult from a higher conideration of the Caues propounded. For al thoe Caues now alleadged eem as wel common to Boys of big growth, as to Children, whereupon it may very pertinently be enquired, How it comes to pas, that they which are grown to mans Etate are not infeted with this evil, as wel as Children? Then again, Seing that the Caues propounded are al of them almot common, both to England and many other Countreys, & om of them to al Climats of the Earth, It may be demanded in the econd place, Why this diea is more frequent and rife in England, than in other Countreys? Thee Quetions we hal examine in order, and hal freely deliver our judgment concerning them.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. The Former Quetion.
div.p: WHy they which are elder in years are not equally obnoxious to this Diea as Children? The terms of the Quetion eem to ininuate, that this Affect may happen, though very rarely to thoe of big age. But we reerve the olution of this doubt til the cloe of the preent determination. Therfore in the mean time the Contitutions or dipoitions both of Children that are chiefly obnoxious to this Diea, and alo of bigger Boyes which are rarely ubject unto it, mut be oppoed and every way conidered and thought on: alo of Youths, Men, and Old Men, and that in order and relation to this Affect. For the Quetion is not abolute, but comparative, therfore the firt and bet way of determining it, wil be by a mutual comparion between the different dipoitions of the aid Subjects, how they admit the impreions of the propounded caues either with cae or difficulty. Then certain accidental and peculiar conditions of Yong Children, under uch an age mut be likewie conidered in repect of which they are under one age rendred more, under another les obnoxious to this Diea.

That we may the more uccesfully declare the former comparion, we will ditinguih the ages of men. Here we comprehend Children of ix months of age, a year old, two, three, four years old; there we undertand
thoe of five years of age or more, Youths, Men, and old men, and thoe we cal by the general name of Ju ••
ors and thee by the name of Seniors, unles p •••• ps the matter may require a ubditinction of the g •••• er ort: thee things being premied we ad <> our • lvs to the collation.

Firt, The yonger Children are of a colder temperament than the Elder. For the heat of the temperament is augmented from the time of the birth to mans etate, at which time it tandeth at a tay being far more intenive than that of Children, but afterwards it declineth by degrees unto extream old age, and a little before that extream age, it falleth into the ame degree as it held in the time of Child-hood; but before the approach of this term of extream old age the temperament of aged men is more hot than that of Children, for although yong Children may enjoy a greater plenty of Natural heat, and abound with Natural Spirits, yet there is no neceity that they therfore mut be of a hutter temperament, for there is required a concurrence of many things to contitute a hot temperament, beide the inherent Spirits, and the inherent heat; as for example a large portion of Chollerick humors, and withal or chiefly a trong endeavor of the Vital faculty, namely in the pules, and the Vital Spirits in their circulation. Seing therfore that the yonger Children are more cold, it is no wonder, if they be more ubject to cold Dieaes than others, uch as this is. As for old men, epecially uch as are inclining to extream old age, we grant that they alo are more cold, and upon every light occaion obnoxious to cold Dieaes. Wherfore from hence, namely, from the coldnes of the temperament, we infer no difference between yonger Children & thee
old men, in repect of an aptitude to fall into this affect.

Secondly, The yonger Children are more moit than the elder; for to wax old, if it be taken in a ound ence, is to wax dry. For although old men after their manner may be likewie obnoxious to moit affects, as Cathars, Obtructions, a Cachexy, a Dropie, a Palie, a Lethargy, a loones and trembling of the Nervs, and the like evils, yet really there is ome difference between a moit ditemper which happeneth to Boys, and that which befalleth aged Perons. For in Children an adventitious humidity contituting the ditemper doth not only penetrate the mot retired ubtance of the olid parts, but they are totally incorporated with the ame: But in old Men the olid parts, even then when it is endued with a moit ditemper, doth not eem to part with its earthines, but to be in ome ort compounded of that Earthy Nature, and a certain adventitious crude and moit Juice, or ele an excrementitious drunk into the pores, or into the ubtance of the parts, yet it is not ufficiently incorporated or united. For as and, being drenched in much water, retaineth al its Earthy ubtance, however it be omwhat moit; So alo the Bodies of old Men, however they may be moytened with crude and excrementitious humors, yet do they not depoite that terrene ubtance, or that part which by the Chymicks is deigned by the name of a dead Head, which they dayly accumilate unto themelves from their firt beginning. This ditemper therfore of old Perons is purious not genuine, crude and not perfectly digeted into the ubtance of the parts. And therefore although we grant that old men may in their way, labor with a moit ditemper, yet it is manifet withal by what hath been aid, how great a difference there is between this of aged perons, & that of Yong children. Morover, that
this moit ditemper of old men, is les Homogeneal to the preent affect, then that of children, appears plainly from hence, becaue it produceth not that oftnes and tendernes of parts in old men, as we ee it doth in Children, neither doth it equally dipoe them to a diipation or colliquation of the inherent Spirits, or any lippery paage either of the Blood or Exhalations, which are uppoed in this Affect: But on the other ide, it rather rendreth them obnoxious to obtructions, and the other evils recited before a comparion, therefore being made between the cold and moit ditemper incident to Younger Children, and that which is wont to affect old men, there reulteth a pregnant reaon, why aged people are not o ubject to this Diea as Children.

Thirdly, Yong Children, although they Naturally abound with inherent Spirits, yet by reaon of the eaie tranpiration of their Bodies, & becau of the laxity, tendernes and incoherence of the parts, they are much more prone then Elder perons to diipation and colliquation of the Inherent Spirits, and by conequence upon les and lighter caues they fal into a want of them.

Fourthly, Younger Children by reaon of that very ame weak conitance of the parts, are alo rendred more obnoxious to an atonihment than the Elder. For to the vigor and activity of the parts, there is required beides a jut plenty of Spirits, a trength of their coherence and conitence.

Fiftly, it is not needful for us to ad any thing concerning the Tone of the parts, eing we have o often ininuated the weaknes of it in Younger Children in repect of the Elder, and any man may oberve that upon the increae of years the Tone is more and more confirmed.

Sixthly, As for the diminute ditribution of the blood
to the firt affected parts, (which we have already proved to be a coniderable part of the econdary Eence of this Diea) We ay, that the Elder Children do ue more trong and frequent exercies then the Younger, and therefore that the pules of the outward parts are more trongly tirred up in them, and that a greater heat is raied and cherihed in them, and by conequence a cold ditemper is more potentially driven out of them.

Seventhly, as for the Organical faults, namely, the augmented magnitude of the Liver Head, and their Veels, it is a known thing that the proportion of the parts is more table and confirmed in the bigger Children, and on the contrary that in the Younger they are eaily moved and altered, but the augmentation ceaing they are not any more afterwards altered, without ome unuual and weighty caues. So that even in this repect the Younger Children are mot ubject to this Diea.

Let us therefore conclude the parts of the Quetion, That Young Children, in repect of their Natural Contitutions and dipoitions are more obnoxious to this evil then thoe that are Elder, and o much the more, the Younger they are.

But we mut not wave an Objection, that here we meet with, which alo doth very fitly conveigh an occaion of paing to the other comparion; namly, of Young Children amongt themelves. For if Young Children (as is manifet by what hath been aid) are more prone to this Diea by their Natural Contitution and dipoition, and the Younger they are, the more ubject they are: How comes it to pas, that Children rarely fal into this affect, before they are ix months old and omwhat more? For according to the Opinion delivered, Children
hould eem to be principally ubject to this Diea immediatly after their birth, which yet experience diappointeth; yea, rather indeed it witneeth the contrary; namely, that Children before they are nine months old are eldom or carce ever afflicted with this Diea. Here therefore it wil be needful for us to declare that other comparion of Young Children among themelvs. For it cannot be, that this Affect hould o contantly pare Children, chiefly dipoed unto it, and frequently invade thoe that are les dipoed, unles ome difference did intervene, which did in a divere manner relate to thoe ages, and which notwithtanding the propenity of Nature doth retard the invaion of the Diea, before the firt twelve months were compleatly expired, and yet afterwards, either doth not at all or not o potently defend Children from this Diea. Here therefore we mut find the very reaon of the difference between thee ages: which that we may the ooner do, it wil not perhaps be impertinent to take pecial notice by the way of thoe ages, which upon the authority of experience are oberved to be more frequently affected with this Diea, and likewie thoe ages which are leat afflicted with it.

We affirm therefore, that this Diea doth very rarely invade Children preently after their birth, or before they are ix months old; (yea, perhaps before the ninth month) but after that time it beginneth by little and little daily to rage more and more to the period of eighteen months, then it attaineth its pitch and exaltation, and as it were reteth in it, till the Child be two years and ix months old: So that the time of the thicket invaion is that whol year, which bears date from the eighteenth month, two years and a half being expired the Diea falleth into its declination, and eldom invadeth the Child, for the reaons already alleadged. But the
reaons Why Infants newly born are rarely affected, and why from the ninth to the eighteenth month they are frequently affected, and why after the firt eighteen months they are mot frequently affected hall now all of them in their order be produced.
The Firt Reaons why Children newly born are very eldom invaded with this affect may be thee.

The Firt is, Becau the Embryon in the Womb is by the equal heat and embracement of the Matrix trongly fortified againt this Diea, as we have declared above, and by conequence the ame being brought to light doth for a time retain om of that, muniment & defence which it contracted from that equal warmth of the Womb, and therfore preently after the Birth it doth not o eaily fall into it.

The Second is, Becau the Midwives and Nures do handle them o artificially when they are new born, that their condition is not coniderably different from that which they poeed in the Womb. For they enwrap the whol Body, excepting the Head, in one continual Covering; wherupon the exterior and firt affected parts of the Body in this Diea are fortified againt the injuries of the outward cold, and the hot exhalations breaking out from any part of the Body are duly and equally retained by reaon of that Covering which is two or three times double, and bound about with wathing Bands, and equally communicated to all the parts of the Body, o that they are cherihed with an even heat as it were in a common Hypocaut or hot Hou. Seing therfore that the firt part of the Eence of this Diea coniteth in an unequal cold ditemper, it is no wonder if thee Defences and Fortifications of the Body do avert it at leat for ome hort time.

The Third Reaon may perhaps be the wholomnes of the Diet, for Breat-Milk is the mot olubrious and agreeable nourihment that tender age, epecially when it is ucked from the Breats: for it is a imple and uniform Meat, full of nourihment, eaie to concoct, and friendly and farmiliar to the contitution of Infants. Therfore o long as they are conveniently nourihed with it, they incur the fewer errors of diet, and are rendred the les obnoxious to this Diea. Yet it mut be noted, that if the Nures milk be not laudable and good in it elf, or otherwie diagreable to the Contitution of the Infant, then this reaon is of no force. Therefore if the Nure be big with Child, or immoderatly addicted to Venery, or any ways ickly, or given to drunkennes and inordinate feeding, it is afer to haten the weaning of the Infant, unles you are provided of a better Nure.

The fourth and lat reaon is the lownes of the motion of this Diea in his firt invaions. For it tealeth on o lowly, that it carce bewrayeth any preparations to an aault til ome months are expired, unles the progres of it be advanced by ome extraordinary and mot vehement Caues, as by ome more violent Affect preceding or coming upon it. Seing therefore that this Diea doth o lowly take Root, and eing that Children, as we have formerly hewed, are commonly born free from it, it eldom hapneth to break out evidently into act til the ixth, yea, indeed til the ninth month. And thus we have given the reaons, why Infants newly born, notwithtanding the weaknes of their Contitution, are for many months priviledged from this Diea.
Secondly, The caues why Children from the ninth to the eighteenth Month are every day more frequently infeted with this affect, are thee,

Firt, Becau the firt Cau even now propounded, driving away this Diea in thoe that are new born, doth daily remit, and before the ninth Month doth totally vanih. Secondly, In like manner the econd propulive Cau before alledged till that age doth every day grow more effectual. For the hands of Infants, after ome Months, if not before, are uually et at liberty from the prion of their Blankets, and perhaps their Feet alo before they are ix months old, although at night they are wadled up again. In the day time therfore at the leat thee outward Members are detitute of that common and comfortable warmth. The Nures likewie do many times er, when they cloath the weak and feeble Infants too oon. For they idly define the time of cloathing them by the number of the Months, eing that they hould rather give an etimation of it by the trength and activity of the motion of their Hands and Feet. For when the motion and exercie of thoe parts doth avail more to excite and cherih their heat, and to irritate their Pules, than the warmth of their wadling cloaths, without all controverie that is the time to devet Infants from their wadling cloaths. Moreover thirdly, After the ninth Month Children uually are fed with other aliment beides Breat-Milk or other Milk, and from that variety in feeding there eaily reulteth ome errors in point of Diet. Fourthly, The lownes of the Motion of this Diea doth not hinder, but that it may break forth into act after the ninth Month. For the motion, by reaon of the unperceivable lownes of it, at the end of certain months, doth exhibit ome effects and impreions. Latly the evils of breeding teeth do likewie contribute very much to the ame purpoe. For the Teeth begin to breed commonly about the eventh Month, and come accompanied
with divers Symptoms, which eaily dipoe tender Bodies to this affect.
Thirdly, The Caues why this Diea mot frequently rageth when the Child is eighteen Months old, are;
Firt, Becau the Caues before cited hatning this Diea in the yonger Children, are upon the approach of this age taken away, or at leat they operate with weak and ineffectual powers.

Secondly, The evils of breeding Teeth, although in repect of the immediate Symptoms which they produce perhaps before this time, they nourih; yet for the mot part they leave behind them in the firt affected parts a certain dipoition, which privily hiding it elf within them, after the term of ome months produceth this Diea. But the breaking out of the Dog-teeth chiefly hath reference to this place; eing that thee break out a little before the Child is a year and an half old, and their coming forth likewie is of al other the mot painfull.

Thirdly, Hitherto belong alo thoe accidents which happen by reaon of ablactation or weaning of the Child, and at that time a great alteration befalleth Children in matter of Diet, which they endure not without palpable moletation. For herupon they are angry, they cry, the commotions of their minds makes them forake the nourihment of their Bodies, they are hard to be pleaed, neither do they leep quietly. All which things do eaily imprint in the parts firt affected at leat a foregoing dipoition (although perhaps not till a long time after) to this affect.

And o at length we have alo run through this econd Comparion, namely of yong Children among themelves, and we have briefly explained the Caues why
thoe Children at one age are more, and at another age are les expoed to this evil.

The Third part of the Quetion till remaineth, which as we aid we would reerve to be examined at the cloe of this Diputation; namely, Whether thoe that are of a greater age do omtimes fall (though exceeding rarely into this Diea.)

We ay firt, For o much as concerneth that part of the Eence of this Diea, which coniteth in a moit ditemper, that ome difference mut be expected to be between that ditemper in yonger Children, and thoe that are bigger, in yong Men, Men, and epecially in old Men, for the ame difference which we put before between the moit ditemper of yong Children and old Men, may according to quantity as more or les, be oberved between the middle Ages, and therfore the humidity of the yonger Children will be better concocted and more genuine than that of the elder, as it is obvious to collect, mutatis mutandis, from the ame reaoning.

Secondly, As for the organical faults, we affirm that necearily there concurreth a vat difference between Dieaes of this kind incident to Children, and perhaps to thoe of greater age, for the tumors of the Bones in the Wrets and Ankles, as alo that narrownes of the Breat, likewie that diproportionatly augmented bignes of the Head and Liver, are either les conpicuous or altogether undecernable, epecially in thoe that are grown to full age. For as the years encrea the Figure and proportion of the Parts becomes more compact, firm, and table; neither doth it eaily come to pas that one part doth much grow out more than another by true augmentation.

Thirdly, We ay that excepting the two premied
conditions, and that in that manner as they are propounded, this affect according to the other parts of the Eence thereof (although indeed very rarely and upon the highet caues only) may happen to Boys, Young Men, Men, and old Men. For firt a cold ditemper without al controverie may befal them, though not o eaily as Children. Secondly, A moit ditemper may alo invade them, but yet only by the limitation propounded. Thirdly, A want of inherent Spirits, may alo befal them, but then it mut proceed from the mot potent caues. For Chronical Dieaes and uch as conume the habit of the parts, or diipate it into ayr, or wat it by long fating and an Atrophy, do necearily leave behind them a paucity of Natural Spirits. We ee the outward parts even in thoe that are grown to ful age, when they are extenuated and conumed by uch like caues, to wax feeble, to languih, wither, and become detitute of al ufficient Spirituoity. Yet we grant that in thoe that are grown to full age, the evil which caueth leannes being overcome, the wated Spirits may oon be repaired by the vigor of the Pules, and that the rudiments and impreions of this Diea may be rooted out within one or two weeks, and by conequence, that they are eldom affected with it. In the interim, if it hould o fal out, that upon that conuming of the Inherent Spirits ome impediment hould intervene that might retard their reparation, it is poible that this diea may grow from thence in that manner as hath been aid. But a numbnes of the Inherent Spirits mut necearily follow upon a fewnes of them. Fourthly, The parts of the Secondary Eence, eing that they have a trong dependance upon the Primary faults, where thee perevere long (the Organical faults being excepted) they may upervene in their order. So that we do not
doubt but this Diea may happen to any age after childhood; the retrictions which we have now propounded being granted, and upon the urgency and pereverance of great and weighty caues.

One amongt us affirmeth, that he had a Gentleman in cure about thirty yeers of age, who by dayly immoderare ue of Wine and Tobacco, continued for ome whole years, having neglected the due receiving of his meat, fel into uch a weaknes of Stomach, that continually every morning he vomited, and loathed al kind of Meat, and if at any time he wallowed any with unwillingnes, he preently vomited it up again: to appeae this quezines of Stomach, he was at lat compelled to a continual ue of ordinary Aqua vitae, but afterwards his cutome was to mingle it with tale Beer, and a quantity of Sugar; and with this drink alone he preerved himelf alive for many months. In the mean time all thoe parts which in this Diea we cal the firt affected, were extreamly lean, and became oft, looe, languid and withered, o that he could neither turn himelf in his bed, nor rie, nor walk, nor tand upright, yet he felt no pain, neither was there any privation of en and motion, no cough, no uneay repiration, his face was well colored, and al the parts about his Head were in a good condition, and wel habited, o that had you judged of him by his countenance only, you could carce have upected that he was ick. As he lay in his bed he would chat with his Companions, take Tobacco by turns, and drink that mixture of Beer and Aqua vitae aforeaid. The event of the Diea doth not indeed belong to this place, yet we hal et it down to gratify them who are deirous to know it. The Phyitian being ent for, he trictly forbad al intemperance, and amongt other remedies having given him one grain & a half of Laudanum Londinenis,
he appeaed the naueous infirmity, and tumult of his Stomach, which part he likewie trengthned with internal and external applications, and precribed him uch a diet as was mot eay of concoction. Intead of exercie he olicited the heat unto the outward parts with rubbing them every morning: having firt given a mal quantity of trengthning and opening Electuary, made up with a little portion of Steel, which he drank in two ounces of Wine, compoed of Wormwood and Mint, a little Saffron being hung in it, to give it a tincture; three ounces of mal Beer, being tempered with it, and a quantity of Sugar to make the tate of it more pleaant. Moreover, he purged him by fits with gentle Medicines, and in the evening comforted him with cordials. Within twenty days he grew to uch a degree of amendment, that he could walk abroad, for the pace of an hour, and could without any triving or much wearines climb ladders without any help.
