But afterwards by a relaps into the like intemperance, he died in the abence of his Phyitian. But let us return from this degreion into the way, & direct our peech to our intended cope. The Affect being now confirmed, as it was upon the firt coming of the Doctor; Beides the faults of the Stomach, it eemed to include a great part of the Eence of this Diea, we now treat of. For in the parts ubervient to motion; namely, thoe that are firt affected in this Diea, there was a cold ditemper, either through defect of motion, or by reaon of the immunite afflux and dipenation of the Vital Blood. Again, the oftnes, lipperines, laxity, and lithernes of thoe parts hewed that there was a moit ditemper in them. Alo the extream leannes of thoe parts did ufficiently demontrate a fewnes of inherent Spirits, and the unfitnes to motion, and affectation of ret and ea did trongly
witnes a numbnes in thoe parts. The ful and florihing habit of the parts about the Head, when the other parts were extenuated, was a forcible reaon to prove the unequal ditribution of the Blood. But the peculiar caue of this inequality in this ick man, might be his frequent vomiting, whereby a more plentiful afflux of the Blood was driven to the parts about the Head the other being almot detitute of it.

Any man may perceive by what hath been aid, that at leat the greatet part of the Eence of this Diea was comprehended in this mentioned Affect. From whence at length we may probably infer, that it is poible for this Diea to happen to thoe of ful growth, being conidered according to the propounded limitations; although it very eldom coms to pas, becaue great caues and length of time are required to the production of it. And thus at lat we have put an end to the earch upon the former Quetion.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. The latter Quetion. Why this Diea happeneth more frequently in England, then in other Countreys? And whether it be Natural to Englihmen?
div.p: IT is acknowledged by the common conent of Phyitians that there are certain Country Dieaes; namely, which more frequently infet the Inhabitants of ome one Region, than of another, by reaon of om Common Cau. But eing the relation of the Country to the Dieaes uually raging in it, may be oberved to be of a diver kind; and eing wie men have improperly denominated ome Dieaes from certain Countreys: Finally, eing that they who have hitherto written of Countrey Dieaes have without difference, called all Dieaes which are mot rife in any Region by the name of National or Countrey Dieaes as if they did equally participate of the Nature of a Countrey Diea; we have judged it to be a profitable enterprize to premie ome things in this preent diquiition, concerning the differences of thee Dieaes among themelves.
Firt, Therefore thoe affects which have the denomination of Country Dieaes, from the Region, are properly, or les properly, and abuively o called.
There are four conditions required to denominate a Country Diea properly o called.

The firt condition is, That the Diea be more frequent in that Region, unto which it is attributed, as Natural and common, then in any other Region, unto which it is not attributed as uch. For a common or Country Diea, is always uppoed to have an unequal reference to divers Regions, and to infet one more (namly, that unto which it is acribed) and another les.

The Second Condition is, That the Diea depends upon ome kind of inclemency of the place. For a Diea properly common imputeth a certain crime or faultines to the very place; therfore when a place is not guilty of om peculiar fault, uch an imputation is improperly, fally and unjutly acribed unto it.

The Third Condition is, That the inclemency and harpnes of the Region be o great, as to affect the more wary, and uch as oberve a du Regiment of health, and uch an one as is apropriated to the place. For in the Regiment of health ome peculiar Caution is due to certain Countries. Therfore when a People neglecting uch a peculiar Obervation of the place, hal fall into ome Epidemical Diea by an erroneous ue of the nonnatural things, that it is not to be reputed a common diea, but to be imputed to the error, want of wit, incogitancy and negligence of the Inhabitants. For this diea, which we uppoe might have been prevented, had the Regiment of health apropriated to the place been rightly oberved.

The Fourth Condition is, That that vicious contitution of the Country do either continue long, or return often. For the fault of a place that is fugitive, not permanent nor often returning, mut be accompted as omewhat forregn and meerly accidental in repect of the
Region, and cannot properly denominate a common Dieae. As for example, If a pernicious and unuual Air hould chance to be blown hither from other countries, and hould produce a common diea, which hould not prevail beyond ome months; that diea ought not properly to be called common, but rather caual and chanceable. Wherfore the Feaver of Hungary, and the Sweating-icknes of England, although they obtained their Names chiefly from thoe Regions, yet are they abuively termed common, becaue they want a durable fomentation from thoe places, and becau they either cea altogether, or at leat are not for the preent more predominent in this or that place than in another.

Dieaes improperly comon do indeed include the firt propounded condition of uch as are properly o called, namely, becaue they more frequently occur in that Region whereunto they are attributed, then in another, (for otherwie they would not deerve the apellation of Dieaes improperly common) yet they want the econd third, and fourth. For they either lack that fomentation that is rooted in the Region, or that fomentation which they have is very weak and in coniderable, which alo may be overcom by a Regiment of diet appropriated to the place; or finally the fomentation is not permanent nor durable, nor frequently returning. Now by fomentation we undertand omwhat that is faulty in repect of health, founded likewie in the condition of the Country. Therefore when om common and frequent Diea arieth from the abue of ome commodity of the Region, as if om Nation by reaon of the great plenty of fruit, and the like fruitfulnes of the place, or by reaon of a long and ecure peace hould abue themelves to intemperance, loath or the like vices and thereby incur om common Diea, that Diea is not properly to be
called common. For the occaion of that Diea, which the Country did upply with, was laudable in it elf, and therfore what event oever ucceeded, the abue therof ought to be imputed to the error of the inhabitants, not to any unkindnes or dicourteie of the Region. In like manner if the fomention of a Diea be culpable, yet hall not that be founded in the very contitution of the Country, but in ome action of men, as when after the deolations of War the unburied Carkaes pollute the Air with their putrifaction, and therupon introduce an Epidemical Diea, this ought not to be called a common or Country Diea, becau it dependeth upon the liberty of mans will, and was not procured by any proper fault of the place.

Somtimes alo a Diea is acribed to a Nation or Place by calumny, and abuively through the malevolent and corrupt intentions of ome People to traduce the Fame of their neighbor Nations. After this manner the Neopolitans call the Venereous Evil, the French Pox, as if it were Natural and Common to the French. And on the contrary, the French to requite the Slander, term it the Neopolitan Scab. But of this enough.

A Diea properly called Common, is either Original and Ancient, or Adventitious and New. The Original is that which from the firt Inhabitation of the place hath infeted the Inhabitants: of this kind perhaps is the Diea in the Throat called Branchocele among thoe that dwell about the Alps; that burning Feaver which they call a Calenture, under the torrid Zone: the mortification of the parts under the cold Zones towards the Poles by extremity of cold.

A Country Diea that is new and adventitious, is that which is brought into a Country by ome common Cau. This is threefold, for either it proceedeth from
ome Original fault of the Region, prevailing by the advantage of time againt the health of the inhabitants, or from ome alteration or innovation hapning to the Region it elf. Or from ome incongruity between the Place and the complexion of the Natives.

Firt, A new common Diea invadeth a Country by ome Original fault in proces of time prevailing more and more. For 'tis poible, that the firm and trong Bodies of the firt Inhabitants of any place may powerfully reit the unwholom influence of the Region, and for many Ages may repel the invaion of the evil, although their poterity afterwards, in length of time, being by degrees changed in that peculiar Reaon of the complexion wherby they maintained the former reitance, may fall at lat into ome common Diea. For the Plica of Poland, and the Scurvy, are common Dieaes to the Sarmatians, Polanders, and the Inhabitants of the Baltick Ocean, and they are likewie new Dieaes, and (as all men confes) totally unknown to the Ancients. But to this day it is not known that any notable or remarkable Change or Innovation hath hapned to thoe Regions before the breaking out of thoe Dieaes, to which you might probably acribe the beginning of a new Diea. Wherfore we ought rather to ay that thoe new Dieaes did proceed from ome ancient and original fault of the places: and yet that they did not bewray themelves at firt by reaon of a peculiar reitance made by the Natural trength of the Inhabitants. For to this very day ome Families in thoe places are free from thoe Dieaes, and very credible it is that they may o perevere, not yielding to the injuries or threatnings of the Region.

Secondly, A new common Diea may reult from the altered or innovated contitution of the place. Such
kind of innovations happen in Countries, either by Earthquakes, or Inundations of Water, or the burting forth of ome new pernicious Springs, or perhaps of ome new Mineral Exhalations from the Caveous of the Earth, or from ome malignant Apect of the Stars and the like Caues.

Thirdly, A new common Diea may proceed from the incongruity of the Place with the complexion of the Natives. Such kind of Dieaes chiefly happen to Nations, when they tranplant themelves from one Region to another: epecially when the Contitutions of thoe Countries which they go to poes, are very different from thoe they forook. So the Englih who firt inhabited Virginia were frequently afflicted with a welling of the Abdomen, and the Hypochondriacal parts; who upon their return to England were cured without any difficulty, but they who continued in Virginia were not o eaily retored to health.

Moreover, National and common Dieaes differ among themelves. Becau ome of them totally depend upon the inclemency of the Region, and others in part only. The mortification of the parts eemeth to be of the firt kind which befalleth men in the Northern Tracts near the Poles. For the whol Eence of the Diea may be acribed to the cold and harpnes of the Place. Of the econd kind the Venereous Pox among the Wet-Indians eemeth to be. For there it is conceived to be partly gotten by impure Copulation, and partly to be contracted from the Inalubrity of the place. In like manner the Bloody Flux is predominent in Ireland, depending partly upon the contitution of the place, partly upon an erroneous and prepoterous diet. And thus much in general be poken of the differences of common Dieaes. In the next place we mut
enquire why this Diea is more rife in England than in other Regions? And by the way it mut be oberved, Whether, and how far forth this Diea may be aid to be Natural to Englih men?

Firt, it mut be oberved, that England is an Iland which borroweth ome humidity from the adjacency of the Sea, and ome frigidity from the ditance from the Equator, then that it aboundeth with innumerable fountains, dicovering their Springs almot in al places. Latly, That it is watred with many and frequent howers of rain more than other Regions. All which things do ufficiently attet the frigidity and humidity of the place. Seing therfore that a cold and moit ditemper is a part of the Eence of this Diea, we may eaily infer that the bodies of the Inhabitants are here more inclined to thoe ditempers then in other hot and dry Countries.
If therefore you demand, Whether this Diea, at leat conidered in this part of it, may rightly be aid to be natural to Englih men?

We anwer, That in om ort it may (although perhaps not properly) namely, o far forth as the ame is attributed as natural to other Regions, alike cold and moit (although perhaps it may not yet be oberved in them.) For thoe Countries are as readily dipoed to imprint a cold and moit ditemper as England it elf. Yet it mut be oberved, that a cold and moit ditemper is a common part of the Eence of this Diea, and that it alone doth not manifet the Affect, for every cold and moit ditemper doth not introduce this evil. Wherfore although we grant, that an exces of cold and moiture may be imputed as a fault to England, yet we deny that from thence it can be rightly inferred that the whol Diea is common and Natural to Englih men.

Moreover, Some Countries may perhaps be found out far exceeding England both in cold and moiture, as Scotland, Holland, Zealand, Ireland, and Denmark, and the like; wherin notwithtanding this Diea hath not been oberved to appear much. Therfore if this Diea be not rightly imputed to thee Regions, wherein that common caue is predominant; namely, the exces of cold and moiture. Certainly neither can it jutly be imputed to England, by reaon of that common Caue, which is here les prevalent. Again, The coldnes and moitnes of this Kingdom doth not o far trancend a a mediocrity, but that by outward and inwaad applications, exercies and the like; namely, a right ue of the ix things not Natural, they may be ufficiently corrected to the cahiering of that imputation, Wherefore if thee things be o, namely, if a cold and moit ditemper be only a common caue of the Diea, if other Regions wherein this Affect hath not yet been oberved to make any impreion, are at leat equally obnoxious to cold and moiture: Finally, if thoe ditempers may be prevented by a Regiment of diet appropriated to the place; certainly the reaon drawn from the coldnes and moiture of the Climate, which even now we produced to hew why Englih men hould be more frequently invaded with this Diea then others, will be very weak and inufficient, o that we can by no means place our content in that alone, and therefore we intended nothing more by that aignation, than that England doth more dipoe the Bodies of the Inhabitants to this Affect than hotter and drier Regions do the Bodies of their Inhabitants. And • o we proceed to the earch of the other caues of the rifenes and frequency of this Affect.

In the econd place we can note that England is very
ruitful and Child-breeding being ufficiently favorable both to Conception and Child-bearing, and not ubject to caue abortions. Now from hence it comes to pas, that not only trong and able bodied men, and uch as are endued with perfect health, but the weak and ickly perons do alo generate; weak & unound women likewie, and uch as are prone to a conumption, do conceive, carry their children nine months, and bring them forth in a decent and laudable manner. But it is no wonder if the Iue begotten by uch matter, and which oweth its life almot to the clemency of the place alone, hould be feeble and languid, and very ubject to this Diea. For as much as the very benignity of the Region may in this repect be the occaion of ome infirmity in the Iue. For as barbarous People in time pat by an inhumane experiment upon their new born infants; namely, by dipping their naked bodies in the coldet water, detroyed the weak ones with the extremity of the cold, and gave education only to the trong ones, whoe vigorous Contitutions overcame the injury of their cruel policies, purpoing by that inhumanity to have an univeral race of trong & luty people. So on the contrary the very clemency of the place promicouly preerving the languihing and weak Children together with the trong & healthful, doth miniter an occaion of bringing forth a mixt kind of people ome trong and ome weak and ickly. Yet leat any hould mitake, we do not mean that all the Children in this Kingdom which are born of weak and ickly Parents are ubject to this Affect. For although if one or both of the Parents be infirm, the Children will be infirm; yet it is often een that when the Parents have been very trong and healthful, yet their Children have been very ubject to this Diea. Wherefore neither do we ret in this econd caue, but
another mut yet be enquired out, from whence we may derive a ufficient reaon of the frequency of this evil.

We affirm therfore in the third place, That the rifenes of this Diea in England hath been much promoted, by that long and ecure peace, which we enjoyed before the firt breaking of it. For by this the more wealthy families, which were firt invaded by this evil, and which doth til infet them more than others, had addicted themelves to idlenes and a looe and effeminate life, and therupon they fel into a moiter, ofter, and degenerate Contitution, and uch as was les purged and cleaned from excrementitious humors, and by conequence their Children were even procreated obnoxious to this Affect. You wil ay, that Scotland and the Northern parts of England, although they enjoyed peace and ecurity, yet they are eldome oberved to fal under this Affliction.

We anwer, True it is that Scotland and the Northern parts of England are les affected with this Diea than the Southern and the Wetern. In the mean time peradventure the firt impreions and rudiments of it are far more frequent in thoe places; yea, and in ome forraign Countries, then is commonly beleeved. For although this evil be very familiar in the South and Wet parts of this Kingdom, and very wel known among the Vulgar ort, yet we have many times een Children afflicted with it in a light manner, of whom neither the Parents nor others of the ame family did upect the leat evil: Yea, we have known many, whom none of their friends thought to be affected, to be healed without any help of Phyick by the ole benefit of the increaed heat, or by the increae of age or exercies. How much eaier therfore may the firt rudiments of this Diea be
concealed from them, to whom it is les familiar, and among whom it eldom acendeth to that degree, that they need to implore the Phyitians help. We conjecture therfore that this Diea is more frequent then is commonly beleeved both in Scotland and the Northern parts of England; yea, and in ome Countries wherin the people are ignorant of it to this day: but in thoe places they are o gently tormented with it, that they are eldom condemned to the hands of the Phyitian. For that is the cutome of the Vulgar ort, not to end for the Doctor (epecially to Infants and yong Children) unles the vehemency of the Diea contrain them. However the matter is, we eem not yet to have given atisfaction to the objection propounded, Why the South and Wet Country men of England are more grievouly & frequently conflicted with this Diea, then the Northern People and the Scots, although both Kingdoms equally hared the bleing of the lating peace and ecurity. Therfore we grant that a higher reaon yet mut be given for this difference. Fourthly, therefore and latly, we ay, That the caue of this difference is the affluence of all good things in thee Southern and Wetern Countries of England. For this part of the Kingdom is much the more fruitful, rich and florihing, and abounding with al manner of allurements to pleaure. Therefore it is no marvail if the cutoms of men do firt generate here, their Spirits decay, and the trength of their Bodies begin to diolve now, that this degenerate and delicate manner of living doth weaken families, is a truth o olidly and contantly atteted by Hitorians, that it were an impertinence to offer any proof of it. For you may oberve that the mot Noble and Gallant Families have been very much reproached for thee very caues; yea, and ooner or latter omtimes totally extinguihed, and o much the ooner as they have the more refued to undergo
labors, and to innure themelvs to maculine exercies. Neither are families ever plunged in a greater danger of degeneration, then when they abound with al good things, and lying open to plenty and ecurity they are mot powerfully invited to delicatnes, idlenes and effeminatenes, without any labor, care, and olicitude. Who was more rich, ecure, and effeminate, than Solomon? He left Rehoboam a degenerate Son behind him. And perhaps the family of Henry the 8th. is extinct for the like caue. We could heap up almot innumerable examples to prove this, if it were needful. However it be, we ee plainly, that this Diea doth more frequently and vehemently invade the families of the wealthy, than the cottages of poor men, and therfore it ought not to eem trange that it likewie infeted the richer and more pleaanter parts of the Kingdom; namly, the South and Wet, before the North parts. But thee things hall uffice to have been poken concerning this matter. It remaineth only that we enquire, Whether and how far the three lat aigned caues relate to the denomination of a Common Diea, and whether in repect of them, this Diea may be acribed to England as common and Natural?

You mut know then that thee three caues in as much as they depend upon the Region, are not properly caues, neither by their own nature do they produce this affect, but that they are only an occaion wherby this Diea may accidentally arie. For in themelves they denote the laudable conditions of a Country, at leat they infer not what is culpable in it. For who can accue his Country, becaue it favoreth the procreation of Children, much les make outcries againt it, becaue it enjoyed long and ecure peace. Finally leat of all calumniate the pleaantnes, fruitfulnes, and affluence of all
good things: For all thee things are in themelves bleings, and conditions to be wihed for in a Country. Seing therfore as we have hewed above, that a Dieae properly common doth imprint om mark of a vitious Contitution to the place to which it is acribed; It is impoible that any Diea can be attributed unto it as properly Common, by reaon of the commodity of the Region. Wherfore (that we may comprehend all in a word) although this Diea in repect of the coldnes and moitnes thereof have a fomentation in the very Contitution of the Country Although alo that it borrow three other occaions of invading from the Country; Yet eing that thoe ditempers may be prevented by a due obervation of the Regiment of Health appropriated to the place; and eing that the three other occaional caues, are not properly blamable, but deirable, we mut affirm that this Diea is not properly Common to England. And o we have put an end to the earch of the caues of this Diea.

div.head: CHAP. XX. The differences of the Diea, called the Rachites.
div.p: THere are many differences of the Rachites in regard of the concoure of everal evils, and more than any man would eaily imagine; ome wherof are of great importance, and others les coniderable we have reolved here briefly to propound the chiefet. For the knowledg of them is not only profitable to define the prognotical caues, wherby the various events of a Diea are ditinctly fortold according to thoe differences; but it alo much conduceth both to the prevention and the cure of a Diea; namly, that by a conideration of them apt and fit remedies may be choen.

Now thee differences arie either from the Eence of the Diea, or from the caues therof: or latly, from Dieaes conjoyned with it. The Eence of a Diea may vary many ways: Firt, By reaon of the parts of the Secondary Eence either preent or abent. Secondly, In regard of the magnitude of it. Thirdly, In repect of the vehemence. Fourthly, in regard of the Spirits; And fiftly in repect of the times.

We grant indeed, That there is a certain agreement between om differences comprehended under thee titles; yet eing that the formal conceptions of them are ditinct, it mut be confeed that they deerve ditinct
coniderations. For although a Diea, even in that very repect may be called greater, becaue it containeth many parts of the Secondary Eence in the ame Patient yet this is a different & ditinct conideration from that of the magnitude of that Affect. For the magnitude properly hath repect unto the degree of reces from the Natural State, and not to the Nature of the part of the Eence either preent or abent, for hereupon reulteth more then a gradual difference. In like manner ome of the other differences do perhaps ignify the ame thing, in • concrete and retrained acception, which notwithtanding in an abtracted and formal conideration denote a diverity. But let us proceed.

The firt difference of this Diea is that which arieth from the preence of few or many of the parts of the Secondary Eence therof. For although all the parts of the Primary Eence are perpetuàlly preent with the Diea it elf, yet there is no neceity that all the parts of the Secondary Eence hould be always preent. For thee are after-comers to the firt Eence, and do by degrees come upon it: Yea, ome of them may be o highly intercepted by the intervention of reiting caues that they may not at all appear. Hither you may refer that difference, which we propounded at the foot of the precedent diputation, and which we hewed might poibly though indeed very rarely, befal thoe that were grown to ful age. But becaue our purpoe here is only to handle the Diea as it is incident to Children, we hall be content to pas by that difference thus noted by the way. But even in Children themelves there omtimes happen ome parts of the Secondary Eence, which have a mot trict conjunction with the Primary Eence, at leat they ucceed them in the order of Nature. For the Primary Eence hath the efficacy of a caue, which in
Nature doth ever go before the effect. But in order of time ome parts of the Secondary Eence do conpire as it were, and concur with the Primary Eence in the invaion; and others again do come afterwards, thee we mut here ditinguih. For the former ort are abolutely ineparable, the latter ort eparable from this Affect.

The ineparable parts of the Secondary Eence may be reduced to thee Heads. Firt to the afflicted Tone of the firt affected parts. Secondly, to the unequal and imperfect ditribution of the Vital Blood. Thirdly, to the too mal participation of the Vital influx in the firt affected parts. Fourthly, to the Secondary faults of the Animal Contitution. Thee faults are ufficiently unfolded above in our dicoure of the Secondary Eence of this Diea; where likewie becaue of their trict carriage with the Primary Eence, any man may perceive with ea (though they have a caual dependance upon the Primary Eence) that they begin together at the ame time.

But al the Organical faults which we have alo already recited, are found to be eparable, and omtimes actually eparate from this Diea. For the magnitude of the Head, and the leannes of the Joynts, the crookednes of the Shank-bone, or the Elbow, the inflexions of the Joynts, the harpnes of the Breat, do not necearily accompany this Diea preently from the beginning, but in proces of time they bewray themelves by degrees and upervene upon the Affect. And although the Conumption of the parts, which in ome ort hath an influence into the aid faults, may be aid to be preent in ome light degree from the begining of the Diea, yet is it indeed only a Symptom, and not a Diea; neither is it able preently to produce thoe Dieaes of magnitude,
Figure and Place. Moreover it is not neceary, that thee Organical faults hould equally and at the ame time invade one that hath the Rachites, we grant indeed that the extenuation of the firt affected parts, when the Diea is of ome continuance, doth alwaies and necearily ucceed it, neither can it afterwards upon the pereverence of the Diea be removed, that it is likewie a principal part of the eparable parts of the econdary Eence; yea that the extenuation whilt it is making doth immediatly follow the malnes of nourihment of the firt affected parts, almot no otherwie than the malnes of nourihment immediatly followeth the primary Eence of the Diea in the aid parts; but withal we affirm that the extenuation being made which is it elf a econdary part of the Diea wherof we dicour, doth necearily preuppoe the motion and time of the Diea, and that it cannot be in the firt moment of the exitence of the Diea. We ay moreover that Phyitians do not acknowledg any change made in the parts expoed to the en, which doth not yet appear to the ene, and by conequence they affirm that extenuation befalleth the firt affected parts, til it be made obvious to the enes which certainly doth necearily prerequire ome duration of the Diea. But the improportionat magnitude of the Head, doth begin almot at the ame time with that extenuation of the firt affected parts, but it may o fall out, if a conuming Phtiick be joyned together with this Diea, that that magnitude of the Head may vanih before death, as we have already proved by one example in our Anatomical Obervations. The Magnitude of the Head therfore is more eparable from this affect than the extenuation of the firt affected parts, for this cannot be removed without the Diea be cured. The ticking out of the Bones
appear omtimes ooner, omtimes later, and they omtimes grow out more, omtimes les, but upon any long continuance of the Diea they are eldom (if ever) een to be abent. The narrownes of the Breat doth not appear, but after a long time when the Diea is confirmed, and for the mot part is the forerunner of a Ptyick. Again, the crookednes of the Bone in the Arm, and the Shank-bone, as alo the inflexion of the Joynts may be abent through the whol cour of the Diea, and may be more or les preent, and indeed is the mot chanceable among thoe things which follow this affect. We conclude therfore that thee Organical parts of the Secondary Eence are eparable after that manner as we have aid, and as a more or fewer of them are preent, o the Difference of the Diea is contituted, as being more or les compounded.

The Second Difference of this Diea reulteth from the magnitude therof. And the magnitude is etimated from the greater or leer reces from the natural condition of it. There is a vat difference in this Diea in repect of the magnitude. For ome are o gently affected with it that you would carce uppoe them to be ick. They complain of nothing, they eat, they drink, they leep like thoe that are ound in health; only they play with more unchearfulnes, and hew forth ome other very light igns of icknes, By the only benefit of Nature likewie without any aitances of Art they perfectly recover, neither their Parents, Nures, nor the By-tanders o much as once upecting that they are affected with this evil. On the contrary, Others are o vehemently afflicted that they cannot be recued from death or the danger of imunient death by the mot approved remedies.

The Third Difference is from the vehemence of the
affect. Now this is valued by the violent motion of the Diea and the reitance of Nature, and alo by the harpnes of the conflict of thee things among themelves. This Diea, although it be otherwie very great, yet is it low in motion unles ome fewer, or ome other urgent affect be conjoyned with it, and tir up the Nature of it to a fiercer oppoition, yet is the motion therof omtimes more vehement, and omtimes very dull, and thereupon it happeneth to be differenced.

The Fourth Difference, is from the trength of the ick Child or Infant. This is etimated by the greater or leer preence of thoe things which are according to Nature. Hither belongeth the condition of the temperament, the plenty of inherent Spirits, the activity and trength of the Tone, the vigor of the Vital and Animal Contitution, and the tructure of the Organs. For as thee are more or les obedient to the precriptions of Nature, o their Spirits ought to be judged more or les trong, and according to them the evil mut be determined the more or les dangerous. For this cau the yonger Children caeteris paribus are more dangerouly affected than the elder.

The Fifth Difference, is from the times of the Diea. And this difference in a qualified and limited acception includeth almot all the precedent; for what difference oever hapneth to any Diea, mut necearily happen at ome time of the Diea. Phyitians reckon up four times of a Diea: The Begining, the Augmentation, the Conitance, and the Declination. But it mut be noted that Phyitians are not o exact in ditinguihing the eaons of things as the Phyloophers, for they do not retrain the beginning of a Diea to that point of time wherin the Diea begineth; but o far they extend it, till there appear o great an alteration
of the Diea, that it may be known by certain and enible evidences. For the indiviible begining is not the time, wherin the Phyitians help is perfected, and why hould that ditinction of a Diea be profitable which could not be grounded upon any alteration of it known to us?

Galen therfore hath rightly deduced the times of Feavers and Inflamations from the undertandible alteration of them: that is, The begining from the crudity of the matter cauing the diea, the augmentation from the manifet coction therof; the tate from the Excretion, and the Declination he computes from the Reduction of the Reliques to the Natural tate; and indeed thee times do weetly agree in the general, and differ in particular from the crudity and coction of Feavers and Inflamations. But the truth is, That this ditinction of times hath not the like ucces in many other dieaes: For in thee Nature doth not o regularly proceed from crudity to coction, o to expulion, and at lat to reduction; neither by the can we truly and afly know the progres of the diea. Other alterations therfore of thee Dieaes, uch as are more cleer and eaily known mut be weighed. Yet we grant that even the dieaes when they are directed to health, do run thorow thoe four eaons, the begining, the augmentation, the tate or conitence, and the declination. But when they tend to the detruction of the Patent, they carce attain to the conitance, but are daily more and more augmented even to the let period of life. Wherfore in the the augmentation admitteth the greatet latitude, neither doth it deerv a higher difference, or a lower ubdiviion: but when an indifferent tate of a diea of the ame kind is made the Middle term between the begining and the end of uch an augmentation, than we can conveniently
ditinguih. The encrea into an augmentation on this ide, or beyond, or beneath, or above the conitence. An encrea of the firt kind about the conitance we may cal a imple encrea, in regard that it differeth not from the thing it elf commonly received by that name, an encrea beyond or above the tate, we call an encrea excrecent, exceive, trancendent and deperate.

Moreover, Two kinds of declination may be oberved in a Diea. The firt is legitamate when the Diea imply declineth towards health and recovery. The later is purious, when a diea remitting changeth into another of a different kind. And o although there are in tho that recover health, only four times of a diea, yet in others two more differences may be dicerned: Yet it mut be noted, that the ix times are never to be found in the ame diea, or the ame patient, but where there is the ame diea in the Species in divers ubjects. Let us now apply thee things to the preent affect. We affirm therfore that ix differences of this diea do occur in repect of the times therof. For it hath a beginning, and may be called incipient: it hath an encrea, and may be aid to be confirmed; it hath a tate, and then it it may be termed conitant; it hath an encreae beyond the tate, and may be called deperate: it hath a tru declination, and may be aid to be an affect remiting or imply declining; and it hath a purious declination, and may be called a change, as when it chancheth into om other diea. Of al which we wil peak in their order.

Firt, The Rachites is called a Diea begining, when the firt Rudiments and impreions thereof are, though very obcurely, firt oberved, and before there hapneth any manifet extenuation of the firt affected parts.

Secondly, This diea is aid to be confirmed, when an evident and manifet extenuation of the firt affected
parts becoms obvious to the Senes. And here the Reader perceiveth we do not ditinguih the two times from crudity and coction, but from another alteration of the Body, namly, The Extenuation made in the parts firt affected; for the begining of this diea can no ways be dicerned from the encrea therof by crudity and coction: But otherwie, o far as the nature of the thing is capable of it, we hal willingly follow the example of Galen, and as he ditinguiheth the encrea from the begining by the manifet coction, o we alo put a different between the times in this affect from a manifet alteration, namly, the extenuation made in the aid parts.

Thirdly, This diea advanced to its conitence, is that, which having attained the highet vigor and exhaltation, is arreted, and for a time is neither enibly encreaed, or leened, but continueth at a tand.

Fourthly, This diea exceeding the Mediocrity of the conitance is called deperat, namly, Becau in magnitude and vehemence it urpaeth the very tate of the ame diea in another Patient indifferently affected, and withal is continually encreaed, neither is there any hope but that it will daily encrea til it hath altogether ubdued and diolved the Patient For which cau this condition of a diea is termed deperat.
Fifthly, This diea is aid to be truly remitting or declining, when the Eence therof is by little and little diminihed, and when the Signs and Symptoms of it are daily mitigated.

Sixthly, This diea is aid to be illegitimatly declining, or paing into another diea of a diver pecies, when the Eence, Signs and Symptoms therof are o leened, that new ones of a different kind, and perhaps more outragious appear in their tead. Thus the Rachites frequently degenerat into a Conumption, a Hectick,
and omtimes perhaps into a low putrid Feaver; yet for the mot part the ame diea doth accompany the upervening affects to the diolution of the Patient. And let this uffice concerning the differences of this diea deduced from the Eence.

This diea in like manner in repect of the Caues is as it were taken into pieces, or divided into parts, namly into a natural affect, and into an after-coming or newly contracted malady. Again, This diea may be termed natural in a twofold en In the firt properly, As when the Sick is born actually affected with this diea. In the later improperly, when the Patient at his birth is not actually affected with it, but trongly dipoed by his native principles to fall into it. If it plea the Reader to ummon thoe things to his memory which were aid above concerning the caues of this Effect on the Parents parts, he wil eaily conceive the reaon and foundations of this difference, and conequently that wil excue us from any further explication: Only we ad, that this difference is of great ue in the judicial part of cure, which coniteth in applications antidotal and preventive, but it is not of o great moment in the Method of Cure. In like manner this Affect is meerly coming after, when being fomented by no Natural dipoition, it is newly contracted after the birth & here alo it is twofold. For it either ucceedeth om foregoing Diea; or it is immediatly produced by an erroneous ue of the ix non-Natural things: We have ufficiently dicoured of both, where we hammered out the caues of this Diea after the birth, and thither we direct the Reader.

Again, this Diea admitteth om differences by reaon of other Dieaes wherwith it is conjoyned in the ame ubject. It mut not be expected that we hould give in a Catalogue of all Dieaes, wherwith this Affect
may poibly be conjoyned, we hal only reckon up thoe which ate the uual Companions of this Malady Som wherof have a certain dependance upon this Diea and the caues of it; others have not any, or at leat not any worthy of a ditinct conideration.

Of the former kind are a Hydrocephalus, the faults of breeding Teeth, an Athma, the Ptyick, an Hectik feaver, a low, and erratical Feaver, and the Acites, which is that kind of Dropy when water hath gotten between the fleh and the Skin.

The Hydrocephalus hath a great correpondence with this Affect, eing that this Affect alo doth for the mot part uppoe an increa of the Head preternaturally encreaed, and an overplentiful afflux of the Blood unto the Brain by reaon of the largenes of the Arteries thither extended. And hereupon it eaily coms to pas that the Brain being oppreed wth the abundance of the Blood, mut omtimes needs uffer the more erous portion therof (as being the mot permeable) to evaporate or weat out into the Ventricles and cavities within the Menynges, and by conequence to produce the Dropy of the Brain. But this, as we have already noted, doth always appear.

The faults of breeding of Teeth alo are omtimes jutly acribed to this Diea going before. For it is well known that they who are affected with this Diea do commonly breed Teeth with extream pain, and many times the Teeth themelvs fal out by pieces. But we have above reduced this fault to the unequal nourihment of the parts, and there the Reader may find further atisfaction. In the mean time it mut be oberved, that a painful breeding of Teeth may likewie precede this Diea, and utain the force of a cau in reference to this ubequent evil, as we have likewie hewed above.

Moreover, An Athma or difficulty of breathing doth familiarly follow upon this Affect, becaue the Blood is omwhat cooled in his circulation thorow the firt affected parts, and is rendred more thick, vicous, and luggih in motion, neither is it always perfectly corrected before its return to the right Ventricle of the Heart. Wherupon being unapt for paage, it is powred back from the right Ventricle thorow the Arterious Vein into the ubtance of the Lungs, and for that Reaon doth eaily introduce obtructions, hard tumors, difficulty of breathing, omtimes inflammations, impotumes, Ulcers, the Ptyick, the Dropy of the Lungs, a Hectick Feaver, or el a low erratical Feaver.

An Acites is alo omtimes conociated with this Affect. But whether it proceeds from a copious flowing of the Blood to the Bowels of the Abdomen, we dare not yet attet for an undoubted truth. Yet certain it is that the flowing of the Blood to this Belly is very copious and ufficiently active in this Diea. For the Liver is great, and the other Bowels are oberved to be rather more ful than ordinary, than pined away. Wherupon it may happen, that that watry moiture from the Bowels which are oppreed with a fulnes may be carried into the hollownes of the Abdomen, but we affirm this with a ditrutful confidence, becaue we have not yet given our elvs ful atisfaction in this matter.

Nevertheles thee recited Dieaes may happen to Children although the Rachites have not preceded, and may be the cau to introduce it. Yea, they may likewie com upon this Diea from other caues; as for example, by om errors in the Regiment of health; although in this cae alo this Affect may be partly guilty, if it went before: And thus much of complicated Dieaes of the former kind.
But of the latter kind, namely, uch as have little or no nependance upon this Affect, are a malignant Feaver, the French Pox, the Scurvy, and the Strumaticall Affect.

Firt it is certain, That a Malignant Feaver may come upon this Affect, becaue for the mot part it is produced by infection, from which this preent Affect leaveth not Children free, we ad only, that this Feaver doth eldom or never ow his Origin to this Diea.

Secondly, If the French Pox chance to be complicated with this Diea, it is either derived from the Nures infection, or from the Parents by Inheritance. For it is a Diea altogether Ditinct from this, and hath carce any affinity with it.

Thirdly, The Scurvy is omtimes conjoyned with this Affect. It is either hereditary, or perhaps in o tender a Contitution contracted by infection, or latly, it is produced from the indicreet and erroneous Regiment of the Infant, and chiefly from the inclemency of the Ayr and Climat where the Child is educated. For it carce holdeth any greater commerce with this Diea, then with other Dieaes of longer continuance, wherin after the ame manner the Blood in time contracteth for the mot part this peculiar infection, yet it mut be granted, that this Affect doth omwhat the more dipoe to the Scurvy in regard of the want of motion and exercie.

Fourthly, and latly, The Strumatical Affect doth omtimes aociate this evil. But it is credible that it oweth more to other caues proper unto it, then to this precedent Diea. Although we deny not, but this may miniter om occaion of invading, in as much as it rendreth the humors more vicous and gros.

Some other Dieaes are peradventure omtimes complicated with this, but becaue they happen exceeding
rarely, and have yet carce fallen under our obervation, we pas them by, for the preent and proceed to the igns of the Diea, and the difference of the igns.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. The Signs of the Rachites, and firt the Diagnotical Signs.
div.p: WE ditinguih the Signs of the Diea into three Chapters. The firt containeth thoe Signs which demontrate the preence of the Affect, and are called Diagnotical. The econd containeth thoe that ditinguih among themelvs the differences of the Diea, and thee are called, Diacritical, or Dicrepant. The third comprehendeth thoe Signs which preage the event of the Diea, and they are termed Prognotical. In this Chapter we hall not treat of the firt kind.

We divide the Diagnotical Signs into Pathognomonical and Synedreontal. And here the Phyical Authors eem to be more trict in the definition of the word Pathognomonical, then the neceity of the nature of the matter doth require. For they wil have it to be Ineparable and (as Logicians peak) Proprium quarto modo, that is, to agree, omni, oli, & emper. Indeed it mut be granted, that uch an Ineparable Sign, or, Proprium quarto modo, mut be according to the mot proper en a Pathognomonical Sign. For whether it be preent, or
whether it be abent, it is ever demontratively ignificant: When it is preent it certainly witneeth the pecies of the preent malady, and being abent it heweth that that pecies of the Diea is not preent.

But when we truly and eriouly conider how eldom uch Signs as thee occur and of what ueles conideration they will prove, the knowledg of them being thus retrained; we are induced to think of the amplifying of the uual ignification of the word. For although the Ancients to upply this defect, did ubtitute < in non-Latin alphabet > in the place of one true Pathognomonicol Sign trictly taken, and we our elvs do mot willingly accept of, and approve this very ame < in non-Latin alphabet > ; yet eing that this < in non-Latin alphabet > doth eldom appear from the begining of the Diea, and by conequence eldom obtaineth the reputation of an Ineparable Sign, it necearily followeth, that it alo can but eldom perform the office of a Sign, quarto modo propriè, and therfore alo that this notion is reduced to an extream narrow ue. We are compelled therfore that we may fully prevent, or avoid this inconvenience to extend omwhat higher the ignification of a Pathognomonical Sign; yet o, as that we wil abate nothing of the Nature and certitude of the ignification.

Therfore we define a Pathognomonical Sign to be omwhat appearing about the Patient, which certainly and infallibly demontrates the Species of the Diea, And in this extended en it may be divided into a Sign Ineparable, or, proprium quarto modo, and a Sign Separable; namely, as being proper only, Modo ecundo; to wit, becau it is competible only to one kind of Dieaes, although not always. In like manner the Paththognomonical Syndrome, or Concour of Symptoms may be divided into two kinds, repectively Analogical to thoe
aforeaid. For omtimes it beginneth with the Diea it elf, and doth ineparably aociate to the very lat period. So the pricking pain of the ide, and acute Feaver, the difficulty of breathing, and the cough, if they be taken collectively, they are indeed a Syndrome, but uch an one as is always equivalent to one imple Pathognomonical Sign of the firt kind, and doth ineparably accompany a Pleuriie from the firt beginning to the very end. But omtimes the Syndrome or concour of Symptoms is not compleat and perfect from the begining of the Diea, yet afterwards it is made perfect by the intervention of the other Signs, and doth infallibly denote, the pecies of the Diea. For example, in the mal Pox upon the firt begining of the Diea, the Syndrome, is o incompleat, that it doth not yet certainly determine the pecies of the Diea; but afterwards the Pox breaking out of the Skin very thick, and tending to maturation, then the Syndrome is finihed, and the pecies of the Diea is put out of al doubt.

But that a Sign proper to one Diea alone (although not in the fourth manner) whether it be imple and olitary, or compounded of a concour of many together, may uffice, when it is preent to make a Sign truly Pathognomonical: It is manifet from hence, becau, when it is preent, it doth as certainly and infallibly denote the pecies of the Affect, as a Sign doth, which is proper in the fourth manner. For that which agreeth to one pecies only, when it is preent, doth necearily infer the preence of that pecies alo. Although therfore that a Sign proper in the econd manner, be not Ineparable, and where it is abent, doth not determine the abence of the Diea, as a Sign doth proper in the fourth manner; yet when it is preent, it is as we have aid of the ame valu and certainty. For Phyitians do eteem the
dignity of the Sign by the certainty of the ignification. For to that purpoe they enquire out the igns of a Diea, that they may attain to a certain knowledg therof. Therfore eing that Signs proper in the econd manner are equivalent in repect of their certainty, when they preent to Signs proper in the fourth manner: we hall here comprehend them under the extended ignification of Pathognomonical Signs.

You may ay after this manner many after appearing Signs may be reduced to the Pathognomonical and are confounded with them. Be it o, provided that they do infallibly denote the pecies of the Diea. For in this repect they are worthy to be evered from the other after appearing Signs, neither wil any confuion follow hereupon in the method of the emeiotical art, but rather the valu and dignity of the Signs wil by that means be more plainly and eaily oberved.

Of the Synedremontal or aident Signs we have nothing of moment to ay, but wil directly proceed to the Signs themelvs as they are to be reduced into order. Yet no exact method mut be expected from us, becaue for the mot part the Signs flow from o many everal fountains, that they wil carce uffer themelvs to be marhalled into any accurate order. Wherfore, that they may be contituted which have ome affinity among themelvs, we have reduced the igns of this Affect to the ubequent Method.
We hal propound therfore
Firt, The Signs which relate to the Animal actions.
Secondly, Thoe which have reference to the irregular Nutrition.
Thirdly, Thoe that concern the Repiration.
Fourthly, Thoe that appertain to the Vital Influx.

Fifthly, Certain vagabond and fugitive Signs reducible
to no Clais. Under each of which we hal ubjoyn the valu of the Signs.
Firt the Diagnotical Signs relating to the Animal Actions, are thee. The loones and oftnes of the parts. The debility and languidnes. And finally, the lothfulnes and tupefaction.

Firt, A certain laxity and oftnes, if not a flaccidity of all the firt affected parts is uually oberved in this Affect. The Skin alo is oft and mooth to the touch, the muculous fleh is les rigid and firm; the joynts are eaily flexible, and many times unable to utain the body. Wherupon the Body being erected it is bent forwards or backwards, or to the right ide or to the left.

Secondly, A certain debility, weaknes, and enervation befalleth al the parts ubervient to motion. This weaknes dependeth much upon the laxity, oftnes, and lithernes of the parts aforeaid: for which reaon we have placed thoe Signs before this, as alo this before the lothfulnes and tupefaction in the next place to be enumerated, which ow much both to the loones and oftnes. Moreover, this debility begineth from the very firt rudiments of the Diea. For if Children be infeted within the firt year of their age or therabouts, they go upon their feet later by reaon of that weaknes, and for the mot part they peak before they walk, which amongt us Englih men, is vulgarly held to be a bad Omen But if they be afflicted with this Diea, after they have begun to walk, by degrees they tand more and more feebly upon their legs, and they often tagger as they are going, and tumble upon every light occaion: neither are they able to utain themelvs long upon their legs without itting, or to move and play up and down with an uual alacrity, til they have reted. Latly, upon a vehement increae of the Diea they totally loe the
ue of their feet; yea, they can carce it with an erected poture, and the weak and feeble Neck doth carcely, or not at al utain the burthen of the Head.

Thirdly, A kind of lothfulnes and numbnes doth invade the Joynts preently after the begining of the Diea, and by little and little is increaed, o that dayly they are more and more avere from motion. The Yonger Children who are carried about in their Nures arms, when they are delighted and pleaed with any thing do not laugh o heartily, neither do they tir themelvs with o much vigor, and hake and brandih their little Joynts, as if they were deirous to leap out of of their Nures hands, alo when they are angred they do not kick o fiercely, neither do they cry with o much fiercenes as thoe who are in health. Being grown greater, and committed to their feet, they run up and down with a wayward unchearfulnes, they are oon weary, and they love to play rather itting then tanding, neither when they it, do they erect their body with vigor, but they bend it omtimes forwards, omtimes backwards, and omtimes on either ide, eeking om props to lean upon that may gratify their lothfulnes. They are not delighted like other Children with the agitation of their bodies, or any violent motion; yea, when the Diea prevaileth they are aver from all motion of their limbs: crying as they are at any play that is never o little vehement; and being pleaed again with gentle uage and quiet ret. In the interim, unles om other Diea, Symptom, or cau of icknes doth com between, they are moderate in leeping and waking, they are ingenious, not tupid, but for the mot part of forward wits, unles om other im pediments arie, their countenances are much more compoed and evere than their age requireth, as if they were intent and ruminating upon om erious matter.

Thee Signs being taken together, unles they reult from ome evident warines, or proceed from ome primary affect of the Brain (which indeed hapneth very eldom in this tendernes of age) do contitute a ufficient Pothognomonical Syndrom of the firt kind, & where they are preent together, they certainly witnes the preence of the Diea, & when they are abent together they infallibly attet the Eence of this Diea. But if at any time a weariomnes do bewray any Feaverih, or any other like Signs, they may eaily be ditinguihed from thee, both becaue the reaons of the wearines have gone before, and alo becaue the Signs from thence ariing do uddenly break out, and aoon vanih. But in this affect the igns do invade by degrees, and perevere, or ele they are dayly more encreaed. Now the primary Dieaes of the Brain are ditinguihed by their proper Signs. And thus much of the Signs which relate to the Animal Actions.

div.head: The Signs which belong to the diproportioned Nourihment of the Parts.
div.p: Of how great moment the Alogotrophy, or unequal Nourihment of the Parts is in this affect, we have already hewed; we hall here therfore proecute thoe igns which in ome great meaure depend upon it, and we hall preent them as if they were to be beheld at one View.

Firt, there appeareth the unuual bignes of the Head, and the fulnes and lively complexion of the Face, compared with the other parts of the Body. But although this Sign may preuppoe ome motion of the Diea before it hine out, yet is the Diea o obcure before the appearance of it, that it is accounted in a manner unperceivable:
Therfore commonly this Sign heweth it elf more or les from the firt beginning, and continueth till the departure of the affect, unles (as we have noted before) the pining of thoe parts upervene from ome other cau.

Secondly, The Flehy parts, epecially thoe which are full of Mucles beneath the Head which we have lited among the firt affected, in the progres of the Diea are dayly more and more worn away, made thin and lean. This Sign doth not preently hew it elf from the begining of the Diea, becau it pre-requireth ome notable motion of the Diea before it evidently appeareth; yet in time it mot certainly is expoed to the enes, and accompanieth the Diea to the lat tep be it either to life or death; excellently demontrating the motion and degree of the Diea by its encrea. Moreover this Sign being conjoyned with the former doth at leat contitute a Pathognomonical Sign of the econd kind, that is uch an one as is proper to this Diea alone; and where they are preent together they infallibly denote the preence of this Diea, although upon their abence they do not equally ignifie the abence of the Diea.

Thirdly, Certain wellings and knotty excrecences, about ome of the joynts are oberved in this affect; thee are chiefly conpicuous in the Wrets, and omwhat les in the Ankles. The like Tumors alo are in the tops of the Ribs where they are conjoyned wth grizles in the Breat. We have noted abov in our Anatomical Obervations that thee tumors are not cituated in the Parts, but in the very Bones; although this conideration doth carce belong to them as Signs, eing that of themelves they are earce conpicuous. This Sign doth alo uppoe ome kind of motion of the Diea, neither is it
emergent a Principio principiante, as the Phyloophers phrae it, yet it offers it elf as an object to the enes ooner than any coniderable extenuation of the parts. But where it is preent, it contitutes a Pathognomical Sign of the Second kind, and without dipute witneeth the Species of the Diea.

Fourthly, Some Bones wax crooked, epecially the Bones called the Shank-bone, and the Fibula or the mall Bone in the Leg, then afterwards the greater Shank-bone, and the undermot and leer of the two long Bones of the Elbow, but not o much altogether nor o often; omtimes alo the Thigh-bone and the Shoulder-bone. Again, there is omtimes oberved a certain hortning of the Bones and a defective growth of them in repect of their longitude. This by chance was omitted above, where we gave the Reaon of the Organical faults. Yet this affect doth eem to depend upon the ame irregular nourihment; namely o far forth as the nourihment taken in encrcaeth the Bones according to breadth and thicknes more than length. From hence it comes to pas that ome Children long afflicted with this Diea become Dwarfs. Hither perhaps may be referred that folding in the Wrets, the Skin it may be having better nourihment and more growth than the Bones of thoe parts, wherupon it mut needs be contracted in the Wrets into a folding or wrinklednes. Finally, to this place alo may belong a certain ticking out of the Bones of the Head, epecially of the Bone of the forehead forwards. For it concerneth the common kind of viciated Figure and the Alogotrophy of the Bones. Yet this in the Bone of the Forehead doth evidently eem to depend upon the free nourihment of that Bone in his circumference, wherewith it is coupled to the Bones of the fore part of the
Head, and contitutes that eam called S • tura Coronalis, which lieth in the foremot parts therof. For herupon it mut needs be thrut forwards. And indeed in that place it is plentifully nourihed without any difficulty, becau this Bone in Children is cartilagineous towards that Seam. And this alo was pretermitted above where we dicoured of the Organical faultines, becau we have but lately oberved it.

Fifthly, The Teeth come forth both lowly and with trouble, they grow loo upon every light occaion, omtimes they wax black, and even fall out by pieces. In their tead new ones come again though late and with much pain. This kind of Sign, as alo that which we noted in the former Article, may be referred to the Synedremontal Signs, becau neither of thee is either perpetually preent, or if it be preent, it doth not undoubtedly confirm the preence of Diea.

Some have imagined that the Bones in this Diea are transfigurable like wax; But we have never een it, neither have we received it from any eye witnes who was not of upected credit. Wherfore we reject this Sign as altogether Fabulous.

Sixthly, The Breat in the higher progreion of the Diea, becomes narrow on the ides, and ticking up foreright, o that it may not be unaptly compared to the Keel of a Ship inverted, or the the Breat of a Hen or Capon. For on each ide of the middle it rieth up into a point, the ides being as it were preed down. If any demand whether this Sign be olely apropriated and peculiar to this affect; We anwer, That the Breat may be a little encreaed in an Atrophy or Phtiick, and les than the other parts of the Body, and o by conequence it may be narrower: but it can carce o fall out according to the change of the Figure without an
Alogotrophy, namely that which is proper to this Diea. Wherfore this Sign alo when it is preent, although the invaion of it be tardy mut be reputed a Pathognomonical Sign of the econd kind, becau when it is preent, it certainly denoteth the Species of the Diea, though not on the contrary. And thus much of the Signs which have reference to the unequal nourihment.

div.head: The Signs which belong to Repiration.
div.p: Firt, The narrownes and ticking up of the Breat already mentioned mut be hither referred, wherof we then dicoured at large.

Secondly, A welling of the Abdomen, and an extenion of the Hypochondriacal parts, which hindreth the free motion of the Diaphragma downwards, and by conequence doth omwhat interrupt the breathing. Yet it mut be noted that the Abdomen and the Hypochondries alo in repect of their outward parts appear very lean and extenuated, but inwardly, namly in thoe parts which are contained in the Cavity of the Abdomen, they well, from whence arieth this fulnes. This welling proceedeth partly from the windines of the Stomach and Guts, and partly from the bignes of the Liver and other Bowels. Somtimes alo a watry moiture into the Cavity of the Abdomen, introducing an Acites, joyneth in this conpiracy. This Sign is eldom abent, and yet it mut be numbred among the Pathognomonical Signs, becau it is common to many other Dieaes.

Thirdly, A Cough is frequently preent in this Affect, as alo a difficulty of breathing, and many other faults of the Lungs, as Stoppings, hard Tumors, Impothums,
Inflamations, a Coaleence of them, with the Plura, and the like; Yet thee carce deerve to be reckoned among Signs, becaue of themelvs (whilt the Patient liveth) they are not ufficiently conpicuous.

Fourthly, Children afflicted with this Diea are ofaver from lying upon their Sides either the right or the left, or at leat it is troublom to them; namly, either becau of the Coaleence of the Lungs with the Plura, or by reaon of om Tumor on the contrary ide, but to lie with their Faces upwards they are very much delighted. And the igns alo being taken together wil not amount to pathognomonical igns of either kind, but yndreciontal only and are common to other Dieaes.

div.head: Signs belonging to the Vital Influx.
div.p: Firt, The Veins and the Arteries are more lender than ordinary in the firt affected parts, and les conpicuous than you would expect in a lean Body. But in the Face (repect being had to the gracility aforeaid in the other part) they exceed the jut proportion. This perhaps is a pathognomonical ign, although it be difficult to be oberved, and indeed not yet ufficiently ifted by us.
Secondly, The Pul in the Wrets, and the other affected parts is mal & weak, otherwie perhaps it is moderat, unles when a Feaver is preent.
Thirdly, A moderate Ligature cat about the Elbow or the Knee, doth not o oon wel and color the part beneath and above the Ligature with Bloud, as it doth in other ound Children of the ame age.

div.head: Centain vagabond and wandring Signs.
div.p: Firt, An appetite to Meat and Deink that is either moderate, or unduly weak, unles where a Feaver is conjoyned.
Secondly, The Excrements of the Belly and Bladder do commonly reemble theirs that are in health, unles ome other Diea do interdict it.

Thirdly, It is oberved, that thoe which are ick of this diea do abominat weet things, as Syrups, and Junkets condited with much Sugar or Honey Perhaps alo uch things as thee are hurtful for them, as alo for thoe which are troubled with the Scurvy, becaue they thicken the humors.

Fourthly, Some have oberved, That they have een om Children affected with the Rachites, to weigh heavior than others of the ame age and tature. If this be o, it mut be attributed partly to the facility, and partly to the inequality of the Nutrition of the bony ubtance in this Affect. For when this weight can carce be acribed to the Fleh, which are here extenuated, it eemeth plain that this mut be attributed to the bony ubtance: And eing that the Bones in this Diea are not yet oberved to encrea beyond meaure in repect of their longitude, it followeth plainly, that it mut be imputed to the thicknes of them which is uperfluouly augmented. Thee are alo common igns, neither do they merit a more worthy etemation. And thus much for the Diagnotical Signs, the Diacritical now follow.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. The Signs of the differences of the Rachites, or the Diacritical Signs therof.
div.p: WE hal init in the ame Method we propounded above, wher we dicoured of the differences, whoe Signs we now enquire after. We have above deduced five differences from the very Eence of the Diea. The firt was eparable from the parts of the Secondary Eence, whether they were preent or abent. But no other Signs mut be expected beides the very pars preent or abent, which of themelvs are ubjected to the enes, and therfore they are numbred among the Diagnotical Signs in the econd Clais in in the precedent Chapter.
The econd difference was from the magnitude of the Diea; the igns of this are many and great, or few and gentle and preent igns; namely, to be fetched from among the Diagnotical Signs above decribed.
The third difference was taken from the vehemence of the affect. This is ditinguihed by the low or quick encrea of the Diagnotical Signs.

The fourth was from the trength of the Sick; we have hewed the way to judg of the trength above: But the difference of a Diea ariing from hence hath repect unto the danger, and therfore we refer the Signs therof to the Prognoticks.

The fifth difference was deduced from the times of the
Diea. In which repect we have above reckoned up ix divers apparitions of this Diea: to wit, The begining, the encrea, the tate or conitence, the encrea beyond the State, the true declination, the uperious declination, or the paing into another affect.

It mut be known that the beginning of this Diea, beides the igns that difference this time from the encreae, doth likewie require ome peculiar Signs of the preence of this Diea: for it is a time of the greatet obcurity, wherin the Diea doth as it were lurk and hide it elf, neither can an unattentive and in expert Phyitian eaily ditinguih it from the Diagnotical Signs above rehered. For by this time mot of the Diagnotical Signs aforeaid do not yet openly break forth; and uch as make a dicovery of themelves, preent only ome obcure impreions to the Phyitians Obervation. Therfore the indication of this time requires an accurate and peculiar collection of the firt appearing Signs, and a diligent conideration of them; but the other times, beides the Diagnotical Signs above granted, want only a difference among themelves, which is performed by an eaie indutry. Wherfore in the firt place we will declare the Signs of the preence of this Diea, being newly begun or rather beginning, and then the difference between that and the encrea.

div.head: The Signs of the preent Diea of the Rachites newly begun.
div.p:
Firt, Diligent Obervation mut be employed about the three kinds of Signs acribed above to the Animal Actions; namely, the loones and oftnes of the parts, the weaknes and languidnes, the lothfulnes and numnes. For thee do in a remis degree, and ubobcurely
yield advantage to circumpection and heedfulnes preently a principio principiante, as they phrae it.

Secondly, The colour mut be conidered, and the habit of the Head and Face in relation to the Joynts. For if the colour or the habit be more freh and lively in thoe than in thee, it preenteth a trong upition that this Diea hath taken root. For although the Bulk of the Head which is evidently encreaed, and alo the extenuation of the parts affected do pre-require ome coniderable motion and duration of the Diea before they appear, yet from the beginning a certain difference may be oberved by an accurate attention or intuition in repect of the heat and the habit of thee parts compared one with another.

Thirdly, The Wrets and the extremities of the Ribs mut be noted. For before the end of the beginning certain rudiments of knurls or knots begin to appear in the Wrets, and Excrecencies alo in the tops of the Ribs.

Fourthly, A kind of welled fulnes and tretching the Belly is conpicuous immediately after the beginning epecially in the Hypochondriacal parts. For the magnitude of the Belly compared with the magnitude of the Breat exceeds the jut and due proportion.

Now thee Signs collectively taken do auredly demontrate the preence of the Diea even from the very beginning. But if no enible and manifet extenuation of the firt affected parts do appear at the ame time, in that very repect it is cleerly ditinguihed from the encrea therof.

The Signs of the other times are with ea differenced from one another by the decriptions of thoe times already laid down; yet becau they may point to this place, and be dipatched in a word, we hall not decline the Annotation of them.

All thoe Signs which appeared at the beginning become more intene and evident in the encrea of the Diea, and many other and more grievous are daily accumulated. This time, as hath been aid, is ditinguihed by the manifet extenuation of the firt affected parts; but after the conitence by the continual aggravation of the Symptoms and Signs aforeaid.
In the State of the Diea the Signs and Symptoms are mot outragious and conpicuous. But o long as this time lateth it neither manifetly encreaeth or decreaeth.

In the encrea beyond the State, the Signs and Symptoms exceed that condition which they retained in the indifferent State, both in repect of their magnitude and vehemence, and likewie in repect of the dejection of the Spirits, and from that time forwards they dayly grow wore and wore; for which coniderations this time is ditinguihed, as well from the ordinary encrea, as from the means of the conitence.

But in a true declination A kind of imple remiion of the Symptoms and Signs tending to a perfect retauration of health begins to dicover it elf; no other Signs of the invaion of any other Diea appearing.

On the contrary, in a purious and illegitimate declination, Other Signs of a new and ucceeding affect are involved and complicated with the Signs and Symptoms of this Diea: and thee are ditinguihed according to the various condition therof, and mut be fetched from their proper Fountains, and ought not to be expected here. Moreover, if any particular Signs of any of thee times do occur, which concern the event of the Diea, they mut be reerved among the Prognoticks; and thus much of the Signs of the Differences of this affect deduced from the Eence therof.

The Differences of the Caues ditinguih the Diea into Natural and Accidental, and the Natural again into that which is properly o called, and that which is o termed improperly. A Natural Diea properly o called, becau it is uppoed to be actually preent from the very Birth, requireth no other Signs than the Diagnotical recited in the former Chapter. For upon their appearance preently after the Birth the Diea is certainly known to be Natural.

But if thoe Signs appear not preently after their Birth, yet a Natural dipoednes to this Diea may be inherent from the Birth, which afterwards actually breaketh out, and the Diea produced by it, may (though with ome impropriety) be termed Natural, in regard of that dependance upon the Native faultines. A Natural Diea in this en, requireth other Signs than thoe which we have recited above, to ditinguih it from the ame Diea when it is altogether and plainly Accidental.

div.head: The Signs of a Natural Diea improperly o called.
div.p: Firt, A weak and ickly Contitution, and the Dieaes of both or either of the Parents: As a cold and moit ditemper, a Cacochymy, epecially the Phlegmatical, a Cachexy, a Dropy, an Atrophy, the Phtiick, the Gonorrhea, the Whites, the Venereous Pox, the Scurvy, and the like affects.
Secondly, The Slothfulnes, Effeminacy, and Sedentary life of the Parents.
Thirdly, The Errors of the Mother during her going with Child, all which things we have dicued above more at large, when we examined the Caues of this Diea in relation to the Parents.
Fourthly, The Debility of the new born Infant when it proceedeth not from the difficulty and labor of the Birth.
Fifthly, The invaion of the Diea before he is exactly a year old; for this argueth ome Natural dipoition to the ame.
Sixthly, If the elder Brothers or Siters were before affected with the ame Diea; for then it may well be upected that ome Infection was contracted from the Parents.

Seventhly, If no remarkable error was committed in looking to the Child after the Birth, and before the invaion of the preent Diea. Of which we have poken above in the Chapter of the Caues after the Birth.
Eighthly, If this affect hath not ucceeded ome other which was apt to leave this behind it. Of the Dieaes of this kind we have alo dicoured above.
The Signs of a Diea newly and totally contracted after the Birth, are in a manner contrary to thee, and therfore we hall only run them over.
Firt, If the Diea cannot be imputed to any weak or dieaed Contitution of the Parents, or their manner of life, or the errors of their cutoms.
Secondly, If no debility appeared preently after the Birth.
Thirdly, If the Diea began when the Child was above eighteen months old.
Fourthly, If the Brothers and Siters were free from the Diea.
Fifthly, If any notorious errors were committed about the Child after the Birth.

Sixthly, If any Diea went before which might occaion a upition that this followed it. If there be a confluence of mot or all of thee Signs, they do ufficiently
witnes that this Dieae mut not be attributed to any Natural Infection, but to the future Errors and Irregularities. And thus much of the differences of this Dieae in repect of the Caues.

Latly, Som differences happen to this Diea by reaon of other Dieaes, wherewith they are peradventure complicated; in which cae, beides the Diagnotical igns already reckoned, ome other may be deired as peculiarly proper to the complicated Diea. Nevertheles an accurat Decription of them cannot be here expected, becau for the mot part they are the ame which are every where artributed to thoe Dieaes by practical Writers. But becau om Dieaes do more frequently accompany this than others, we wil briefly look into their Signs.

Firt therfore a Hydrocephalus or Dropie in the Head being complicated with this Affect needeth omtimes no igns to make it known, but is ufficiently, yea abundantly manifet of it elf: namly, either by the exceeding magnitude of the Head, or by the water that is outwardly contained under the Pericranium (which notwithtanding we uppoe doth very rarely happen) or by om extream opening and widenes of the eams in the Head, Water having gotten into them, and lifting up the Dura Mater, o that a oft and waterih tumor is outwardly perceivable by the touch in the paces between the Bones. Many times the Hydrocephalus is omwhat obcure and requireth igns to dicover it. Firt, Therfore all the inward and outward enes are more dull than otherwie they ue to be in this effect. Secondly, The magnitude of the Head is omtimes greater than at other times. Thirdly, The Sutures, or eams in the accutomed places do gape more wide, and are cloed again more lowly than they are wont to be. Fourthly, The Bone in the Forehead is
more outwardly ticking out, and in the other Bones of the Head you may oberve certain inequalities and bunchings out of an unuual bignes.

Secondly, The conjoyned evils of breeding Teeth are thus known. 1. If the accutomed time of breeding Teeth be either approching, or now at hand; for from hence arieth ome upition of pain from thence proceeding. This time ordinarily begineth in the eventh month after the birth, and continueth til the Child be a year and ix months old, and longer, if the Teeth come lowly; which hapneth very commonly in this affect; and it endeth when the number of the Teeth is compleat. 2. Children to mitigat the raging pain do ue to put their Fingers into their Mouths, according to that old aying, ubi dolor ibi Digitus. 3. The Gums wax white on that ide where the Tooth is to break out, and are omwhat hot in the touch. 4. The Teeth that come forth ometimes wax black or are loo, or fal out by pieces. 5. To thee you may ad watchings, the loones of the Belly, Feavers and Convulions, which notwithtanding are chanceable Symptoms.

Thirdly, An Athma is perceived by the very difficulty of breathing, when it doth not proceed from the tretching and fulnes of the lowet Belly. But if withal there be a welling or Impothum, & that in either ide of the Lungs, they can carce endure to lie on the contrary ide; but if it be on both ides, then they deire to lie errect or with their Faces upwards. The ame thing for the mot part hapneth in an Inflamation, with a growing together of the Lungs with the Pleura, as alo in a Pleuriie, but then there are added, an acute Feaver, a Cough and pitting of Bloud, moreover in a Pluriie a pricking pain in the Side. The Phtiick is known by a diuturnal Cough, and a roundih and omtimes a purulent pittle
(although indeed Children do eldom pit out, becau that matter which the Cough fetches up into the Mouth they wallow by the oephagus) alo by a putrid Feaver conjoyned, and by a udden Colliquation in the parts. An Acites is dicovered by the unreaonable bignes of the Abdomen.

Fourthly, A Hectick Feaver bewrayeth it elf by a continual heat, being omwhat more vehement than that in a Quotidian Ague, epecially about the Arteries, and til encreaeth after the receiving of meat; alo by the wift and peedy conumption of the parts: a putrid feaver is known by the urin being at the begining cude, afterwards more concocted, then alo from the extream high color of it. Moreovor, if it be an intermitting Ague, it is dicernable by the inequality of the heat, the external parts being at the begining extream cold, & afterwards exceive hot; alo from the fits either contant or erratical; again, by the contraction of the Pul upon the approach of the fit, afterwards unduly encreaed.
