A continual Feaver is known by an intenive and un-intermitting heat, alo by thirt, roughnes of the Mouth, and the altered color of the Tongue, and the like.

Fifthly, The Venerious Pox is uppoed to meet in complication, if either of the Parents or the Nur were before infected; if any ulers appear in the Head, Mouth and Notrils; or if any eminent and cruted Wheals break out, epecially uch as ordinary Medicins cannot ubdue if hard tumors grow conpicuous, or knots defiling the Bones in the Fingers with rottennes, or any other parts; if unquietnes and bitter pains in the night-time alarum the ick; or if Buboes break out in the Groyn.

Sixthly, The Scurvy complicated with this affect hath thee igns: 1. They that labor under this affect do impatiently endure Purgations; but they who are only affected
with the Rachites do eaily tolerate the ame. 2. They are much offended with violent exercies, neither can they at all endure them. But although in this affect alone, ther be a kind of lothfulnes and averation from exercie, yet exercie doth not o manifetly, at leat not altogether o manifetly hurt them, as when the Scurvy is conjoyned with the Rachites. 3. upon any concitated and vehement motion they draw not breath without much difficulty, they are vexed with diver pains running through their Joynts, and thee they give warning of by their crying, the motion of the Pul is frequent and unequal, and omtimes they are troubled with a Falpitation of the Heart, or threatned with a Lypothymie, which Affects ar for the mot part oon mitigated, or altogether apeaed by laying them down to the ret. 4. Tumors do very commonly appear in the Gums. 5. The urin upon the abence of the accutomed Feaver is much more inten and encreaed.

Seventhly, The Strumatical Affect, if extreamly complicated with the Rachites, is ufficiently conpicuous by Swellings obvious to the enes; yea, where many knotty Excrecences do outwardly occur, it may be jutly upected that the like Tumors do lurk in the Bowels. But if the knots grow inwardly only, they are carce dicernable by any certain ign; for that Rule which ome have oberved, namly, That thoe who have hort Necks, low and narrow Forheads, with compreed Temples, and wide Cheek-bones, are ubject to thee trumatical Tumors and Excrecencies, is too uncertain and fallible; Others affirm, That Purging Medicines taken otherwie in a jut proportion will carce work with thoe who are thus affected; but we anwer from our own Experience That it is omtimes only, and not alwaies true. Thus much of the igns of the differences.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. The Prognotical Signs in the Diea of the Rachites.
div.p: THis Diea in its kind is not mortal, yea omtimes it is o light and gentle, as the Children affected therwith have been retored to health by the ole benefit of Age, the Vital heat being encreaed and ummoned forth to the external parts by the force of frequent Exercies. Yet it omtimes o vehemently prevaileth, that the iminent danger of life can carce, yea omtimes cannot be prevented by the bet and mot prudent applications. Wherfore it is very neceary that a Phyitian hould firt diligently contemplat the Prognotical igns of a diea, that hemay be the better intructed to foree the everal events of it. But in general thoe things which abet the Diea, that is, all uch things as war againt Nature, require a contrary conideration, and as the are the tronger and they the weaker, o much the more grievous and pernitious is the Diea. But becau it is not obvious to every one to give an accurate Judgment of Particulars from this General Admonition, it will not be impertinent or unprofitable to inert om particular and pecial Rules and Obervations hitherto belonging.

Firt, This Diea properly Natural, or that which invadeth before the birth, is the mot dangerous, and eldom, if ever, end in health. For it argueth a deprivation
of the Seminary principles, and by conequence that the Spirits are very infirm; beides it ininuateth a vehemency in the caues.

Secondly, The more early the invaion is after the Birth, the more dangerous (caeteris paribus) the Diea is: for the Spirits are o much the weaker. In like manner, The Elder Children, and uch as go up and down, are more eaily cured then yong Infants that cannot ue their legs.
Thirdly, A Diea improperly o called; namly, that which in part dependeth upon the Natural Inclination, is more dangerous than that Which is contracted by the meer error of the Nure or Mother.

Fourthly, This Diea proceeding from om other fore-going Affects, is more dangerous than that which is introduced by an erroneous Regiment of health; For it implyeth a precedent dejection of the Spirits.
Fifthly, Som have oberved, That Infants who have had red Haird women to their Nures, have been mot obnoxious to this Affect. Yet we indeed upect this rule of om fallability.

Sixthly, Some affirm, That Girls are more frequently infeted with this Diea than Boys, and more eaily cured. The truth is, we have not yet had any unupected experience of this. Yet we grant that Girls are of a more cold and moit temperament, which holdeth the greatet correpondency with this Diea, and for that reaon probable it is that the Female Sex may be affected with the lighter caues, and for the ame reaon alo be the ooner retored.

Seventhly, This Diea doth chiefly invade the Cradles
of the Gentry, epecially, of thoe who live at ea, and fare deliciouly; then of the poorer ort, by reaon of the manifold and various errors which neceity introduceth as wel in the diet of the Parents, as the Regiment of their Children; but it findeth the mot difficult acces unto thoe who are priviledged from uch aaults by a mediocrity of fortune, and accutomed to undergo ome pains-taking and labor, and are not detitute of neceary means to utain life and a healthful competency to prevent indipoition.
Eighthly, By how much the more the firt affected parts are extenuated, o much the more difficult caeteris paribus is the cure of the Diea.

Ninthly, The greater the Head is, the longer and the harder is the Cure. When therfore the Bone of the Forehead ticks much out forwards, it portendeth at leat a long continuance of the Diea; the ame alo do the other irregular tickings out of the other Bones of the Head.

Tenthly, The weaker the Back-bone, the greater and more dangerous is the Affect. Wherfore they which are unwilling to it upright, much more they which are not able to it upright, but mot of all they whoe feeble Necks cannot underprop the burden of the Head, are in hazard of their lives. Moreover, by the Diuturnal weaknes and bending of the Back-bone, Children become Crook-back'd, or ome other waies incuruated, and the trunk of the Body is afterwards carce reducible to its Native Figure.

Eleventhly, Great Swellings in the Bones of the Wrets and the ends of the Ribs preage the continuance of the Diea. Moreover, The crookednes of the Shank-bone, Shoulder-bone, or the Bone in the Arm, prognoticate no les. Again, The greater that the inflexion of the Joints
is, the more difficult and retarded will the retauration be.
Twelfthly, They whoe Thigh and Shank-bones are much encreaed, rather according to latitude and thicknes, then according to longitude, for the mot part becom dwarfs.
13ly. They who draw their Knees upwards and unwillingly, uffer them to be extended, recover not without om difficulty.
14ly. When the Teeth wax black or fal out by pieces, there is om danger, and o much the more, the later they com again, that is, others in their room.

15ly. Al they who attain to the conitence of the Diea, ecape the danger of it, being carefully lookt unto, unles perhaps om other Diea be conjoyned with it, or do accidentally com after, and diturb the Patient with a higher encrea. In like manner the declination of the Symptoms doth auredly promie a retitution of health.

16ly. If an Hydrocephalus be complicated with the Rachites it ever importeth great danger. But if it prevail far, as that the Sutures of the Brain pan do gape, and that om water gotten into the middle Spaces doth well the Dura mater into a waterih and oft Tumor, it is mortal.

17ly. A painful and laborious breeding of Teeth coms omtimes accompanied with mot vehement Symptoms, and even threatneth death. But commonly it is violent and ceaeth in a hort time; however, o long as it is conjoyned, it much accelerates the motion of the Diea. But the Dog-Teeth com forth with more vexation, than the ret and portend more danger.

18ly. An Athma (especially the Orthopny, when the Patient cannot draw breath, but with an erected
neck, and that difficulty of breathing when he cannot ly on either ide) is very dangerous. For that prompteth to a upition of om Tumor, Impothum, Pleuriie, or Inflamation of the Lungs, or om growing too of the Lungs with the Pleura, all which affects want not their danger.
19ly. If the Ptiick be complicated with this Affect, it is for the mot part mortal, especially if one and the ame ulcer of the Lungs continu above forty days.

20. We affirm that if this Diea be of any long continuance it eaily changeth into the Ptyick, or a Conumption, or at leat commonly brings a Conumption to the detruction of the Sick, unles om other affect per adventure, or grievous ymptom do intervene, and prevent the Conumption by hatning death; as a Convulion, the loud Cough, the welling of the Lungs, (vulgarly called, THE RISING OF THE LIGHTS) a continual Feaver, a Pleuriie, &c.
In the next place, We aert, That if a Dropy of the Lungs, or an Acites be complicated with the Rachites, it portends a desperate and deplorable condition.
Again, An Hectick, low, putrid, and epecially a continual Feaver, conuming the firt affected parts doth vehemently haten the motion of this Diea, and render it the more dangerous.
Alo, If the Venereous Pox be conociated with the Rachites, b e it hereditary or contracted by infection, it is almot uncapable of remedy.
The Scurvy likewie conjoyned doth very much retard the cure, thoug h les than the Pox.

In like manner Strumatical tumors either internal or external do not very much uspend the hopes of cure, though otherwie of themelves they are not eaily ubdued in this tender age. For the external
parts are exulcerated, or inflamed with inupportable pain, and do vehemently irritate Nature, and wat the Spirits, but the internal much more, epecially, if they invade the more noble parts, or bring moletation to the adjacent members with their weight and bulk.

Moreover, Whooever are not perfectly cured before the firt five years of their age be spun out out, they afterwards for the mot part live mierable and ickly, and being either Atematical or Cachectical or P • yical they dy before they arrive to the conitence of their age, or ele they grow deformed, crooked, and dwarfih.
If Scabs, wheals, pimples, or the itch com after this Affect, it doth hopefully expedite the cure.
Finally, They which eaily endure any kind of agitation of the Body, caeteris paribus, are cured without difficulty.

Thus at length we have finihed the Hitory of the three kinds of Signs, according to the bet faith of our obervations hitherto. In the next place we hal proceed to the Method of practice, which comprehendeth the prevention and cure of this Diea.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. The Method to practice and Indications in general.
div.p: THE Method to practice is divided into the Therapeutical and the Prophylactical part, or the Curative and the Preervative. We hall dicour of the former in this Chapter, although perhaps we hal here alo propound om things which are common both to the Prophylactical part, and the Eugieihal. But the Prophylactical in particular and uncommunicated we reerve for the cloe of this Tractate.

The Curative part is uually called the Meth od of Cure, wherof, as of every other art, there are two general intruments, namly, Reaon and Experience, the uniting wherof comprehendeth the whol skil of the Artit. Now by experience we undertand not only the Hitory of one or more Dieaes, and the ucces of Medicines, but alo the obervation; that is, the application of the Hitories unto thoe things, which reaon dictates in the ame affect, and that by way of comprobation or diallowance. In like manner, by reaon we mean every operation of the mind, o as we do not only comprehend the third; namly, ratiocination either demontrative, or probable and Analogal, but alo the firt and econd, that is, a imple apprehenion, comprehenion and diviion. For this
part of Medicine includeth or rather preuppoeth the Phyiology, Patholog y and Semeiotical part, which certainly require a manifold exercie of every operation of the undertanding. Again, no man can undertand any propoition, who doth not firt apprehend the imple terms therof, nor any Syllogim, who is ignorant of the Propoitions of which it coniteth; o that it is manifet that every operation of the mind doth meet with an employment.

Indication, That noble intrument of the Method of Cure (by the ue wherof the Dogmatical Phyitians do principally glory to dicriminate their Sect from the Empericks) doth likewie vindicate a tation among the parts of reaon. But becaue om things both difficult and obcure do occur concerning this intrument which have not received an unfolding and ful illutration, from the Neotericks themelvs, we judg it expedient here briefly to unvail them by an examination. We wil enquire therfore.
Firt, What is Indication?
Secondly, Unto which operation of the undertanding it relateth?
Thirdly, Into what kinds and differences it is ditributed?

As for the firt, although perhaps many ignifications of this word may be found among Authors, yet that is the bet and mot proper which is delivered by Galen, in his book de Method. Meden. Indication (aith he) is an ininuation or declaration of the conequence, that is of omthing to be don. In this en Indication may be defined and decribed to be an objective action of the Indicant relatively conidered, which repreenteth to the undertanding the thing Indicated, that is, what may be helpful what hurtful, and by conequence what mut be
elected and applied, what foraken and avoided, that this Decription or Definition may be the better undertood, let us further examin what is here ignified by the Indicant? what by the thing indicated? what the action of the Indicant is? of what ue ditinction is of the thing indicated into helpful or hurtful, into that which mut be choen, and that which mut be refued?

Firt, Although thoe terms Indication, Indicant, Indicatum, or the thing Indicated may peradventure be extended to other Arts and Sciences, yet becau it hath hitherto been only apropriated by the Indutry of Phyitians (epecially of Galen) to the Method of Practice, their definitions which we hall here declare, hall have repect only to this Method, all other ue of them being pretermitted.

The General Definition therfore of the Indicant mut be derived from the mot general Nature which doth indicate in our Art. The Indicant therfore may be defined in general to be a tate of the Body as it is fluxible or movable, or rather, as it is actually influx or motion, relatively conidered, namely, as it intimateth what is to be done in that particular.

Firt, We affirm that the Indicant doth perpetually imply ome tate or condition of the Body; wherfore becau that which is without the Body, and doth not yet affect it, is no tate or condition of the Body, it can carce rightly be aid to indicate. The external cau therfore, which doth not yet affect the Body, is not the Indicant, although the averion of it may poibly be the thing indicated. Secondly, the tate of the Body as it is frail, or movable, or rather as it is actually in motion, is required to the Eence of the Indicant. For as Galen mot luculently proveth to Thrayb. If our Body
were immutable and perpetual, there were no need of Medicine, but becau the heat doth continually feed upon the moiture, and becau health it elf in the mot perfect tate is frail and fluxible, yea actually fluitant, and in ome meaure is already flowed away, manifet it is that the Phyitians Art and the Practical Duty of the Phyitian are both exceeding requiite. For if the tate of the Body and the alteration therof be only conidered abolutely, a bare and naked peculation only reulteth from thence: but if it be conidered in order to that which is to be done wherby the Phyitian may rightly execute his duty concerning that tate, preently it meriteth the denomination of a Practical Intrument, and is inveted with the nature of an Indicant. For uch a tate doth indicate, as it is frail and in motion that care mut be every way had of the health, and that that care mut be exercied and practied with all diligence and circumpection. And conequently this very general Indicant doth point out, that which the general cope of the Phyitians ought after, but it mut not be expected that the conideration of the mot general Indicant can repreent any other thing than a mot general action correpondant to the general cope. For if the Phyitian deireth a higher proecution of the particular cope, he ought to decend to more particular Indicants.

Secondly, The thing Indicated is a Medical Action required on the part of the Indicant. For the Indicant primarily and formally denoteth the action, but econdarily and by conequence the intrument wherwith the action is perfected. Therfore by way of an appendix let us ad to the propoed Definition, that econdarily, by conequence, and in a concrete acception, it includeth the Intrument wherwith that action is accomplih'd.

Firt, We ay, that the thing indicated is an action For the Phyitian ueth Indication to that end, that from thence he may collect what is to be done: you will ay perhaps, that when the criis is at hand or legitimatly proceedeth, the thing indicated is an abtinence from, or a upenion of the action, and not the action it elf.

We anwer, That this abtinence in that very regard that it is enjoyned adviedly and according to art, is evidently contained under ome kind of notion of a Medical Action; and the ame is to be aid of any kind of prohibition of any action in our Art.

Secondly, We ay that the thing indicated is a Medical Action, that is directing the Action to health. For the end of Medicine is health, and therfore that Action which doth aim at health is rightly termed a Medical Action.

Thirdly, We ay, That the thing Indicated is an Action requiite and importing at leat in repect of the Indicant. For every indicated action ought not preently to be reduced to Practice, neither can it be imply aid to be requiite, but only in reference to the Indicant: wherfore it mut be expoed to a further examination before the exercie of it can be reolved on; and if neither the Spirits do diwade, nor no other contra-Indicant doth more potently reit, then it is imply requiite, and mut be put in practice in its due time, with all poible convenience. And herupon the thing indicated is rightly ditinguihed into profitable and unprofitable. The thing indicated becomes unprofitable either by defect of Medical matter, wherwith it hould be accomplihed, or by the preence of a tronger Prohibent, or contra-Indicant.

Again, A thing indicated and profitable is rightly
ubdivided into an Indicate, Circumtantiate, and non-Circumtantiate. The firt by which is meant an Action rightly cloathed with circumtances mut be proecuted without any delay. The econd mut be deferred until it have perfectly acquired due circumtances. We ay fourthly, That a thing indicated in a concrete and econdary en doth alo include the Intrument, wherby the Indicated Action is perfected. As for example, the tate of health doth primarily and formally indicate an act of conervation, but econdarily and by conequence it doth withal indicate the Intrument, wherby we conerve it. This paage of an Indication from the Action to the Intrument doth not eem to depend upon the ole vertue of the Indicant, but in part alo upon ome general certain and commonly received principles, as like things are conerved by the like, things contrary are cured by their contraries, and therfore we indutriouly aid that uch an Intrument is the Indication or thing Indicated in a Secondary en, and by conequence inferred, and becau it includeth the Action together with the Itrument, we termed it o likewie in a concrete ignification.

Moreover, Seing that the Practical duty of a Phyition hath great affinity with the Indicated action; we hall here conider wherin they unite in ome agreement, and wherin they differ among themelves. The general Duty of a Phyitian is to attain (as much as in him lies) the end of his Art, namely Health. And that ame obtaining of Health is in a manner the mot general Indicated Action, yet this is ditinguihed from the general Duty of a Phyitian, becau the Purchae, and retauration of Health is not alwaies attainable. Therfore although the obtaining of Health be perpetually Indicated; yet when that is impoible, the Phyitian
is diobliged, eing that no man is bound to impoibilities, and o conequently, it is no part of his Duty. In like manner an Indicated Action is omtimes unprofitable for the reaons before alledged, in which cae it appertaineth not to the Duty of the Phyitian. Again, An Indicated action, though when it is profitable it mut be performed in its place, yet o long as it continues an apparel'd and deveted of due circumtances, it preeth not the Duty of a Phyitian. For it is the part of a Phyitian not only to precribe things profitable in the Species, but they mut be uch, regard being had to time, order, and other conditions of a jut and regular adminitration. Finally a profitable Indicated Action being robbed in all its due circumtances doth truly exact the duty of a Phyitian. For a Phyitian is obliged to execute uch actions, and only uch, at leat when they are conpicuous.

Beides; The cope and intentions of the Phyitian having a divere repect to the Indicated Actions and the Duties of the Phyitian, and holding ome commerce with each of them, we hall likewie here conider in what repect this falleth out. But in the very entrance into this Dicour thee copes eem omtimes to be properly ditinguihable into little notions or forms of enquiry after every Duty of a Phyitian, and the things themelves to be enquired after. The forms of enquiry are nothing ele but apt Quetions or Interogations, which ubdivide every Duty of a Phyitian into o many parts, as it containeth to be ditinctly ifted and examined. Argenterius reckons up nine Forms of this kind: Firt, Whether? Secondly, What? Thirdly, With what matter? Fourthly, How much? Fifthly? Of what kind? Sixthly, After what manner? Seventhly, When? Eighthly, Where? Ninthly, In
what order a thing mut be done? Others contract thee to fewer Heads, but for further atisfaction the undertanding Reader may conult with the Books. The real Scopes or things themelves to be enquired are thoe very parts, into which each Duty of a Phyitian may be aptly ditinguihed. They are therfore o many in number as there are found parts in that duty to be examined. Thee Scopes thus found out differ not really, but only in reaon from thoe that are yet to be found out, namely in repect of the divere relation to the intellect eeking, and actually undertanding. From hence it appeareth what affinity there is between thee Scopes and the Duty of a Phyitian, and alo the indicated actions. For the notional Scopes or forms of Scopes, and the things themelves to be enquired after under thoe forms do both aim at the ame mark, namely the ditinct invention of all the parts of a Phyitians Duty. But the things to be ought out are the parts themelves of the Duty aptly eparated and disjoyned from one another the better to facilitate the invention and examination.

Moreover, Thoe parts of this Duty, in as much as they are found out by the force of Indication, are the very indicated Actions; o that the Scopes invented by the Indication, and the Indicated Actions do really ignifie the ame things. We ay really, becau the Scopes even when found out differ in reaon from them as they are Scopes, eing that beides the Indicated Actions they eem to note together an intention of proecuting the ame Actions, as the Scopes not yet found out do intimate an intention of enquiring into them. Thus much of Indicates or things Indicated.

Thirdly, The action of an Indicant is Objective and
Indicant, as an Object beides it elf, doth in om ort ininuate another thing to the undertanding. Perhaps om may wonder, how an Object can repreent any other thing beides it elf.

We anwer, Such is the Nature of relatives, that (as uch) they cannot be conceived without an implication of their correlatives. For one relative in his proper conideration doth at leat obliquely involve the conideration of another, and by that means it eaily uhereth the undertanding to the knowledg of the other.
Som may reply, If the force of the Indication be built upon the meer relation of the Indicant to the Indicatum, How coms it to pas that the ue therof is retrained olely to the Art of Medicine?

To this we anwer, We deny not, but this intrument may be extended to other Arts and Sciences, as we have before ininuated. For in moral Philoophy it is lawful to ay, that Vertu doth Indicate the protection of her elf, and Vice the uppreion of it elf. But neither doth this kind of relation conit only between the States of things, and the Actions therunto belonging, but alo between the terms meerly peculative; as twice two are four, a man is not a hore. But here we conider the Indication and the efficacy of the Indicant only in order to the Method of Phyick, o as it wil not be here needful to extend the ue of this intrument further, neither indeed did Galen, becaue it would contribute little to the cope therof. Yet we affirm, that every relation is not a ufficient bais of an Indication, but it mut be uch, as hath either an evident conformity and agreement between the Indicant and Indicatum, wherby they may be fitly marhalled into a propoition of undoubted truth; or a diparity and repugnance of them among themelvs
that o they may aptly be divided from one another; that is, they may be dipoed into a negative propoition equally certain. Now becaue the propoitions elected by this indication are certain and evident, not needing any higher proof: from thence it is manifet that every undertanding that is Mater of it elf, not clouded with a vail of prejudice, nor wittingly ennared with ceptical Sophims and fallacies, mut necearily pay an aent unto them o oon as he undertandeth the terms. Moreover, the Scepticks themelvs, though in their diputations they wil lie in wait to travere any verity, how manifet oever it be, and buy themelvs to equal the mot certain principles with things extreamly doubtful, yet in performing the necearies of life, eing that they relieve hunger by food, hoard up mony, avoyd tripes, and do thee and the like things contantly and without any ditemper of mind, they plainly dicover that they are led by om bad dipoition of mind, or governed by a deire of glory, or tickled wth a hope of victory in the contention, rather that they doubt really of the truth of uch Propoitions. In the interim, it mut be oberved, that the very Indication is fallible and deceitful, where the abolute nature of the Indicant or the Indicatum hath not been exactly undertood before. For in this art of Indications, we do not preuppoe only that a Phyitian hould always have learned before, and duly known what al thoe things are, which we cal according to Nature, as alo in what the Eence of a Diea, and all the parts therof conit, and to have an exact knowledg of all the caues of an Affect. Yea, it is neceary that he undertand all Medical actions, and upon occaion be able to render a ready account what alteration is, what heating, what cooling, &c. what evacuation, purgation, and the ection of a vein, &c. what conervation, and the
like. For the Indication doth not make manifet the abolute nature either of the Indicant or the Indicatum; but preuppoing this as already known, it repreenteth only a mutual relation; namly, either a trict connexion and conformity which they retain among themelvs, or a diparity and oppoition, wherby they may be formed into an undoubted propoition: but the certainty of the indicated propoition cannot exceed the certainty of the knowledg of the Indicant. Therfore if at any time we cruple the certain knowledg of the Nature of the Indicant, it is not afe to trut to the Indication alone, til it hal better be confirmed by om other Reaon or experience. But this doubting mut not be imputed to the Nature of the Indication, but to the ignorance of the Indicant.

Moreover, it mut be conidered that the relation of the Indicant in the Method of practice, doth demontrate beides the evidence omwhat of duty in repect of the Indicated action, and that the propoitions formed from the Indication do either explicitly, or at leat implicitly ininuate that duty. As in this Propoition, a Diea doth Indicate the ablation of it elf, the ablation is decreed and reolved upon, as a requiit action on the part of the Indicant, that is a Diea: as if one hould ay, a Diea requireth or importuneth the removal of it elf. Yet this duty of the action is more frequently and indeed much more elegantly expreed by the Participle in dus, as a Diea is to be taken away: which Propoition in the fulnes of its ignification hath a manifet coincidence with the former.

There remaineth til an objection to be anwered concerning the action of the Indicant; and this it is, If the Indication be the very action of the Indicant, how can it be called an operation of the undertanding? For all
writers refer the Indication to om generation of the undertanding.

We anwer, The Indication is indeed an action of the Indicant, but yet an objective action, and that it is united to the intellective faculty, and abideth in it as in its ubject: Moreover, that the undertanding a power, both actuated, and as it were informed by its ubject. Wherfore although the action of Indication be objectively attributed to the Indicant, yet ubjectively it is acribed to the Soul, and epecially to the intellective part therof, which is as it were the act and form of it. And from hence it wil be mot eay to reconcile Galen with himelf, who omtimes defineth Indication to be an Emphais, omtimes a Catalepis.

Fourthly, It mut be examined whether that ditinction of an Indicated action, into an action helpful and hurtful may tend. For om may urge, that Galen doth perpetually affirm, that one Indicatum only can be ininuated from one Indicant; and that in his Method. Med. he doth affirm, That they vainly attempt the Method of cure, who are ignorant that one thing is Indicated from one Indicant, and that all who have written of this matter do eem to attet the ame thing,

We anwer, That Galen mut be undertood of the three ditinct kinds of Indicants, which mut by no means be confounded, nor their Indicates, that is, the things indicated by them. For that which a Diea doth properly Indicate, mut not be attributed to the caues or the Spirits: In like manner that which the caues Indicate mut not be applyed to the Spirits or the Diea it elf. Finally, that which the Spirits Indicate mut neither be acribed to the Diea nor the caues. For in this repect one Indicate anwereth to one Indicant, and he that oberves not this, mut unavoydably confound all
things, and in the employments of art makes an unuccesful ue of this intrument, according to the judgment of Galen. But it mut be conidered, that in each of thee kinds, the Indicatum may be divided into two parts, one wherof is an advantageous action, and to be proecuted; the other is noxious and to be avoyded yet each of them belongeth to one and the ame kind amongt the aforeaid three, and is as it were a middle part of the whole Indicate: For the Spirits direct to an election of uch things as may cherih and protect them, and to an avoidance of uch things as may in a further degree empair them: and both thee actions concur to advance and acertain the compleat and final conervation of them. In like manner, both in cure and retauration, and alo in caution and prevention, there is found an action as well to be embraced, as abandoned; yet whether of them exceedeth the bounds of its kind, o that no confuion can from thence be feared. For whilt we cure, we make choice of thoe things that wil demolih the Diea, and we deliver the application of uch things as wil augment it. In like manner, when we preerve, we take away the caues, and withal we hun the ue of tho things that may conpire either the continuation, or future breeding of them. And for this Reaon in the definition which we have preented above of an Indication, we ditinguihed the action indicated into that which ought to be proecuted, and that which ought to be waved: which very thing alo we were about to do, in the enumeration of the particular Indications to this Diea.

It is now time for us to proceed to the econd enquiry propounded at the beginning, namely, Unto which operation of the Intellective faculty the Indication belongeth. We ay, firt, That the Indication doth in om ort include the imple apprehenion of each term, both
of the Indicant and the Indicate. For he can never undertand a Propoition who is ignorant of the Terms therof. Yet this knowledg is only preparatory and preuppoed in the art of Indications, as we have already noted. We affirm econdly, That compoition and diviion is an explicit operation of the Intellective faculty in the perception of an Indication. For the Indicant by force of his relation doth repreent the Indicate to be aptly continued together into a relative propoition. Now that a Propoition thus contituted may in its own nature be o manifet and evident, that no man can reaonably doubt of the truth therof, or need any cleerer proof, is exprely taught by Galen— < in non-Latin alphabet > ; and again in another place— < in non-Latin alphabet > . Here om calumniate Galen, as if he had devied an art eparated from all experience, and quarrelling with Reaon; but becaue Galen intended nothing ele, than that Propoitions framed by Indication are of elf credit, and need not any comprobation from Reaon or Experience, the Criticks may perceiv their own rahnes and retract the candal. Senertus indeed objecteth, that the Indication cannot belong to the econd operation of the mind, becaue the Indicate is neither affirmed nor denied of the Indicant. But that learned man was herein mitaken. For although peradventure that the Indicate be neither affirmed nor denied of the Indicant directly, and by the bare Verb Subtantive or Copulative (et.) Yet indirectly and obliquely it is manifetly predicated of the ame, and after the ame manner as it ueth to be in relative Propoitions. As for example, A ound State is the Indicant of its own conervation; a ickly condition is the Indicant of om remedy, &c. And if any man wil expres the Indicate with his relation to the Indicant
by the participle in dus, than the Predication will be direct. As a ound State is to be preerved; a dieaed State is to be cured, a Diea mut be removed, &c. If the Learned Senertus can deny thee to be Propoitions, he may with the like facility deny that an Indication belongeth to this Operation of the Undertanding; but if he mut needs confes that, there is no room left for the denial of this. Now we have aid that the Indication doth belong to the econd Operation of the Mind, becau the Undertanding, in reference to the order of time, doth withal comprehend the mutual relation between the Indicant and the Indicate, and thereupon frameth a Propoition, which formation and contexture of the Propoition is the very Indication; and explicitly a econd Operation of the Undertanding. Now that the Undertanding doth together at one time comprehend the Indicant and the Indicate in the Indication, is elegantly expreed by Galen in a decompounded word which he ueth in the definition therof, < in non-Latin alphabet > : alo in another definition, < in non-Latin alphabet > .

We ay Thirdly, That Indication may likewie implicitly be referred to the third operation of the Undertanding; Becau in the order of Nature the Undertanding eemeth firt to perceive the evident relation of the Indicant to the Indicate before it can conclude of the certainty of the Propoition from thence reulting. Although in the order of time the Mind (as hath been aid) comprehendeth them together; neither is it neceary to form an explicit Syllogim, for the truth is, The Undertanding can comprehend thoe things together at one time, which by the Intitution of Nature are termed Succeive, as the Sun and Light, Fire and Heat, &c. But in regard that this imultaneous comprehenion
of an Indication doth include a certain dependance of the knowledg of the Indicate from the perceived relation of the Indicant, it uppoeth alo that the aid relation is ooner perceived at leat in the order of Nature, and that the Indicate is later undertood and by an implicit bringing in, for a kind of tranition, in repect of the order of Nature doth eem to be here implied from the relation of the Indicant, as the Medius terminus, to the Propoition contituted of the Indicant and the Indicate as to the concluion; and this may be called an implicit reaoning.

We ay Fourthly, That by circumlocution and circumtances of peech, an Indication may be reduced to an explicit reaoning or yllogim, or rather, that the ame thing which we purue & argue at by Indication is to be found out and proved by way of Syllogim. For the Reaon of the evidance of an Indicated Propoition may explicitly be applied, as the Medius terminus, to infer that propoition. In the interim a Syllogim o pieced together will be either abolutly frivolous and childih, or at the bet only explicatory. As if any one who would prove that a Diea were to be removed, hould thus proceed: That which is contrary to Nature is to be removed; A Diea is contrary to Nature, therfore a Diea is to be removed. The Medius terminus (that is againt Nature) is not the reaon of the Relation of a Diea to the Ablation therof, but it is only an Expoition of the general Nature of a Diea. For whooever undertandeth what a Diea is, doth at the ame intant preently conceive omthing not natural. And therfore uch a yllogim is only expoitory. Yet we do not uppoe it to be alwaies unprofitable, becau it may omtimes be erviceable to the conviction of a tubborn, or the information an ignorant Ditemper. Hither alo we may
refer the tranlation of an Indication from the Action to the Intruments by vertue of general Rules: Likes are preerved by their likes, Contraries cured by their contraries.

We ay Fifthly, That a Collation of the Indications among themelvs, wherby we may guide our choice by the conent and dient of the Indicants to what imply and abolutly ought to be done, doth necearily involve the third Operation of the Undertanding. For the limitation of any Indication uppoeth a midle term extraneous to that Indication, which being firt undertood, the limitation is inferred as a concluion. For he that findeth out an external for a middle term (thereby to aert the verity of any propoition) doubtles he manifetly argues and diputes. Seing therfore that beides the Indicant and the Indicate a third term, and the affirmation or negation therof is required to the limitation of an Indication, evident it is that the third Operation of the Undertanding is requiit to the Invention therof. Therfore although imple Indications may ubminiter the firt rudiments of Method to Practice, yet to the complement and perfection of diputing the Art mut likewie be joyned with it.

We affirm Sixthly, That the election of the Phyical Matter in particular, and the apt and prudent adminitration therof, doth not only imploy every Operation of the Undertanding, but that it alo requireth experience; for without this, who can ufficiently undertand to adminiter a doe of Scamony or of any other purging Medicament, or know what humors uch and uch a Plant draweth away by a peculiar propriety? Again, in Medicines alterant there may perhaps lurk om hidden quality, which may be hurtful to the Patient, and this without experience cannot be dicerned. We conclude therfore
