(the proper force and ue of Indications being continued) that to a compleat method of Medicine all the dictates of Reaon, and the contributions of Experience are pre-required.

We now proceed to the Third Title propounded at firt, namly, Into what kinds and differences Indication is ditributed. Som differences may eaily be oberved by what hath already been poken, which therfore we hal here omit. Now here we ditinguih Indication into general, ucceeding, and pecifical. The general is derived from the general Indicant, the ucceeding fro¯ the intermediat kinds of Indicants, and the pecifical from the lowet Species of them. We have already noted that the general Indicant is the very tate of the Body conidered in general, as it is frail and in motion; this tate indicateth that health mut be intended, which is the mot general phyical action, and the mot general Indicate; yet this action is in om ort concrete, and equally includeth two general actions in the abtract, namly Conervation and Correction. For the general tate aforeaid is alo concrete, and comprehendeth two like Coniderations in the abtract, namly, one of the parts yet qualified according to the precript of Nature, which require a pure Conervation: The econd of the parts omwhat degenerated from their integrity, which in like manner require a pure correction. Thee two actions are perpetually conjoyned in every work of Art. For he that conerveth, withal correcteth, that is, he rectifieth om irregularities; and he which correcteth, hath at the ame time conervation for the object of his Undertakings. The complication of thee actions is o ubtil, that it eemeth to have poed that mot acute Phyitian Argenterius, who in his Book Off. Med affirmeth Conervation to be that very Correction,
which is exercied in the art of maintaining health. But his Error is twofold. Firt, becaue he uppoeth Correction and Conervation in < in non-Latin alphabet > to be one and the ame action, when indeed they are two ditinct actions, however they are complicated in the Exercies of Art. For they are indicated (as we aid before) from the everal Coniderations of the Indicant, and Conervation hath repect to thoe things which are according to Nature; but Correction reflecteth upon preter-natural faultines. Moreover, They are perfected by intruments formally ditinct, yea oppoit: For Correction even in the very art of defending health, is accompliht by Contraries, but Conervation by Homogeneals; as in this Art we help Emptines by taking Nourihment, contrary indeed to the Emptines, but homogeneal to the Parts which are to be nourihed: Therfore although thee Actions be complicated in the Execution, yet indeed they are formally ditinct, and ought ditinctly to be entertain'd by the Undertanding. The Second Error of Argenterius is, becaue he granteth the correction of Errors only to be the General Action of al Medicin, when as Conervation is equally univeral and alike exercied in al the works of Art.

No man doubteth but we conerve in the Hygienal part, and that we correct. Alo Galen demontrats in his Book, whether the matters of preerving health belong to a Phyitian. You will ay, That Galen in that place doth prove every Medicinal Action to be correction, and that conervation is comprehended under the latitude of correction. But Galen mut not be o undertood, as if he intended correction to be a kind of conervation, eing that (as we have hewed before) conervation and correction even in this art of preerving health are actions formally different and differently ditinguihed:
for Galen's meaning is, that every Medical action when it is actually adminitred, doth imply and comprehend correction, and in that repect may be called Correction, and o by conequence Correction will be the general Action of all Medicine; yet Galen confeeth Conervation to be equally general. For what hinders but there may be two general abtracted Actions in Phyick? That doth not detroy, if any man have uch conceptions, the unity of the Art, it rather indeed confirms it. For the unity of an Art coniteth in ome community, which may be attributed to all the parts therof; and this union is to be eteemed o much the more firm, as all the parts of art are reciprocally conjoyned among themelvs by more communities. If therfore there are two general Actions, and thoe common to all the parts of Medicine, o much the more firmly will thoe parts conpire the advancement of the Art. Wherfore he contradicts not Galen, that affirms conervation alo to be a general Action of all Medicine; eing that the cope of Galen was only to hew the unity of the Medical art by the community of that general Action, namely Correction; now he might as eaily have hewed it, if the nature of the thing had required it, by the community of Conervation. For in the Hygienal part of the mot noble circumtance is the Conervation of the whol concrete action, and therupon the whol action is denominated from the more principal part, and the Art it elf an Art conervative. Although otherwie (as hath been aid) it alo includes Correction. But in the Prophylactical part the principal cope of the Medical Action is preervation, namely the correction of the cau of the imminent Diea: yet this is o performed, and by uch means which the preent pirits can allow, but in no wie by uch things as may
detroy them. And therfore alo in the Prophylactical part regard is had to the Spirits, and their conervation is Indicated.

Now after the ame manner the whole concrete Action (although as hath been aid, it alo includeth Conervation) is called Preervation and Precaution from the more Noble part. Finally, In the Therapeutical part, although in like manner the whol concrete action be called Curation, and the art it elf a Curative Science from the principal part of the action, yet to peak properly and truly all this action of cure may be divided into three abtracted parts, and evidently ditinct; namly, into the Cure of the caue, the Cure of the Diea, and the conervation of the Spirits. For the Vital or Conervative Indication doth evidently, and by the unanimous grant of all Phyitians belong alo to this part of Medicine, and mut be conulted of in every curative action before it be undertaken. From whence it is manifet that this part likewie of Medicine doth perpetutually conerve, that is, provide and foreee in every Cure, leat the Spirits hould receive more detriment than profit from the precribed remedies. Al thee things therfore being thorowly weighed, we conclude, That a general Indicate is a certain concrete thing, and may be properly ditinguihed into two general abtracted actions which are exercied in every part of Medicine, and that in the work of art they pertually make one compleat or complicated action.

Moreover, The general Indicant, namely the State of the Body, as frail and in motion may be divided, beides the parts or obtracted coniderations already propoed, into three kinds, or rather three ucceeding kinds equally and alike concrete: namely, into a ound tate, a dieaed tate and a neutrality. Thee three
Species are the ubjects of the three kinds of Method to Practice; namely the ound tate of the Hygienal part, the dieaed tate of the Therapeutical, and the Neutral of the Prophylactical part. Thee three tates are alo concrete Indicants, and repectively Indicate what is particularly to be done, or what the Phyitians Duty is in all thoe Arts: namely a ound tate indicateth the conervation of health; a dieaed tate the removal of ome affect, and the Neutral tate that the cau of an imminent malady ought to be corrected leat it break out into a Diea. Now thee three Indicates are alike concrete, and each of them as we have proved above, abtractively includeth both Conervation and Correction.

Finally, In a Dieaed tate the action of correcting is diolved into two Species; into the correction of Cau, and the correction of the Diea, and o here may be dicovered three kinds of abtracted actions. For a dieaed tate brancheth it elf into three Species evidently abtracted, into the Eence of a Diea, the caues of a Diea, and the Spirits or thoe things which remain in this tate according to Nature. For thoe things which are preternatural and indicate correction in general, are here eparated (as hath been aid) into two parts, namely into the Eence of a Diea, and the Caues of a Diea; and therfore there are three parts of this tate, each of which do formally and ditinctly Indicate. Three kinds therfore (that we may put an end to this matter) of Indications are to be conidered in this tate; namely, from the Eence of the Diea, the Curative; from the Caues the Preervative, and from the Spirits the Vital or Conervative. To the Caues we refer all impediments of cure, as alo vehement Symptoms, and uch as divert the Progres of
the Cure to themelvs, for in this repect they are inveted with the Nature of Caues. And thus much of Indications in general.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. Indications Curative.
div.p: WE have already affirmed that thee Indications are deduced from the Eence of the Diea, we hall therfore in this place lightly run over all the parts of the Eence of this Diea, that the Reader may perceive, what every one ininuates to be done.

Firt, Therfore the Eence of this Diea partly coniteth in a cold and moit ditemper, this Diea therfore in repect of this part of its Eence Indicateth, not only that all thoe things are to be avoided, which are in any wie endued with a faculty to cherih and augment that ditemper; but alo that the aid of uch things ought to be implored, which may ubdue the ame; namely, hot and dry.

Secondly, This Diea partly alo coniteth in the want of inherent Spirits, therfore not only all thoe things are to be avoided, which can any further catter, and conume the Spirits; but uch things mut be elected which are vertuous to retore, cherih, and multiply them. Strong dicuing remedies are therfore in this cae to be declined, becau withal they conume the Spirits: in like manner uch as are extreamly hot, for
they cau them to evaporate and vanih into air; but much more uch as have power to diolve the parts, as violent Catharticks. But the bet nourihment mut be choen, and Medicines that are eay of Concoction, as much as may be, and amicable and benign to the Spirits.

Thirdly, The Eence of this Diea coniteth partly in a numbnes or atonihment of the Spirits: this numbnes ininuates a prohibition and abtinence from all uch things as vehemently make thick and fix the Spirits or any other waies tupifie them, as narotical remidies, and many Minerals, which participate of the nature of Lead, as Cerus, Litharge, Sinople or Vermilion; and all uch things as have power to excite the Spirits, to expel their tupefaction, and to render them active and agile, are to be made choice of, as exercies, motions, Frictions.

Fourthly, The Tone being over oft, loo, flavid, and withered, indicateth an avoidance of uch things as are wont to mollifie, looen and weaken the parts; and that uch Medicines are to be outwardly applied and inwardly given, as may render them more firm and olid. The ame Tone as it is internally too brittle brings a upicion upon all uch things as abound much with an inward lipperines, and eemeth to deire ome roughnes, or indeed atriction in thoe things applied or taken.

Fifthly, The corrupted Vital Contitution on the part of the Generation of the Vital Spirits is not o coniderable; but on the part of the ditribution of the Vital Spirits, the inequality therof is of great importance, and indicateth a caution to be had of thoe things which promove the flux of the Blood towards the Head, as alo of uch things as retard the paage therof to the firt
affected parts, but that choice mut be made of uch things as tir the Pules of the Arteries in the parts firt affected, and temper thoe that are in the Head. A low and diminute current of the Blood through the firt affected parts indicateth the ame things, namely an evocation of the Pul to thoe parts. But an over facile and lippery paage of the Blood through the habit of the parts, is coincident in its indication with the lipperines of the Tone lately recited. A defect of the Vital Contitution on the part of the union ufficiently vigorous and pleaant between the Vital and the Natural Spirits, indicateth an election of uch things as can both nourih and cherih the Spirits, and alo excite them to a greater activity, and that their contraries ought to be avoided. The Vital heat, as deficient indicates almot the ame thing as a cold ditemper, provided that regard be had withal to the trength of the Heart and Arteries, and to the vigor of the Vital Spirits.

Sixthly, The unequal Nutrition Indicateth thoe things which promove the even and impartial ditribution of the Aliment and Heat. Or indeed that which is too liberal to the parts that are nourihed beyond a due meaure; the extenuation of the parts requireth a fuller Nourihment. The irregular magnitude of the Head, chiefly things extenuant and uch as are of the flux from the Head. The Tumors of the Bones indicate the ame thing; the crookednes of the Bones require uch things as attract the Aliment to the hollow ide, as moderate rubbings; but things repreing chiefly on the gibbous and bunched ide, as trong bindings. The bending of the Joynts, ininuateth an Artificial erection of them, as much as is poible. The narrownes of the Breat pointeth to Pectorals, and uch
things as have a faculty to dilate the Breat; but the harpnes therof indicateth uch things as have a dilative Vertue.

Sevently, The imperfect ditribution of Animal Spirits, and omwhat defective in the firt affected parts indicateth Cephalicals, and uch things as facilitate the ditribution, as exercies, rubbings, and the like. A defect of due tretching in the Nerves, or Nervous and Fibrous parts, indicateth thoe things as Corroborate the Nerves and trengthen the parts. Thus much of Indications Curative, the Preervative follow.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. Indications preervative.
div.p: THee Indications are deduced either from the Antecedent or the preent caues of a Diea. Thoe which flow from the former kind of caues concern the Prophylactical Part: here we only propound thoe which proceed from caues that are preent and contained in the Body; namly, from common caues, or uch as are proper to this Diea.

Now although that common caues do not eem immediatly to attain to the production of the Eence of a Diea; yet even in this repect that they are eteemed an impediment, and may retard the cure, they Indicate their taking away.

Thee caues are either impurities, or excrementitious
humors collected and impacted in the firt paages, which unles they be taken away, do not only infect the nourihment inward, but they omwhat dul, or otherwie hinder the appropriate Medicines. They indicate therfore an evacuation either by a gentle vomit, or by a lenitive purgation, as occaion hal rather perwade to this or that: or they are common caues deeper imbited into the Parts of the Body, and thee alo require an evacuation. But eing that according to this kind of common caues it is at the ame time driven away and almot with the ame Medicaments, as are the caues which are proper to this Diea, we hal conjoyn both the kinds of them in this preent conideration.

The caues therfore which are proper to this Diea, as alo the Common caues which have a deeper penetration into the Body, may be divided into Blood and Cacochymical humors. The Blood indeed, although it be rather deficient than redundant in the firt Affected parts, yet in the Head for the mot part it requires a particular evacuation, which uually is performed by carification of the Veins in the hollow of the Ear. Hither likewie we may partly refer bliters raied between the firt and econd turning Joynt of the Neck, although thee perhaps may relate over and above in part to the Cacochymical humors.

Cachochymical humors are divided into thoe which til flow in the channel of the Veins, and into thoe which are impacted in certain parts of the Body. The caues or humors flowing in the Veins do (primarily and intentionally) Indicate their evacuation. But if they be unapt for motion (as to the execution) then they require om previous preparation. But becaue it happens for the mot part, that not al the humors are equally unapt, but that om are ufficiently flexible, and others not
o, but reit the Medecines, in this cae they indicate a les evacuation and then a preparation.

Moreover, Thee humors in the chanel of the Veyns may be ubdivided into Feaverih (namly, if there be a putrid Feaver) and not Feaverih. The Feaverih humors are either welling, or not welling. The welling, that is, thoe which are unquiet, or impetuouly agitated, do Indicate a udden evacuation, at leat a leer, unles perhaps they are carried of their accord to the external and more ignoble parts, as it happens in the mall Pox, the Meazels, and the like Affects. But if a Feaver be preent, and that acute, and yet the humors are not welling, they chiefly Indicate that peculiar preparation which they cal coction, that by this means they may be obedient to the Medecine to be aftergiven, and than evacution, but if the Feaver not be acute but Chronical, although the matter be not irritated, and yet om part of it be ufficiently flexible; in this cae, a leer evacuation is firt indicated at any time of the Diea, and afterwards the coction of the relicts, that they alo in their time may be evacuated.

The humors contained in the Veins which are not Feaverih, if they are fluxible, they firt indicate evacuation: but becaue in this Affect low, gros, and clammy humors are almot perpetually preent, preparation (at leat wher a leer evacuation hath gon before) is firt Indicated; and indeed the vicous humors Indicate incident, and the thick attenuant remedies. Again, when the Diea is very Chronical and extended to many months; yea, perhaps to a year and upwards, it is not to be uppoed that the whol matter cauing the Diea can at once be prepared or evacuated; wherfore in this rerepect it Indicateth, that we init upon things preparatory and evacuant by turns. Beides we mut know that
Cholerick humors require one preparation and evacuation, and Melancholy humors another, flegm another, and watry humors another. And that the preparation and purgation is Indicated variouly according to the diverity of the humors commixed with the Blood.

The humors that are impacted in certain parts of the Body do much more require preparation before they are evacuated; according to that of Hippocrates, When you would purg a Body, you mut firt make it fluxible. Neitherdoth a certain general purgation uffice to ubdu the humors, but uch a preparation is required, that hath a peculiar reference to that part, in which they are inherent, and therfore the humors in the Liver require one kind of preparation, thoe in the Lungs another, &c.

Finally, Seing that the propounded kinds of all humors, after they are evacuated, may grow and breed again; they Indicate an avoyding of uch things which may dipoe the Body to an eay generation of uch humors: And thus much of Indications Preervative, it remaineth now that we conider the Vital and Conervative.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. Indications Conervative, or Vital.
div.p: THis Indication arieth from thoe things which are according to Nature. For Life in it elf coniteth in thee things; namly, in a triple Contitution of the Body, the Natural, Vital, and Animal above reheared.
The Natural comprehendeth under it
Firt, The Temperament.
Secondly, The Inherent Spirits with their plenty and vigor.
Thirdly, The Tone of the Parts.
Fourthly, The Structure of the Organs.
Fifthly, The Continuity.

The Vital containeth
Firt, The Generation
Secondly, The Ditribution of the Vital Spirits.
Thirdly, Their participation with thoe parts, unto which they are ditributed; namely, from the union of them with the aid parts, and the communicated heat.

The Animal comprehendeth
Firt, The Generation
Secondly, The Ditribution of the Animal Spirits.
Thirdly, The due Stretching of the Parts depending upon the Influx of the Brain.

All thee things becaue life coniteth in them, are called Vital Indications. But among Authors for the mot part they are known by the common name of the Spirits, but this name is omwhat to gros, eing that in propriety of peech, the Spirits are radicated in the aid Contitutions, and are faculties of them. Yet we have no deign to innovate the cutom of peech, provided that the things may be undertood as it is.

Thee Indicants o long as they continue firm and ound, they require only a general and ordinary conervation by the right ue of the ix non-Natural things but when they are all alike vitiated or obnoxious to imminent hurt, they require not only a general conervation, but uch an one likewie, as is mixt with cure and preervation. Again, Where ome one Contitution, or om one part therof is depraved more than the ret or ubject to uch depravation, beides the general preervation, it requireth in like manner an epecial one to be aociated to the peculiar Curation. Latly, When a Contitution Subject to error, or actually erroneous is fixed to om certain part, it doth higher pecify that conervation; namly, that repect may be alo had of the part o labouring more than the ret.

But becaue om ay, That the Vital Indication is the only, and that Conervation is the imple end, and that they cannot be further ubdivided, becaue that all things, which are according to Nature are comprehended in the word Spirits, and that they Indicate one Action; namly, the preervation of themelvs. We grant indeed that the Spirits, if (as we have already noted) they be improperly taken for their caues; namly, the
three Contitutions aforeaid, may in one word comprehend al things which are according to Nature, but then this word mut be Generical, and diviible into three pecies; namly, the three Contitutions, as Spirits Natural, Vital, and Animal. We grant alo that the end, or that the Indicated action is one; namly, Conervation, but by the unity of the Genus, not of the ultimate pecies. For thoe very things which are according to Nature, however they agree in the Genus, yet in the pecies they may differ among themelvs, and require a different conervation; yea, it is poible that tho things which conerv the Spirits on one part may impugn them on the other; as for example: Wine given may in one repect cherih and trengthen the Vital Spirits, or rather the Vital Contitution, but in the interim it may offend and debilitate the Animal Spirits, or the Animal Contitution. In like manner the Temperament requireth one preervation, the Structure of the Organs another, and the Continuity another. Yea, the very different Contitution of the parts Indicates a various conervation, neither do we after one and the ame manner or by the ame actions provide for the pecial conervation of the Liver, Lungs, Brain, &c. Wherfore when om one Contitution is more infirm then another, or when om one part is weaker than another, it Indicates a proper conervation peculiar and pecial to it elf, and therfore both Conervation and Conervants may be divided into their Species. For the Conervation & the Conervants appropriated to the Animal contitution, differ from thoe which are detinated to the Vital or Natural: And from hence the three firt kinds of Conervation are to be deducted, namly, the Conervation of the Animal, the Vital, and the Natural contitution. In like manner the Conervation of the Liver
is accomplihed by the ue of the Hepaticals, and of the Lungs by Pectorals, &c. Yea, all parts of an eminent diverity do ubdivide the conervation into o many more pecies. Thus much of the diviion of Conervation into its pecies.

Moreover, The ame Conervation eemeth to be further diviible unto its parts. For this Conervation is omwhat complicated, and doth not only relate to imples, but in om ort to contraries, to wit, Indicates both Curative and Preervative, and either permitteth or dialloweth thoe ame things being etimated with the Spirits. It eemeth therfore to be branched into three parts, into an election of like matters, into an election of contraries under a certain condition, and into a prohibition of the ame under a divere condition.

The election of like things is the mot appropriated Action to Conervation, and eems withal to have reference to two kinds of things alike; namely, uch as are eaily aimilated, and are properly nourihments, and uch which although they cannot be aimilated in repect of their ubtance, yet they contain within the ame qualities like unto the contitution of certain parts, in repect wherof they are reputed amicable and familiar to Nature, and do cherih and trengthen certain parts.
You wil ay, Thee are indeed Alterants and do belong to the kind of contraries.

We anwer, That in a diver repect they may be referred to each kind, but in as much as they obtain qualities like unto the du Nature of the parts, although otherwie they alter om mal matter, yet they are to be referred to the imilaries. For the very nourihments do in om degree alter, and are directly contrary to emptines, and conervation it elf doth implicitly include a
certain correction, as we have hewed above. Now thee indeed in regard of a middle nature, which they have between imilaries and Alterants, are not called Medicaments, but Strengthners, Conervants, and Cordials; Again, thee are Indicated as Conervants by the peculiar debility of the Spirits, and as to be elected, and not only permitted, and o they are eteemed in the Books of Practical Authors.

The Permiion of a remedy omwhat contrary to Nature doth likewie belong to this Indication. For uch is the dignity and valu of this Indication, as it ummons both the Curative and Preervative Indicates to an examination before they are reduced into practice, and doth not only moderate and limit the quality and quantity of the remedy, but alo the very time of repeating it, yea, whatoever appertaineth to the ue therof, or the manner of uing it, and al this leat in any wie it hould exceed the Spirits of the Patient, or be injurious to them: nor is the excellency of it thus circumcribed, but it requireth more; namly, that more profit and advantage may accrue to the things, according to Nature by impugnation of the Diea, then hurt or detriment by any violence offered to Nature. And under this Law and Condition. Vital Indication permitteth many things to be don, which of themelvs are contrary to the Spirits, yet always in favor of health, never to the prejudice of Life.

A prohibition of a contrary is altogether a commanding Action of this Indication, and by a kind of Authority dictates this or that thing not to be don, (although it were otherwie Indicated) becau perhaps it endangers life it elf, or brings more diadvantage than benefit of health to the parts. And this is the third and lat force and ue of this Indication. We hall
now in one word apply thee things to the preent Diea.

All Contitutions in this Affect are very weak and infirm; and this is manifet from the bare conideration of this tender age. But the Natural doth yet further uffer by the force of the firt Eence of the Diea; and from hence alo the Vital is omwhat weakned, and indeed neither doth the Animal ecape wholly free, as was hewed above. Wherfore both a general and alo a particular regard mut be had to thee Contitutions, as wel in the Election of Similaries, as in the permiion or prohibition of contraries.

Firt, Therfore in this Affect you mut make choice of the bet nourihments, uch as are eay of concoction, and as neer as you can agreable to the cutom and age of the Patient, to the time of the year, &c. the contraries mut be abandoned, namly, uch things as nourih little, are difficult of digetion, and incongruous to the cutom, age, and eaon.

Secondly, Thoe things mut be choen which cherih and trengthen the weaker Contitutions, and the parts that are mot Affected, and thee mut be either exhibited everally, or they mut be mingled with nourihments or Medicines; but uch things as are neither erviceable to this cope, nor otherwie Indicated, mut be totally avoyded.

Thirdly, Benign and gentle evacuants, or othertherwie ufficiently corrected, mut be allowed in a moderate quantity, jut and du interval of time being oberved. But the contrary things; namely, violent and fierce purgers, epecially uch as are apt to diolv the parts, or are exhibited in an undu quantity, or too often repeated, are forbidden.

Fourthly, Remedies alterant, or uch as prepare the humors, or correct the Diea mut be permitted; uch alo as are friendly and familiar to Nature, or uch as may be made uch by good company, that is, by compoition or ufficient correction. Remedies violently alterant, extream hot, and vehemently dicutient, or any other which in any wie reolv and diipate the parts.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. The ue and right adminitrations of the Indications aforeaid.
div.p: HAving propounded the three kinds of imple Indications, and deduced them into their lowet pecies, we hal in the next place conider the right ue & adminitration of them. The exact knowledg wherof eems impoible to be obtained without rode and experience. For it decendeth unto Individuals, and comprehends not only the Election of a thing among o many Indicates imply to be don in the Species, but alo the invention of quantity, place, form, time, order, and matter of the remedy to be exhibited.

The Conent and Dient of Indications do contribute much to this invention. Now the Conent may be twofold: of Coindication and Permiion. Permiion may be either an Advantage or a Los to him that permitteth
or neither of them. A Permiion that cannot be granted without hurt; mut never be allowed without the greatet circumpection, and o much the greater, as the damage may be the more to him that permitteth. For although the Permittent may part with omwhat of his private right to advance the publick good, yet in repect that he is a member of the whol he is uppoed to be a gainer.

The Dient of Indicants is twofold; namly, either Contradictory or Contrary. The Contradictory among the Books is called Interdiction or Prohibition, and for the mot part it is appropriated to the Spirits, unto wch in this repect we mut always yeeld obedience. The Contrary is called Contra-indication, and this doth not imply forbid, but o far forth as it undergoeth the Nature of an impediment, or om more urgent Indicate.

Firt, Where Indicants conent, either by Coindication or Permiion, atisfaction if it be feaible mut be given to al the Indicates: But if this cannot be performed Medicines of that Nature are to be preferred before the ret, which are correpondent to mot, or at leat to the mot urgent Scopes. But if uch imples cannot be found out, then you mut intitute an apt compoition of divere imples one with another.

The Eential parts of this Diea, although they are very various, yet is there not any coniderable diagreement among them, and nothing hindreth but in a great part they may be conidered together. For Medicines temperatly hot and dry, may at once cherih the Inherent Spirits, and perhaps conduce to the cattring of the numbnes in them, and withal omwhat fortify the Tone of the parts, and facilitate the equal ditribution of the Blood, and conequently the equality of the Nutrition: alo it may increae vigor in the Vital and Animal Spirits,
proritate the Arteries in the firt affected parts, and trengthen the Nervs: unto which Heads almot al the Indicates of the Eence of a Diea may not unaptly be referred. Moreover, the Spirits alo, although they prohibit all extream hot things, yet they allow of thee as mo¯derat, and very congruous to Nature. In like manner there is little or no particular repugnance between thee caues and the Indicates, albeit in repect of time and the order of adminitration om dient may be oberved, as we hall ee afterwards in due place.

Wherfore in what repect and how far thee agree together whilt we intend a cure, we do at once repect not only the Spirits, but in om ort the caues, by chooing uch curative remedies, or by mingling uch ingredients with them, which are able both to attenuate the thick matter, to cut into the vicous, to open the obtructed paages, and the like. In like manner, whilt we are chiefly imployed either in preervation, or in the rooting out of caues, we make choice of uch evacuants, or el we compound them with uch remedies, as are alo partly contrary to the Diea. And all thee things we do to that purpoe; as that (as hath been aid) we may be ubervient to the mot intentions we can.
Now having found out the actions imply requiit in the Species, in the next place we hal enquire out their du circumtances.

1. In regard that this is a great Diea it requireth a great quantity of the Remedy, in repect of it elf. For a Remedy unequal to the Diea cannot extirpate it. It is neceary therfore that the doe of the Medicine be equally to the magnitude of the Affect. But in this Diea the Spirits permit not o great a quantity of Remedies to be given at once. Wherfore that quantity mut be divided & given by turns. For this is a Chronical Diea, and of
low motion, neither doth it necearily require an haty Cure, and although the Spirits cannot wel endure either vehement Remedies or uch as are given in a large doe, yet they permit the ue of Evacuant Medicins by an Epicrais. Wherfore by turns, we mut omtimes make ue of Remedies Preparatory, omtimes Evacuant, omtimes Alterant, and omtimes trengthing.

Secondly, For o much as belongeth to the place of adminitration, the general Rule is, that the remedy ought to arive at the eat, and penetrate to the very Caue of the Diea. If therfore it mut have a paage into the Veels, it mut be taken at the Mouth; but if it will uffice to touch only the thick Guts, it mut be injected by the Fundament. If the humors be naturally ready to move upwards, expel them by vomit; if downwards evacuat them by iege. In like manner you mut humor the inclination of Nature, and root out the caues by pitting, by Urin, or by weating. Particular evacuations mut be intituted in the very affected parts, or in the parts adjacent. For o the force of the Remedy doth the more urely make way to the eat of the Diea and the morbifical Cau. And for the ame reaon external and topical Medicines mut be applied to the next convenient place. Yet you mut know that there is a certain Sympathy between om parts, in which cae the remedies ar frequently adminitred to the part, wherwith that conent intercedeth, and neither to the affected nor the adjacent part.

Thirdly, The form of the Medicament doth partly depend upon the Rule lat propounded. For if the cope be to lenifie the Jaws or the Windpipe, we chue a licking or lapping form, that by degrees the remedy may lide over the affected parts, and tay the longer upon them. In like manner, if the Stomach be affected, we
often precribe Pils, Pouders or Electuaries, that they may the longer abide in the Stomach. To the Kidnies we rather deign liquid things, that they may the more eaily be carried down to them with the wheyih part of the Blood. The forms do alo in om part depend upon the very nature of the Diea, as in burning Feavers liquid things are for the mot part convenient, dry things are carce admitted; on the other ide, in moit Dieaes, and when the Belly is overoluble, more olid forms are preferred. Finally, the forms of the Medicines do alo partly depend upon the nature of the Ingredients. So Caia worketh mot effectually in the form of a Bolus; Harthorn, Coral, and the like in the form of a Pouder; in like manner bitter things, uch as beget a vomiting, and tinking things are concealed in the form of Pills; omtimes alo they are guilded, or el they are enwrapped in Wafers, and exhibited in the form of a Bolus.

Now it mut here be noted, that for the mot part the form of the Remedy is not o coniderable, as it gives place to the more eaie and commodious adminitration, in repect of the Admiion or Reception of the Sick. For many cannot wallow Pills, others preently reject their Potions by vomit, & others are perhaps aver from other forms. In this Affect, in regard that all Children almot are loth to take Phyick, that form is to be preferred before the ret, which hall be oberved to be leat ditatful to them.

Fourthly, As for the time of action, you mut o endeavor to it your adminitrations, that they may as little as poible be interupted with times of eating, exercie, or leep, for at this age the Spirits are carce preerved ound and perfect, without an interpoition of thoe things by jut internals.

Remedies evacuant, opening, attenuate and incident, mut be taken early in the morning upon an empty tomach; and if they mut be repeated the ame day, four of the Clock in the afternoon (upon an empty tomach likewie) is the mot eaonable hour. Strengthning and atringent Medicines, and uch as provoke leep, are to be taken rather in the evening than in the morning; but perhaps om of thee are mot agreable after meals.
Medicines that are mingled with the nourihment, ought to be gratful to the Palat, let they ubvert the tomach and hinder concoction, or cau a loathing of the meat, or el empair the Spirits.

As for the order of proceeding, there occur two general Rules. The former is, That that mut firt be don, which being premied makes way for the following Remedies, and therfore that ought firt to be removed which hath the conideration of an impediment in repect of what mut follow. The later is, That we mut ever give our firt help to the more urgent and weighty Indicant, unles om impediment intervene.

If the Quetion therfore be, Whether the Diea, or the Cau of the Diea doth firt require the help of Phyick? The anwer wil be obvious according to the firt Rule: For the caues are reflected upon under the notion of an impediment in repect of the Cure of the Diea; for they cherih it, and infringe the vertu of the Medicins. Wherfore, before that we are intent upon the vanquihing of the Diea, we premie all poible endeavors to root out the Cau, or at leat to leen, abate and retund it, that it may oppoe no coniderable force to retard the rooting out of the Diea. Yet in the interim whilt we are buie in the removal of the Caues, the Eence of the Diea mut not be totally neglected, as we have before admonihed. Yea when we have o ubdued the Caue
that it cannot for the preent much interupt the Cure, we may (the Caues not being utterly over-come and cat out) the more diligently and earnetly attempt the reiting of the affect; yet with this condition, That if the Caues revert and becom new impediments, that then we are obliged preently to undertake the ubduing and evacuation of them: o that in this Chronical Affect, omtimes the Caues, omtimes the Diea mut be reited by turns: and the Spirits do better undergo this change of action, than if we hould continualy make our battery againt the Caues, till they were abolutely rooted out.

Moreover, When the Caues of the Diea in this Affect are unapt for motion by reaon of their toughnes, grones, and perhaps etlednes; they mut firt be freed from this impediment and prepared before they are evacuated. For according to the Rule of the great Dictator, Quae movenda unt, fluida prius facere oportet. In like manner, that thicknes, toughnes and etlednes of matter, if it be preent, indicate Remedies attenuant, incident and opening. But thee things are not afly taken the impurities till flowing backinto the firt Paages, for then perhaps they are carried along with the Medicines into the Veins, and more defile the Blood, or at leat hinder the efficacy of the Remedies. Thee therfore have the nature of an impediment, and mut be in the firt place removed.

Latly, Univeral Evacuants mut be premied before Particular and Topical Remedies, epecially where it is not permitted at once to mind both intentions. For the Univeral Caues flowing in the Body are eaily urrogated in the room of Particular Evacuations, and renew the Afflux to the firt affected part: but the thinner part of Particular Caues and that which is mot apt for
motion is evacuated, but the thicker perhaps is more impacted. Wherfore Univeral Caues yet flowing to and fro in the Body, as conidered are Impediments in repect of Particular Evacuation, and by conequence mut be firt expelled.

The latter Rule was, That we mut releeve the more urgent and weighty Indicant firt, unles there be an interuption of om impediment. That is termed an urgent Indicant which threatneth the mot danger. Now every uch Indicant is uppoed to induce great afflictions into the Body, and not without manifet danger to wat the Spirits. Therfore in this repect, we mut omtimes firt help the Diea, the Cau being neglected: Somtimes alo we mut neglect both the Diea and the Caues, and adres our endeavors to the pacification of the Symptoms, as in a vehement Flux of the Belly, long Watchings, profue and immoderat Sweating, and the like. But even in thee caes, we mut have a prudent regard both to the Diea and the Caues, and when the urgent Symptom is corrected, or the violence of the Diea repreed, then we mut return to the regular Method of proceeding; for this Rule belongs not to the ordinary and legitimate order of Cure, but to the Method of Neceity.
Moreover, to perfect the right adminitration of Indications, there is required an exact and accurat knowledg of the Medical Matter whereof we hal dicour in the ubequent Chapters.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX. The Medical Matter anwering to the Indications propoed, and firt the Chyrurgical.
div.p: THE Medical Matter mut be found out by Experience and Analogimes, or Arguments drawn by an anwerable neceity from the Cau to the Effect; although the truth is we conceive not any other Reaonings to be abolutly excluded. It is vulgarly and not unaptly ditributed into three kinds, The Chirurgical, the Pharmateutical, and the Diatetical: Of thee in their order.

The Chirurgical commonly received and approved in this Affect, and famous above the ret, are chiefly two; Scarification of the Ears, and little Fountains or Iues. But our enquiry (as we hal ee anon) hal be extended to many more, namly of Cuppin-Glaes, Leeches, Bliters, Ligatures, and Swathing-bands: But the opening of a Vein the Spirits cannot brook, as every one knows, who but oberves the frailty of the age, the extenuation of the habit of the parts, and the malnes of the Veins.

The Scarification of the Ears hal lead our dicour. The Empericks who undertake the cure of this Diea, make more of it than one would imagin. For in their practice they celerate it with great vaporing, and without it carce hope for a happy cure. But we, although we
diallow not this kind of remedy, have een many Children uccesfully recovered without the ue therof. And they themelves who attribute mot unto it, for the mot part take away no coniderable portion of Blood. Yet ome affirm that they have een a large quantity of Blood drawn away with good event. However it be, it is credible that thoe Children do with mot eae endure this remedy, and obtain mot profit by the ue of it, which are of a Sanguin complexion and wel habited, and who are affected with an Alogotrophy, rather than an Atrophy or a Conumption, or any other remarkable extenuation of the parts. Our Practitioners for mot part repeat this operation two or three times in a week. They eldom do it with an Intrument or harp Pen-knife, but mot commonly with an ordinary blunt Knife, taking no notice of the pain and crying of the Child. Moreover, For the mot part they perform it in the hollow of the Ear, but ome extend it to the inward and outward circumference of the upper part of the Ear, yea to the whol circumference. No man hitherto as we know have attempted the Scarification of the hinder ide of the Ear, although indeed it is not eaie to give a reaon, why it hould conduce les being adminitred there than in the hollow part.

Yet it may be lawful for us to offer our conjectures why the hollow of the Ear hould be choen before the other parts for this operation, which notwithtanding we will not confidently aert, although we uppoe we can at leat probably aert it, if that be true which the mot diligent Chyrurgion Fubricius Hildanus hath written in his Oberv. 4. Centur. 1. de nervo quinti parts: For this conjecture is grounded upon this Obervation, and if that be ruinous this perhaps mut perih with it. The Conjecture is this, The ditribution and ue of the
Nerve and of the fifth Pair before mentioned being uppoed, Scarification in the hollow of the Ear may very conveniently both free that Nerve from any kind of oppreion, and likewie hake off the numbnes, and give it vigor. For the hollow of the Ear is the next place unto it which we can come at with an intrument. Wherfore evacuation being here made may immediatly drive away the matter which commonly oppreeth the very beginning of that Nerve, and withal cauing pain and encreaing the heat, and may drive out all tupidnes from within it, and ad vigor unto it. If this Nerve therfore (as that famous Chyrurgion affirmeth) or a part therof be ditributed unto the Marrow of the Back and never forakes the Marrow of the Back, but hooteth out little Branches with the Nervs of the Marrow of the Back to the ends of the very Legs and Feet; it may eaily be granted, that this Nerve thus delivered from obtruction, thus excited and having gotten vigor, may likewie in ome manner excite the Marrow of the Back it elf, and all the Nerves from thence ariing, which by that opinion it doth accompany to the very end of the Body, and imprint ome vigor in them. Wherfore Scarification being made in that place mut needs be of greater efficacy, than if it were intituted in any other part of the ame Ear, more remote from the aforeaid Nerve. The ame may almot be aid concerning the little wound here made by a blunt Knife. For ome Practical Phyitians affirm that the excellency of this operation relats not o much to the quantity of the Blood to be drawn, as to the tirring up of pain in that part; which any man may eaily reduce to the tirring up of the vigor of the Nerve of the Fifth Pair.

But omitting this Conjecture we will propound ome other Coniderations, in repect wherof this Scarification
may be ueful in this affect. Firt, By this means we obtain a certain particular evacuation of the Head, which part, if any other is in this Affect oppreed with a particular fulnes. Secondly, By the very evacuation of the Blood we omwhat correct the thicknes and toughnes therof, and by conequence we promove the more equal ditribution of it, and a more regular and equal Nourihment of the Parts. Thirdly, By this means we in ome ort drive away the atonihment of the parts.

It mut be noted that this operation when it performeth a particular and local evacuation, doth not imply deerve the firt place in the Method of Cure, but mut follow in its order, Univerals being premied.

Latly, It eems to be ridiculous and upertitious which ome are buie about when they adminiter this Scarification; whilt they faten the Blood of the right Ear uck'd up into Wool to the left Hypochondry, and the Blood of the left to the right. Thus much of Scarification.

Iues in this Diea are much approved, and we have known ome Children cured only by the help of this means. For it doth not only perform all thoe things, which even now we acribed to the Scarification of the Ears, but more particularly it is a powerful remedy againt the Hydrocephalus, both Curative and Preervative, and very much conduceth to leen the unuual magnitude of the Head, and to evacuate the uperfluous watrines therof. And latly, to repres the inordinate encrea of the Bones. Alo it manifetly drieth up the too much humidity of the Spinal Marrow, exciteth heat, trengthens the Nerves, and expelleth the atonihment.

Now becau this kind of remedy is properly a little
Ulcer and caueth ome mall pain to the Child that hath it, and bringeth dayly ome trouble to the Nur, it ought not to be precribed, unles the greatnes of the Diea be uch that we depair to conquer it by other remedies without the concurrence of this.

This little Fountain mut be made between the Second and Third turning Joynt of the Neck. Some Burn it with actual Cauteriing, but we diapprove of this way in regard of the vehemence of the pain: Some effect it with a potential Cauteriing: but neither do we like this, becau all Cauticks are adver to the Nature of an Infant, ininuating ome venemous quality, and at leat do too much diipate the Spirits, and weaken the parts. Therfore we allow rather of an Iue made by Simple inciion with a harp Penknife.

Some make ue of Iron tongues contrived for this purpoe, wherwith they take hold of the Skin, the place of inciion being firt mark'd with ink, and by a moderate compreion they dull the en of the part, and then they thrut in the Pen-knife through the middle of the tongs which is pierced with a longih hole, and o they make the inciion. Having made the wound they top in either an Artificial or a Natural Peae, putting upon it a digetive Plaiter: upon this they wrap a Paper or a linnen cloath divers times doubled, and faten to it as it were a Buckler made of ome olid matter, unto which four wathing bands are ewed; thus much of Iues. In the next place we hall examin ome other kind of Chyrurgical Operations.

And firt Leeches offer themelves. Truly we have not yet ufficiently tryed how beneficial the application of them may be in this Affect. But if we conult Reaon, we uppoe that more hurt than advantage may be expected from this remedy. For if they are applied to
any part of the Head, by reaon of their continual ucking they would eaily cau a more violent afflux of the Blood to thoe parts. And if they be applied to other parts, they draw the Blood from the parts which before had too little.

Secondly, Cuppinglaes are not (we conceive) o dangerous as needles; indeed we altogether reject thoe that are minitred with Scarification, not only for the Reaons jut now deduced from the Leeches, but being moved both by fear of dejecting the Spirits by reaon of the pain, and alo in regard of the troubleomnes of the adminitration. Cuppin Glaes without Scarification, as we began to ay, eem not refuable either by the Spirits, or the Diea, or the caues of the Diea. But thee are very little effectual, and we leave it to be perpended, whether the profit ariing from the ue of them, whatoever it be, can recompence the trouble of the application.

Nevertheles it may happen by reaon of the complication of ome other Diea, that the ue of them may be of ome moment, as in a Pleuriie, a Phreny, and wher om dangerous Flux is iminent againt om principal part; in which cae, thoe perhaps that are adhibited with Scarification, may be admitted in great and trong Children. But then you mut apply them to the turning Joynts of the Neck, the Shoulders, the Hanches, to the inner parts of the Thighs, to the oals of the Feet, and to other places as the peculiar complicated affect hall require.

In the mean time it mut be noted, that in an age o tender, you mut make ue of very mal Cuppin-glaes, and that they mut be applyed with a les flame then they are wont to be in others of mans etate, and that the carification, if at all it be admitted, mut be don with a gentle hand.

Thirdly, As for Bliters, although hitherto we have not had ufficient trial of them, and although we banih from this Diea both eptical applications, becau they diolve the parts, and alo cautical, becaue they penetrate deeper and produce a cruted ubtance, yet we conjecture that thoe Pyrotical remedies which only raie Bliters in the Skin may be omtimes profitably admitted.
You wil ay that Cantharides wherwith they are commonly made are extream hot, and beides upected to be of a venemous quality.

We anwer, That we may not here inert any thing of the qualities of Cantharides, we grant that which is aerted. But becau they are adminitred only to the outward little Skin, and only to a little part therof not much extended, and becau as oon as the bliters are raied they are removed, the exces of their heat and their poyon carce penetrates deeper into the Body, than the bottom of the Epidermis, and therfore this remedy may be applyed without any notable harm or danger. But then you may demand what profit can arie from hence? We affirm, that it doth effectually correct a cold and moit ditemper, and potently diipate the atonihment of the Marrow of the Back, the Brain, Nervs, and the Nervous parts, and withal that they make all the parts more firm and teady, and tir up a tronger Pule in the external parts; al which things are of no mal moment in the cure of this Diea.

One amongt us affirmeth, that among other things he precribed this remedy to a Child of two years old who was troubled with the Rachites, and was alo fallen into a continual and malignant Feaver, and grown almot frantick. Hereupon the Child found preent and manifet ea, and after a few days was delivered from his
Feaver. Afterwards having purged him twice or thrice with an infuion of Rhubarb, &c. Beyond the expectation of all that aw it, he alo ubdued this Affect almot without any other remedies. But as you can carce find any commodity without a dicommodity: o neither is this remedy exempted from al inconveniences. For it is unpleaing, ful of pain and moletation to Children: Moreover, for a time it interrupteth their exercie and patime, in repect of which things, unles perhaps om other complicated affect do point at an interdiction of exercie, it may do much more prejudice than advantage. Again, the force of it uddenly wateth, and afterwards by degrees is conumed, which doth not in all repects keep touch with a Chronical Diea. Finally, an Iu which is proper to Chronical Dieaes, may very wel upply its place in this affect. Wherfore we carce admit the application of bliters in the cure of this malady, unles om acute Diea be complicated, which may require this kind of Remedy, as it fals out in the Caue propounded.

Now wher this adminitration is requiit, it is mot commodiouly performed upon the turning Joynts of the Neck, unles om Iu have prepoeed the place; in which cae you mut adminiter them either behind the Ears, or four Fingers below the Iu. We deny not but it may be fitted to everal other places in repect of the complication of other Dieaes. But we here deign the place which a peculiar reference to the preent Diea.

Fourthly, Ligatures alo may be referred to this Title, and indeed we grant, that omtimes they are not altogether unueful in this affect; namly, if they be very moderate, and adhibited by jut ditances, and unto convenient places; but you mut beware that they hinder not the growth of that part, wherunto they are applyed;
which is don if they be ufficiently looe, and made of oft wool, if in the Day time, or for om part of the Day they are tyed up, and unbound at night, if they be fitted to the Thighs and Legs upon the Knee, and to the Arms upon the Elbow.

Yet Ligatures do here eem to conduce much to the toppage of the Blood from flowing to the Head, and that it ought to be fatned to the outward parts that are extenuated: beides, this Remedy is good to retard the over lippery return of the Blood in thoe parts, unto which the Ligature is applyed.

Fifthly, Hitherto alo belong the Faciation or wathing of certain parts, for this hath an affinity with Ligatures. For om ue to enwrap the weak parts in wollen blankets, therby to trengthen them, and to cherih their heat; namly, the Feet, the Legs, the Knees, and the adjacent parts of the Thighs. But you mut be careful that the overtraightnes of them hinder not their growth.

Others, intead of thee wathing bands ue buttond Boots lined with woollen Cloth; the they do not make ue of only for trength and heat, but alo to correct the crookednes of the Bones, and to erect the bending of the Joynts. Som ad little Shingles, or pieces of Whale-Bone, but there are three things worthy of obervation in the making of thee. 1. That they may omwhat cruh the prominent and convex part of the Bone. 2. That they carce touch the hollow, but rather that they defend it from compreion. 3. That they be well fitted to the part, and do as little as poible hinder the motion of

G the Joynts, to this purpoe thoe Boots upon the outward part to the knee may be cut overthwart, or, acros In like manner if there be any need that the Shingles upon the knee be extended to utain and erect the bending therof, then it is neceary that you fahion them with a double Joynt in the bending place, after this manner.

A B Two Iron rings.
C D The Diameter of the Joynts of the Splents.
The Nails wher with the Rings are fatned.
F G The two Splents.
Intead of the Splents you may more commodiouly ue thin plates of Iron, and the whol Intrument may be made of Iron.

The two Axel trees or Diameters C D upon which the Shingles or Splents are bended F G are fatned with two rings or hoops. But the hoops themelves A B C are made of plates of Iron of an exquiit thinnes, that they may not be burthenom, and withal they ought to be wel moothed, and poliht that they hinder not the motion of the Splents. Thee rings mut be of an equal Latitude,
uppoe about two fingers a cros, and they mut be o fitted together, that on every ide they may be paralels; only let there be o much ditance between them, that they may fitly receive the tops of the Splents. Moreover, Thoe hoops mut not only be coupled with a double Axel C and D, but alo with five mal Iron Nails. Latly, The whol compoition of the Intrument mut be o made, that it may be fat and fitly tied to the ide of the bended knee ticking out, and withal that it may erve as well for the extenion as the ordinary bending of it, but let it retrain the deflexion of it to either ide, epecially to the part ticking out. Which is the cau why the Axels are fatned with a double Hoop, namely let the Joynts hould be loo, and yield to the deflexion of the Knee.

In like manner the torion and mihapen writhing of the Feet is alo frequently corrected with Swathing Bands. If the Toes are outwardly ditorted, they mut every night be bound up, little balls of Cotton being put between the Heels and the Ankles. But if the Toes bend inwards, then you mut bind the Ankles, and put a little Cotton between the great Toes.

Latly, To traighten the trunk of the Body, or to keep it traight, they ue to make Breatplates of Whalebone put into two woolen Cloaths and Sewed together, which they o fit to the Bodies of the Children, that they may keep the Backbone upright, repres the ticking out of the Bones, and defend the crookednes of them from a further compreion. But you mut be careful that they be not troubleom to the Children that wear them, and therfore the bet way is to faten them to the Spine of the Back with a handom tring fitted to that ue.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. Of the Pharmacentical matter, and firt of uch things as clene the firt Paages.
div.p: THis matter is of manifold and mot noble ue, and atisfieth very many Indications. For it comprehendeth al Medicaments, thoe only accepted which concern the Chyrurgion, which have a primary relation either to the caues of the Diea, or the Diea it elf, or the Symptoms.

It is divided into remedies Internal or External, and each of them into Simple and Compound. Again the Internal may be ubdivided into uch as clen the firt paagss, as Medicines Preparatory. Into Electively evacuant, and uch as are Specifically alterant and Evacuant, and finally into thoe that correct the Symptoms.

Among thee the Internal obtain the precedency, and of thoe again uch as wah away the impurities of the firt paages, becau thee (as hath been already oberved) are jutly accounted an impediment in repect of the following remedies, and imply ought firt to be removed. But in all the Titles (as far as the Nature of the thing will licen or warrant us) we will place the Simple before the Compound.
Moreover, thee wahing remedies comprehend thee three kinds, namely, Clyters, Vomits, and Lenitive Purgations.

div.head: The ue of Clyters, and ome forms of them.
div.p: The Injection of Clyter-pipes, before we more exactly and earnetly attempt the Cure, is then chiefly prerequired, when the Belly is cotive, and the Excrements are hardned; or when ome windy humors torment the Guts, or ome vehement pain in the Bowels afflict the Patient. In which caes they may not only be injected before any preparation, but alo before a Vomit, yea or a Lenitive Purgation. Thee are frequently compounded of benign and gentle Purgers, omtimes alo of uch as have only a faculty to make the waies lippery, and to expel wind, but never of Cathartical ingredients that are violent they are to be injected warm or lukewarm, and after a long abtinence from meat. We hall preent ome forms.

Take Cows new-Milk, warmed, four or five ounces; Anis Seeds beaten to Pouder ten grains; Cour Sugar, one ounce, one ounce and an half, or two ounces; The Yolk of one Egg: mingle them and make a Clyter; to thee may be added half an ounce of new Butter.

Take a ufficient quantity of an emollient Decoction. An Electuary lenitive half an ounce; Syrup of Roes Solutive, and Syrup of Violets, of each ix drachms; Oyl of Chamomel one ounce; mingle them, make your Clyter and let it be injected lukewarm.

Take the Roots of Marh Mallows beaten together, half an ounce, or in lieu therof, the leaves or Flowers of Mallows half a handful; Flowers of Chamomel one pugil; Hemp Seeds two drachms: boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Whey mingled with Beer: To four or five ounces of the Decoction ad of Diacaia, or Electuarium Paulatum half an ounce, Syrup of Roes Solutive,
and Kitchin Sugar, of each one ounce; new Butter ix drachms, you may if you ee occaion ad the yolk of one Egg.

Take Stone-Hordung that is new, one ounce and an half; The Seeds of Annis, Fennel, Mallows, beaten together, of each one drachm and an half; Flowers of Chamomel one pugil. Boyl them in a ufficient quantity of poet drink: In four or five ounces of the Decoction, diolve ten drachms of Syrup of Violets, common Sugar, and Oyl of Roes, of each half an ounce: Mingle them and make your Clyter.

div.head: The ue of vomiting remedies, and ome examples of them.
div.p:
Emedical Remedies or Vomits, do chiefly perform three things. Firt they evacuate crude or corrupt humors and all manner of impurities contained in the Stomach, and that by a horter and more expedite way, than if they were conveyed through the involutions and labyrinths of the Guts. Secondly, By an agitation and commotion raied in all the parts, epecially the Bowels, they looen the gros and vicous humors adhering unto them, or impacted in them, and frequently expel them, epecially thoe which are collected in the Stomach and Guts; in which repect they are profitable againt torments of the Chollick and very conducible to unlock Obtructions. Thirdly, They mot effectually irritate the expulive faculty of all the parts of the Body, and epecially of the Bowels, and by this means many times upon a ingle application they compel forth the hidden and unappearing caues and fomentations of Dieaes, and epecially of intermitting Feavers. For by the very training to vomit, the Guts are alo intimulated to
cat out by iege. The Liver powreth away the Choller by the Biliary Pore; the weet-Bread voideth his peculiar excrement by the new Veel into the Guts; the Spleen alo perhaps unburdens in a plentiful manner his excrement into the Stomach by Veels not yet throughly known: The Kidneys exern through the Ureters, the Lungs by a trong Cough eject their Flegm through the Windpipe: The Brain emptieth it elf of alt, waterih Rhewms, and matter by the Palate, the Notrils and the Eyes. Finally the whol Body for the mot part is rendred more prone to a Diaphoreis either by a manifet weating, or ele by an occult and inenible Tranpiration. In the mean time it mut be noted that not all gentle Vomits, nor indeed the more vehement, if they be given in too mal a doe wil preently and fully perform all thee things, yet in their operations they effect more or les according to the trength or quantity of the Medicine, and indeed if the tronger be adminitred in a full doe they effectually attain to the three marks propounded.

It is obvious, by what hath been aid, to the conideration of any Reader, that trong Vomits precribed in a full quantity are not competible to Children affected with this Diea, neither can their tender trength overcome and ubdue o great tumults in the Body, and uch an Univeral evacuation o uddenly wrought, Wherfore this kind of remedy ought not to be precribed to Children without diligent precaution and circumpection, and both the trength, quantity, and efficacy of the Medicine are duly to be prepondred. To this end therfore we hall et down ome Cautious in favor of unexperienced Practicers.

Firt, A Vomit is not to be provoked in this Diea, unles the humors tend upwards of their own accord, but
then indeed they may be expelled by vomiting remedies without difficulty.
Seeondly, Not unles Children are naturally or cutomarily apt to vomit, and do eaily endure it.
Thirdly, In Bloud-pitting, the Ptiick and Conumption, in any flowing of Bloud at the Noe, or any internal opening of the Veins, and the like caes, abtinence mut he enjoyned from this remedy.

Fourthly, Vehement vomits exhibited in a larger doe are here forbidden. For the fear is jut and prudent that they may depopulate the Natural Spirits, and further conume the very olid parts which before were over-much extenuated.
It is neceary therfore that the Vomits here precribed, be either in their own nature gentle, or corrected if they be vehement and adminitred in a leened doe.
You wil ay, If they be of a mild and lenitive faculty, or exhibited in a diminute quantity, they cannot compel the humors with any efficacy.

To this we anwer, Indeed where Nature contributeth little or no aitance, it cannot be denied; but in uch caes we totally prohibit the adminitration of vomiting remedies; but preuppoing both a fitnes of the Body and Humors to this evacuation (as is required in the firt and econd Caution) even gentle vomits may expel uch humors as are eated in the firt paages. The thing mut be aid of the trong being prudently corrected and paringly applied. For by reaon of the correction and diminute quantity they do not much hake and dicompoe the Body, or provoke Nature; and again, through the proclivity of the Stomach and Humors they are ufficient to reward this Scope with a laudable ucces. We will now ubjoyn ome few Examples.

Take the tops of Groundel half an handful, Raions one ounce; boyl them in a pound of Ale to the conumption of one half. To three ounces of Colature, ad half an ounce of Syr. Aceto. impl. Mingle them & drink them luke-warm.
Or

Take the Infuion of Crocus-metallorum in Spanih Wine, made in a cold place and well purified, by ubidence one dram, a dram and an half, or two drams (according to the age and trength of the ick) half a dram of Syr. Aceto. imp. Poet-drink an ounce and an half. Cinamon Water ten drops: or intead therof if there be any fear of Convulions, one cruple of Aq. Antepilept. Lang. Mingle them and drink it warm.
Take the Juyce of the Leaves of Aarabacca half a dram, two cruples or a dram. Syrup. Aceto. imp. two drams. Mingle them with a ufficient quantity of Poet-drink.
Take Salt of Vitriol from five to ten grains, Give it in Poet drink.

div.head: Lenitive Catharticks.
div.p:
Thee Evacuant Medicines produce their Effects without tumult, and therfore they requir not o great circumpection as Vomiting Compoitions, or uch as are electively Purgant. Yet three things mut be conidered in the Ue of them. 1. That they do not nauiat the Ventricle with uch an ingrateful tat and favor as may render an abhorrence from all future Medicaments. 2. That they oppres not the Stomach by an immoderat quantity. 3. That the potion drunk be not preently vomited up. To prevent this lat danger it will be a good way preently to bedew and moiten the
Mouth with ome pleaant and agreable Liquor, or with candid Cherries, or preerv'd Barberries 3 or to temper the juyce of Orenges, or the like.
Thee Lenitives may be divided into Simple & Compound: and thee again into uch as are old in the Shops, and uch as are newly made and accomodated to the preent cope of the Phyitian.

p.hi: There are found very few Simples that of themelvs wil atisfie this
p.U: cope; as Manna, Caia fitula, Aloe occatrina, Tamarinds, Polypodium of the Oak. But very ineffectually, unles they be compounded with other Purgative Ingredients (more follow) as Jujubes, Sebetens, weet Prunes and Damacens, Figs, Dates, the Pap or Pulp of roted Apples, the Flowers of Mallows, Violets, Pellatory of the wall, Mercury, the Roots of Marhmallous, Liquoris, the four greater cold Seeds, the Seeds of Mallows, weet Almonds, rare Egs, Fatty ubtances, Butter, Oyl of Olives, Oyl of Almonds, Whey, and the like. Thee although of themelves they are of mal efficacy, yet by the commixture of other Catharticks they require a gentle purgative quality, not to be contemned.

div.p: The Lenitive compound Catharticks which are old in Shops, are thee: Caia extracted with, or without Senna, Diacaia, Electuarium Lenitivum, Diaprunum lenitivum, Electuarium paulatum, A common Decoction for a Medicine, A Decoction of Flowers & Fruits, Syrup and Honey of Violets, Syrup of Roes olutive, Honey of Mercury, Honey of Raions, Conerve of damask Roes, Of the Flowers of Mallows, of Violets. To thee may be ubjoyned om extempory forms. As
Take of the bet Calabrian Manna ix drams, Cremor of Tartar even grains, Poet-Ale in which a few Anieeds have been boyled an ounce and an half. Mingle and give them in the morning.

Take of Polypodium of the Oak two ounces, White Tartar prepared two drams, weet Apples twelve handfuls, Raions of the Sun toned one ounce: Boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Water to a pound. In the Decoction infue all night long Choice Senna an ounce and an half, Rhubarb two drams, Pulp of Caia new drawn half an ounce, Tamarinds an ounce, Liquoris, the Seeds of Annis and Coriander of each a dram and an half: The next morning train it through a linnen Cloth, and to eight ounces of the Decoction ad White Sugar ix ounces; Boyl it a little; and when you have don o, ad to it Manna diolved in Syrup of Roes, of each two ounces; Syrup of Violets one ounce: Make of them a Lenitive Syrup. Let the dieaed Child take an ounce either in Succory Water, or Water of Pellitory of the wall, with a dram of the Juyce of Lemmons.

Take of Lenitive Electuary one dram and an half, or two drams; Syrup of Roes olutive two drams and an half; Cremor of Tartar ten grains; Poet-ale a ufficient quantity Mingle and adminiter them early in the morning.

Take of Aloes waht, or Aromatical Pils even grains; Make two Pills with Syrup af Roes olutive, put them into two Candid Cherries the skius being pulled off, and let them be wallowed whol let the tat be offenive, about leeping time in the evening. In the morning give to drink after them, one ounce of Syrup of Roes olutive in Poet Ale. Or

Take of Syrup of Roes olutive ix drams; Violets half an ounce; Juyce of Lemons one dram; Electuarium Paulatum one dram: Mingle them with Succory or Pellitory Water, and give them in the morning fating. Thus much of thoe Medicines as clear the firt paages.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI. Remedies Preparatory, and their e.
div.p: THee Remedies partly relate to the preparation of the Humors, partly to the waies thorow which they are to be expelled, and partly to the paages themelvs, wherin they are contained. Now it mut be known, That the Evacuation which is perfected by Vomits, doth leat of any pre-requir any preparation; but that which is accomplihed by Catharticks or Medicins Purging, doth mot of all exact it.

Firt, The Humors in general to be prepared are either Flegmatick, namly cold, which mut be qualified and tempered with hot, thick, and mut be attenuated; vicous, and mut be cut and opened; or Cholerick, namly harp, bitter, burning, corroive, which are to be mitigated with lenifying and awaging Medicins; or Melancholly, namly earthy, feculent, tartarous, which by a benignity of application mut be rendred fluxible; or latly erous and waterih, which mut be dipoed and as it were manuducted either to the Urinary paages, as by piing, or to the Belly as by iege, or to the parts near the Skin that they may with the more facility evaporate by Sweating.

Secondly, The waies, thorow which the Evacuation mut be effected, ought alo to be made fit and prepared,
and not only the common, but alo the pecial, by which the peccant matter in particular is conveyed to thoe common Channels. For there is one preparation of the Veels of the Kidnies (which is chiefly expedited by Medicins of a lippery and looning faculty) another of the Veels of the Liver, which is don by opening, clening, and omewhat atringent Medicaments: A third of the Veels of the Lungs, which is mot uccefully wrought by Lenient and Maturant Remedies, omtimes perhaps according to the nature of the matter Medicins incident or atenuant being adminitred, or on the contrary, Adminitrations making thick, and uch as have a vertue to arret and avert the flux.

Thirdly, Thoe parts wherein the vicious humors principally flow or are lodged, require the admixture of Medicaments peculiarly apropriated unto them. And as this or that part is more or les affected, omtimes choice mut be made of Cephalicals, omtimes Hepaticals, and omtimes Pectoral Preparations.

Moreover, (that we may comprehend together mot if not all of the qualities of Preparatory Remedies required in this Affect) we ay, That thee Remedies precribed by Art ought to be moderatly hot (unles there be a Feaver preent) alo attenuant, incident and opening; in like manner, that by a peculiar right they mut have repect to the Liver, the Lungs and the Head, which parts for the mot part are commonly in this Affect oppreed with a plenitude of humors: Again, That there are ome things pecifically apropriated to this Affect and if uch things are not in Readines which are regetred in the number of things preparatory, and dedicated to the Diea, than at leat other pecificals ought to be mingled with the Preparatory Medicines.

Thee things being premied, we judged it expedient to et down uch Simple and Compound Medicines as are uually old in the Shops, and alo ome examples of decompounded Preparatory Remedies. Yet we forbid the expectation of all Simples, or perhaps of any one, that hould comprehend all the qualities, which even now we attributed to thoe exquiite and apropriate Remedies; for then there would be no need of any Compoition, and we hall reckon up uch and o many that a prudent Phyitian may elect and contemper them among themelves, which being dicreetly intermingled they may be correpondent to all the fore recited qualities.

The Simples and Compounds prepared in the Shops in readines are thee. All the Capillary Herbs, epecially Tricumanes, Rhue of the Wall. Spica Roots of O ••• ed royal; the Buds of the male Fernbrake newly prung up, Polipodium of the wall; Harttongue, Liverword, Ce ••• ach, Agrimony, Doddar, Scabious, Betony the Leaves and Bark of Tamarisk, the Bark of the Root of the Caper tree; the Roots of Succory, Endive, Gras, Sparagus, Myrobalans; Liquoris, Raions, Primes, Damens; the Seeds of Annis, weet Fennel Coriander, Caraway, Dill; Syrup of Maidenhair, and Bot • ny, Simple and Compound, Syrupus Bizantinus, Syrup of Succery, Eupatory the five Roots, S • aechadis, and Hortongue.

Out of thee according to preent Emergencies diver others may be Decompounded. As take the little Buds or Gems of the Roots of the male Fernbrake five in number; boyl them in half a pound of Milk to three ounes; let him drink the Decoction in a morning upon an empty Stomach. This is mot agreable to yong Children that are tied to Milk. Or,

Take of the Buds of male Fernbrake newly budded out of the Earth, one handful; male Betony, Harttongue, Liverwort, of each half an handful; Flowers of Tamaris one pugil; Raions one ounce and an half; One Chicken the Guts pulled out, and with a ufficient quantity of Oatmeal, make your Broath according to art. Let the Child take three or four ounces in the morning, and at four of the Clock in the afternoon, adding (if you plea) ten grains of the Cremor of Tartar. Or

Take Maidenhair, Liverwort, Agrimony, Doddor, of each half a handful; the Roots of male Fernbrake, Gras, Sparagus, of each half an ounce; Flowers of Tamaris, one pugil; Raions one ounce; White Tartar prepared one dram; Liquoris half a dram; Mace one cruple: Boyl them in two pints of Fountain water. To one pound of the Decoction ad 3 ounces of white or Rhenih Wine; Syrup of Harttongue one ounce and an half: Mingle them and make your Decoction, wherof let the Child take a draught every morning, and at four of the Clock in the afternoon. This is mot prevalent and effectual againt pertinacious obtructions in the Meentery, Liver, &c. Or

Take of Coltsfoot, Maiden-hair, Harttongue, Liverwort, of each half an handful; the Roots of weet Chervil and Sparagus, of each half an ounce; Spanih Liquoris two drams; Mace a cruple; Raiins of the Sun toned, an ounce; Jujubes by number ix, Sebetens eight, two Figs cut in peices: boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Barly-water, and to a pound of the Decoction, ad Syrup of Maiden-hair, an ounce and an half: Mingle them together; and this is a very good Drink for uch as are troubled with an obtruction in the Lungs.

Take of weet Wort two pound; Liver-wort, Maiden-hair, Harttongue, Scabious, Coltsfoot, Featherfew, of each an handful; blue Figs cut in pieces, Raiins of the Sun, of each half a pound; Liquoris, Annieeds, of each two drams: boyl them over a gentle fire nine hours, train it, and keep it for your ue. It's good for that the former was.

Take Salaperilla cut and well beaten three ounces; the Roots of China, Harthorn havings, Ivory, of each one ounce; the Leaves of male Betony, Liverwort, Scabious, of each three handfuls; the Buds of the Root called Royal Omond, and Fernbrake, of each two ounces: Boyl them in four gallons and a pottle of new Ale four or five hours over a gentle fire: Then after om hours repit train it thorow an Hair-Sieve: afterwards put in of the Juyces of Scurvigras and Brook-lime, of each half a pound; a ufficient quantity of Barm or Yeat: Let it work according to the uual manner, put it into a little veel and drawn out for the ordinary drink. This is mot conducible, where there is any upition of the Scurvy or Venerious Pox, being complicated with the Rachites.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII. Remedies Electively evacuant.
div.p: THe matter of the Diea being prepared, and the paages opened to facilitate the evacuation, the next thing is, To conider what remedies wil electively expel the peccant humors in particular. Now thee Medicines do partly concern the humors, and partly the parts wherein they are lodged; but in each of them a du regard mut be had to the Spirits.

The violent mut be either totally prohibited, or ele exhibited after a du correction or a circumpect diminution of the doe; and for yonger Children, and uch as are weak, they mut be the les in quantity, and the more gentle in quality; for great and luty Children you may prepare tronger remedies and in a larger doe (provided that they exceed not the trength of the Child. In both caues it is afer to favor and go les then the trength wil bear, than to trancend it in the leat degree: and in this affect it is altogether better to proceed by an Epichrais, then together and at once to attempt the ful evacuation of the peccant humors.

Moreover the predominant humors in the Body require proper and peculiar remedies; as Choler, Medicines purging Choler: Flegm, Medicines purging flegm: Melancholy Medicines purging Melancholy: and waterih humors uch as purge water.
