Again, If the Liver be oppreed with humors more than the other parts, uch Catharticks mut be choen as peculiarly belong to the Liver. In like manner the Lungs being vehemently infeted, or the Brain, and the other parts, uch remedies mut be choen as are appropriated to thoe parts. But if there be not a ready upply of purging Simples peculiarly dedicated to thoe parts, that defect mut be made good by a prudent commixture of uch ingredients as are familiar to thoe parts.

Latly, You mut endeavor (as much as poibly you can) to make choice of uch purgers as are directly oppoite to the Eence of the Diea. In this repect we commend Rhubarb above al other imples. For it is a Medicament moderatly hot and dry, very familiar to the inherent Spirits of all the parts, it gently dipelleth the tupefaction of the parts, and trengthneth the oftnes & loones of the parts, omwhat correcteth the internal lipperines, ummons the Pul to the Arteries, and encreaeth the heat of the outward parts, and finally it cheriheth the vigor and activity of the inner parts, and especially of thoe which are ubervient to nourihment. Ad in a word, That it exceeding rarely (provided that you give it in a jut doe) caueth uperpurgation, for it is a Medicament afe for all ages, and every Complexion.

Thee things being premied, we hal propound om imple purgative Medicines, and om examples of the Compound. For nothing hindreth, but that many of the prerecited lenitives, may be commodiouly referred hither, though in a different repect. For there they are conidered as quickners of the lenitives which of themelvs are omwhat dul: But here rather as they qualify and attemper the violence of the trong.

div.head: Simple and Compound purging Medicines which are old in the hops.
div.p: Manna, Caia fitula, Tamarinds, all the orts of Myrobalans, Rhubarb, Aloes, Syr. of Roes olut. yr. of Cichory with a double quantity of Rhubarb, yrupAugutanus, Scammony, Agarick, the eeds of batard Saffron, Mechoacan, Jalap, Turbith, weet Mercury, yrup of Roes olutive with Agarick, Epythymum, Polypody of the oak, Senna, Syrup Magitralis againt Melancholy, yr. of Apples of King Sapor, Diabalzemer, Electar lenitivum de prunis. olut. Electar paidat Diacatholicon, Confectio Hamech, Benedicta Lexativa.

div.head: Som Examples of extemporary Compounds.
div.p: Take yrrup Augutan one ounce, yrrup of Roes olutive two drams. Succhory water half an ounce to diolv the yrrups, make a potion to be adminitred in the morning upon an empty tomach.

Take the bet Rhubarb beaten to pouder eighteen grains yrrup of Succhory with a double quantity of Rhubarb ix drams, yr. ro. olutive two drams, water of the leavs of Fernbrake ix drams, mingle them for a potion, this agreeth bet with Cholerick Contitutions, and uch whoe Livers are ditempered.

Take the leavs of Senna, Polypody of the Oak, Epithymum of each a dram, Rhubarb one cruple, Chrital of Tartar, Fennel eeds of each a crupel, make an infuion in a ufficient quantity of fumitory water, to the trayned infuion, ad yrrup Magitralis ix drams, Cinnamon-Water, even drops; el Langius his Antipeleptical Water half a cruple: mingle them for a potion accomodated to Melancholy Contitutions.

Take the leavs of Senna two drams, the pulp of Tamarinds
ix drams, the eeds of Anis, Liquorice of each half a dram, cremor of Tartar half a cruple, make an infuion in a ufficient quantity of fountain water for the pace of a night, with three ounces of the trained infuion make an emulion according to art with weet Almonds blanched, half an ounce. The four greater cold eeds of each two cruples, for two does, adding to each doe yrrup of ucchory with a fourfold quantity of Rhubarb, and the bet Manna of each three drams. This qualifieth and evacuateth harp and adut humors.

Take lenitive electuary three drams, Rhubarb a cruple, Cremor Tartar and Anni-eeds of each half a cruple, the flower of Burrage and Roemary of each half a Pugil, Fumatory water as much as is ufficient: after you have infued them, certain hours train it through a thick Cloth. And to an ounce and half of the infuion ad yrup of Apples of King Sapor, half an ounce: mix them together for a potion.

Take Elder flowers a pugil, Rhubarb two cruples, Jalap, Mechoacan of each a cruple, Cremor Tartar half a cruple, Nutmegs fifteen grains, firt infue them, then boyl them gently in the water of broom flowers, & Rhennih Wine, of each o much as is ufficient, train it. And to an ounce and an half of the decoction ad yrup of Roes olutive half an ounce or ix drams: mix them together and make of them a potion which will be very agreable for uch Bodies as are troubled with flegmatick or dropical humors, or a Cachexia.

Take of the leavs of enna a dram and an half, Rhubarb two cruples, Agrick trochicated one cruple, Tamarinds two drams, Anni-eeds, Cremor Tartar, of each a cruple, Roemary flowers a pugil, make an infuion in a ufficient quantity of fountain water, and after a very gentle boyling to an ounce & an half of the decoction, ad
yrup of Roes olutive with Agrick, Magiterial yrup againt Melancholy, of each three drams mix them together for a potion to clene the Body of mixt humors.

Take the leavs of enna one dram and an half, or two drams, Agarick trochic. half a dram, Fennel eeds half a dram, flowrs of Chamomel ten in number. Boil them in a ufficient quantity of fountain water, and to ten drams or an ounce and an half of the decoction, ad half an ounce or ix drams of yrrup of Roes olutive with Agarick, Manna three drams, mingle them for a Potton dedicated to evacuate thick and Flegmatick Humors.

Take weet Mercury fifteen grains, conerv of violets one dram, powder of Gum Dragon one grain. Mingle them; and make them into a Bolus, with yrups of violets to be given in the morning drinking after it an ounce of yrup of Roes olutive, diolving a draught of poet drink. This is mot proper for uch Children as are troubled as well with the Rachites as the worms, and on the contrary; alo for uch as have the French Pox, complicate with the Rachites: alo to uch as are troubled with a Struma.

Take weet Mercury twelve grains, Jalap eleven grains, Nutmegs half a grain, the pulp of Raiins a dram. Mingle them, and with yrup of Violets make a Bolus to be taken in the morning. Intead of Jalap you may make ue of Diagrydium, to three or four grains: This is proper for Children that are afflicted with Strumatical Affects, and uch as are upected to have the French Pox, and uch as are difficultly purged, and are avere from Remedies of an ungrateful tat.

Take of weet Mercury a dram, gummy Jallop half a cruple, white ugar diolved in Betony water three drams or half an ounce, make them into Lozenges according
to art of a dram or two cruples and an half weight of which let the dieaed take one at a time.

Take the bet Rhubarb one dram and an half, Raiins of of the Sun, the tones being pickt out, one handful, a pint of ordinary Ale, infue them for twelve hours, train it and give it to Children that are greedy of drink in the night eaon.

Take Aloes uccotrine even grains, Rhubarb in pouder eleven grains, with yrup of Roes olutive, o much as is ufficient to make it into pibbles which mut be given in preerved Cherries, the tones being taken away, or ele you may guild them for the more eay wallowing.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII. Specifical alterant Medicines.
div.p: THe caues of the Diea being now prepared and in part evacuated, or at leat o ubdued, that for the preent they cannot retard the cure, you mut proceed to thee Medicines specifically alterant, wch as it were fly at the very throat of the Diea, and in regard wherof the premied Medicines both preparatory and evacuant took place.
Now thee pecificals may be defined to be, Remedies diametrically contrary to the Nature of the Diea, and uch as directly impugn it.

Thee are either Simple or Compound, the Simple which hitherto we have had knowledg of, are thee that
follow: the root of Omund the Royal, or rather the pike of the root, the middle being thrown away, the root of the male Fernbrake, or rather, the little buds before their peeping forth out of the earth; the roots of Gras, Succhory, Asparagus, Madder, Eringo, all the Maiden hairs, Ceterach, Harts tongue, Liverwort, Betony, the flowers and leavs of dead Nettles, Borage, age Roemary, Tamarisk, Southernwood, Pontik Wormwood, The greater Sulendine, Saffron, Turmerick, the roots of Saraperilla, Salaphras, China, the three orts of Sanders, the wood of Guiacum, and its Bark, flowr of brimtone, teel prepared, Crocus Martis, alt of teel, wine teelified, yrup of teel, white and Rhennih wine Sperma Ceti, Musk, Ambergreece, Catoreum, Earthworms, the Livers of Frogs and yong Ravens, Woodlice, waht in white Wine, bak'd inan Oven, and beaten to powder, and uch like things.
But if any demand, After what manner, or by what action thee Medicaments do especially over-rule the Eence of this affect?

We anwer, That perhaps it is not neceary, that we preently fly to occult qualities, which for the mot part is but the Sanctuary and refuge of ignorance: but that the primary and econdary parts of the Eence of this Diea above decribed ought to be reduced to Memory: for by making a comparion between thoe parts, and thee Medicaments, we hal plainly dicern an obcure contrariety and repugnance between them. For this Diea coniteth in a cold and moit ditemper inherent in the Spirits together with want and atonihment of the Spirit and weaknes of the parts afflicted: on the contrary thee remedies heat and dry, cherih the Natural Spirits, diipate that numbnes which is in them and trengthen the parts.

Moreover, In regard that thee remedies with their heat and drines obtain withal a manifet friability and thinnes of parts, it comes to pas, that they cut through all vicous matter, they attenuate all gros and thick humors, and procure a certain equality of all the juyces that have their circulation in the Sanguinary Mas, and an even ditribution (conideration being had of the ditance from the fountain of heat) both of heat and Blood. Herupon the external parts which before were lean enjoy a more liberal heat and nourihment, and the Parenchimata of the Bowels which were irregularly encreaed, are delivered from thick and vicous alimentary juyces, and therupon are omwhat lened: by this means that Alogotrophy or irrational Nourihment of the parts, from whence o great a eries of organical faults reulteth, is corrected. Finally, Thee remedies do alo trengthen and cherih the inewy parts, and likewie the extream weaknes of the Bone of the Back.

You will ay, That all the Simples above recited by us, do not fully perform all thee things. For the everal kinds of Sanders, though they may by their drines, friability and thinnes of parts trongly impugn this Diea, yet by their coldnes they eem rather to come neer to the parts of the Diea; we ay therfore that Simples of this Nature ought not to be given alone, but being commixt with ome other, which may prevalently correct the noxious quality; in like manner ome Simples extreamly hot, as Saffron, Catoreum, Flowr of Brimtone, &c. are very repugnant to this Diea, yet you mut refrain the adminitration of them unles they be duly attempered. Moreover Saraparilla, Saaphras, Osmund the royal, the kinds of Fernbrake, all the Maiden-hairs, Harttongue, Ceterach, and the like,
their heat and drines being conjoyned with a notable friability and thinnes of the parts they contribute very much to the equal ditribution of the Blood, as alo to ubdue many other parts of the Diea. But they carce lend a ufficient trength to the inewy and fibrous parts; wherfore they eem to crave an admixture of Cephalical Remedies. Again, Lignum Vitae, by its heat, drines and friability, and by its Balamical and Roinih ubtance, doth very much trengthen the Tone of the parts, and is contrariant to ome other parts of the Diea; yet becau it helps very little the contemperation of the Juyces contained in the Sanguinary Mas, but on the contrary is rather an hindrance therunto, it ought not without great caution to be precribed, and that in a mall quantity and well corrected. Latly, Among the Simples here recited, ome are received to trengthen all the Spirits rather than to ubdue the Eence of the Diea, as Sage, Musk, Ambergree, and the like which come not into ue but when they are mingled with other effectual and more apropriate ingredients.
If any hall further demand, Which among all thee propounded Simples are to be valued as the mot noble and effectual; we comprehend our Anwer in thee Rules.
Firt, They are the mot noble Medicines, which joyntly make the tronget oppoition againt mot parts of the Eence of the Diea.

Secondly, Thoe Caeteris paribus, are to be eteemed the more noble, wch directly affront the Eence of the Diea, epecially if at the ame time they advance the equal ditribution of the Blood and Vital Spirit, wherby o many organical faults are corrected.

Thirdly, Such things as oppoe the Diea mot eminently by an eential contrariety, provided they be
not as well too trong for Nature as the Diea.
Fourthly, Thoe which are both repugnant to the Diea, and yet withal, grateful to Nature, in no wie offering any violence to her.
Fifthly, Thoe wch are mot grateful & pleaing to the ick Child, & uch as adminitred trouble not its Pallate.
Thee things being premied we hall now ubjoyn ome examples of compound Medicines.

div.head: Decoctions, and Phyical Drinks.
div.p: Take the Spikes of the Roots of Omund the royal, ix in number; Pauls Betony, Harttongue, Ceterach, Liverwort, Maidenhair, of each one handful; Sage, and Roemary Flowers, of each half a handful: mal Raions three ounces; Spanih Liquoris half an ounce; Mace two cruples; Boyl them in ix pound of Fountain Water; take three pound of the Decoction and ad unto it three ounces of the Syrup of Maidenhair, mingle them and make your Apozem. Let the Child take a draught of it every morning, another at four a clock in the afternoon, and a third in the night if he then call for Drink; yea if it plea him, let him take it for his ordinary Drink. This is mot proper for thoe who are adly afflicted with the Rachites, complicated with a cough and an obtruction of the Lungues.

Take the Leaves of Royal Omond, Harttongue, Liverwort, Ceterach, the Flowers of Tamerisk, the Roots of the Male Fernbrake, of each a handful; Raions two ounces; white and red Sanders, Saafras Wood, of each two drachms; Coriander Seeds one drachm; Mace one cruple; Sage Leaves, half a handful; boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Fountain Water according to art, to three pound; Let the Decoction be weetned with Sugar or Honey, for ordinary Drink. This is bet for uch whoe Liver is mot afflicted.

Take Saaperilla cut and beaten, three ounces; the Roots of China cut into little pieces, two ounces: Infue and boyl them according to art, in even pound of fountain water, to four and a half: then ad two drams of Saafras roots, the roots of Omond royal, the leaves of Harttongue, Ceterach, Maidenhair, Archangel, of each half an handful; Spanih Liquoris two drams; Mace a dram: boyl them to three pound. To the Decoction ad Honey or Sugar three ounces. Mingle them for ordinary drink. This is mot conducible where there is upition of the French Pox, as alo in Strumatical Affects.

Take the Flowers of Tamaris one handful; the male Pauls Betony half an handful: brui them gently, and infue them in two pound of common Beer cold, in a tone or glas Flaggon, well topt with Cork for the ordinary drink.

Take Saraperilla eight ounces; China two ounces Saafras half an ounce; Ivory an ounce; Omond royal, Palus Betony, Harttongue, Ceterach, Maidenhair, Liverwort, tops of dead Nettles, of each two handfuls: cut them and brui according to art, and boyl them in four gallons of new Ale till one be conumed; then when you have taken it from the fire, ad another gallon of the ame Ale to it, and when you have added it, tir it up and down with a tick, and when you have done o, train it, and when you have trained it, put the Ingredients in a Boulting-bag, and put a piece of Iron into them, and ad a bit of Leaven to it, and hang it into the Ale with a tring, and let the Child drink it for its ordinary Drink; o oon as it hath drunk half of it, draw out the ret, and top it cloe in tone Bottles for the Childs ue.

Take Wine of S •• ll half an ounce; Syrup of Succory
with Rhubarb two drams: let the ick drink of it every morning for five or even daies or longer, unles ome loones of the Bowels or debility of the Stomach do advie a prohibition: in which cae, intead of Syrup of Succory with Rhubarb, take Syrup of dried Roes.

div.head: Broaths and Panadaes.
div.p: Take Harttongue and Cetrach, Liverwort, Maidenhair, Sage, of each half an handful; the Bark of Tamaris, red Sanders, of each two drams: Put them into the Belly of a Cock-Chicken or Hen, or an old Cock. Sew up the Belly, and boyl it with two ounces of Malaga Raiins in a ufficient quantity of Fountain water, adding alo a ufficient quantity of pure Oatmeal flower: Make your Broath, and let it be oundly boyled.

Take the roots of China cut into mal bits, two ounces; white and medulous Saraperilla liced and well beaten, three ounces Infue them for a night in ten pound of fountain water: In the morning after a gentle bubling, train it, and to the Decoction ad Hartstongue and Pauls Betony, of each an handful; Mace half a dram; Currance an ounce; and with Mutton, Veal, or a Capon, adding Oatmeal: make your Broath according to art.

But if thinner Broths be more deired, you may boyl a crut of Bread intead of the Oatmeal; and if you would have it thicker, you may mingle with it the yolks of Egs and grated Bread: Moreover, to help a weak concoction, you may omtimes ad a few poonfuls of Wine.

Panadaes alo may be made of the ame Broth trained, and boyled again with grated Bread, adding at
length a little Butter and Sugar. The ame likewie may be made of the Decoctions even now precribed, unles peradventure they contain ome bitter and unpleaing mixture. Morrover, the Panadaes and ordinary Broths may be altered with thee enuing Pouders, and by conequence apropriated to the cure of this Affect; if the Child deire Milk mot, let them be made in Milk; if the Child deire it thick, you may make it thick either with Flower, or Oatmeal; and if you mix a little Saffron with it, it will be the better. But if any thing in the Pouders do nauiate and offend the tat, let them be omitted, and ubtitute om other things that may be more acceptable to the Palat.

div.head: Pouders and Electuaries.
div.p: Take the Roots, but rather the Buds of the male Fernbrake carce prong out of the Earth, and dried in a hady place; the pike of Royal Omond, of each two drams; Mace, Annieeds, of each half a cruple; Saffron half a grain: make a Pouder. The doe from half a cruple to a cruple, in Milk, or Poet drink, ome Decoction, Broth or Panadaes.

Take the medulous part of the Root of Saraperilla two drams; the Roots of China one dram; the Root of Saafras one cruple; the eeds of Caraway and Coriander of each half a cruple; the Roots of the male Fernbrake, Omond royal, of each two cruples: Mingle them and make a Pouder to be ued as the former.

Take Wood-lice, or as ome Countries cal them, Sows wahed, firt in water, and then in White-Wine, afterwards calcined in a Crucible; Bread dried as much as you plea: make them into a Pouder. The doe is from half a cruple to a cruple, either in Broth, or any thing
el: In the ame manner you may if you plea prepare the Livers either of Frogs or yong Ravens: We gave you the manner before.

Take of Flower of Brimtone two drams; Diarrhodon Abbatis, Diatrion antalon, of each half a cruple; Saffron half a grain; refined Sugar three ounces: All of them being made into very fine Pouder, make them into a Pat with a ufficient quantity of Roe water: Dry them, and when you plea you may beat them into Pouder, and give a dram of them at a time.

Take Conerv of Red Roes one ounce and an half; Conerv of the flowers of Borage, Archangel, Sage, Roemary, of each half an ounce; Steel prepared one dram; Cinnamon, Spanih Liquoris, of each half a dram: Saffron half a cruple; Red Sanders a cruple: beat uch things (as are reducible) to pouder; make an Electuary according to art, with yrup of Succory with Rhubarb a ufficient quantity. Let the Sick take half a dram, two cruples or a dram every morning, either by it elf, or in a poonful of Poet-Ale, or om appropriated Syrup, or ele in Wine.

Take Conerv of Archangel flowers one ounce; the flowers of Sage, Clove-Gilliflowers, Roemary-flowers, Myrobalans candied in India, Citron Pills candied, of each half an ounce; red Sanders, Cinnamon, Spanih Liquoris, of each half a dram; Salt of Steel, or el Saffron, half a cruple; with a ufficient quantity of yrup of Wormwood, make your Electuary. The doe and manner of uing it is the ame with the former.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV. Remedies that correct the Symptoms.
div.p: SOme Symptoms upervening upon this Affect, do omtimes anticipate the legitamat Method of Cure, and require a particular manner of proceeding. Of this ort are the flux of the Belly, the Lask, wherwith omwhat of a Lientery is frequently joyned; profue Sweats, laborious and painful breeding Teeth, and the Toothach.

The flux of the Belly doth very much follow this Affect; which if it perevere for any long time, it is either very violent, and eaily watereth the Spirits, conumeth the olid parts, manifetly puts on the nature of a cau, and as a cau indicates its own correction. A Bloody-flux rarely hapneth with this Diea. But a Lask with exulcerations in the Guts, or complicated with a Lientery is very ueful. For in repect of the debility to the parts ubervient to digetion, a Lask, or a Lyentery may eaily upervene, but not a Bloudy-flux. Yet there is a frequent concurrence of other caues; as of the indigeted nourihment vicious either in quantity or quality; om feaver, watchings, worms, painful breeding Teeth, &c. al which things do likewie eaily occaion a Lask, or Lyentery rather than a Bloudy-flux. As for the Cure, it is partly perfected by Purgations, partly by atringent Remedies; partly by uch as open, and partly by uch as trengthen the parts.

Thee Purgers are mot proper which leave behind an evident binding after evacuation; as Rhubarb, Senna, Tamarinds, Myrobalans, &c. out of which for the mot part we frame a Bolus or Potions, becau they are mot eaily wallowed under thoe forms. As,
Take Conerv of Red Roes half an ounce; Rhubarb in Pouder twelve grains; with a ufficient quantity of yrup of Coral make a Bolus to be given in the morning.

Take of the Pulp of Tamarinds one dram; Rhubarb in Pouder even grains; Sugar of Roes half a dram, with a ufficient quantity of yrup of Quinces, make your Bolus. Intead of this Syrup you may ue yrup of Coral, or yrup of Mint, or yrup of Myrtles, or yrup of Pomgranats.

Take Senna half a dram; Rhubarb one cruple; Tamarinds a dram and an half; Annieeds bruied ten grains: Infue them in a ufficient quantity of fountain water: boyl them very gently: and to an ounce and an half of the Decoction, ad yrup of dried Roes half an ounce: mingle them together for a Potion.
Take Plantan or Succory water, or Saxifrage water, one ounce; Rhubarb in pouder ten grains; yrup. Augutan. yrup of dried Roes of each two drams: Mingle them and make your Potion.

It mut be oberved, That a more full evacuation is omtimes requiit, namly, when the flux hath not been immoderat, or of long continuance, and in the mean time the matter offending hath bin copiouly collected in the Body. In which cae, in lieu of the Syrup of dried Roes, you may take om drams of yrup of Roes olutive, yr. Augutan. or of Succory with Rhubarb or Manna: But commonly the afet way is, to augment the doe of Rhubarb, or el of Senna, not omitting the yrup of dried Roes.

In the evening after the Purgation, you may adminiter ten grains of Diacordium boyled in Wine, with Cloves, and a little Cinnamon, and mixed with a third part of Erratick Poppy water, and ome cordial Syrups, as Syrup of Clove-Gilliflowers to trengthen the Spirits and to tay the Flux; or if the Flux be tubborn, you may mingle two drams of Diacodium for a doe intead of the Syrup aforeaid. Or

Take of Poet-drink made with white-Wine, the Curd being taken off (aromatize it with a little Saffron tied up in a rag, cruhing it gently between your Fingers) Confectio Alkermes one cruple; Pomgranat Pils in pouder even grains; Diacodium two drams: mix them together to be taken when the Child is minded to leep. Or

Take Laudanum according to the London Dipenatory, half a grain; Magiter of Coral twelve grains; Conerve of Clove-Gilliflowers, or Red Roes, one cruple, with a ufficient quantity of Syrup of Quinces, make a Bolus to be taken at bed-time.
If there be obtructions, you may precribe Crocus M • rtis, or Salt of Steel, to be taken in the morning. As,

Take Conerve of Roes one ounce: the Roots of Succory preerved, Myrobalans preerved in India, of each half an ounce: Salt of Steel half a cruple, or Crocus Martis one cruple: Cinnamon, Liquoris, red Coral, of each eighteen grains: Saffron a grain and a half: Syrup of Succory without Rhubarb a ufficient quantity: make your Electuary according to art, wherof let the Child take half a dram each morning. Red hot Iron may be quenched to the ame purpoe in its ordinary drink.

If the Child be troubled with a violent flux, you may give it om binding Conerves, imagin Conerve of Sloes, and mix it with uch things as the Child delights to eat, but in o doing be ure you plea its Palat.
Somtimes a profue and exceive weating find a peculiar buines for the Phyitian in this affect: for it very much wats the Spirits and retards the cure of the diea.

Yet caution mut be ued not to retrain it rahly, if perhaps there be a Feaver, or if any feaverih fit, or immoderat heat hath gon before: For in thee caes it may be upon a critical time, or at leat it may bring more advantage to the Body by the mitigation of the Feaver, than damage by the los of the Spirits. For we know not whether any thing doth more potently or indeed more weetly expel the feaverih heat tha¯ weating.

In the interim when it floweth inordinately and caulely, it argueth that the Body is oppreed with obtructions, with crude juyces and unprofitable uperfluities, which whilt Nature triveth to mater, and to ubdu, by that very labor, (the opennes of the pores withal concurring) it is evaporated by weat, and indeed an unprofitable one, very laborious and uch as wateth the Spirits, which therfore as oon as poible mut be corrected This Hippocrates meant, where he advieth, That that weat which floweth away without caue, requireth purgation. For what can more commodiouly diminih and diipate thee uperfluities? Again, this motion is contrary to weating, wherfore it meriteth the preheminence among the remedies oppoed to this Sympton, and eing that it clears the way for Medicines aperient, and uch as trengthen the skin, and move forward concoction, (which perfect the lat part of the cure) it ought in al right to be premied before them.

Purgative Medicines hitherto belonging, are thoe that are oberved to be friendly, and agreable to Nature, and withal uch as open obtructions, and trengthen the Bowels: al which things whither any Simple can perform o wel as Rubarb, we very much doubt. Yet al thoe Simpl and Compound Medicaments propoed above in the Chapter of Remedies Electively evacuant, may, according to the Condition of the Patient, and the Prudence of the Phyitian, be tranplanted hither. Som very much commend Beer in this cae medicated with Rubarb.

Take Rubarb cut into any mal peeces, two Drams; Raiins toned and lit, one ounce; mal Bear, two pound; put them into a Glas or tone flagon topt with the bet Cork; et it in a very cold place, and tir it very often, but before you ue it let it ettle again, a whol day, then draw out the liquor for your ordinary drink. When the flagon is empty fil it again with beer but put not in a new quantity of Rhubarb.

Moreover, The mot noble Aperients which both help concoction, and repres unprofitable weating, are French Wine, and Rhennih Wine. But if there be any fear of their heat in this tender age, they may be tempered with roted Apples, Borage, or red Roe-water, adding a little Sugar and grated Nutmeg, let them be alo taken in a leer quantity and only at meals.

They are likewie the mot effectual Aperients, which do not only help concoction, but alo trengthen the Tone of al the parts, epecially of the Bowels. Among which we chiefly commend things made with teel, as wine made with teel, and the Electuary before named, and the like. Now although teel doth indeed effectually perform thoe things which we have aid; yet becaue it doth not in all repects anwer to om other copes of
great moment in this affect, but doth more hurt ometimes in one particular, than it doth good in another; we thought it expedient to ubjoyn thee following Cautions concerning the ue therof.

Firt, Seing that Steel is an enemy to the Lungs, and doth eaily tir a cruel flux of flegmatick matter in tender Bodies, therfore you mut totally abtain from the ue therof, where there is any Cathar, Cough, obtruction of the Lungs, and much more, if there be any Inflamation, Pleuriie, Blood-pitting, or a prones of dipoition to any of thee affects.

Secondly, Becau Steel contributes little or nothing to the operation of the Blood: but on the contrary (however it may attenuat the tough and flegmatick part thereof) doth rather expedit the eparation therof from the other mas of Blood by reaon of the tart quality that is predominent in it, it cannot be admitted but with circumpection, epecially that inequality of the Blood being o importunat and urgent.

Thirdly, Seing that the attenuating, cutting and opening faculty in Steel is conjoyned with an apparent and extream drines and binding, and therfore perhaps doth more compact thoe humors, than diolve and catter them; the ue therof ought to be refrained, at leat upected in any coniderable Alogotrophy of the parts. For the fear is let it hould bind too cloe and conolidate the hort parts of the Bones & thoe that are too cantily nourihed; wherby afterwards they may becom les prompt and apt to grow in length: but the parts ticking out (as alo the convex ides of the Bones) which are liberally nourihed it cannot diolve, and then there may be a jealouie that it will too much confirm them and make them tubborn; namly by an extream thickning and hardning of them.

Fourthly, In all acute Feavers the ue of Steel is hurtful, becaue it over-dryeth and bindeth the Parts, yea, for that very regard that it retraineth Sweating, and makes the humors more fierce and harp.

Thee Cautions being rightly oberved, we admit the ue of Steel in this Affect, but becau Mountebanks and Quacks cannot ditinguih between the ue and the abue, we would not perwade any to make tryal of this noble Medicine without the advie and counel of ome prudent and knowing Phyitian, becau if it be not circumpectly adminitred, the danger is very great. Some other Aperients of les note may erve this cope; as the Roots of Succhory or Borrage, or Conerve of their Flowers; the Roots of Gras, Sparagus, Fernbrake, Madder; the Leaves of Ceterach, Spleenwort, Maidenhair, &c. Among the Compounds Species, Diatr. antal. Diarrhod. abbat. &c. Or

Take of the bet Sugar three ounces, diolve it in Roe Water and boyl it a little beyond the conitence of a Syrup, then ad Conerv of Barberies one ounce; Diatri. Santal. and Diarrhod. Abbat. of each one dram; pouder of Saffron, one grain; mingle them and make your Electuary.

The painful breeding and the aching of the Teeth are the familiar Symptoms of the Rachites; and becau they breed Feavers, unquietnes, watchings, and other evils, they alo deerve a peculiar mitigation; if the Tooth therfore as it is working through the Gum puts the Child to very much pain, you mut without delay (unles it were done before) appoint ome univeral evacuation: as a Vomit, which is thought to be a potent remedy againt the Toothach. Now that may be moved by the only tickling of the Throat, putting
in a Feather, or the Nures Finger into the Childs mouth; or ele with rubbing the Tooth that is breaking forth with a Tobacco Leaf wrapped about the Nures Finger, and a little moitned with Beer; or latly, by giving ome vomiting draught above decribed. But this remedy is forbidden reiteration in regard that it too much may weaken the Stomach. The day following (the pain periting or returning) ome Cathartick Potion or Bolus among thoe above rehered, or like unto thoe mut be adminitred. After this univeral Evacuation you mut decend to Topical Remidies. Nures are wont to rub the Gums with Corral polihed for that purpoe. But the Phyitians do rather commend the Root of Marh Mallows, which do mollifie and looen the Gums that they may obtain the more eaie paage. Others report it for a great ecret to rub the aching Tooth with the Root of the harpet Sorrel. Others very much commend the rubbing of that Gum where the Tooth is coming out with a Cocks Comb newley cut off, or with the hot Blood ditilling from that Wound. We have had no experience of thoe things which they ue to intill into the Ears; in like manner, neither the Plaiters of Matich, Olibanum, or red Lead, which in thoe of full growth are oberved to top the Rhewm. Others apply mall Epipatick Plaiters behind the Ears, which perhaps compel back the matter that breeds the pain in the Teeth. But neither do we interpoe our judgment concerning thee things. Only when Univerals are unavailable, we have recour to Hypnotical Remedies, which indeed by outward application profit little, but being taken inwards they are very helpful, epecially being rightly prepared and duly corrected. Therfore when want of ret and watchings beget moletation, thus we proceed.

Take Diacordium even grains; Syr. de Meconio, one dram and an half, or two drams; Poet Drink made of Milk and white Wine, with a little Saffron, one ounce, or ten drams; mingle them and give it at Bedtime the next night following after the Purgation.

Take Ladanum, according to the London Dipenatory, half a grain; the Cordial Pouder of the Claws of Crabs ten grains; Conerve of Clove-gilliflowers one cruple; with a ufficient quantity of Syrup of Balm make a Bolus to be wallowed in the evening at leeping time. Thus much of uch things as correct the Symptoms.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV. External Remedies.
div.p:
HAving finihed the Diquiition of the matter and kinds of internal Remedies, we hall now direct our Dicour to external Remedies. Which indeed we have reerved for the lat place, not becau they mut perpetually be lat put in execution, but becau they are altogether of a different kind from the internal: now Univerals are to be adminitred immediately after Evacuants, or at leat after thoe that are electively Purgant, and withal with the Specifical Alterants, unto which kind they belong, although indeed as they are external, they differ from them. Now we deire that we may here be undertood by external Remedies to ignifie and intend every kind
of Medicament which cannot properly be referred to Chyrurgery, or thoe things that are inwardly taken, provided that they have their ue in the Cure of this Affect.
Therfore we divide it into two Kinds, namely, The manner of Exercie, and things externally Applicable.

div.head: The Manner, or Kinds of Exercie.
div.p: All kinds of Exercie, unto which Children are accutomed, may be ueful in their time and eaon. But becau Children who are moleted with the Rachites are omwhat aver from motion and by reaon of their weaknes of Spirit, and unaccutomednes of Exercie do carce after the beginning of the cure, or indeed not at all endure violent motions; therfore they mut begin perpetually with gentle Exercies, and afterwards proceed by degrees to tronger; in like manner at firt they mut continue but a hort time, but afterwards a longer pace without any intermiion.

We therfore ditinguih Exercies into gentle, and vehement or Maculine. The gentle we refer firt to the manner of lying down. Secondly, To the agitation of the Body in the Cradle. Thirdly, To the carrying them about in the Nures Arms. Fourthly, To edentary patimes.

Firt, Lying upon the Back among all the potures of the Body doth chiefly recede from Exercie, and is almot only allowable in the extream weaknes of the Spirits, as in accute Feavers when the Spirits are pent, likewie in many caes of the Chet and Hypochondriacal parts, as frequently in an inflamation of the Liver, Spleen, Lungues, in a Pleuriie, in the growing of the Lungues with the Pleura, and an Impothume, &c.

The lying upon one ide either right or left cometh neeret to the Supine Poition, and participates very little of the Nature of Exercie. Wherfore it is alo allowable in any great weaknes of the Spirits, at leat in regard of altering the poture of the Body, as alo when a profound leep is not expected. Moreover, it is omwhat profitable to trong Bodies in the time of the firt or econd leep, after jut internals till changing ides. But afterwards perhaps it is not o agreable unto, nor beneficial for them, epecially when the Body is fully refrehed with leep. For then that poture is bet which draweth neeret to the Nature of Exercie.

The Simple Lateral Poition containeth omwhat more of Exercie, and is inconvenient for weak Bodies and uch as are not ued to it in the time of profound leep: but otherwie it may be made familiar, if for a while they will accutom themelvs unto it. It is at all times good for trong Bodies, provided that a due care be had to alter and vary it.

The lying on one ide towards the Belly is laborious and troubleom, and not to be continued long by trong and robutious Bodies that are not ued to it. But the moletation being overcome by cutom, it is more eaily tolerated: and becau it eaeth the pains in the Head, helpeth the Concoction of the Stomach, mitigateth the pains of the Chollick, and looneth a cotive Body, it may be omtimes ueful when Nature is throughly atisfied with leep, and in this affect it may upply the place of Exercie. For it omtimes hapneth in this Diea, that Children for ome time are not without diadvantage truted to their own Feet, yea many times they gain more by ret than walking up and down. For walking rather confirmeth than cureth the
bended Joynts; but lying down, when the parts are well wathed, conduceth not a little to their erection. Then again, lying down helpeth very much to tretch and lengthen the hort parts, as may be perceived by the growth of the parts in length after a Diea. Thirdly, Lying down, in regard of the common Coverings of the whol Body, advanceth an equal diperion of the heat through all the parts. Latly, lying down, if you oberve a right way of placing and making the Bed, may contribute very much to correct the crookning of the Back-bone and the whol Body, for when they lie upon the gibbous and bunched Side, a little bag made for the ame purpoe may be laid under the parts ticking out, and o made fit that the gibbous parts may in a manner utain the weight of the whol Body, and o they may be compelled as it were to traightnes. But when Children roul to the other ide, the bed hould be o made, that if the little Pillow or Bay be taken away the hollow part hould carce touch the bed unles he conform himelf to a traight line, that by his weight it may be depreed to a traightnes.

Secondly, That kind of exercie which is performed by the rocking of the Cradle omwhat emulates this lying down. The Cradles are utained upon two Arches, or two parts of a Circle: now the more they have of a Circle, the more effectually they exercie the Infant. This motion in time of leep mut be intermitted, or at leat remitted; but whilt the Child waketh it mut be omtimes intended, and omtimes remitted. It is mot profitable for weak Infants that can carce tand upon their Feet, or are otherwie hindred from waking.

Thirdly, The bearing them about in the Nures Arms is almot agreable to the ame Children; and under the ame conditions: in like manner the rejoycing
of the Child whilt the Nur ingeth, either as it its in her Lap, or is held up in her Hands, as alo the toing of it up and down, and waving of it to and fro, and if the Child be trong by holding it gently up by the Hands, if it be weak, under the Arms, yet o that the Thighs and the whol Body may hang down. Alo the drawing of the Children backward and forward upon a Bed or a Table between two Nures, the one holding it by a Hand, the other by a Foot. The two lat motions eem to contribute omwhat to the erection of the crooked or bended Back-bone, epecially if the Hand which is laid upon the depreed Shoulder, and the Foot which is belonging to the elevated Hip be drawn with more trength and vehemence than the other hand or foot. To the ame end alo tendeth the lifting up of the Child, taking him by his Feet only, o that the trunk of his Body and his Head may for a time hang down in an inverted poture; although indeed this action may alo eem in ome manner to relate unto the growing to of the Liver, if any uch at that time be: as alo that convolution of the Body, whereby the Head being lowermot the Feet are lifted up; and then again the Head being lifted up the whol Body is inverted. Hitherto alo may be referred that rouling of the Child, which om ue, upon a Bed or Table, the Body being laterally declined: which we more approve if it be not rouled quite round about, but only backwards and forwards, laying a little hard Cuhion underneath, wheron the gibbous part may ret, & utain the weight of the Body. This exercie being rightly practied doth help much to traighten the Body.

Fourthly, Sedentery Games and patimes are the leat profitable among all exercies for Children that have the Rachites, and indeed they are only allowable to till
and quiet them. But the more beneficial wil be to tempt them to a frequent ue of their Feet by playing ome little Ball or Cat before them that they may be often kicking them. But if the Body of the Child be crooked, uch ports mut be invented as may allure him to move his Body to the contrary ide. When therfore one Shoulder is higher than another hold up om Gewgaw or Rattle before the Child that he may tretch out the Hand belonging to the lowet Shoulder to reach after the offered object. But a thouand uch like inventions may be found out, and we leave them to the Nures indutry.
The Maculine Exercies of greater note we reduce to thee three Titles.
1 To Going. 2 To an Artificial hanging of the Body. 3 To Friction, rubbing, and contrectation of the Hypocondries and the Abdomen.

Firt, Otentation or waking may be numbred amongt the more noble Exercies. For Children that are big and trong, and ued to run up and down every day, do by walking and tirring about, the more eaily rid away this Diea. But this kind of Exercie mut be refued unto them whoe Joynts are not knit and confirmed, and whoe Ankles, Knees & Back are o weak that they cannot utain the Body. For when Children by the negligence of their Nures are too oon committed to their Feet, it eaily coms to pas, that they uffer thoe Joynts to be bended either inwards or outwards, backwards or forwards, and conequently they are the occaion of that deformity which befalleth the Bodies of mot men and women. Moreover, thoe Children which have already contracted uch a bending in their joynts, either by the natural weaknes and loones of the Ligaments, or by the bad uage or indiligence of
their Nures, mut be truted to exercie their Legs, till ome plents or other intruments be provided, which may be able to erect the bended Joynts and to keep them in an erected poture. The driving of Children up and down in their Coaches or Chariots is much to the ame purpoe, provided that they be o contrived that there be no danger of tumbling or overthrowing.

Secondly, The artificial upenion of the Body is performed by the help of an Intrument cunningly made with wathing Bands, firt croing the Breat and coming under the Armpits, then about the Head and under the Chin, and then receiving the hands by two handles, o that it is a pleaure to ee the Child hanging pendulous in the Air, and moved to and fro by the Spectators. This kind of Exercie is thought to be many waies conducible in this Affect, for it helpeth to retore the crooked Bones, to erect the bended Joynts, and to lengthen the hort Stature of the Body. Moreover, it exciteth the vital Heat, and withal allureth a plentiful ditribution of the Nourihment to the external and firt affected parts: and in the mean time it is rather a pleaure than a trouble to the Child. Some that the parts may the more be tretched, hang Leaden Shoos upon the Feet, and faten weights to the Body, that the parts may the more eaily be extended to an equal length. But this exercie is only proper for thoe that are trong.

Thirdly, Friction or rubbing may in ome manner be likewie referred to Maculine Exercies: nor indeed in repect of any active motion in the Child requiite to the adminitration therof (for it is performed by an action of the Nur rather than of the Child) but in repect of a like force and efficacy which it hath in the curing of this Affect. Now Friction eemeth to be
twofold, as partly belonging to the kind of Exercie, and partly to thoe things which are outwardly to be applied, for which cau we have reerved it unto this place, that it might be the lat in the number of the Exercies, and immediately precede the external applications. This mut be done (at leat in the Winter time) by a warm fire, the Child being in all repects well fortified from the injuries of the weather, and the violences of the cold Ayr. Some Nures adminiter this Friction with a hot hand, others with Linnen Cloathes dried and heated; others with woolen Cloathes; and others again with a little Bruh, and indeed ome do mot commend the Bruh, and prefer it before the other waies, but becau there eemeth to be o little difference in all the waies, we approve them all, and leave the choice to the Nures widom. But let them begin this Friction at the Back Bone, the Child being laid upon his Belly, and let them tir their Hands now upwards, now downwards, now on each ide, then to the Thighs, Hips, Legs, Ankles, the Soals of the Feet, and all the parts of the Body, thoe excepted where there is a ticking out of the Bones, and there let them rub the hollow part of them. This action mut not be continued beyond a moderate ruddines raied in the parts, let the Natural heat hould be cattred, rather than cherihed. This kind of exercie is mot agreable to weak Children; and uch as are carce able to tand or go. For it upplieth the defect of running up and down, exciteth the Natural heat, ummoneth the Vital, and attracteth the Nourihment to the affected parts. Yet we grant that Friction doth not o powerfully ummon the heat and nourihment to the Fleh of the Mucles, although perhaps it doth more to the Skin, as exercie doth properly o called, and conequently that it mut
yield in dignity and nature to true exercies. To Friction alo belongeth that contrectation of the Belly, or of the Abdomen and the Hypochondries, omtimes lifting up the Bowels, omtimes depreing them, omtimes removing them towards the right, omtimes towards the left hand, and omtimes thruting in the tops of the Fingers under the Batard Ribs. And Phyitians hope, and not without reaon, that by this action they may deliver the Liver from any preternatural growing with the Peritoneum, if any uch hould chance to be. And here we note by the way that uch growing of that Bowel may eaily happen in this affect by reaon of the greatnes of the Liver and the tretching of the Hypochondriacal parts, wherupon the Peritoneum and the Membrane of the Liver are are mot neerly and trictly conjoyned, and being conjoyned may remain long in the ame Poition, and o by the help of time they may eaily grow together. This growing together in as much as it dependeth (as we have aid) upon the tretching of the Hypochondries, and the bignes of the Liver, it may not incongruouly be referred to the econdary Eence of this Diea, namely, to the organical parts viciated, among which it deerves to be reckoned, although above we chanced to omit it in its proper place, and therfore we thought good to mention it here. Thus much of Exercies, now follow the External Applications.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI. Things to be Externally Applied.
div.p: THee remedies (as we have aid) do not only prerequire Friction, but for the mot part they are adminitred with a gentle Friction.

Now they are either General, or Univeral, repecting all parts alike, or Particular, and dedicated to certain Regions of the Body. The matter of the Univerals is almot the ame with that which we have propounded above in the Chapterof Specifical Alterant Remedies: but the matter of the particulars mut be ditinguihed according to the variety of the Regions of the Body unto which they are applied. The forms of either kind eem to be common, and they are five in number, Liquors, Oyls, Liniments, Oyntments, Playters: although Plaiters are dedicated rather to certain parts, and never are at once applied to the whol Body.

Liquors that have been commended by long experience in this Affect are almot all kinds of Wine; but epecially Muskadine. But ome do prefer the Pruiian Beer, which indeed may help much to trengthen and conolidate the Parts, but very little or nothing at all to effect the equation of the Blood, or an equal ditribution of it. The ame judgment is alo to be made of Aligant, as alo of red Wine. Some intead of Wine ue ordinary Aqua vitae, which is beleeved to be nothing
inferior to Wine, Decoctions alo may be prepared for the ame ue. As,

Take the Roots of Royal Omond, the Leaves of Sage, the Flowers of Marigolds, the Leaves of Bay-tree, Pauls Betony, Harttongue, of each half an handful; Roemary, red Roes dried, of each one pugil; boyl them in Fountain Water, and ordinary Aqua vitae, of each a pound, to the conumption of the third part; train it and keep for your ue. Or

Take the roots of the male Fernbrake one ounce, the leaves of royal Omond, Clary, Bay tree, Sage, Pauls Betony, of each half a handful, infue them in ome Wine, and keep the trained liquor for your ue.

But thee Liquors are eldom or never adminitred alone, but mut be mixt with equal parts of Oyls, Liniments, or Ointments; and indeed they mut be ued before a warm fire, and rubbed on with a hot hand til they be dry.

p.U: uch as are approved in this Affect are very few, and thoe ineffectual: but there are many Simple Oyls, as Oyl of Earth-worms, Chamamile, Marygold flowers, Pauls Betony, Neats-foot Oyl, unto which you may alo ad Oyl of Foxes, Oyl of Whelps, Oyl of Swallows, provided that thee lat be prepared Simply by themelves without any commixture of extream hot ingredients.

div.p:
Oyl of Exeter, although ome Practitioners ue it, and though it be a little hotter then is fit to be ued alone to o tender an age as is troubled with this Diea, and o are other things which are vulgarly ued, as Oyl of Catoreum, or Jacobi de Manliis, and Ung. Antiparalyticis, and other Ointments, as, de Nervino, Martiato, Aregon, and the like. And the reaon is, becaue uch a numnes afflicts not thee as it doth uch as are Paralitical, nor
the ame Defect of Vital Spirits, nor the ame unequal ditribution of nourihment. But becaue this is a new Diea, if any deire Oyls, Ointments, or Liniments proper to the Evil, let him make ue of a right Method, an able Phyitian, a pecifical way either of Oyls or Ointments as we hal hew you by thee examples:

Take the leaves of red Sage, Betony, Pimpernel, Marygold flowrs, of each two handfuls: the roots of royal Omund ix ounces, May Butter three pound, white Wine half a pound: cut the Herbs, bruie the Roots, and boil them according to art til the Wine be conumed: Afterwards train them being yet hot, and put to them oyl of Nutmegs drawn by expreion one ounce and an half, mingl them diligently, and after etling, cating away the dregs, make your Ointment, which you may reerve in a glas Veel for your ue. Or,

Take the leaves of Brooklime, Chamomile, Watercrees, garden Scurvygras, Pauls Betony, Motherwort, Maidenhair, Harttongue, Ceterach, Bayleavs, the tops of Mint, red Sage, Roemary, Ivy-berries, of each half a handful: the Roots of royal Omund four ounces, Mucadale half a pound, May Butuer three pound: cut the Leaves, brui the Berries, and boil them all to the conumption of the Wine, train it whilt it is hot, and eparating the pure ubtance from the etlings, make an Ointment according to art. Or,

Take the leavs of red Sage, Pauls Betony, Harttongue, tinking Gladon, of each two handfuls: the roots of royal Omond ix ounces: the tops of Lavender, Roemary, Bay-leavs, of each a handful: common Aquae vilae, one pound: Oyl of Neats-feet, and Foxes, of each half a pound: Deers-uet, or the uet of an Ox, Oyl of Worms, of each one pound, boil them to the conumption of the Aquae vitae: train out the Ointment whilt it is hot, and
making a eperation of the dregs, keep it for your ue.

Fourthly, Take the green leavs of royal Omond, ix handfuls: Pimpernels, Morigold-flowrs, the leavs of red Sage, Clary, Mother-wort, Brook-lime, Watercrees, of each a handful: the leavs of Roemary, Bay, of each half a handful: chop them together very mal, and beat them diligently in a Marble or Wooden Morter, with a wooden Petle, with ix pound of unalted Butter, and o let them tand fourteen days, then melt them gently in a Bath, and as oon as they begin to be hot, train them, and then put in a new quantity of Herbs as before: at length train and purify your Ointment, and keep it for occaions.

To thee general external Remedies om particular ones relating to om certain parts of the Body may be ub-joyned: as if the region of the Abdomen, epecially the Hypocondria, be tretched, hard and welled, and this tretching hardnes, and welling would not yeild to a Purgation though rightly adminitred, then you mut proceed to Local Remedies: As,
Take Oyl of Capers, Wormwood, Elder, of each one ounce: of the general Ointment firt decribed, one ounce and an half: mingle them and make a Liniment.
Or,

Take Ointment of the opening juyces Foeius three ounces, the firt general Ointment two ounces, mix them together and make them one Ointment: alo Oyl of Saxifrage made of a manifold infuion, and boiling of the bruied Herb in common Oyl is much to be commended to be mixed with it.
In the time of uing it, this and the like Liniments or Unguents may be mingled for penetration ake with om appropriat liquor: As,

Take the flowers of Elder, the flowers of red Sage, Bay-berries bruied, white Sanders lightly beaten to pouder, of each two drams, white Wine two pound, teep them for three days in a cold place in a glas veel accuratly topt with Cork, and hake it twice a day: when you ue it, train as much as will erve your preent occaion, then top your veel again. Or, if you deire a tronger,

Take the roots of white Bryony well dryed and liced, Bay-berries, Goo-dung, of each two drams: Cummineeds one dram: the leavs of red Sage, the flowrs of Elder, of each one pugil; boil them in one pound and a half of Rhenih-wine to a pound: keep the Decoction in a cold place diligently topped.

Thee and the like Liquors mingled with the Oyntment, and heated at the fire, mut be rubbed upon the Abdomen, and epecially the Hypochondries, even to drines. Let the Nure alo having well warmed her hands, handle thoe parts gently, omtimes preing the Bowels upwards, omtimes downwards, omtimes to the right hand, and omtimes to the left, according to our former Directions.
The mot galent thing of all is the Balom of Tolu mixed with any Oyntment or Plaiter, and o applied to the Region of the Back either in form of an Oyntment or Playter.

Plaiters alo eem to contribute omthing. As Take three ounces of Ceratum antalinum; Gum Ammoniacum diolved in Rhennih Wine, or in om other medicated wine above decribed, purified and boyled again to a thicknes, one ounce: make your Plaiter according to art. Spread part of this upon Leather and lay it upon the right Hypochondry, or el the left, if the hardnes be there mot enible, which indeed is very eldom. Or

Take the Juyces of Brooklime, Watercrees, Garden-Scurvygras, Wormwood, the bark of Elder, the roots of the male Fernbrake, of each one ounce: Let the Juyces be purified with a gentle heat, and being extracted reduce them to a thick body, then ad one dram & an half of Mace, and two drams of yellow Sanders in pouder.

Take of this Mixture one ounce and an half: Gum Ammoniac. diolved in Wine and boyled to a body four ounces. Mingle them bot, and tir them continually till they begin to wax cool and hard, and make a Plaiter to be applied as the former.
Moreover, when the Lungs are il affected many times a peculiar pectoral Plaiter is very ueful. As

Take Oyl of Violets, white Lillies, and the Ointment of Orenge flowers, of each one ounce: Mingle them and make a Liniment to be rubbed with a hot hand upon the Breat, laying a Lawn Paper over it lined with Wool or linen cloth. To this Liniment you may ad a mal quantity of Natural Balom. Or
Take two ounces Unguent. Pectorale; an ounce and an half of imple Ointment of Liquoris: one ounce of Oyl of Violets. Mingle them and make a Liniment to be ued after the ame manner.
The Ointment of Liquoris is thus made.

Take new and Juycy Liquoris four ounces: new unalted Butter waht in Roe water one pound: lice the Liquoris and beat it wel with the Butter in a tone Morter, afterwards fry them, then train and queeze them, and repeat the ame labor thrice with a new quantity of Liquoris.

Again, Som Plaiters may be prepared proper againt the weaknes of the Back, which very frequently hapneth in this Affect. In the Shops you may have the Plaiter of Betony, and Diachalcitheos, unto which nevertheles
when you ue them, you mut ad Matich and Olibanum in pouder of each half a dram: the Plaiter alo which is called Flos Unguentum may hither be referred, provided that you omit the Camphire, in like manner alo Emplatrum Nervinum. Or

Take two ounces of the firt general Oyntment; five of the Herbs that are contained in that Compoition, cut and chopped very mal; Yellow Wax four ounces; the puret Roin eight ounces: the Oyntment, Roin, and Wax, being melted ad the Herbs and according to art make a Plaitrr. Or

Take fifteen ounces of the third general Oyntment; Litharge of Gold beaten mal and ifted nine ounces; boyl them together continually tirring them to the conitence of a Plaiter; then ad Wax, Burgundy Pitch, of each three ounces; Oyl of Nutmegs by expreion three drams; Matich, Olibanum, Mirrh, of each one dram and an half; Cotorium half a dram; white Vitriol in pouder half an ounce; make your Plaiter according to art.

The Practioners in Phyick differ in the Figure, and about the Application of thee Plaiters. Some chue a longih and narrow Figure, and apply it according to the length of the Back-bone. Others appprove a broadih and almot triangular Figure, uch as you ee here, and they extend it from the Loyns, downward upon the Os acrum, even to the utmot end therof. But when the lower parts of the Back-bone, as alo the Knees and Legs, namely thoe parts which borrow their Nerves from the lower part of the Spine, are weaker than the Superior, we do
not judg this latter to be a convenient form; but when the upper parts of the Back-bone eem to be the weaker, we uppoe the former longih form to be the more agreable.

In like manner ome commend a Liniment for the weaknes of the Back-bone which coniteth of Gelly of Harts-horn, made with uch things as trengthen the Sinews, adding the Flowers of Sage, and the Roots of our Ladies Seal. In the time of anointing mingle therwith a little Oyl of Nutmegs by expreion, or Oyl of Worms, or Mans Gras. And thus much of external Remedies.
